HEADLINE: A Hub Once More?

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT

DATELINE: HEMPSTEAD

 BODY:
THIS is New York's oldest and largest incorporated village. Now Hempstead is campaigning to become the state's newest city -- and that is only one of many changes afoot here.
After four decades of decline and sporadic attempts at revival, Hempstead is on an upswing. Government officials, sometimes working in concert with a new core of community activists, are determined to recapture some of the old glory of Hempstead's nearly four centuries of existence. 
 "In 1989 it was like a ghost town here," said James A. Garner, who became mayor that year. "They were giving property away downtown -- free rentals." Today Hempstead is capitalizing on the national and local economic boom to foster major new developments in the village. Mayor Garner said: "If not now, when?"
Settled in 1643 by Puritans seeking religious freedom, Hempstead reigned well into the 20th century as the undisputed hub of Long Island as the region's population and business center. It has served as a transportation crossroads since early in the horse and buggy days -- the official village seal depicts George Washington arriving here on a stagecoach in 1790.
"Historically, Hempstead was the downtown area, before suburbia spread throughout Nassau," said Lee E. Koppelman, executive director of the Long Island Regional Planning Board. "It was the center, the destination point."
But Hempstead fell on hard times after World War II. The village was dwarfed as swaths of farmland across much of the island were transformed into thickly populated subdivisions. Hempstead Town -- the entity that surrounds and includes the village -- grew to 725,000 people, making it the nation's most populous town.
The accompanying rise of indoor shopping malls, especially at nearby Roosevelt Field, siphoned shoppers from the once-flourishing village downtown. One by one, stores like Arnold & Constable, Town & Country, Lane Bryant, Sears, S. Klein and TSS Seedman closed. The final blow came in 1992 with the demise of the giant Abraham & Straus department store, which as late as 1969 had been the nation's highest-grossing suburban store. Along with those closings, "we lost our mom-and-pop stores," said Dorothy L. Goosby, a Town Council member who lives in the village.
Hempstead was not alone. "All our downtowns have suffered because of the malls," said the town supervisor, Richard V. Guardino Jr. But Hempstead was the biggest and suffered the most.
Suburbia's emerging automobile culture and drive-in economy relegated Hempstead's once-thriving bus terminal and train station to second-class status. As blacks became a majority in the village, followed in more recent years by a wave of Hispanic immigrants, household income lagged behind the county average. School rankings plunged. Crime rates soared, and concerns about safety loomed large for many whites who used to frequent the downtown.
Adding insult to injury, three years ago County Executive Thomas S. Gulotta appointed a panel to promote the concept of a new Nassau Hub. Its focus shifted north and east of the Village of Hempstead, to the business and county government complex in Garden City, the retail zone in and around Roosevelt Field and the Mitchel Field area with Nassau Coliseum, office buildings and colleges.
"They stole our name," said Hezekiah Brown, a trustee on the village board.
Mayor Garner is not ready to yield. "Hempstead was the Hub of Nassau County, and, as far as I am concerned, still is," he said. "There's no sense trying to establish a new Hub. Don't reinvent the wheel."
So far, little has materialized of Mr. Gulotta's dreams for a new Hub, featuring the construction of a new coliseum, convention hall and entertainment center. Instead, the county's economic future is clouded by its recurring deficits and falling credit rating.
The old Hub, meanwhile, is forging ahead, and local officials have even higher hopes if Hempstead can reap the financial advantages of becoming a city.
"This is the new downtown," Mayor Garner said last week as he watched construction workers smoothing the freshly poured concrete floor at what will become a 135,000-square-foot Home Depot. The store will anchor a new mall -- called the Hub -- that will symbolically resurrect the vacant old A. & S., which was finally demolished last year. It will also house Old Navy and ShopRite stores and provide parking for nearly 1,300 cars. The ShopRite will fill a void left by the closing of a 10-year-old Waldbaum's last year, which was a jolt to the village.
Nearby is a new mall that opened last year on the former TSS site, with Staples, Pep Boys, Hollywood Video and McDonald's. Construction is under way for a new $22 million Long Island Rail Road station.
The latest surge of development comes after a decade of incremental progress downtown. The county's First District Court House opened in 1990. A new $8 million bus terminal, serving 26 Long Island routes and three interstate companies, was built in 1993. The old terminal was renovated into shops. The Rivoli, a handsome four-story building with 112 apartments for the elderly and ground-floor businesses, opened in 1998.
The latest improvements win praise from Supervisor Guardino, who grew up in the village. "I'm looking out the office window right now at Mayor Garner's revitalization efforts," he said. "What he has done is a real model."
Dr. Koppelman is more guarded about Hempstead's prospects. "The village has tried valiantly to make a turnaround," he said. "But you know, when you lose an anchor store, it leaves a big hole and you lose all the little stores. It's very difficult."
He called the efforts remarkable, though, and said the village had restored parts of downtown "into a very nice walking area, very nice." Even so, he predicts that Hempstead will never fully recover its former pre-eminence. "Historically they were the Hub," Dr. Koppelman said, "but realistically now, forget it."
Hempstead is in ferment politically as well as economically. For the first time in 20 years, Democrats were elected to the five-member village board last year: Mr. Brown and his running mate, Wayne Hall. Both also had strong support from the union-oriented Working Families Party. The two new village trustees are also prominent members of the national Association of Community Organizations for Reform, known as Acorn.
Acorn opened its Long Island chapter in Hempstead a little over a year ago and has championed a variety of causes, including more neighborhood police patrols, more bilingual police officers and rent relief for the elderly. Its major focus has been housing, marshaling tenants and badgering village officials to crack down on landlords who have neglected major downtown apartment buildings.
"A majority of the people are tenants, and nothing was being done about it till the tenants were organized," said Acorn's head organizer here, Ann E. Sullivan. "Since Hez and Wayne got elected, there has definitely been a sea change. The mayor has come to Acorn meetings and has begun to call the landlords in on the carpet."
Asked about Acorn, Mayor Garner said: "They're aggressive, very aggressive. But I'm being very responsive to them. I'm working with them. Their message has been heard, and we've been very tough on these unscrupulous landlords," seeking civil and criminal penalties.
"This is a very beautiful community," Trustee Brown said. "The homes are kept up, the lawns are kept up. The streets are cleaned. We do have a perception problem. If you drove through Hempstead and did not see black faces, you could not tell any difference from any other community." Housing ranges from the downtown apartments to the stately manses of Cathedral Avenue to the more typical middle-class, single-family neighborhoods.
But Hempstead Heights, a scrupulously neat neighborhood in the area around Princeton, Yale and Harvard Streets, is dotted by signs of trouble even in these rosy economic times: boarded-up houses. Ms. Sullivan blamed what she called "predatory mortgage companies" that stick naive homeowners with unconscionably high loan rates. To fend off foreclosure, owners often resort to carving out illegal apartments. Whether in houses or apartment buildings, rents are so high that tenants are often forced to double up, Ms. Sullivan said.
The resulting overcrowding strains the schools and other services. Although there has been little residential construction in the village in recent years, experts estimate that its population, which the 1990 census recorded at 49,453, had soared 16 percent to 57,476 by 1997. "There is a vast undercount," Mayor Garner said. "The village seems to be a mecca for Central Americans."
Another issue for Hempstead is the overtaxing of its homeowners under the county's archaic assessment system. Community leaders hope pending litigation will force an overhaul that will give the village homeowners relief.
Among Hempstead's assets are the New York Jets headquarters and training camp, Hofstra University, the African American Museum, the Calderone Theater, Hempstead Lake Park, Hempstead Golf Club, Island General Hospital, the nation's oldest continuous Presbyterian congregation, a Best Western hotel and the dealerships on the still-expanding "automobile row," a strip that dates to the early 1900's. Near the village perimeter are Mercy Hospital, Molloy College, Adelphi University, the Garden City Hotel, the stores and brokerage houses of North Franklin avenue -- and the upstart rival hub of Roosevelt Field, Mitchel Field and the business offices and county government complex in Garden City.
"The real strength of Hempstead is that it is centrally located: 10 minutes to Suffolk County, 10 minutes to Queens, 10 minutes to the North Shore, 10 minutes to the South Shore," Mayor Garner said.
Even if he is shaving several minutes from the actual driving times, all roads do seem to lead to Hempstead. The Southern State Parkway is the village's southern border and connects to the nearby Meadowbrook, Northern State and Cross Island Parkways. Hempstead Turnpike, Franklin Avenue, Clinton Road and Peninsula Boulevard are also major thoroughfares.
Over the years, many government agencies have located offices in Hempstead, drawn by the transportation system, reasonable rents and extensive parking lots that are the envy of other villages. The offices and agencies include Town Hall, Nassau's off-track betting headquarters, the courthouse, the motor vehicle department, the worker's compensation board, the parole office, the labor department and the state tax department.
Drawing thousands of visitors and commuters daily, those offices have helped to stabilize Hempstead's downtown. But few people linger; many streets seem relatively deserted at night and on weekends. Despite urban renewal demolitions over the years, some storefronts are still vacant, including the building next to the mayor's family business, Grand Central exterminators.
Among the few night life attractions are the Jamaican-Chinese restaurant Nakisaki and the adjoining Jam Roc club. Hispanic restaurants and Caribbean food shops have proliferated downtown but have not drawn a wide clientele. "There are lots of nice little restaurants -- I've been to most of them," said Donald Kehoe, a retired O.T.B. executive, "but I found it hard to get guys from the office to go with me."
Planners hope that the new large stores will help create the critical mass and customer traffic to support more small shops.
Census statistics show enormous demographic shifts. In 1950, as the tide of suburbanization began, the census reported that Hempstead's population was 29,135, with about 91 percent white and 9 percent black. The countywide figures were 672,765, with 97 percent white and 3 percent black. By 1980, blacks had become a majority in the village, at 57 percent, compared with 40 percent for whites, 9 percent for Hispanics and 3 percent for Asians, American Indians and others. (The total exceeds 100 percent because Hispanics, who were counted separately for the first time in 1980, may also identify themselves as black or white.) By 1997, the big change was among Hispanics, who had risen to nearly 23 percent of the village's population. The countywide population had grown to 1.3 million but remained mostly white, 86 percent. Blacks were 9 percent, Hispanics 7 percent and Asians, Indians and others 5 percent.
Hempstead's household income has fallen behind the countywide average for decades. In 1950 the median figure for the village was $24,781, calculated in 1997 dollars. By 1997, that figure had grown 104 percent to $50,672. But the countywide figure, which was $27,738 in 1950, had grown 164 percent to $73,364 in 1997.
The village has also had one of the highest crime rates in the county. In 1998, for example, Nassau had 25 murders, of which 8 were in Hempstead. But the village police chief, James Russo, claims big strides in reducing crime over all, which dropped 42 percent in 1997 and 1998, according to county statistics. "Usually it's a domestic type of thing or involves drugs or gangs," he said.
Still, the perception of downtown as unsafe has persisted in some minds. Village officials say that it is largely a myth and that some white suburbanites simply feel uneasy around blacks and Hispanics they are not acquainted with.
Hempstead's schools have come under criticism. For much of the 1990's, barely 6 percent of high school seniors earned Regents diplomas. "The schools are not educating the kids to get the jobs they need to raise families," Ms. Sullivan of Acorn said.
Mayor Garner said that the district's new superintendent, Dr. Nathaniel Clay, had brought stability after a period of high administrative turnover and succeeded in removing the district from a special state review for failing schools. Dr. Clay did not respond to requests for comment last week, nor did the district respond when Acorn organized a protest two years ago.
The schools could get a boost if Hempstead becomes a city. Mayor Garner is frank about his reason for seeking city status: more money. He said Hempstead would be entitled to keep several million dollars a year in local sales taxes that now go to the county and town, which would enable it to go ahead with new programs and property tax cuts. And the schools would qualify for more state aid.
Converting to a city, which is a rarely taken step, requires state legislation, followed by a local referendum, and the village has hired a lawyer to help guide the complex process. Long Island has only two other cities, Glen Cove and Long Beach, both smaller than Hempstead.
There may be philosophical objections. "Some people may say, 'I moved to the suburbs to get away from the city,' " Trustee Brown said. "But we don't see any downside to it. We're really a city already. We have all the services: police, sanitation, water, you name it. The only thing we don't have is the sales tax."
Mayor Garner said, "We just want our fair share." With sales thriving on automobile row and the prospect of cash registers humming at Home Depot and the other new stores, he said, "incorporating the village as a city comes at the right time."

HEADLINE: Law Students Aid Abuse Victims

BYLINE: By JAMES V. O'CONNOR

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS

 BODY:
WHEN a Westchester woman called the Pace Women's Justice Center here, her husband had accumulated 18 guns and 200 pounds of ammunition, and he was not even a hunter. He had mutilated the family cat and then bludgeoned it to death. He suffered from bipolar disorder, was an alcoholic and a wife beater.
The woman is one of 96 who have applied for orders of protection against their batterers through the Pace Women's Justice Center, an organization that provides legal counsel to battered women under the jurisdiction of the White Plains County Courts. The organization moved into its own office in the court building on Oct. 26 through grants from the county and Pace University. 
 What makes the program unusual is that it has been authorized by the courts to allow law students to represent abused women in Family Court to get an order of protection. Orders of protection can require that a person vacate the home, make no contact with the woman being abused or require the batterer to pay restitution for damages.
Law students who take part in the program must complete a course in domestic violence advocacy offered by the center. "The program is unique in that we provide one-stop legal shopping for civil relief for battered women, and it is done by law students supervised by attorneys," said Victoria L. Lutz, executive director of the Pace Women's Justice Center and an adjunct law professor at Pace University Law School.
There were more than 60,000 orders of protection issued in the state last year for battered women and more than 4 million incidents of spousal abuse a year in the United States, Ms. Lutz said. An order of protection in Family Court under state law requires that the parties be married, related by blood or have a child. Orders that are sought against people who do not fall into those categories have to be sought in criminal court. "There have been bills before the State Legislature to expand the definition of a family member," Ms. Lutz said, "but it has never been successful because some people think that this would open up the floodgates and overburden the Family Court system."
In the case of women being abused by their live-in companions the act has to be a criminal violation or misdemeanor and the order must be sought in Criminal Court.
Six months ago, the Pace Women's Justice Center established a special program called Deter with the White Plains Police Department. Its aim is to provide immediate legal counsel for abused women when they first come into contact with the criminal justice system, usually a 911 call to the police. The program has lawyers on call 24 hours a day to provide legal advice to battered women.
The White Plains police call the center when they are called to a domestic dispute that indicates that a woman is a potential victim of abuse, and the lawyers talk to the woman about her legal rights. A follow-up meeting is scheduled within 24 hours to ensure that the case is not dropped. "We think that by having contact with an attorney early on the women are more confident in facing their batterer in court and are more likely to follow through," Rebecca Fialk, director of Deter, said.
The program has already made a significant impact on the number of completed orders of protection, Ms. Lutz said. Since Deter started, 65 percent of the orders of protection initiated have been followed through, compared with 45 percent previously. And 95 percent of temporary orders have been upgraded since the program began, compared with 25 percent previously.
Although Deter is being done as a pilot with the White Plains Police Department, the center wants to expand it countywide. The program receives an average of 10 calls a month, with most coming in between midnight and 4 a.m. on Mondays and after holiday weekends. "We don't know why this is when we get most of our calls," Ms. Fialk said, "but it seems to have something to do with the end of the weekend, and drinking is usually involved."
The center conducts legal seminars for other lawyers, battered women and social workers to teach them about the legal aspects of domestic violence since often women do not realize that menacing and harassment can be remedied through an order of protection.
The law students and the lawyers in the program usually try to persuade an abused woman to get a vacate order immediately, which requires the abuser to leave the home.
"The victim doesn't often realize it but they are in the most danger when they seek to change the situation," said Mary Meenan of White Plains, a second-year law student in the program. "It's clear to us that the best thing is to get the guy out of the house, but quite often they aren't ready to make a clean break. But we are there for them if it takes going to court 10 times to get the situation right."
Ms. Meenan observed that abuse is about control and transcends all social and economic levels. The more educated batterers will use manipulation and cruelty rather than physical battering to abuse a spouse, she said. "We have had rich professionals to the poorest of the poor come in here, but they all have one thing in common: they want the abuse to stop," Ms. Meenan said.
Quite often women do not realize that the legal approach is the only way to get the abuse to stop, Ms. Fialk said. A number of conflicting emotions like fear, loyalty, embarrassment and denial prevent many battered women from following through, she said. "Most people don't want further complications in their life, and they don't rush to the justice system unless it is very serious," Ms. Fialk said.

SECTION: Section 14NJ; Page 1; Column 1; New Jersey Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 2630 words

HEADLINE: Main Street Braces For Another Assault

BYLINE: By DEBRA NUSSBAUM

DATELINE: HADDONFIELD

 BODY:
IT is about 1 p.m. on a Saturday, and there's a wait for a table at The Maple Leaf Diner in downtown Maplewood. In the meantime, people are checking out the window at Sweets and Treats by Jacqui, where gingerbread houses made by local Girl Scouts are on display.
That same afternoon in downtown Summit, you can barely find a seat at the Starbucks across the street from the train station, and you have to thread your way through upscale shopping district a few times before finding a parking space. 
 Back in early December, borough officials in Haddonfield published a letter in a local newspaper urging holiday shoppers not to get so caught up in the Internet shopping craze that they would forget to spend some of their dollars closer to home.
"As we make our holiday shopping lists we should all be mindful that the viability of our town depends on the vitality of our business district," wrote Mayor Eugene H. Kain and two commissioners. "Every dollar we spend downtown is a dollar invested, a dollar that will pay dividends for our entire community."
As merchants along the Main Streets of New Jersey's 566 municipalities look back on the prosperous 1990's and ahead to a new century, they have reason to be pleased but wary. To them, shopping on the Web is yet one more assault on their desire to work and live the American dream.
First, in the post-World War II 1950's, came the flood of cars and the appearance of the shopping center. In the 1960's, 70's and beyond, enclosed malls lured shoppers. And in the 1980's and 90's, designer-name outlet stores and slick catalogs began competing for shopping dollars. All the while -- as suburban sprawl created the need for more and more strip shopping centers -- Main Street suffered.
Then in 1995, as merchants came up with new and creative ways to draw shoppers back downtown, Amazon.com opened to the world and people began ordering off the Web.
"Just when you thought you'd evolved into something different than the malls, there's the virtual world," said Sheila Goodman, president of the Haddonfield Business and Professional Association and owner of N. K. Thaine Gallery. "But that's retailing."
Mary Lou McLarney, who has owned and operated the Country Fair gift store on Main Street in Moorestown since 1993, sees the charm and practicality of shopping downtown this way. "It's a personal touch, like knowing someone's name when they walk into the store," Ms. McLarney said. "That's what's holding small-town shopping areas together. These are people who enjoy shopping and it's an experience for them."
While Internet shopping did surge this year, merchants insist that e-commerce -- thanks to the booming economy and a wariness by many about buying online -- did not hurt New Jersey's downtowns, which in fact enjoyed a healthy holiday season.
Retailers and Chamber of Commerce presidents, like many of the nation's larger retailers, reported a late but good shopping season.
The holiday season, which brought an estimated $300 billion in sales nationally, included a jump in online holiday shopping and ticket sales to about $10 billion in 1999 from $3.5 billion in 1998, according to Shop.org, the trade association of online retailers, and the Boston Consulting Group. The study showed a 270 percent growth from 1998 in the number of orders placed by online consumers.
In 1999, about 1.2 pecent of holiday shopping was done on the Internet, as against 0.5 percent the previous year, said James Vogtle, director of e-commerce research for tThe Boston Consulting Group. But in areas like books and computers, the figures were higher, with about 5 percent of book purchases and 9.2 percent of computer purchases made online. About 5 percent of ticket sales were also made on the computer, Mr. Vogtle said.
"It's a small percentage now," he noted. "In most categories, retailers haven't felt a big impact."
But that could change as people get more comfortable with e-commerce and as the generations that used computers as small children become the nation's primary consumers, Mr. Vogtle said.
"In 10 to 15 years, it's going to be quite remarkable," he said. "There will be a whole generation that has never been able to not shop on the computer. That is going to be the watershed. The really broad sweeping effect may not be felt for 10 years."
A Small Business Administration study made public last year showed that about 35 percent of small businesses now have Web sites, but many of those sites are used for information and advertising rather than sites where customers can place orders. The cost to establish and maintain a Web site is still too high for many small operations, coupled with the need to have the technical ability to maintain the site or hire someone to maintain it, said Bruce D. Phillips, director of the Office of Economic Research for the federal agency.
While e-commerce is gaining in popularity, it is still too soon to tell if it will hurt small businesses, and particularly the traditional type of Main Street retailers, Mr. Phillips said.
"What it means for individuals, stores and individual towns we don't really know yet," he said. "It's too new yet. Its effect is going to be location specific and industry specific."
Stores that sell books or music may be affected more than purveyors of gifts and art pieces, Mr. Phillips said. A study of small booksellers now underway shows that "they are feeling the squeeze," he said.
"If you've been around for 30 years I don't think e-commerce is going to wipe you out," he said. "How many people are going to buy a $500 piece of art online?"
And many people still want face-to-face service that the Web cannot yet deliver.
Ms. McLarney, who operates the Country Fair gift shop and is president of the Moorestown Business Association, said the town's stores -- including her own -- had a good holiday season.
Even on a Saturday afternoon in early January, the downtown streets in towns like Summit, Maplewood and Haddonfield are bustling.
In Maplewood, for instance, store occupancy is 100 percent downtown. Elliott Schabses, the owner of the Cornercopia gift shop and president of the town's Chamber of Commerce, said the holiday season was a good one.
"I do think e-commerce will hurt some businesses like books and toys," Mr. Schabses said. But he said there are many "loyal customers" in Maplewood and in adjacent towns who support the local businesses.
In Summit, Jane and Ralph Eboli have come down from Brooklyn to shop, as they do many weekends. They recently bought a bed at a store in Summit that they could easily have purchased at a specialty shop in Manhattan, but they prefer the small-town experience.
"I like coming, looking and feeling," said Ms. Eboli. "There's a quaintness. It's clean and it's pleasant."
Indeed, some of the businesses that seem as if they would be hurt the most are still doing well. Christopher's Books and Gifts in Summit had a very good Christmas season -- better than 1998, said Rayma Moore, one of the owners.
"It's basic information, not just service" that gives her store an edge over the Internet or the chains, Ms. Moore said. When someone asks for a book for a specific age group, the staff is ready to make recommendations and show what is in stock.
"With young children's books, they really need to see it," said Ms. Moore, whose store has been in Summit for 22 years.
Others -- like those buying shoes or sneakers -- have to feel it.
Joe Puleo, who opened the Haddonfield Running Company three years ago on Kings Highway, the borough's main shopping street, said, "I wouldn't say the Internet is something we're worried about because our whole premise is, we need to see your foot in here."
Mr. Puleo said his business was up 20 percent compared with the 1998 holiday season. And though he has a Web site, he said it was for information and sale shoes only.
"We don't encourage people to get shoes off the Web site," he said. "Without your foot being here, we can't do it."
Around the corner, Tom Joyce, who owns the Trailboss, with his wife, Ronda, knows that customers might find cheaper backpacks and hiking boots on the Web, but if they want his high-end items and they want them to work well, Mr. Joyce says, they need to come into his store and walk around in the boots with the pack on their back. They also carry brands that aren't on the Internet, he said. "We set up to be Internet proof," he added.
Haddonfield, established in 1713, is a borough with a mix of Victorians and many older homes that have undergone renovations, landscaped lawns and historic buildings. At Christmas, almost every home has window candles and at Halloween every porch has a scarecrow. Country gift stores, galleries, a dog bakery, high-end clothing boutiques, restaurants and a Starbucks line Kings Highway.
Quaint and comfortable as it may be here, the owners of small specialty businesses seem to understand that they need to put out a hand to their own community and surrounding towns. In the front of Mr. Puleo's running store is a bulletin board with newspaper clippings about the area's high school runners. In the past he has closed the store to attend cross country meets in the area, and can often be seen running through town with his customers.
"You need to have a relationship that goes beyond them giving you money and you giving them a product," Mr. Puleo said. "You have to reach out and get people to come in here."
Downtown events have become another way to entice people and familiarize them with their local shopping districts. For instance, Summit, Maplewood and Haddonfield all sponsor events during the year. Haddonfield and Summit have a First Night celebration on New Year's Eve, and Maplewood's streets are packed on Halloween with costumed children seeking candy. On July 4, when Maplewood Avenue is closed to traffic, 10,000 people come to town for Independence Day activities. Haddonfield tries to hold an event every month, and in early July about 100,000 people pack a closed section of Kings Highway for a crafts festival.
At the end of January, the borough and business association plans to try "Souper Saturday" for the first time. In conjunction with National Soup Month, restaurants will have soup samples and there will be a recipe contest.
"It's a constant battle," said Letitia G. Colombi, Haddonfield's deputy mayor, who has lived in the town 31 years. "These business cannot rely on just the 12,000 people in town to keep them going."
In addition to special events, the towns must be willing to put money into enhancing the business district, Mrs. Colombi said. Last year, the borough put $30,000 in its budget for requests from the business association. This year, the commissioners are expected to approve $50,000 for the downtown shopping area for such enticements as advertising, special events and to run the visitors' center.
"My vision of a downtown is not just a place to shop, but the heart of a community," she said. "You have to hope that the person who moves to this town feels a commitment to support it."
To that end, Summit plans a $4 million streetscape improvement project this spring, said Joe Steiner, president of the Suburban Chamber of Commerce, which serves Summit, New Providence and Berkeley Heights. The project will include new sidewalks, street lights, trees and utility upgrades.
In recent years the downtown, which has about a 95 percent occupancy rate, has faced competition from the Mall at Short Hills and from the Internet, Mr. Steiner said.
"Our goal is to compete on the highest level with quality and expert service," he said.
Mr. Steiner said likes to tell customers that when they go to the mall they won't meet Mr. Nordstrom in his store, but they will meet Bernie or Mark Needell if they show up at Nee Dell's for their shoes.
Sometimes, bad experiences on the Internet will bring people back to Main Street. For instance, Linda Springer of Puzzles and Pageantry, a store with collectibles, gifts and games in Haddonfield, said a couple came into her store last month looking for a chess set. They had ordered one through the Internet but when it did not come they went back online and found out the set was back ordered and would not be delivered by Dec. 16, when they needed it. Instead, they bought a $500 chess set from Ms. Springer.
"The Internet companies still have some growing to do in their own fulfillment," she said. Ms. Springer had a Web site for several years by shut it down in 1997 because it was too difficult to fill orders off the web and give full attention to the store. This year, she said she had her best holiday season, with sales up 20 percent from last year.
While people may not always want to buy off the Internet, they are increasingly using it to check prices and learn more about the items they are interested in purchasing.
Kevin Kozlowski, manager of J. E. Caldwell, a jewelry store on Nassau Street, the main shopping street in Princeton, said he had noticed that when people came to look at diamonds, they had already done research on the Web.
"Some people think it's the death knell for retailers as we know them," Mr. Koslowski said of the Internet. "We don't think so."
People still want "the emotional and visceral experience" of buying a piece of jewelry, he added.
He said he thought that for jewelers, the Internet would probably have its greatest effect on the watch business because people can see a certain brand and style and then try to find it for a better price on the Web. Caldwell, which is based in Philadelphia, is now setting up a Web site with product information.
Melanie Willoughby, president of New Jersey Merchants Retail Association, advises businesses to at least have a presence on the Web so that if someone looks up where to buy a certain type of bicycle, their shops come up on the list.
"I think everyone is going to have to look at the fact that the typical e-commerce customer is very well heeled," Ms. Willoughby said, noting that most have annual incomes of at least $75,000. "You're going to have to advertise online and be in the mix."
Downtown shopping may become more the venue of the shopper who wants to take some time, rather than someone who wants to quick buy a few gifts on the Web during a break at work.
Joan Brennan, who owns Bayberry's, a gift shop in Merchantville, says her shoppers want to browse and look at the Boyd's Bears and Mary Engelbreit items before making a purchase. It's "a different kind of customer" than someone who uses the Internet to order items, Ms. Brennan said.
Emi Hava, who has owned Paperfolio in downtown Summit for 16 years, also sees her customer base as people who want to see and touch what they are buying.
"We battled the battle of the malls and then came the catalogs," said Ms. Hava, who is also chairwoman of Summit Downtown Inc. "When everything shakes down you'll lose some money, but the fact of the matter is that people like to shop. They like to go to lunch and shop."
And the downtowns still have the tug of nostalgia that a Web site cannot create. Haddonfield advertises itself as "shopping the way it used to be."
"At one time that comparison was with the hustle and bustle of the malls," said David Hunter, the owner of "What's On in Haddonfield," the twice-monthly newspaper that published the letter urging consumers to shop downtown.
"Now it's going to have a different meaning," Mr. Hunter said. "It's not the mall that's the threat, it's e-commerce. I think it's going to be a challenge for small towns. They will have to emphasize personal service and value for money. Certainly the Internet lets you shop day and night from anywhere, but it seems to me that people will always value personal contact."

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY & CO.;
Maplewood Hopes to Save A Historic Piece of Its Past

BYLINE: By ANITA DENNIS

DATELINE: MAPLEWOOD

 BODY:
Who wants to buy a 10-room Greek Revival home built in 1843 and the 1831 mill next door to it? That's a pressing question for the descendants of one of New Jersey's oldest families, and for their neighbors.
In 1831, Lewis Pierson opened a three-story gristmill in an area that would ultimately become Maplewood. This year, the business he started, which has since evolved into a lawn and garden center, will close after nearly 170 years in operation, giving up its fight to remain one of the area's last links to the state's agrarian past. 
 Now the Pierson family's two-and-a-half-acre property and historic buildings -- nestled alongside the golf course of the Maplewood Country Club and depicted in murals in town hall -- are on the market for $1.65 million, and the community is anxiously watching to see what will become of them.
For the family, changing times have made it impossible to continue.
"It's just too hard to stay in business," said Greg Pierson, 48, a member of the sixth generation to run what is now called Pierson's Mill Garden Center, which caters mainly to area homeowners. Mr. Pierson and his brother, Mark, 45, started working in the business in their 20's, but there is no seventh generation of Piersons -- after whom a local street is even named -- to follow in their footsteps.
Long a part of the town's fabric, the family is remembered for extending credit in the Depression and for making deliveries when a buyer could not get to the store. The Pierson family has worked with groundskeepers from such places as Rockefeller Center and Riverside Church, and the store is renowned locally for its variety of lawn seed mixes in distinctive cloth sacks.
According to Mr. Pierson, several factors have contributed to the business's closing -- set for June 30 -- including a nearby Home Depot that has sliced off about 15 percent of his business. While less than a decade ago the Piersons might have had as many as four full- and part-time employees, they are now down to seasonal part-time help.
Ironically, the strong economy has presented another challenge, enabling more homeowners to hire landscapers instead of tending to their own yards, says Greg Pierson.
Even before Home Depot arrived, Pierson's had begun opening on Sundays to make shopping easier for busy two-income families. "My brother and I are dedicated people, but everybody needs a day of rest," Greg Pierson said. Along with the family patriarch, Hubert, 76, the sons decided that the business had seen its day.
Greg Pierson plans to relocate to New England with his wife, Patty, though he is uncertain what he will do once he gets there. "I'm not afraid to work," he said, "although I'd like to avoid retail."
For generations, residents of Maplewood and surrounding communities relied on the Piersons for seed and grain in its early days and, more recently, for garden supplies and advice.
"If you go in and ask about a problem you're having with your lawn, they'll say, 'Let me take a ride by and look at it,' " said Barbara Heisler Williams, who lives within walking distance of the mill. "You'll see people pulling their red Radio Flyer wagons down to Pierson's to pick up bulbs in the fall."
The family's personal approach has been good business. "Our expertise has always been problem solving, helping people, that's why we managed to survive," Greg Pierson said. "I can't offer price points because of my overhead. But to provide a high level of service, I have to spend too many hours that I'm not necessarily compensated for."
The possible loss of the buildings has prompted the town, which boasts a number of historic homes under private ownership, to address the question of historic preservation. Recently the township formed an ad hoc committee to study the issue, but the sale of Pierson's "is a private business transaction and the town really has no standing in the deal," Mayor Jerry Ryan said, noting, however, that any buyer would be subject to local zoning regulations. "My hope is that the family will be able to sell it at a price they want to someone who will preserve it."
News of the sale took most residents by surprise. "Since the family has been there for six generations, you're lulled into a sense of complacency," said Ellen Davenport, a former mayor and an owner of a plant shop that had been operating on the property since 1976 but that closed last year in anticipation of the sale.
It has also galvanized preservationists. "We were shocked to realize there is no town ordinance to prevent tearing down an 1830's mill," said Alison Blank, a member of Preservation Maplewood, a group formed last September after the Piersons' plans became known. The Durand-Hedden House and Garden Association, a local historical organization, has offered to underwrite the cost of research to nominate the buildings to national and state historic registers, which would qualify a buyer for tax incentives, according to the association president, Susan Newberry.
Ms. Newberry says the site may boast the only extant mill building in Essex County and one of the last temple-front Greek Revival houses left in the state.
Marion Harris, chairman of the Morris County Trust for Historic Preservation and an instructor and member of the advisory board at Drew University's certificate program in historic preservation, said: "The property is absolutely unique in so many ways. It's an unusually intact site from a period that doesn't have a lot of examples. In addition, the house was built by one of the founding families of New Jersey."
The community's concerns about the consequences of a sale often are overridden by the town's affection for the family. While Ms. Heisler Williams acknowledges that she worries about increased traffic in her neighborhood if the site is developed, she said, "nobody begrudges them the opportunity to relax after building this business all their lives. No one can be mad at someone who has been such a good neighbor."
Local preservationists say they are concerned that the family's realtor, Chip Mandell of Weichert New Homes and Land Co., is not doing enough to market the property to buyers who might be interested in its historic qualities. "The realtor needs to be careful because if you compromise the site in ways that don't respect the historic value, you lose all of that value," Ms. Harris said.
Preservation Maplewood, which has started its own word-of-mouth marketing campaign, has met with Mr. Mandell, Ms. Blank said, urging him to take such steps as advertising the site in preservation journals.
But Mr. Mandell said the property, which has generated a great deal of interest, was being advertised in newspapers' "prestigious homes" classified sections. He said he envisioned it being bought for use as anything from townhouses or an assisted living center to a professional office building, bed and breakfast, microbrewery or child-care center.
For the Piersons, the issue comes down to family. "I'd like to see the property used in a way that is in the best interests of the town," Greg Pierson said. "But the money my father gets from the sale has to carry him through the rest of his life. This is not the type of business that offers a large retirement fund. Deep down, I'd hate to see it torn down. However, I have to look out for my family."

HEADLINE: ON THE MAP;
Where Washington Commanded, a New Battle Begins

BYLINE: By KAREN DeMASTERS

 BODY:
The stone house built in 1750 atop of a hill in West Amwell Township leads to a 38-acre farm now owned by David and Peggy Dondero. It was originally owned by Cornelius Coryell, a scout for George Washington and a patriot who was captured by the British and paraded along the Delaware River as a prisoner of war.
Washington conferred with patriot leaders at the farm and kept an eye on the Delaware and the boats that were to be used to ferry soldiers across it for the Christmas Day attack on the British in Trenton. 
 The site also has more recent significance. It was one of the first areas preserved under Governor Whitman's pledge to preserve a million acres in the state when an agreement was reached last spring between the state, two conservation groups and the Donderos to ban further development of the buildings and the woods surrounding them. Mr. Dondero and Linda J. Mead, executive director of the Delaware and Raritan Greenway, talked recently about the farm and its future.
Q. Why is this site important?
A. MS. MEAD New Jersey had more Revolutionary War battle sites than any other state. This site is one in the series that will form a trail linking Revolutionary War sites in central New Jersey together to show their historical importance.
This is also one of the first sites preserved as part of Governor Whitman's pledge to save one million acres over the next 10 years as open space and farmland.
This farm is the westernmost point of a stretch of greenway we want to extend across the center of the state to New Brunswick encompassing the Sourland Ridge, a ridge of high ground that runs east and west. The Delaware and Raritan Greenway has preserved pieces of land along the ridge. Our goal is to connect all of them and have a hiking trail that travels the entire route.
 Q. Why is it important to save the land?
A. MS. MEAD Nine acres from this farm on the north were sold off in the past that are actually within the border of Lambertville, which used to be known as Coryell's Crosssing, and condominiums have been built there. You can see them from the yard. On the other side, you can see the big estates marching up the road. A big corporate office center is going to be built nearby and the demand for housing is going to increase even more. If we don't save this and other places like it now, it will all be gone.
 Q. What does Greenways do?
A. MS. MEAD On this project we worked with the state's Green Acres program and with the Hunterdon Land Trust Alliance to put together money to buy the development rights from the Donderos, who donated part of the value of the land to conservation. The Donderos continue to own the land and they can leave it to their heirs or sell it to someone else, but it has to be preserved as it is forever.
In general, we work with property owners who are interested in preserving their land to work out the economics of it. There are a lot of ways this can be done and a lot of tax implications that have to be taken into consideration.
Q. As a property owner, why do you care what happens after you are gone?
A. MR. DONDERO The farm had already been cut up when we bought it and we did not want it to be cut up any further. We wanted to know that years from now this property would be the same. On my stewardship, the property was not going to be reduced further. People hike through the woods now without permission, and we don't really mind, but now there will be public access and hiking trails. We don't mind sharing the land. We have owls and turkeys in the woods. You'd be amazed at how remote it is.
 KAREN DeMASTERS

HEADLINE: IN BRIEF;
And More Cars Cross Bridges and Tunnels

BYLINE: By STEVE STRUNSKY

 BODY:
Automobiles made a record number of crossings between New York and New Jersey in 1999, with a 2 percent increase driven mainly by economic growth, officials said last week. 
 A total of 123.6 million cars, trucks and buses made round trips through or over the Holland and Lincoln Tunnels and the George Washington, Bayonne, Goethals and Outerbridge Crossing bridges, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said. Much of the increase came from commercial traffic, particularly trucks headed to and from the Port Authority's Howland Hook Marine Terminal on Staten Island.

HEADLINE: JERSEY FOOTLIGHTS;
Essex County Cuts Off Arts Center

BYLINE: By LYDIA POLGREEN

 BODY:
The New Jersey Performing Arts Center can expect no contribution from Essex County this year, according to the county executive, James W. Treffinger.
In a statement released last week, Mr. Treffinger (below) said that while his administration "appreciates the importance of the arts and recreation to the quality of life of our citizens," the county could not spare any money for the center, which is in Newark. 
 Essex County sold $5 million worth of bonds to help finance the center in 1998, the year it opened.
Mr. Treffinger said the county was "committed to implementing welfare reform and to the construction of a new jail facility that will solve decades-old correctional problems."
Mayor Sharpe James of Newark, who has championed the arts as an essential component of his city's revitalization, expressed disappointment with the decision.
"We cannot say we want to have cultural facilities and not support them," Mr. James said. He added that he hopes the county will make in-kind donations to the center, as the city has done in providing a parking garage.
The state provided $100 million to build the center, and has continued to support it through the state arts council.
Lawrence P. Goldman, president of the arts center, said in a statement last week that while more than 90 percent of the money raised for the center comes from the private sector, he hoped that "the county executive and the freeholders would be open-minded about continuing the partnership."
Mr. Goldman also said that the arts center had stimulated the economy by increasing property values and investment in the county.
 LYDIA POLGREEN

HEADLINE: Answer to a Question About Transit Concierge

 BODY:

To the Editor:
We were pleased to read about the success of the concierge service at the Maplewood train station in your section ("Finding Themselves, And Their Niche, In the Marketplace," cover, Dec. 19.)
In response to the author, George James, wondering where the concierge concept originated: We came up with the idea when we were working with New Jersey Transit on their Station Renewal Program. The object was to rejuvenate transit stations and the public spaces around them as a catalyst for community revitalization. The concierge service resulted from the need to provide services for riders at stations with low use. It also provided an opportunity to involve and help build business while at the same time attracting ridership. It looks as though it worked. 
 The New Jersey Transit Station Renewal Program has grown into the New Jersey Transit Model Stations and Shelters Program, with more than 50 bus and train facilities targeted for development.
 
KATHLEEN MADDEN
New York, N.Y.
 
The writer is vice president of Project for Public Spaces.

HEADLINE: Quiz Shows Make Every Contestant A Video Gladiator

BYLINE: By JULIA CHAPLIN

 BODY:
WHEN David Karraker, a computer games fanatic who works for the Sega company in San Francisco, first tuned in to "Who Wants to Be a Millionaire" and "Greed" last fall, what he noticed right away was how similar they were to some of his favorite video games.
"Millionaire," the blockbuster quiz show that revived ABC, had a circular glass stage raked by beams of light, while the host, Regis Philbin, perched face to face with a single contestant surrounded by a black void, like the gladiatorial arenas in games like Virtua Fighter. 
 "Greed," the me-too entry from Fox with a more sinister tone, featured a set painted to look like stone blocks, reminiscent of the torch-lighted medieval castles in games like Doom and Soul Calibur.
And when Mr. Philbin intoned his Yoda-like line, "Are you confident that's your final answer?" -- suggesting a warrior guru, a stock figure in fantasy games -- the case was sealed for Mr. Karraker.
"I was shocked," said Mr. Karraker, 31, whose Sega job is in public relations. "Here was this fluffy, friendly person like Regis hosting a show with extremely dark undercurrents that was very similar to the video games I play. I thought, 'This is stranger than anything I've seen on network TV before.' "
What he and other viewers who were raised on video games and science fiction movies are noticing is how much new television game show sets resemble computer games and special effects from films like "Star Wars" and "The Matrix" and futuristic music videos like TLC's "No Scrubs." The look of interactive computer games has come to that stodgiest of television formats, the quiz show, and with it has come an unexpected mirror of the anxiety felt by many Americans over computer technology.
As no television viewer can have escaped noticing (try though one might), the programming phenomenon of last fall, when "Millionaire" ran 18 consecutive nights, has spread to the other leading networks. Quiz shows consume more hours of weekly prime time -- six and a half -- than at any point since the 1950's. They have also spread to cable, where MTV's version, "webRIOT," allows viewers to participate via the Internet.
"Winning Lines," the latest network entry, which made its debut on CBS last weekend, has a look and format described by Ron Pearson, a comedian warming up the audience, as "the Jetsons on acid." Now, any game show with so much as a visible microphone seems as archaic as an eight-track cassette.
"Action films with special effects and home video games like Sony's Playstation have definitely influenced the look of these new game shows," said Michael Davies, the executive producer of "Millionaire," which now runs three nights a week. "Whole generations of people have grown up playing video games. The last thing you want on prime time is something that looks outdated."
Game show staples from the "Jeopardy!" era, like catchy theme songs and circus lights, are as passe as yesterday's fashions. The new game show staging calls for music throughout the show, beating like a heart when danger lurks and crescendoing for victory; black backgrounds that resemble a galactic void; graphics that lie atop one another as in a Windows computer program; and cockpitlike chairs in front of computer screens.
The ageless Dick Clark, who is now the host of "Winning Lines," which airs on Saturday nights, sounded amazed as he explored his latest domain. "Have you ever seen a set like that?" he asked the audience in a pilot episode of the show. "It's going to be launched into outer space later on."
The producers of "Winning Lines," a British import, like "Millionaire," aimed to recreate the feel of an arcade video game, particularly during the hectic final minutes, when a player must defeat the Wonderwall to win as much as $1 million. Sitting in a black seat modeled after a video arcade chair, the contestant holds a kind of joystick and maneuvers among three huge video screens, shouting out the answers to questions in a race against time.
Andy Walmsley, 33, the English set designer responsible for both "Millionaire" and "Winning Lines," said he was surprised when he took a tour of the sets of "Jeopardy!" and "Wheel of Fortune" while in Los Angeles recently, because they were so out of date. "They were still using video walls made out of plain glass TV screens, instead of the flat plasma screens," he said. "It was so 80's-looking."
Throughout their history, game shows have held up a mirror to the times. In the 50's, the set of "What's My Line" mimicked a cozy suburban parlor, complete with seating area and pleated drapes. Other shows spoke of the newness of television itself by mimicking radio conventions like "On the Air" signs and isolation booths. The most infamous of these shows, "Twenty-One," which precipitated a scandal over rigged questions, has just been revived by NBC. Many elements of its vintage set remain intact, including the isolation booths. (It is the only one of the new batch of prime-time game shows not notably influenced by video games.)
In the late 60's and early 70's, psychedelia arrived on the sets of shows like "The Dating Game," with its bubble-shape lettering and big plastic daisies. After the 70's, game-show ratings were poor, and the no-frills set of "Tic Tac Dough" reflected the lower budgets.
But then came "Millionaire," with its nerve-rattling music, eerie blue lighting and space age metallic set. "The set and format is a look toward the next platform of programming, which is a converged medium between the TV, telephone and the computer," Mr. Davies, its producer, said.
"Millionaire" embraces high-tech effects to heighten the drama, which the new shows have emphasized over the mere answering of questions. The show is shot almost entirely in close-ups. "When the contestants first walk out on the set, they're terrified about falling through the glass floor or making too much noise with their shoes on the metal," Mr. Davies said. "They never feel that comfortable, and here they are, ordinary people in a new city, across from Regis Philbin, having to make the most important decision of their lives."
Jimmy Cuomo, the designer of "Greed," noted that the overtones of science fiction incorporated in his set, which was inspired in part by the Starship Enterprise from "Star Trek" and by the castle settings familiar from video combat games, contribute to a sinister atmosphere.
"Computer technology does represent a level of anxiety to the middle generation," he said. "It's like, 'Do you really want your credit card number out there in this void where people can steal it?' There is a scary element. So computers and technology, or at least the symbolism of them, can heighten the tension that's part of the appeal."
By contrast, MTV's game, "webRIOT," which is pitched to a younger audience, 12- to 24-year-olds, imparts a different vision of technology. The colorful set was described by its producer, David Salles, as having the "user-friendly optimism of iMacs and VW Bugs, rather than the foreboding hacker look of 'Millionaire' and 'Greed.' "
"Our viewers don't have those same kinds of dark issues with computers," Mr. Salles said.
The four contestants on "WebRIOT," shown daily at 4:30 p.m., are suspended in cartoonishly round pods and are referred to by their screen names (as in, "Vid-kitten, what's the answer?"). The zany host, bullet-headed Ahmet Zappa, speaks remotely via a video screen, which enlarges his image to four times life size. The audience, projected onto multiple screens, is also virtual. The show goes further than any of the others in marrying life in front of a computer screen to a television game show.
"The concept for the show was that everyone lives in their own private suspended reality now," said Brian Graden, MTV's head of programming. "You don't have conversations with people in the same room. You communicate with people behind a screen via the Internet. Players of computer games like Quake and Doom relate to each other in an abstract space, and we want these kids to feel like MTV is an extension of their community, much like the game worlds."
Which vision of computer technology, sunny or dark, exerts the more powerful psychic hold on viewers just now? In a week in which America Online, Pac Manlike, swallowed Time Warner Mr. Karraker of Sega made a case for the grimmer version, a view of everyday life as mortal combat.
"We're in this booming economy right now, where everyone is reaching for that brass ring," he said. "People read these articles about kids making millions in I.P.O.'s. They're asking themselves, 'How do I get in on an Internet start-up?' There's a desperate need to catch up, to have millions, and it's made us more battle-oriented."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 4; Column 5; Money and Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 878 words

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW;
As the Good Times Roll, The Marxists Are Mellowing

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
IT is remarkable how a booming economy flattens ideology in this post-cold-war era. The good times in America have many economists rewriting their views, and none more so than those who see the world through Marxist eyes. Only the final outcome -- the Day of Reckoning -- sets the Marxists clearly apart from mainstream economics. And the Day of Reckoning has been postponed.
No one expected the current economic expansion, which started in 1991, to last so long. Certainly not the Marxists, who hold that too much of the national income has gone to corporate profits in the 1990's and not enough to labor, a painful imbalance that cannot be sustained indefinitely. Now that view is being edited. A rising tide that keeps on rising quiets a lot of people. 
 "If the expansion continues another three to five years," said Ismael Hossein-Zadeh, a Marxist economist at Drake University in Des Moines, "the trickle-down effect is bound to be seen increasingly in wages." That raises the possibility, he said, that the workers, instead of protesting, could get "sucked into" the good times.
Few mainstream economists -- or mainstream politicians -- would disagree. Democratic and Republican economic policies count on this happening. The Marxists differ mainly in degree. They do not believe that companies competing for labor in an expanding economy will raise incomes enough; they want government intervention to make income distribution more equal.
They mention measures like a higher minimum wage or laws that strengthen unions, policies that many non-Marxists also favor. But for the moment, government intervention gets soft-pedaled almost everywhere in economics.
HAVING been wrong so often about when the expansion would end, economists of all stripes are self-consciously covering all the bases. Plausibility seems to require no less when so many Americans respond to pollsters by saying that they see no setbacks coming. So Anthony Gabb, a Marxist economist at St. John's University in Queens, offers a forecast acceptable today even on Wall Street.
"If this expansion continues for 5 to 10 years, I would not be surprised one bit," he said. "But by the same token, if the economy went into recession soon, I would not be surprised either."
The long-running expansion came up often at the annual meetings here last weekend of the American Economic Association and various other social science groups. To most of the economists, the expansion reflects a well-functioning free market and some good luck. For the Marxists, the expansion is an anomaly requiring explanations. Their organization, the Union for Radical Political Economists, offered the only session devoted entirely to "The U.S. Expansion and What Comes Next."
Mainstream economists see the expansion as a phenomenon that can continue indefinitely, until some outside shock or policy mistake provokes a recession. A stock market sell-off could be such a shock, or a financial crisis that frightens lenders, who then stop lending; or the Federal Reserve could raise interest rates too far, or be too slow to lower them in a pinch. The Fed has been blamed for almost every recession since World War II.
The Marxists, in contrast, believe that the expansion contains the seeds of its own undoing. Their latest revisions try to explain why it is not yet undone. Some skate pretty close to mainstream economics.
The expansion, in the Marxist view, is a long upward wave that started in the 80's, when business got the upper hand over labor and profits rose. Stability, investment, technology, rising productivity, deregulation -- all have reinforced profits, the Marxists explain. And the brief 1990-91 recession did not stop the wave. These are observations heard from mainstream economists, too.
The New Economy enthusiasts, in particular, are finding kindred spirits in a strange place. Or as Mr. Gabb put it, "The system is more resilient than we may want it to be."
Still, the undoing will come in the struggle to consume all the output. Wages are rising, the Marxists acknowledge, but not fast enough. So people borrow, helped by the strong stock market, and credit flows in from abroad. Rising debt loads are part of any expansion, but this one is getting to the point that people are borrowing more just to make payments on existing debt. A shock to this fragile structure would bring it down.
That is farther than most mainstream economists will go. They, too, worry about debt, but without a Marxist's pessimism. The mainstreamers generally hold that policy can save the day. The Fed, for example, can defuse a debt crisis by quickly lowering rates, a move that would preserve the expansion and reassure workers.
Marxists doubt that it would be so easy. Much of labor's "passive acceptance," said Fred Moseley, a Marxist economist at Mount Holyoke College, in a recent paper, "has been based on the optimistic premise that the years of 'pain' will soon be over and the U.S. economy will soon return to the more prosperous conditions of the postwar period, with its steady and substantial increases in real wages. Continued stagnation, or worse, would invalidate this premise; perhaps then acceptance will turn into resistance."
Perhaps. But for now, wages are rising.
