SECTION: Section 14; Page 1; Column 1; The City Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 3010 words

HEADLINE: Where the Solos Last Till Dawn;
With Endless Music and Open Jams, Smalls Stands Out Among Jazz Clubs Like a Blue Note in a Major Scale

BYLINE: By ARAM SINNREICH

 BODY:
IT'S 2:30 on a Monday morning, and things are just getting under way. A jazz quintet is playing up in front of the small subterranean room, which is filled nearly to capacity. Candlelight reflects from the decorations on the wall: dim photographs of jazz legends from days gone by, odd sections of brass instruments oxidized by years of smoky air. Seated around small round tables or on padded benches along the wall, people bob in time to the music, smiling and humming between sips of beer.
No clear line divides performance from audience. Instead of playing on a stage, the musicians squeeze into a tiny area cleared around the beat-up baby grand piano. Even the band has blurry boundaries; halfway through a song, the tenor sax player hands his instrument to a man sitting on the sidelines. The man takes a solo without leaving his seat, then hands the sax back to his friend, who finishes the song with a reprise of the melody. 
 This is the eighth consecutive hour of music, and the fourth band. When the final set ends around 3:30 a.m., the last barrier between band and audience will fall. There will be an open jam session, and all comers are welcome to test their jazz mettle in public. The jam will continue until the music peters out or until dawn, whichever comes first. When the session finally ends, 12 straight hours of music will come to a close.
It is a marathon at most clubs, but just another night at Smalls.
In an age and a city where jazz is increasingly considered the realm of the elite, a quaint relic of a bygone era best preserved in the rarefied air of Lincoln Center or near-museums like Birdland and played only by a handful of revered masters and their humble acolytes, Smalls stands out like a blue note in a major scale. Few famous names grace its roster, and most of the players are under 30. And in the wee hours of a weekday night, when the band is hot and the air is full of smoke and sweat, the atmosphere is anything but rarefied.
If Smalls sounds like a bit of an anachronism, it is alive and real for the musicians who play there. In the five years since the club opened on West 10th Street, a block away from the noise and traffic of Seventh Avenue South, Smalls has become something of an institution among young jazz players and a growing number of jazz fanatics. And although the quality of the music varies from night to night, the club is, in the words of Ehud Asherie, a 20-year-old pianist who is one of the club's denizens, "unique in the whole world."
"There's no other jazz club like it, really," adds Mr. Asherie, who got his start at Smalls as a high school sophomore.
It is paradoxical that a club like Smalls should be such a rarity. For more than half a century, New York was the crucible where jazz was forged. Like an alloy of the city's many cultures, jazz was continually remolded into something new, thrown back into the furnace before it got a chance to harden. Change was the only constant, and experimentation was the key to change. From Harlem down to Midtown Manhattan and the Village, in clubs like Minton's Playhouse and the Onyx, musicians poured in when their money gigs were over, and then the real music would begin.
Mainstream acceptance of jazz contributed to the decline of this tradition. As musicians flocked to university jazz programs and audiences to upscale venues, most jam sessions were relegated to the status of amateur night.
Smalls turns this equation on its head. While no other club in New York City today offers the sheer volume of scheduled music Smalls does, it also far exceeds other jazz clubs in the amount of time dedicated to jam sessions. The four or five hours of music available at the more famous jazz spots in the neighborhood, like Sweet Basil and the Village Vanguard, pale in comparison to Smalls' all-nighters. While more established clubs often charge upward of $25 for an hourlong set, Smalls charges a flat fee for a night of music: $10. And while weekly jam sessions are virtually a given at jazz clubs of any size, only Smalls allows its guests to bring their instruments and play seven nights a week.
THE scores of young jazz fans who line up around the block on a chilly Friday night to get into Smalls probably aren't thinking about a dying New York tradition. But they do sense an aura of history about the club that belies its tender age.
"It's like the musicians are still here in spirit," says Amelie Develay, a slight, waifish-looking brunette who moved to New York from France last spring, as she scans the images of jazz greats enshrined on the wall. For Ms. Develay, 24, a freelance journalist, it's her first visit to Smalls, and she's entranced by the dinginess. "It's nice because it's not a clean place," she says.
One table away, Phil Cappello, 22, a television reporter for RNN, a cable news network that serves the New York area, sits nursing a beer. "This place has a pretty rich history," says Mr. Cappello, who has been a regular at Smalls since the club opened on the site of Lenny's Hideaway, a legendary gay bar from the 50's. And there's something else he likes. "It doesn't seem to be gouging you at the door."
It isn't surprising that a venue devoted to experimentation should draw a young crowd. The low cover charge, relaxed atmosphere and late sets help as well. But its youth appeal might have a simpler reason: there's no age limit. While Smalls is equipped with a bar, the only beverages served are water, iced tea, lemonade and coffee. Guests may bring drinks of their own, and by the end of the night, beer bottles cover most of the horizontal surfaces.
Still, if the customers are younger than the demographic most jazz clubs try to court, that's only half the story. Smalls is also "really unique in that it caters to the young jazz musicians," says Neal Miner, 29, a tall bassist who has been leading a quartet at the club for more than a year.
"Smalls is definitely kind of a school," Mr. Miner says. At this school, aspiring musicians can take their first steps as public performers, band members and, ultimately, bandleaders. Mr. Miner, who gained most of his early experience before Smalls existed, no longer puts in the kind of time that the younger and less experienced players do. "I can't say I hang out there," he says, "like some of the people who live there, practically."
Ehud Asherie, 10 years younger than Mr. Miner and just beginning his career as a bandleader, is one of those who consider Smalls their home away from home. A quiet, confident young man with a handsome face and a keen stare, he still winces when discussing his first night playing piano at Smalls five years ago. The band was playing "Confirmation" by Charlie Parker. When the guitarist took his solo, Mr. Asherie continued to comp -- to play the chords of the song as an accompaniment -- as he had during the original statement of the melody. The guitarist, an older Smalls regular named Sol Rubin, got upset and started yelling at the uncomprehending Mr. Asherie to stroll, jazz jargon for "stop playing while I solo."
"Finally, I got it," Mr. Asherie says. "I was very embarrassed, but, you know, I learned from it. Besides learning the jazz vocabulary, I learned musical etiquette."
Smalls is not simply a kind of music school. It also has elements of a finishing school. It gives aspiring musicians a place to meet older and more experienced players, to absorb jazz culture and history as they work on their technique.
Mr. Miner says he has developed something of a mentor relationship with Mr. Asherie since the two met about 18 months ago on a Sunday night at Smalls.
"I taught him a lot of tunes," Mr. Miner says proudly. "He's very talented and works very hard."
This kind of camaraderie is the product of a deliberate effort by the club's owner, Mitch Borden. Despite the studied casual aura he and his club project, it is clear that he is fanatical about his vision of a musician-friendly jazz club, which he says is the key to keeping the music alive.
"There are not too many places like that you can go," he says, pausing as if to search for other examples. "In fact, I think there are none."
Mr. Borden, an impish, balding man of 42, had no experience as an impresario when he opened his club. His father, Herbert Gordon, was a painter who, coincidentally, had a studio on West Ninth Street, a quick stroll from what later became his son's club. Mr. Borden, who was born in Neptune, N.J., remembers family jam sessions with his parents; both father and son played the mandolin. Although the younger Mr. Borden initially worked as a nurse, opening Smalls was not so much a departure for him as a return to the musical foundations of his family. A cousin, Mark Sanders, played conga with Gato Barbieri and Nat Adderley, who died this month, and Mark's father, Morty Sanders, started the Latin jazz jams in Central Park.
Although Smalls was named after the legendary Small's Paradise in Harlem, Mr. Borden sees his club as more akin to the Village Gate, a longstanding jazz venue and late-night "hang" that closed its doors in 1994 after 36 years.
"There needs to be a Smalls," he says. "There was a Smalls. It was called the Village Gate."
By Mr. Borden's account, Smalls is more a pot of trouble than a pot of gold. Altogether, he says, his monthly expenses include $4,000 in rent, $1,300 in rental fees for a Steinway grand piano, $1,200 in utilities, $700 in sales tax on the door charge, $400 in insurance, $200 in music licensing fees and $1,300 in salary to himself, for a total of nearly $10,000. Until recently, he paid an average of $700 a night in musicians' fees, for a monthly total of $20,000; musicians who jam are not paid. Because of a legal problem involving the United States Department of Labor, to which Mr. Borden has paid $7,000 for failure to provide workers' compensation and unemployment insurance for his performers, he will not discuss any current arrangements with musicians.
Because Smalls doesn't sell food or drinks, Mr. Borden's sources of income are not as numerous as his expenses. The only revenue from customers is the $10 door charge, which he waives before 9 p.m. on weekends and is lax about enforcing in general. With a maximum legal capacity of only 48, he says, total income from the door amounts to about $25,000 a month.
Mr. Borden says he subsidized Smalls during its early years with money from a thrice-mortgaged house that he owns in Ocean Grove, N.J. (He lives on Carmine Street, with his wife, Sharon, and their two children, 12 and 15.) Now, he says, the place is picking up in popularity and beginning to pay for itself. The low overhead helps. There is no liquor license to renew and no staff to pay. Mr. Borden is bouncer and busboy, barker and barkeep.
"He's hung in there all the time," Mr. Miner says with a tinge of awe. "It's not like he has people doing all the stuff for him. He does it all himself."
Mr. Miner is not alone in his adulation. Most of the musicians who play at the club seem similarly awed by Mr. Borden. Mr. Asherie calls him "a saint" for his dedication to younger musicians. "He's the best thing that's happened to the jazz community," he says. "He started a scene."
Perhaps the only role Mr. Borden shirks is that of M.C., a task he leaves largely to the musicians themselves. Unlike more visible jazz club owners like the Knitting Factory's ubiquitous Michael Dorf, Mr. Borden seems to shrink from publicity. He is loath to talk about himself, and when pressed recently, he mumbled only that he was in no way special before walking away.
Running even a modest club like Smalls is hardly without its problems, and Mr. Borden has had more than his share.
In addition to being in trouble with the Department of Labor, he has run afoul of the city's Health Department. Last week, Mr. Borden appeared in court in connection with $2,000 in fines levied by the agency for infractions like smoking in the bathrooms. He is contesting the charges.
The city's Landmarks Preservation Commission has taken action against Mr. Borden repeatedly in connection with changes he made to his building, which is an official city landmark. He has already removed an advertising marquee from the facade, and the commission has said he will be fined if he fails to remove his awning and security gate.
There are also private lawsuits pending. Mr. Borden is facing lawsuits by customers who have fallen on the steep stairs of his basement club. He is seeking a more accessible space.
Mr. Borden has neither a lawyer nor an accountant to help him navigate these choppy waters ("Do you know how much lawyers cost?" he asks), but he says his troubles have been a learning experience.
"Some of my problems are from my own folly," he says. "If I had the chance to open up another club, I'd do things differently."
Some of the patrons at Smalls probably do not realize that the diminutive man with the shaved head and the fez clearing the bottles off their tables or taking their money at the door is the proprietor. Out in front of the club, far from the spotlights, such as they are, noodling on his violin and chatting with the regulars, he seems more like an adjunct to the scene, one of the eccentrics at the margins of the club rather than the force at its center.
Mr. Borden seems not only aware but also downright delighted by the dubious impression he often makes on his clientele. "They always think, 'Oh, no,' " he says with a chuckle, " 'I just gave $20 to some homeless guy.' "
THE quality of playing at Smalls, especially at the jam sessions, is hit or miss. Because all are welcome to play at the jams, there is no quality-control mechanism to ensure that a musician who takes the stage knows the first thing about jazz, or about playing an instrument. While the result can be interesting from an anthropological perspective, it's not always a pleasant musical experience for either the listeners or the more experienced musicians.
"I don't really play the jam anymore because it can be kind of a disaster," Mr. Miner says. "And it's a lot of work. The level of talent is a lot lower than playing a gig. You don't really enjoy it after a while."
The audience at Smalls usually responds to unskilled players politely, with a few seconds of encouraging applause. But the off-duty regular musicians, congregating at the bar or in the back between the entrance and the door to the kitchen, can be brutal.
One Saturday morning around 4:30, the jam is not jelling. Kenji Rabson, the house bassist, is manning the piano. Everyone else on stage is an unpaid musician. The band launches into a loose interpretation of the Herbie Hancock standard "Footprints," a jam session favorite because of its simple structure and malleable rhythm.
A young vocalist is rapping and scatting over the chord changes. The bass player is struggling to match his groove to the older and steadier drummer. The trumpet player clearly doesn't know the song very well, so the regular musicians at the back of the club start singing his part to him in mocking, nasal voices.
When the bass player takes his solo, the heckling intensifies, and he completely falls apart. "Why don't you footprints on out of here?" one musician shouts. The bassist panics, losing all semblance of rhythm. He seems to be forcing his fingers to move, playing any note he can until finally the solo section is over, and the reprise of the melody ends the song.
As soon as it's done, he gives the bass to another player and heads up the stairs onto the street, averting his eyes as he passes his tormenters. Outside, the sun is coming up. The bassist stands on the sidewalk, breathing deeply. His name is Richard Hill, he is 21, and he has just moved to the city from Philadelphia. He says he has been playing the bass professionally since he was 16 and has played with notable jazz bands, like the Sun Ra Arkestra. But he admits that sometimes he has a hard time at jam sessions.
"I've had cats come to me after like, 'Do you know the tune?' " he says. "I'm still working. I'm still developing."
The vocalist from "Footprints" emerges from the club and approaches him. "You sound good, man," he says. "Don't kill yourself too much." He gives Mr. Hill his number and asks him when he's free to play some gigs. "Call me, man," he says. "I'm serious. I need some bass players."
The bassist smiles. "All right," he replies. "I will."
SUCH experiences are common at Smalls' jam sessions. "Because it's an open forum, musically sometimes it can just be a complete disaster," says Karl Welz, the tenor sax player in Mr. Asherie's band. "People will just make fun of whoever is out there. But the regular musicians are there all the time, so it's just like someone going into your house and doing something. I think it's always been that way. It can either make them quit or try to change and get better."
Mr. Welz says he feels uncomfortable judging other musicians' techniques. "If they're young and seem nice, I wouldn't do that," he says. "But if you're going to get up and play in front of people, you have to be ready for the response."
For those, like Mr. Asherie, who manage to live through their baby steps at Smalls' jam sessions, the club can take them giant steps closer to a career in jazz. Mr. Borden gives promising young players the chance to headline, an opportunity reserved for established recording artists at most clubs.
But it takes time and dedication. According to Mr. Welz, Mr. Asherie's devotion to music has made him "a zombie," with such persistence that failure is not an option.
"He's there every night," Mr. Welz says. "And he finally convinced Mitch to give him Sunday late night" to lead his own ensemble about a year ago.
From Mr. Asherie's perspective, the opportunity to headline at a jazz club at the age of 20 is the result of providence, not persistence. After all, where would he be if it weren't for Smalls?
"I have no idea," he says with a shrug. "Thank God for Mitchell Borden."

The Village Vanguard: Ralph LaLama on alto sax with the Vanguard's house band. (Ozier Muhammad/The New York Times)(pg. 12)
 
Chart: "CHORD PROGRESSIONS -- From Cotton Club to Knitting Factory"
If New Orleans was the birthplace of jazz, New York is where the music matured. From the Jazz Age to the present, no other city has offered such a large or varied roster of venues or matched its reputation as a font of musical innovation. Here are a few standouts among the hundreds of the city's clubs.
 
The Cotton Club
 
The Cotton Club was home to big bands such as Duke Ellington's and Cab Calloway's during Harlem's halcyon days. When Harlem started to decline in the mid-30's, the Cotton Club relocated to midtown, where it finally closed in 1940.
 
Dan Wall's Chili House
 
It was at a jam session in this otherwise unremarkable Harlem eatery in 1939 that, Charlie Parker later claimed, he first conceived of be-bop harmony. His musical companion was a guitarist named Biddy Fleet, and the song was Cherokee, a tune by Ray Noble which became a staple of Parker's repertoire and a symbol of the be-bop revolution.
 
Minton's Playhouse
 
Perhaps the most famous jam session spot in New York history, Minton's was a Harlem club where serious jazz musicians would come to play and innovate after their money gigs. The house band included such luminaries as Thelonius Monk and Kenny Clarke.
 
The Onyx Club
 
A midtown speakeasy which became one of the top jazz clubs on 52nd Street in its heyday. During Prohibition, the password was "I'm from 802," a reference to the local chapter of the musicians' union. When Harlem musicians started bringing be-bop to a larger audience, the Onyx was one of the first clubs to embrace it.
 
The Savoy Ballroom
 
A major Harlem institution for big band jazz music during the swing era. Due to its nationally syndicated radio broadcasts and large, upscale audiences, the Savoy was known as more than just a club; it was a steppingstone to fame.
 
The Royal Roost
 
A former chicken restaurant on Broadway in the theater district, the Royal Roost began presenting jazz in 1948. The impresario Symphony Sid would broadcast from the club on Tuesday nights, giving musicians like Miles Davis, Charlie Parker and Dexter Gordon national exposure. The Royal Roost also had a non-drinking section for younger audiences.
 
Birdland
 
Originally a midtown jazz club named the Clique, Birdland was reopened and renamed in honor of Charlie "Bird" Parker in 1949. Sadly, before Parker died in 1955, his heroin addiction and consequently erratic behavior would cause him to be banned from the club. Birdland still exists, though it has relocated twice in the intervening years -- first up to 106th Street, then back to midtown.%%Peter: parker's wife is very sick or may have died last week and i think she owned the club. can you check? c%%
 
Studio Rivbea
 
Founded by the reed player Sam Rivers, Studio Rivbea on Bond Street was one of the main sites of the "jazz loft" era. During the 60's and 70's, some of New York's most prominent jazz musicians would open their own venues (sometimes their own apartments) for performances so that music could be free of commercial pressures.
 
The Village Vanguard
 
When the Village Vanguard opened in 1935, it was the first integrated club below 14th Street. Since then, it has played host to an extraordinary number of jazz legends and been the site of over a hundred live recordings by artists such as John Coltrane, Bill Evans and Wynton Marsalis. The club is still run by Lorraine Gordon, the widow of the founder Max Gordon, who died in 1989.
 
The Village Gate
 
During its 36 years on the corner of Bleecker and Thompson Streets, the Village Gate was a cultural landmark, featuring both new and established acts from the worlds of jazz and folk. In 1994, financial troubles forced the owner, Art D'Lugoff, to close up shop and move to midtown, where his club flickered and died after less than a year.
 
The Blue Note
 
Opened in 1981, the Blue Note is the epitome of the modern, upscale jazz club. This Greenwich Village institution generally features only big-name artists and has become a jazz marketing powerhouse to boot, with franchises around the globe. The Blue Note does host jam sessions, however, on Friday and Saturday nights from the end of the last set until 4 a.m.
 
The Knitting Factory
 
Founded in 1987 as an alternative to New York's more mainstream jazz venues, the Knitting Factory has paradoxically become one of the strongest forces in determining the course of new music in the city. In 1994 the club moved from its humble beginnings on Houston Street to a larger, more commodious location on Leonard Street in TriBeCa. (pg. 12)

HEADLINE: CALLINGS;
Trade Shows Without Borders

BYLINE: By LAURA PEDERSEN-PIETERSEN; Laura Pedersen-Pietersen is a Manhattan author and public speaker. Her column profiling people whose work is their passion appears the third Sunday of each month.
E-mail: yourmind@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
TO Peter Nathan, the word "no" is merely a request for more information. In the 1970's and 80's, Mr. Nathan, a trade show impresario, arm-wrestled Soviet and Chinese apparatchiks into allowing him past their frontiers to produce a variety of Western industry shows. This week, he will preside over the five-day U.S. Healthcare Exhibition -- the first American trade expo in Cuba in more than 40 years.
Undaunted by the trade embargo against Cuba (which does not include medical supplies) and the tug-of-war over Elian Gonzalez, the 6-year-old survivor of a shipwreck, Mr. Nathan is convinced that now is the time to open up the Cuban market. 
 Still, producing a trade show in such an environment requires someone special, said Steven Hacker, president of the International Association for Exposition Management in Dallas, who called Mr. Nathan "the Green Beret of international exhibitors."
As such, Mr. Nathan, 66, demonstrates that the advantages, and the risks, of being an early mover extend far beyond the technology world. With his forays into untested markets, Mr. Nathan is trying to go where even major multinationals often stumble.
Is the payoff worth it?
"Definitely," he said. "The authorities from those countries are pleased when someone takes an interest in their country, and so, going forward, you have the ear of the right people."
With Cuba, he figured that the humanitarian benefits of medical equipment and pharmaceuticals would make the trade fair an easier sell to both governments. While it took three years to get Washington's approval, said John S. Kavulich II, president of the U.S.-Cuba Trade and Economic Council in New York, Havana approved in 10 days.
"It's absolutely incredible what he's accomplished," Mr. Kavulich said. "Anyone else would have given up after getting turned down so many times."
Last year, Mr. Kavulich told Mr. Nathan that he should consider his show a success if only 10 exhibitors showed up. As of last week, Mr. Nathan's company, PWN Exhibicon International L.L.C. of Westport, Conn., had signed more than 100. The principal sponsor is Archer Daniels Midland; other exhibitors include Eli Lilly, Medtronic, Hewlett-Packard and Eastman Kodak.
Mr. Nathan relishes breaking into new territory. In 1971, long before glasnost, he organized the first American industrial machinery show in Russia, overcoming currency and language barriers, shipping catastrophes and "unfathomable amounts of red tape." But dealing with Moscow became much easier, and other successful shows followed.
To make it in the business, "you have to be a professional, round-the-clock problem solver," he said. He has seen many such problems -- waking up to blizzards and an exhibit hall fire, and giving up many a night's sleep in union confrontations.
WHY put on shows in markets like Cuba? "The short answer is the Mount Everest one," Mr. Nathan said. "It's the challenge."
Fortunately, his wife of 45 years, Sandy, enjoys the challenge, too. She will be working as an on-site administrator in Havana.
Mr. Nathan arrived on these shores in 1937 as a 4-year old German-Jewish immigrant; his family had fled the Nazis. He received a bachelor's degree in life sciences from the University of Connecticut in 1954. While waiting to start at the Marine Corps officers school, Mr. Nathan took a temporary job as an office boy at Clapp & Poliak, an exhibition company based in New York.
After two years in the Marines during the Korean War, he returned to the firm, eventually rising to partner. (He stayed with the company until it was sold in 1982.)
In the early 1970's, the federal government hired Clapp & Poliak to organize an air and transportation show at Dulles International Airport outside Washington. That was the start of a long relationship. Two years later, the government persuaded him to run Expo 74, the world's fair in Spokane, Wash., for six months.
President Richard M. Nixon, who was increasingly enmeshed in the Watergate scandal, flew out to open the fair. While being escorted around, Nixon pointed to the walkie-talkie in Mr. Nathan's hand and asked, " 'What's that?' " Mr. Nathan recalled. "I explained it was a two-way radio. Mr. Nixon replied, 'It's not a tape recorder is it? Because I don't like those things.' "
In 1980, Mr. Nathan put on the first two American electronics exhibitions in China. At the first, in Beijing, the booths were overrun by 20,000 Chinese consumers, leading panicky officials to call in security. It wasn't needed. The friendly stampede was simply the result of tremendous interest in American products. As with the first show in Russia, many more exhibitions followed.
Mr. Nathan expects his Cuban odyssey to have a similarly happy ending. The licenses and approvals that he sought for so many years were eventually granted. And the federal departments that stymied Mr. Nathan for three years -- State, Commerce and Treasury -- are now sharing a big booth at the show to encourage future trade.
"We're very enthusiastic about the expo," said Charles S. Shapiro, the director for Cuban Affairs at the State Department. He attributes the turnaround in large part to President Clinton's call last year for more people-to-people contacts with Cuba.
Perhaps the Hollywood version should be called "Mr. Nathan Goes to Havana."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS;
At Graduate Schools, a Great Divide Over E-Business Studies

BYLINE: By DAVID LEONHARDT

 BODY:
ASK deans and professors at America's leading business schools to weigh in on what has become the hottest controversy in management education, and some decidedly unacademic epithets start flying.
Silly. Crazy. Dishonest. Stupid. 
 At issue is whether the online selling, buying, marketing and distribution of products -- known collectively as e-business -- should be taught as a separate academic subject or as an inseparable part of a general business curriculum? Money, prestige and the ability to attract the most desirable students hang in the balance.
Some deans have chosen separation, creating new majors that have rapidly become among the most popular on campus. Other deans are rolling their eyes at what they see as an empty gimmick and are moving instead to weave e-business into existing majors and courses.
"You're missing the point if you set up a separate program," said Edward A. Snyder, the dean of the University of Virginia's Darden School.
"It seems silly to ghetto-ize it into a course or a string of courses," said Eric J. Johnson, a professor at Columbia Business School.
"It's almost like making it the flavor of the month," added Robert S. Hamada, the dean of the University of Chicago Graduate School of Business.
What do advocates of a separate major make of such attacks?
"Crazy," said Donald Jacobs, the dean of Northwestern University's Kellogg Graduate School of Management. "It is crazy not to do it separately." Success on the Internet calls for a very different way of thinking than managers in traditional businesses are trained for, he said.
The alternative approach is too slow, said Patrick T. Harker, interim dean of the Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania. Integrating e-business throughout a curriculum "doesn't happen overnight," he said, "and anybody who says it does is not telling the truth."
Is that all, gentlemen? Not quite yet.
"It does happen overnight," responded Professor Johnson, who taught at Wharton with Professor Harker until this fall. "It has happened overnight in the real world. Business schools are trying to catch up."
INDEED, all the schools are devoting vast resources to writing new case studies about the Internet, overhauling existing courses to reflect the changes it has caused, and using online material to supplement lectures. Deans of schools on both sides of the divide say corporate recruiters will snap up M.B.A.'s who seem to understand how the World Wide Web is changing the economy. And prospective students will shun any school they see as lagging behind the Internet revolution.
But the deans part company on how best to stay abreast. "They are very different paths that the schools have taken," said Cathy Baker, the vice president in charge of recruiting at Mercer Management Consulting, which hires about 90 M.B.A.'s a year.
The debate mirrors one raging in the bricks-and-mortar economy. Some companies, like General Electric, have directed managers in every department to rethink their business with the Internet in mind, while others have set up separate Web divisions meant to stay free of corporate bureaucracy.
At separate-major schools like Wharton, Northwestern, the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and New York University, professors say they are able to study e-business intensively and to spread its lessons to other departments.
Northwestern is typical. Last spring, a committee appointed by the dean found that its proliferating e-business offerings were too haphazard and were leaving some gaps. So the school brought the faculty together to fill out its course roster, eliminate overlap and inaugurate a major in technology and e-commerce last fall.
After a first year of core subjects, students in the program take a survey course, then choose 3 of 16 electives ranging from data mining, a new class taught by an engineering professor, to the evolution of Silicon Valley, a class that includes a 10-day California trip to meet with dozens of chief executives.
At Cornell University, business school students are given the option of spending one semester studying nothing but e-commerce.
Several schools have set up research centers along with new majors, including M.I.T., whose Center for eBusiness draws faculty from the business school and from media and computer science laboratories.
Carrie Oliver, 28, is in her second year at Vanderbilt University's business school, which in 1995 became the first major school to offer such an e-business program. After working for Sanford C. Bernstein, an investment firm in New York, she wanted to concentrate on studying Internet commerce and applied only to Vanderbilt, she said. About 90 percent of her elective courses have been inside the major.
"Recruiters can't get enough of us," she said of her class of e-business majors. She credits the e-business label and the specialized course work with helping her land job offers from Deloitte & Touche, Nortel Networks and a small Internet start-up.
FACULTY members at other leading schools, like those at Chicago, Columbia and Dartmouth, are skeptical. Often, they say, the creation of an e-business major is little more than a marketing exercise, rearranging existing classes under a new heading.
"It's easy to raise money" for programs labeled "e-business," Prof. Hamada of Chicago said, noting that dot-com millionaire alumni are often willing to donate to them.
The skeptical schools are using other strategies to make their programs Internet-aware. The University of Virginia's Charlottesville campus was host to 1,000 PricewaterhouseCoopers partners for three-day sessions last summer and fall to discuss and study the Internet. The school then rewrote parts of its first-year M.B.A. curriculum to reflect what it learned from the consultants, Mr. Snyder said.
Columbia, which recruited Prof. Johnson from Wharton last year, has revamped syllabuses for 30 courses and created seven new ones with heavy Internet emphasis in marketing, finance and other departments.
These schools also know they must work harder to broadcast the weight they give the Internet. Dr. Hamada says he has instructed his recruiting director to tell prospective M.B.A.'s at admissions conferences that e-business is no less important at Chicago than it is at schools with separate majors.
Their job may be easier among corporate recruiters, many of whom put more stock in candidates' intelligence than in course work. "What we're looking for is talent, and not a specific major," Ms. Baker of Mercer said. She said she found the most Internet-oriented M.B.A.'s at Harvard and Stanford, where students do not specialize..
The two sides of the argument agree that the Internet is crucial to the future of business schools, and there is a consensus that the schism will narrow in time, as it did in a similar debate in the 1980's over the wisdom of separate international management concentrations. With globalization now an important theme in most courses, the international majors that still exist are dwindling in popularity.
"In the long run," said Professor Harker, Wharton's interim dean, "it makes no sense to have a separate major" about e-business. "The question is how you get from here to there."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 4; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1348 words

HEADLINE: BUSINESS;
At the AOL-Time Warner Wedding, Visions of Better and Worse

 BODY:
WHEN the Godzilla of the Internet decides to wed the King Kong of content, it is a natural time for the other denizens of the jungle to wonder what the future will hold for the colossal couple and the world they inhabit.
The question of what America Online and Time Warner see in each other is inseparable from the question of what the Internet landscape will look like in a few years. Will cyberspace be mainly a source of information and entertainment, or an interactive communications medium? Will the crucial asset be a subscriber base, a broadband electronic pipeline or a server full of movies, music and news? Will the primary entrance point be a computer, a television a cellular phone or perhaps a Webcam? 
 Verne G. Kopytoff and Julie Flaherty were assigned by Money & Business to ask Internet seers in business and academia how they saw the online experience evolving over the next five years, and whether last week's announced merger of tree-snapping behemoths advances, retards or misreads those trends. Here are their replies.
 
WILLIAM H. DUTTON -- Professor of communications at the University of Southern California and author of "Society on the Line" (Oxford University Press).
Internet providers don't want to be limited to people who have computers. But to date, efforts to introduce interactive television and other interactive services like video text and video services have all failed.
You have to be skeptical about to how well the Internet model translates to the television set. They're totally different. People who watch television generally are passive and don't interact with it and don't want to. So changing their viewing habits is going to be difficult.
Clearly the Web has been a trigger service that has caused more people to get computers and get online. But there are also other trigger services, like word processing and spreadsheets.
People who see big synergies in the AOL-Time Warner merger are ignoring the fact that electronic mail and communicating with others is why most people use the Internet. Access to information, including entertainment, is not the major reason why people go online.
People will still watch television on television, which will be much like it is today, though in a few years it will have many more links and ties and references to the Internet.
 
GORDON M. TUCKER -- Chief executive of Egreetings Network, an online digital greeting and gift company based in San Francisco.
I believe that the desktop computer will remain the anchor point for people going online. I don't believe that people who are information-centric organize their lives around television.
Television doesn't handle the variety of needs. You want to reduce the number of communications options you are forced to deal with. The problem is that more and more people are getting frustrated with the number of devices they have to manage. Wireless phones and laptops will be there, but as a supplement to computers.
It's all about making it easier and easier for people, and faster and faster. Obviously people today want instant gratification, and mergers like AOL and Time Warner are just going to accelerate the achievement of that goal. In a few years the Internet will be a lot more dynamic, and you'll have the ability to personalize a Web site you visit: it will be possible to present a fundamentally different Web site for you versus everyone else.
In online retailing, global commercial access transforms companies and the way they sell products. Right now it is difficult to sell products internationally, but as the barriers to international trade come down and Web sites address the need of international consumers, you'll have access to anyone in the world.
 
MARIO GERLA -- Professor of computer science at U.C.L.A., now working on developing Internet 2, a high-speed successor to today's Internet.
I see a lot of changes happening. One is wireless access to the Internet. Nowadays, we connect mainly from the home or the office, but we already see a trend of access to the Web from cell phones. Soon a commuter riding to work in a van will be able to video-conference or take a class on a laptop. We will be able to stand in the aisle of one store and see what others are charging. There is definitely the need to access the Internet from anywhere.
All of this raises the question of cost. You may pay a provider for access, but no one is charged for actually using the network, regardless of the traffic. That's all right for now when there isn't that much traffic. But in the future, if everyone is building bigger conferencing and video on demand, you'll just exceed the bandwidth available. That will be resolved by charging people, or by giving free access but having advertising subsidizing the network as an indirect charge.
This is especially true for wireless access. If I'm in the middle of Central Park, I'm sharing the spectrum with a large number of people, so pricing will be the controlling factor.
The other complementary act is that we will have the so-called smart office, and the smart network to appliances in the home, and video cameras in every room that can be accessed from the Internet. You will be able to see what your kids are doing -- that's an extension to the concept of the Web.
As for the AOL-Time Warner merger and the proliferation of entertainment on the Internet, there is a limit to what you can sell. We are already flooded. I don't have any time for that; maybe kids do.
 
MICHAEL L. DERTOUZOS -- Director of the Laboratory for Computer Science at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and author of "What Will Be" (HarperBusiness).
I am not surprised by the merger, for it confirms the industrial world's progress toward a powerful information marketplace.
I am surprised, however, by the hyperventilation over "content." Even with interactivity, such uses will only be roughly as big a part of the overall economy as entertainment and news are today -- less than 5 percent. But office work, at 50 percent of the industrial economy, could reach $4 trillion a year online worldwide.
Within five years, 50 million Indians, who read and write English and have office skills, will be ready to sell their information work to us at bargain prices. Interconnected computers will further automate many of the things we now do with our eyes and brains. People will collaborate over time and space wherever they may be. They will be able to retrieve the information they want, rather than infojunk; control their physical environment; and customize goods and services to individual needs.
And, we hope, more people than the privileged 2 percent of the world who are interconnected today will join in. Much more than interactive "content" lies ahead.
 
BOB METCALFE -- Founder of the 3Com Corporation; now a commentator on technology and vice president of the International Data Group, a large publisher of computer-related books, newspapers and magazines, in Boston.
In five years, most Americans will be enjoying broadband Internet from home, maybe 100 times as fast as dial-up modems and always on -- no more waiting for personal computers to power on, boot up, launch browsers, accept dial tone and then dial their screeching modems only to get busy signals from, well, America Offline.
What we'll attach to the always-on, high-speed Internet will be mostly devices other than personal computers. What comes and goes over the broadband Internet will be much less like clicking a computer than like talking on the telephone. And it will be less like talking on the telephone than like watching CNN, reading Time magazine, laughing through Looney Tunes at the movies, hip-hopping with Rampage on Elektra records and exercising with Jane Fonda.
All we have to worry about on the broadband Internet is preserving freedom of choice among competing alternatives. Worry about Big Business taking over the Internet if you want -- AOL Time Warner, Microsoft and the telephone monopolies, for example -- but be sure to keep an eye on Big Government.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 3; Money and Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 560 words

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
First Jolts of the Internet Shakeout

BYLINE: By GRETCHEN MORGENSON

 BODY:
FOR months, if not years, the virtual has trounced the real in the stock market. Valuations of Internet concerns vastly exceeded the values that investors assigned to companies unlucky enough to own tangible assets. Companies with profit were bounced for those with "eyeballs."
Last week, on the strength of several significant announcements, the tables turned. The real world is back in the ascendant, and investors are about to experience the Great Internet Shakeout. 
 A big indication that the tectonic plates of the virtual world were shifting was the bid of the highflying America Online to acquire the landlocked Time Warner. Then the Charles Schwab Corporation, online broker to the world, said it would acquire U.S. Trust, an investment firm known for asset management services it provides its decidedly blueblood clientele. Schwab appeared to be protecting itself should the online trading boom evaporate.
Another straw in the wind: Wal-Mart Stores announced on Jan. 7 that it was spinning off its Web operations into a dot-com. Wal-Mart is expected to show that brick-and-mortar retailers can beat e-tailers at their own game.
So, even as Alan Greenspan rhapsodized in New York on Thursday about the joys and gains relating to the Internet, that world was starting to undergo wrenching change.
"This week is a bit of a watershed, in which the highflying world of the Internet meets the concrete test of the marketplace," said Brian J. Fabbri, chief economist at the Paribas Corporation, an investment firm in New York. AOL and Schwab were the first. "For the rest of the unreal world, the acid test is to come," he said.
Nevertheless, investors remain extremely optimistic about Internet stocks. The Interactive Week Internet index of 30 stocks closed at 555.27, just 7.7 percent below its record high reached on Jan. 3.
"My general concern is investors are feeling too complacent over the extraordinary gains they got in Internet stocks in 1999," said David Readerman, director of Internet strategy at Thomas Weisel Partners in San Francisco. "It's not going to be that easy this year. There are going to be some colossal failures."
Jim Breyer, managing partner at Accel Partners, a venture capital firm that is a partner with Wal-Mart.com, believes last week's shift was epic in its significance. "The reckoning is coming soon," he said, adding that second- and third-tier Internet companies are highly vulnerable. Equally threatened are old-economy companies that do not get Web strategies off the ground now.
Investors in the stock market have been very forgiving of Internet companies with big plans but little in financial results. "Public investors have played the role of venture capitalists in these companies," Mr. Breyer said. Now, venture capitalists are getting tough with Internet companies trying to raise money, and individual investors ought to do the same.
Mr. Readerman suspects that the shakeout has begun, noting that in the first half of January, as Wall Street firms held Internet investing conferences, Internet stocks did not perform that well. "If calendar 1999 was one of discovery of the Internet, 2000 is going to be characterized by much more rigorous scrutiny of the business models," he said. "You don't want to be completely out of these stocks, but I'm not averse to taking some profits."

SECTION: Section 4; Page 1; Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 1494 words

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends: Lost in Cyberspace;
Whistling Past the New Economy

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER

DATELINE: COUNCIL BLUFFS, Iowa

 BODY:
WHEN America Online and Time Warner announced the biggest merger in history last week, it set off a furious, if predictable, debate that swept through the airwaves, chat rooms and hyperactive financial markets, which couldn't decide if it was a brilliant idea or a marriage made in cyberhell.
Is it good for the country, many asked, for a single media conglomerate that already bestrides the print and cable world to also control America's most popular entrance ramp to the Internet? 
 Will it further widen the technological gap between rich and poor?
What does it mean for America's relations with its allies, who are increasingly uneasy with the nation's dominance of the Net?
And are these matters Washington should wade into, as it did in the Microsoft case, or should they be left to the invisible electronic hand?
All interesting questions -- except out here on the campaign trail. America may be plunging into a new global economy at warp speed, but the major presidential candidates would rather talk about ethanol subsidies than the future of the Internet.
For Republicans and Democrats alike it's Old Economy 101, perhaps because times are so good, perhaps because the politics of the New Economy are far too complex for a slogan, perhaps because even Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, admits events are moving so fast that nobody can truly understand what they mean.
"People don't ask about it much because we've filled up all that empty office space downtown," said Midge Leiter, a 47-year-old Democrat who came to a Rotary meeting in Portsmouth, N.H., on Thursday to hear Gov. George W. Bush. "Health care is the big issue," she said.
It's true that the candidates get a bigger earful on managed care and access to medical insurance than on any other subject. But it's also remarkable how little is said about the huge range of potential political issues raised by the explosion of the digital economy since the last presidential election.
Log on, and you are barraged with arguments about the privacy of electronic records, the wisdom of keeping the Internet tax free, the national security implications of super-encrypted messaging that can protect your credit card data or be exploited by international terrorists. And then there is the thorny issue of whether the government should play a role in making sure technology does not further widen the divide between the wealthy Net-savvy of the world and the digitally deprived.
IT'S not just the dizzying changes in the electronic economy that leave the candidates mute. Many of the biggest foreign policy crises that Washington has faced in the past decade have been rooted in the turmoil that can roil the global markets, from Russia's economic implosion to the financial meltdowns that struck Mexico and Asia.
But the protests six weeks ago at the World Trade Organization meeting in Seattle had the chief effect of underscoring to politicians how potent the issues raised by economic globalization have become, both in America and abroad. And the politicians' response has largely been to drive around the whole thing as if it were a bad neighborhood.
Among the candidates, for example, only Gary L. Bauer has raised questions about China's imminent entry into the World Trade Organization.
Mr. Bush's foreign policy speeches have dealt at length with the traditional issues of the 1980's and early 90's -- national missile defense, Iran and Iraq, peacekeeping -- but when he got a question from a voter in New Hampshire last week about how he would have handled the near-collapse of a huge hedge fund 16 months ago, he stumbled, then erroneously said that the Treasury had bailed out the wealthy investors. (He quickly corrected himself after questions from two reporters, acknowledging that private investors, not the taxpayers, had bailed out the fund.)
Vice President Al Gore may be more comfortable dealing with questions about the global economy: after all, he participated in all the administration's midnight meetings about how much to aid Russia, whether to rescue the Mexican peso and how to keep the Asian upheaval from spreading to American shores. But as one top economic aide says, he is "scared to death to open his mouth" on these issues.
Who can blame him?
The administration's all-out push to get China into the W.T.O. has angered labor unions at the very moment Mr. Gore most needs their support. Trade agreements that fail to require other countries to enact environmental protections have driven a wedge between Mr. Gore and his favorite constituency. His foray into government regulation of the export of encryption software put him at odds with Silicon Valley -- at least until last week, when the administration backed down and dropped virtually all controls on such exports.
And just the mention of Russia, Mr. Gore knows, invites the Republicans to ask uncomfortable questions about what happened to America's multibillion-dollar "investment" in converting Russia to capitalism with taxpayer-financed "enterprise funds," which Mr. Gore once proudly hailed. Actually, it's no wonder he'd rather talk about managed care and saving Social Security.
"What's changed in eight years is that globalization is a reality, and it's a very controversial reality," said Mickey Kantor, President Clinton's former trade representative and commerce secretary. "Economic change has run way, way ahead of the politicians, and they don't know how to get a handle on it."
It's hardly the first time.
Back in the presidential election of 1908, when steel and railroad trusts were a national preoccupation and J. P. Morgan played the role of Bill Gates, everyone ran on a don't-mess-with-a-good-economy platform. Then one day William Jennings Bryan argued that "public ownership is necessary where competition is impossible." He quickly backpedaled, but Wall Street and the business community decided he was unfit to run the American economy.
SO it's not too surprising that no one in this year's race dares to wander far from the siren song of the markets.
They are all free traders, promising to destroy trade barriers overseas, but mindful of Mr. Greenspan's message that surging imports keep inflation in check. (In Congressional races, however, where workers at a local factory can form a large and angry voting bloc, trade is often still hotly debated.)
Similarly, everyone is foursquare in favor of letting entrepreneurship flourish. But does the AOL-Time Warner deal encourage innovation and easy access to the Internet for all, or squash it?
"I think it's too early to judge," Mr. Bush said carefully when asked -- for this article -- on Friday. "It's important for people in public positions to be mindful of what could happen in access to the Internet."
Neither Mr. Bush nor Mr. Gore -- nor the other candidates, for that matter -- have ventured far into the murky waters of the Microsoft case, and have taken particular care not to address the question of whether the company should be broken up, much as Standard Oil was a century ago, or AT&T in the 1980's.
"The market is changing too rapidly," said Mr. Bush, who added, "I haven't paid that much attention about the details."
The candidates are probably wise to be cautious. While the tycoons owned the trusts, lots of steelworkers and secretaries have Microsoft in their 401(k) plans. Worse, the terrain keeps changing. A week ago Microsoft was the biggest gorilla on the block. Now, assuming the AOL-Time deal comes together, there will be two gorillas battling for content and distribution, meaning the market may set up a better competitive fight than the courts ever could. The fact is, no one knows.
But it might be refreshing to determine if Democrats and Republicans had a different approach to ensuring the privacy of computerized records, an issue the Supreme Court touched on last week when it barred states from selling data on drivers' licenses.
And it would be interesting to hear competing plans for bridging the digital divide. Years ago, when utilities stayed neatly within state and national boundaries, the government made sure that basic telephone service reached even the more remote and impoverished outposts. Does a similar plan make sense for the Internet? And who should pay to wire up villages in India and ghettos in Brazil -- their own governments? American foreign aid? The World Bank? AOL-Time Warner?
RIGHT now, the candidates wooing Silicon Valley for cash are steering clear of such discussions. Instead, they talk about keeping the Internet tax free, at least for a while, even though it is not entirely clear why a sale that takes place over the Net should be treated differently from one that takes place over the phone.
"The Valley's attitude is that they just want government as far away from the Internet as possible," an adviser to Mr. Gore said the other day.
So for the next few months at least, it's back to the Farm Bureau.

LENGTH: 930 words

HEADLINE: Dot-coms in an Alien Universe

BYLINE: By Ron Chernow; Ron Chernow is the author, most recently, of "Titan: The Life of John D. Rockefeller Sr."

 BODY:
On Monday morning, Wall Street awoke to the sound of shattered glass.
For several years, the stock market has been divided by a glass partition. On one side, gleeful investors on Prozac have sacrificed current performance for future profits, bidding up Internet and other high-tech shares to giddy levels tethered to no tangible reality. Meanwhile, on the bricks-and-mortar side, stocks have often been penalized for earning real money and paying decent dividends -- embarrassing proof, in the current climate, of a lack of corporate imagination. 
 Then, with the stunning news that America Online would absorb Time Warner, the delirious dot-com universe suddenly collided with the old-fashioned economy of companies that must earn money to survive.
In many ways, AOL has been a traitor in an industry notoriously bereft of profits. Its earnings this past year of nearly $900 million far outstripped those of Time Warner. Yet the stock market has magnified AOL's ample girth to gargantuan proportions. With 12,000 employees and less than $5 billion in annual revenues, the online company has swallowed a media behemoth with 70,000 employees and nearly $27 billion in revenues. This anomaly occurred because euphoric stock investors assigned America Online a valuation as high as $200 billion before the merger, while Time Warner stock languished in the vicinity of $100 billion.
Before this week, virtual companies exchanged their highly inflated shares to take over other companies on the same side of the glass divide. These swaps of Monopoly money didn't threaten traditional corporations and unfolded in a separate, slightly lunatic, realm. Now that Time Warner has accepted AOL's shares as legitimate money, the barrier between the real and virtual economy has been punctured irrevocably, and many dot-com companies will be tempted to rush through the breach. Since these deals will be executed in stock, not cash, the exorbitant price of digital companies will make them natural predators, eyeing traditional companies for dinner.
Yet it's not clear that Internet companies will maintain their heady valuations. After Monday's announced merger, AOL's shares skidded nearly 20 percent before rebounding modestly later in the week. This precipitous slide may foreshadow a distinct aversion of Internet investors to the whole idea of blending the old and new economies.
These traders will sorely miss the glass barrier that kept them sequestered in a financial Brigadoon of fantasy prices and cloudless skies. They've had the luxury of operating in a market of "pure plays" -- that is, companies tied exclusively to the cybereconomy. Now fast-growing Internet companies will be swapping their stock for companies growing far more sluggishly, intermingling the two worlds. The resulting hybrid companies will flush Internet investors from their enchanted kingdom into an alien world where real earnings count.
Investors in the old economy may be no more enamored of these unions. As they receive their AOL stock, will conservative Time Warner investors accept the new math of Internet valuation? Or will they introduce conventional yardsticks of value into a sector that has enjoyed a reprieve from reality?
America Online's bumpy experience last week suggests that high-tech executives wishing to capitalize on inflated shares to shop for real assets may be trapped in a paradox. On the one hand, their current power resides in their elevated stock prices. Yet once they try to exercise that power in the conventional economy, their stocks may plunge, dispelling that very power.
The AOL-Time Warner deal was initially trumpeted as a vindication of cyberpower. As AOL stock subsequently plummeted, however, it underscored instead the perils of Internet companies venturing into the real economy. Should this trigger an exodus of investors from such high-flying companies, it will have profound repercussions, for the stock market has played a critical role in high-tech business strategies.
Once upon a time, fledgling companies relied upon bankers for start-up loans until they had booked enough earnings to justify stock listings. Now, in a superheated investment environment, companies can bypass the banking system altogether, advancing swiftly from conception to a billion-dollar initial public offering in less than a year. These companies then exploit their wildly appreciating shares as currency to take over other companies. At the same time, by dangling stock options, they can lure talented managers from the old economy without paying hefty salaries.
Tumbling share prices in the virtual world would hamper the ability of high-tech companies to hire, expand and innovate, and America might lose some technological sparkle in the process. Yet the bursting bubble would have collateral advantages. Fresh capital would be more equitably distributed across the economy instead of being concentrated in just one sector. The willingness of investors to bankroll every dot-com venture has often appeared indiscriminate, creating expectations among investors that may never be fulfilled, and a measured decline in Internet stocks might mitigate the damage from these excesses.
Whatever the problems along the way, the stock market's glass barrier will disappear. Over the next few years, the technological marvels of cyberspace will so permeate the economy that most companies will represent some blending of old and new. And that will mean a gradual convergence of two sides of a stock market that has suffered from a unique split personality.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 7; Column 1; Week in Review Desk

HEADLINE: Correspondence/Jail-House Translator;
Seeking Asylum, Some Immigrants Find A Fate Worse Than Criminal

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF

 BODY:
I WAS, frankly, unprepared for jail in this country.
While living in Asia, I often encountered people -- particularly Chinese -- who had endured Kafkaesque months or years in prison without ever committing a crime. Their futures were decided not by legal principle but by luck, and American presidential candidates this election season have denounced the arbitrary and often brutal nature of the Chinese system. 
 After my years abroad, I returned to the United States and spent the last few months of 1999 writing a book in my hometown in Yamhill County, Ore., a place as bedrock America as can be, a place that I revere as God's Country and that is the antipodes of China. Except, it turns out, for the jails that house immigrants.
I was pressed into service by county officials as an interpreter for a half-dozen Chinese immigrants who were languishing in jail, awaiting the outcome of their asylum applications. They are among the 17,000 foreigners held by the Immigration and Naturalization Service in prisons and jails around the country.
A couple of days later I walked through a series of clanging steel doors into the women's section of the Yamhill County jail. Among the mostly American prisoners, five Chinese women stood out as they walked in a circle around the room, trying to get some exercise.
For months -- in some cases nearly a year -- they had been stuck in jail, not knowing the status of their cases or what would happen to them, not able to ask questions or seek help. According to inmates and jail officials, when two of the Chinese women were ordered to switch bunks and did not understand, guards knocked them to the ground and handcuffed them, bloodying one. Those two women's fear, humiliation and wretchedness increased when they were placed on a punishment regimen for the next four weeks, effectively penalizing them for not understanding English.
When the women heard me speak their language, when they were finally able to explain their nightmare, they began to cry. They told how they had come from various villages in Fujian Province, the area on the coast that is home to many of the Chinese who come to America. Two were teenage sisters, and the rest were in their 20's. They were smart, enterprising and brave, as one would expect of young people who had mortgaged their possessions and taken considerable risks to forge a new life in a land whose language and customs they could not understand.
All had arrived at Portland International Airport and requested asylum. Instead of finding freedom, they were hustled into different jails. Although they had broken no law, they were often treated worse than criminals, who were at least allowed the use of the exercise yard each day. The Chinese were never allowed outside. Supporters in groups like Amnesty International initially were not permitted to give them materials in Chinese, although that was reversed after a county commissioner intervened.
The only stroke of luck these women had was that Jim Bunn, a Republican, lost his re-election bid for Congress and ended up working as a humble jail guard. He took an interest in them, bought Chinese-English dictionaries so that they could communicate and became their guardian angel. "I just kept thinking, 'What if I were in China and in jail?' " he said. "So I wanted to see if I could make things a bit easier for them."
The I.N.S. is often criticized for the way it treats foreigners, sometimes denying them the dignity and safeguards Americans demand when they are jailed overseas. But while the Chinese women had terrible things to say about the I.N.S., they said they were also mistreated by the guards, who looked down on them because they were foreigners and could not communicate.
Still, the women's fundamental concern was not so much their daily treatment as the way they had been locked up without the right to make their case effectively or without any knowledge of what was happening to them.
The well-meaning jail officials for whom I was interpreting asked specific questions about what the Chinese wanted, such as their preferred meal for Christmas. The women shrugged, conferred and decided. "We'd like rice," they said.
What these women cared about most was not better food, outside exercise or even English lessons, they said, but some insight into how their fate would be resolved. "We can get by whatever you feed us," one woman said fervently. "Just tell us, does anybody know about us? Or have we been forgotten?"
Because the women had met only briefly with interpreters, poor ones at that, they said they felt they had been unable to recount their histories thoroughly. Most of them believed they had been lost in a bureaucratic I.N.S. limbo rather like the Chinese criminal justice system.
And maybe they are right.
Under the immigration agency's rules, some of them will be granted asylum and end up American citizens, and the others will spend a year or more in jail and be deported. The children of the former may end up American Ph.D.'s, and the children of the latter will probably end up as Chinese factory workers. The difference between the two groups is largely whim and luck.
It is clear to anyone who talks to Chinese peasants in places like Fujian why they come to America: for the same reason my ancestors did, to live a better life. Most Chinese, however, are smart enough to insist that they are fleeing China's restrictive birth policy. A Congressionally mandated law provides that as many as 1,000 people yearly can gain asylum to avoid persecution on that basis. Some of the refugees may be telling the truth when they say they have violated the policy and face forced sterilization or fines, but there is no way of verifying their stories. The upshot is that immigration judges tend to reward the best-coached, smoothest liars rather than the most deserving applicants.
I put the women in touch with people at Linfield College in nearby McMinnville, and the few Chinese living in the area. Life began to look up for them as they got English lessons, Chinese Bibles and magazines, as well as arrangements to call relatives in China. Then last month, the I.N.S. abruptly took the women away in the middle of the night to other jails, scattering them and telling no one where they had been taken.
One of the women wrote her English teacher, saying her new jailers in The Dalles, Ore., had taken away her Chinese-English Bible, which also helped in her study of English. She also said she is given two envelopes each week, each with 33 cents postage, but could not combine them to get a single envelope with the 60-cents postage needed to write her family in China. "This is not good place to been," she wrote in her newly acquired English. "I'm sad and scared and broken heart. Why they did it for me?"
SOME who made friends with these women thought immigration officials deliberately moved them so they would no longer have any local supporters to monitor their treatment. If that were true, then it mimicked the times in China when I tried to help people and ended up getting them in trouble with their government.
I asked Bill Strassberger, an amiable I.N.S. spokesman, about all this, and he said that the agency would not have moved them to isolate them. The agency tried to remind local jails that these immigrants are not criminals and should be treated with dignity. "I'll be honest with you," he said. "We haven't been totally successful in that."
Now I have moved on, to New York, and I doubt I will see any of these women again. Those who are released and become Americans will eventually see a warmer side of America, but I wonder about those who are sent back to China. What will they say about human rights in this country?
I realize that these women and others like them are fundamentally economic immigrants who in most cases have lied about the reasons they came. Perhaps they should be sent back. Yet I have hectored so many Chinese officials about the importance of a justice system that treats people with compassion that I still feel deeply let down by the fate of these women, especially in a place in the heartland whose essential goodness I cannot question. It would have been nice if Americans could have adhered to the standards to which they hold China.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 17; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 276 words

HEADLINE: Debating Retirement's New Lines

 BODY:

"On the Retirement Road, 65 Is Still Their Limit" (Seniority, Jan. 2), by Fred Brock, suggested that raising the retirement age to 70 would be difficult for Americans whose jobs required hard physical labor -- construction workers, for example. The column drew varied responses from readers.
To the Editor:
 I think your conclusion is correct that the people making the rules (a small minority) don't need to retire on Social Security as early as possible. They are in high-paying jobs that allow them to carry on with a minimum of pain and strain. That is not so with the vast majority of people. 
 I happen to be in another well-hidden class of people. I hold a Ph.D. in chemistry and was forced to retire at the age of 53. Because of my age and the fact that I have 25-plus years of experience I am virtually unemployable. A company can hire a person straight out of graduate school for half what it would cost for a person with my experience. I have offered to work for the reduced amount, but it does no good since they feel that I will keep looking for another job and leave at the first opportunity.
I receive about $14,000 in pension benefits from my old company. The bottom line is simple. I can't support my wife and 17-year-old daughter on my current income.
I think there are a lot of people in the same position. I paid the maximum into Social Security for the first 25 years of my working life, because I was making a high salary. Now that I'm making much less money, my contribution is far lower. I wonder if I will ever get anything out.
 
ROBERT F. ARMBRUSTER, Ph.D.
Harveys Lake, Pa., Jan. 3

HEADLINE: DATABANK: JANUARY 10-14;
In a Whirlwind, Investors Hold On to Hats

BYLINE: By MICKEY MEECE

 BODY:
Investors held their ground last week, even as announcements from some of the country's biggest companies swirled around them like debris in a windstorm.
 America Online's deal on Monday to acquire Time Warner would have been enough for investors to get their arms around, but there was much more: Microsoft named a new chief executive; Charles Schwab decided to buy U.S. Trust; Warner-Lambert and Pfizer were talking the merger talk, and a speech by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, suggested that the Fed would raise interest rates only slightly in early February. 
 The market raced in high gear on Monday, down-shifting on Tuesday and Wednesday, before ending the week in cruise control. For the week, the Nasdaq composite rose 4.7 percent; the Dow Jones industrials climbed 1.7 percent to a record, 11,722.98, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 1.6 percent.
 The market gyrations are keeping investors off balance, said Alan Ackerman, senior vice president at Fahnestock & Company. Nonetheless, as averages move to new highs, investors who vowed to remain risk-averse are relatively risk-ready. MICKEY MEECE

HEADLINE: France Presses the U.N. to Help Poor Nations Get AIDS Drugs

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Jan. 14

 BODY:
As more international attention focuses on an AIDS epidemic spreading out of control, France is prodding the United Nations to find ways to make cheaper drugs available to poor countries, where treatment is beyond the means of most people who need it.
The Clinton administration also supports the cause championed by France. But officials and AIDS experts contend that drug companies have been resistant to pleas that they alter their pricing policies or donate medicines to poor countries. 
 Alain Dejammet, France's representative at the United Nations, proposed during an all-day Security Council meeting on the AIDS crisis in Africa last Monday that a three-way conference be convened to bring together rich nations, their pharmaceutical companies and representatives of poorer countries in desperate need of affordable medicines.
Mr. Dejammet said the interests of pharmaceutical companies, which fear the erosion of their patents on drugs developed at enormous costs in research and testing, would have to be taken into account.
He said that for this reason, France was proposing that the companies and countries involved in both buying and selling drugs get together to discuss how to avoid more confrontations over intellectual property rights.
He said in an interview Thursday that given the huge numbers of AIDS cases in the developing world, treatment should not be forgotten in the rush to support prevention efforts -- many of them more educational than medical -- and the development of an AIDS vaccine. The 21 countries with the world's highest H.I.V. infection rates are all in Africa, and these nations are also among the world's poorest.
Vice President Al Gore, speaking at the same council session on Monday, also raised the question of how to make medicines more readily available, an issue President Clinton had addressed at the contentious World Trade Organization meeting in Seattle in December.
"We are also committed to helping poor countries gain access to affordable medicines, including those for H.I.V./AIDS," Mr. Gore told the Security Council. "Last month, the president announced a new approach to ensure that we take public health crises into account when applying U.S. trade policy. We will cooperate with our trading partners to assure that U.S. trade policies do not hinder the efforts to respond to health crises."
Mr. Gore said the United States would add $150 million to next year's budget for fighting AIDS. A third of that amount would go to the Global Alliance for Vaccines and Immunizations, which sponsors medical research and works on the distribution of drugs to the third world. In total, the Clinton administration is seeking to make $325 million available for the American contribution to the worldwide campaign against AIDS.
Mr. Gore learned last year how complicated efforts to aid poorer nations can be when negotiations with pharmaceutical companies are involved. He drew protesters to his campaign rallies after he presented the position of American drug companies in talks with South Africa.
The talks concerned a 1997 South African law that allowed imports of cheaper, but unlicensed, copies of American drugs for AIDS and opened the way for South African manufacturers to produce generic versions of their own.
Forty pharmaceutical companies responded by first lobbying the South Africans and then filing a lawsuit. The suit was suspended in September when South Africa said that the law would be re-examined.
