HEADLINE: Price of Joining Old and New Was Core Issue in AOL Deal

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR and LAURA M. HOLSON

 BODY:
The journey to last week's announcement that America Online would buy Time Warner in history's largest merger began last fall and included secret meetings in New York and Boston and a key dinner on Jan. 6 at the home of Stephen M. Case, the chairman of America Online.
But the turning point for the deal came not at a dinner or a power breakfast, but over the New Year's holiday in the solitude of the small library of the Vermont vacation home of Gerald M. Levin, the chairman of Time Warner. It was there, where Mr. Levin says he does his best thinking, that the chairman of the world's largest media company finally decided he would accept less than half ownership of the combined company. 
 Time Warner, to be sure, would contribute about 80 percent of the revenues of the new company, thanks to the cash-producing might of a media empire that spans Time and Sports Illustrated, Warner Brothers and CNN. But it was America Online, with its Internet flash, that was the hot stock on Wall Street, and thus worth far more than Time Warner.
So Mr. Levin accepted that the price of leaping into the Internet era with America Online would be a high one. But there were limits, too. In Vermont, he came up with the make-or-break offer he would propose at dinner later that week at Mr. Case's home in suburban northern Virginia: Time Warner shareholders would agree to own only 45 percent of the new company, while America Online shareholders would get 55 percent.
"I decided then that if AOL would go along with that, we had a deal," Mr. Levin recalled last Friday. "If not, we were going to have to go our separate ways."
The story of how the America Online-Time Warner deal was put together is the step-by-step account of two major companies -- a front-runner in the New Economy and a leader of the Old Economy -- grappling with those issues of business strategy and pricing.
In industry after industry, executives are being forced to confront the same issue that Mr. Levin faced: At what pace and at what price to enter the Internet economy? And for their part, as the Internet moves into the mainstream, other Internet executives face the core issue that Mr. Case did in this deal: Does it make sense to buy into established industries even if it means slower growth and a lower stock price?
At times, America Online and Time Warner seemed far apart, almost to the point of parting ways. But "we kept on dribbling the ball, even when it seemed that there was no air in it," observed Kenneth Novack, America Online's chief negotiator on the deal.
Eventually, the executive teams of both companies decided that heading as one into uncharted territory was a gamble worth taking.
"If they are right," said James L. Barksdale, an America Online board member, "this could be an awesome company, and one that delivers long-term value for shareholders."
If they are right.
Mr. Case took the first step in October with a telephone call to Mr. Levin. The two men had spent time together the previous month at executive gatherings -- first the Global Business Dialogue on E-Commerce in Paris and then the Fortune Global Forum in Shanghai, sponsored by Time Warner.
What made Mr. Levin most interesting to Mr. Case was the strategic research that the senior management team had been conducting at America Online's headquarters in Dulles, Va.
With their company's stock price rising sharply last year, the America Online management team looked anew at the possibilities for those increasingly valuable shares -- a currency for forging alliances and making acquisitions.
According to one team member, they focused on three types of companies: cable television or telephone companies that might give America Online assured access to powerful, high-speed communications networks; Internet companies they might acquire; and media concerns that they might team up with or buy outright.
Time Warner loomed in two of those fields, as a huge media company and as the nation's second-largest cable network operator. And Mr. Case got along well with Mr. Levin in Paris and Shanghai. So he called Mr. Levin to describe a future in which the media and Internet seem increasingly likely to converge -- as the personal computer, the television and the telephone become parallel digital pathways to new types of information and entertainment services.
"My motivation is to position this company to capitalize on the era of convergence," Mr. Case explained in an interview. "Time Warner has powerful media brands, and I think people underestimate the power of established media brands and the customer relationships that those brands represent."
Mr. Case called Mr. Levin in October not simply to spin visions, but also to float a specific proposal. He said he was thinking of a 50-50 "merger of equals" in which Mr. Levin would be the chief executive officer, running the company, and Mr. Case would be chairman. Intrigued, Mr. Levin suggested that the two meet soon.
On Nov. 1, they dined at the Rihga Royal Hotel in Manhattan in a private room, "so no one would see us," Mr. Levin recalled. As they sat down, Mr. Levin told Mr. Case he did not want to discuss the subject of price just yet, but instead wanted to focus on what he called the "social issues" -- whether the two shared similar perspectives on management and whether Mr. Case understood the need to avoid allowing business considerations crimp the independence of Time Warner's thousands of magazine and broadcast journalists.
Both men came away from that dinner satisfied that they should take things to the next level. And so a pair of skilled corporate sherpas -- one representing each side -- started gearing up for the climb to the summit.
For America Online, the key negotiator was Mr. Novack, the 58-year-old vice chairman, a Boston lawyer who for years has been a trusted elder adviser to Mr. Case, who is 41. On major matters, as one senior manager put it, "Ken Novack is the last guy Steve talks to before he pulls the trigger."
Time Warner's chief negotiator was Richard J. Bressler, 42, who joined the company in 1988 from Ernst & Young, where he had become one of the youngest partners in the history of the accounting and management consulting firm. He quickly rose up the ranks to become chief financial officer and, last summer, chairman of Time Warner Digital Media -- a priority for Mr. Levin, 60, who in a recent company memo described Mr. Bressler's mandate as the "digital makeover of all Time Warner."
At noon on Nov. 16, Mr. Novack and a colleague, Miles Gilburne, met with Mr. Bressler in his 28th-floor Rockefeller Center office, a view of ice-skaters in the rink below. They wanted to explore what new services might be feasible if the two companies merged.
They discussed how people receive information and entertainment, or "content," today (through magazines, television and Internet-connected PC's) and how they might receive it in a couple of years (digital cell phones, wireless hand-held devices).
Mr. Gilburne, a senior strategist at America Online, usually explains his ideas while scribbling on a huge whiteboard at his office in Virginia. Because Mr. Bressler's office had no such amenity, Mr. Gilburne asked for an easel with a large pad of paper attached. Soon sheets of Mr. Gilburne's diagrams and notes covered Mr. Bressler's gray walls.
When the three-hour meeting ended, Mr. Bressler recalled, "We walked out of there really juiced about what we could do."
But even as the business logic of a merger looked more and more appealing, the pricing issue was becoming increasingly difficult. That became apparent the next morning, Nov. 17, when Mr. Case and Mr. Levin met for breakfast at the St. Regis Hotel in Manhattan.
America Online's stock had been rising steeply. For Mr. Case, that made his original notion of a 50-50 ownership deal no longer practical. The currency of the deal, after all, was America Online stock. "I was prepared to pay a premium," Mr. Case recalled, "but there was only so far I could go."
By then, according to people close to the talks, Mr. Case was pushing for 60 percent to 65 percent ownership of the combined company. Although the two men decline to disclose what ownership percentages were discussed over breakfast, Mr. Levin recalled: "It was clear that we weren't together. I said, 'I don't see how we're going to bridge that gap.' "
Hoping to narrow the gap, the two sides held a pair of meetings in December, one in New York, the other in Boston, accompanied by senior investment bankers: Eduardo Mestre, a vice chairman of Salomon Smith Barney, representing America Online, and Paul Taubman, a managing director at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, who helped advise Viacom on its merger with CBS, representing Time Warner.
The parties agreed that the companies would have the same number of directors on the board. But the ownership ratio remained the big question.
Over the holidays, Mr. Levin and Mr. Bressler talked frequently by phone. Mr. Levin had decided the options were a merger with America Online or a primarily go-it-alone digital strategy for Time Warner.
"I had essentially eliminated in my mind any other merger," Mr. Levin recalled.
Returning from his New Year's holiday in Vermont, Mr. Levin instructed Mr. Bressler to call America Online and set up a meeting with Mr. Case. A dinner was arranged for the following evening at Mr. Case's house in McLean, Va.
On Jan. 6, Mr. Levin and Mr. Bressler, who had flown down from New York on a Time Warner corporate jet, arrived at Mr. Case's house at 6:30 p.m. Mr. Levin noticed that two decorative Christmas reindeer on Mr. Case's lawn had fallen down. Perhaps an omen, Mr. Levin recalled thinking, that "we weren't going to do this deal."
Over wine in the living room, the four men talked about their companies, but other things as well, including sports and Time Warner's HBO hit series "The Sopranos," which Mr. Novack sheepishly confessed he had not seen. The discussion in the living room lasted "about a bottle and a half," or 90 minutes, before they began dinner, Mr. Novack recalled.
Finally, Mr. Levin steered the conversation to the one issue not yet discussed: ownership. He revealed that he was willing to settle for 45 percent ownership of the merged company for Time Warner shareholders. That would mean 1.5 shares in AOL Time Warner, as the merged company would be named, for each share of Time Warner stock -- but not a fraction less.
Mr. Case, who had long been pushing for a 60-40 split, called for a bottle of 1990 Chateau Leoville-Las-Cases from the wine cellar. The deal, in essence, was done.
Still, there was "no clinking of glasses or high fives," Mr. Novack recalled. When the chocolate mousse was cleared at midnight, both sides agreed to go off and sleep on their decision.
Back in New York the following morning, Mr. Levin said, "I got up and felt comfortable that it was the right thing to do."
He asked Mr. Bressler to call America Online. At 9:15 a.m., Mr. Bressler called Mr. Novack. "Is there anything that has changed since we talked last night?" Mr. Bressler asked.
"No," Mr. Novack replied. "Nothing at all."

HEADLINE: Custody Case Is Overshadowing Shift Among Cuban Immigrants

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN

DATELINE: MIAMI, Jan. 15

 BODY:
Wiry, wearing a red St. Louis Cardinals baseball cap, Carlos Rodriguez, 18, speaks in the vernacular of American youth. Just finishing high school, Mr. Rodriguez has lived in Miami for the 10 years since he and his parents fled Cuba, where he said his father was a political prisoner.
At lunch in the heart of Little Havana this week, Mr. Rodriguez was speaking about the one subject that has held Miami and some of the nation spellbound this month: the political custody fight over the 6-year-old Cuban boy Elian Gonzalez. Mr. Rodriguez acknowledged that he shared the contempt for Fidel Castro that many Cuban-Americans here feel. But he did not share the view that Elian, whose mother drowned fleeing Cuba with him in November, should be given to the relatives who are holding him here. 
 The strident Miami voices -- the P. T. Barnums of media manipulation, the high-powered lawyers, the organizers of demonstrations -- have been filling the nation's airwaves and front pages, celebrating what they see as the martyrdom of a mother for her child's freedom.
But tune out the racket and what emerges from the feud over Elian is a split over American trade and immigration policies; fatigue with both the old guard's myths of the pre-revolutionary Cuba and its plots to rout Mr. Castro.
Mr. Rodriguez is among those who have adopted a mellower view. Like most Cuban-Americans, he has relatives in Cuba who want to emigrate. "I have a sister waiting to come over," he said. If Elian is not returned to his father, who remains in Cuba, President Castro might retaliate by prohibiting the legal emigration of the 20,000 Cubans whom the United States agrees to admit each year. "I'd rather sacrifice one boy for 1,000 people," Mr. Rodriguez said.
Others agree, if for different reasons. Small dissident groups have formed to challenge the Cuban American National Foundation, which has long been controlled by hard-line exiles of a generation ago. Two groups, Cambio Cubano and the Cuban Committee for Democracy, would scrap the punitive measures against Cuba, like the longstanding United States embargo, and move toward normal diplomatic relations.
But in interviews this week across the city, Miami's 700,000 Cuban-Americans seem to remain united in opposition to Mr. Castro. A poll by WLTV-Channel 23 here found that 88 percent of Cuban-Americans also oppose the Immigration and Naturalization Service's ruling this month that Elian be returned to his father, Juan Miguel Gonzalez.
For the larger Cuban-American community here, most differences with the old guard lie more in emphasis and priorities than in the substance of policy. "It's not so much a difference of opinion as a difference in agenda," said Lisandro Perez, director of the Cuba Research Institute at Florida International University.
Max Castro, a sociologist at the University of Miami, said: "These are people who do not participate in hard-line political organizations. They have been able to transcend the hard-line groups. They have overcome the hyperhatred of Castro; not that they support Castro."
The softer views do not align neatly along the class and generational fault lines that mark the assimilation of many other immigrant groups. Much of Little Havana, though mixed today with other Latino immigrant groups, remains emphatically Cuban. Cigar rolling thrives, third-generation children speak Spanish at home, quinceaneras -- 15-year-old girls -- still mark their transition to adulthood in lacy white dresses at big parties.
Nowhere is the contrast between the threats and official pronouncements and the daily life of Little Havana starker than at the white stucco matchbox of a house where Elian has settled with his great-uncle, Lazaro Gonzalez, who has petitioned the court for his custody.
All day Thursday, as every day, television networks' big white vans muscle against the house's chain-link fence with satellite antennas on their roofs and 20-foot microphone booms hovering over the small yard. Just home from school, Elian rolled out from the backyard, chewing blue gum, wearing a new wristwatch and driving a new battery-powered toy stock car.
Four men -- Mr. Gonzalez and relatives -- seated themselves on metal kitchen chairs at one side of the yard. Around and around Elian drove, , neither sad nor happy, tracing the same loop. He did not nod or wave to the relatives keeping an eye on him, and though occasionally he is playful with the media, he was not on this day.
The house in Little Havana has become a sanctuary of anti-Castro sentiment, where a few women stand vigil at the fence every day to defend the interests of Elian's mother.
"He should stay," one woman said. "This was the decision of his mother. He loved his mother."
"His mother died in the sea," said Marta Santana, who immigrated here 40 years ago. "He's living. She sacrificed herself to come."
Beyond the house, however, views are more diverse.
"I think it's all a political thing," said Mike Freire, 45, who came to Miami at age 6 and sells cigars made in the Dominican Republic throughout the United States. "They're just using the kid as a basketball." He wants the child returned to Cuba.
"My concern is the psychological effect," Mr. Freire said. "It's horrible, what we are doing to him. The politicians are wrong." This is not a view that Mr. Freire is comfortable expressing. "You have to watch what you say. You might be accused of being a communist."
Elizabeth Rojas, 36, who works for an advertising agency and has three daughters, age 11, 10 and 4, clings to her Cuban culture, requiring Spanish spoken at home and preparing Cuban cuisine.
In many ways, Ms. Rojas, whose parents fled Cuba in 1958 and whose husband is a police officer, is a hard-liner. She would keep Elian here and topple Mr. Castro. But she draws the line on the American embargo against trade with Cuba because, she said, it has worsened the lives of Cubans. "A lot of people are starving," she said.
Efrain Quevedo, 37, a sales manager for a food company, and his wife, Terry, an investigator for the City of Miami, take issue with the Cuban-American leadership's efforts to steer American policy toward ending the Castro regime. "Unless the people there do something," Mr. Quevedo said, "I don't think the United States is going to be able to do anything."
Ms. Quevedo takes issue with demonstrations that disrupt the lives of others, like the traffic-stopping protests last week in Miami against Elian's repatriation. "It's all right as long as it's peaceful," she said.
But the prevailing concern for newer immigrants of the 1980's and 1990's is not so much Mr. Castro and communism as economic opportunity. "For me, Castro is nothing," said Luis Fernandez, a manager of the Versailles Restaurant in Little Havana.
Managing restaurants "is my profession," he said. He left Cuba for Chile four years ago and moved to Miami only two months ago. "Here, when you work more hours, you get paid for more hours." Someday, he said, he will start a business. "I've promised myself that if the government changes, I'd still never go back. This is my thing."

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN;
DECISIVE ROLE SEEN FOR BLACK VOTERS IN LATER CONTESTS

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Jan. 15

 BODY:
When the Democratic presidential candidates finally withdraw from Iowa and New Hampshire, where the electorate is predominantly white, they will move quickly into Southern states where black voters often play a decisive role.
And at the moment, at least, Vice President Al Gore seems to enjoy a commanding advantage with African-American voters, despite former Senator Bill Bradley's passionate commitment to the cause of improving race relations.
Public opinion polls, lists of endorsements and interviews with dozens of Democratic strategists and black political leaders all suggest that Mr. Gore holds a distinct early lead over Mr. Bradley among black voters in states like Florida, Georgia, Louisiana, Mississippi, South Carolina, Tennessee and Texas. 
 Those states all vote in the first two weeks of March, shortly after the Iowa caucuses on Jan. 24 and the New Hampshire primary on Feb. 1. And in each of those places, political history suggests that black voters could make up a significant share of the electorate, particularly in states where competitive Republican primaries may drain white voters from the Democratic contests.
Mr. Gore, who will deliver remarks at the annual Martin Luther King Jr. holiday commemoration at the Ebenezer Baptist Church here on Monday, is counting on black voters in the South to provide a firewall of protection against the possibility of an early loss in New Hampshire, where some recent polls show Mr. Bradley with a narrow lead.
Black voters will also be important in the New York primary on March 7 and, to a somewhat lesser extent, in the California voting the same day. Those two primaries award the most Democratic delegates, and Mr. Bradley may prove more competitive with black voters in those states, where he is better known and will have an enormous incentive to spend time and resources, Democratic strategists say.
Both Democratic candidates have strong -- and largely similar -- positions on issues that tend to appeal to black voters, whether generic concerns like education, health care, crime and economic growth, or narrower topics like affirmative action and racial profiling. And both use deeply personal anecdotes to connect with black voters, with Mr. Bradley describing the discrimination he witnessed against black teammates with the New York Knicks and with Mr. Gore recalling how his father took him to see slave rings in the basement of a mansion in their Tennessee town.
If anything, Mr. Bradley has been more direct than Mr. Gore in using his candidacy to call for a war on poverty, which disproportionately afflicts black Americans, and to appeal for racial harmony.
"If I'm president, I want one thing to be known," Mr. Bradley said in a poignant speech about race delivered in New York last April. "If you want to please the boss, one of the things you'd better show is how in your department or agency you've furthered tolerance and racial understanding."
But in the pursuit of black votes, Mr. Gore holds a card that seems to trump Mr. Bradley's oratorical outreach: the vice presidency. If Mr. Gore's ties to President Clinton have hurt him with some voters, they are an enormous asset among blacks. For seven years, Mr. Gore has played loyal lieutenant to a president who remains immensely popular with black Americans, and he has used his office to champion causes, bestow access, deliver federal aid and raise political funds for black officials across the country.
Those leaders are now rewarding Mr. Gore's efforts, often emphasizing that they hold nothing against Mr. Bradley but have little reason to look beyond the vice president. In interview after interview this week, black political leaders explained their support for Mr. Gore by citing the Clinton administration's appointment of black officials, its economic successes and its support for cities and affirmative action. A CBS News poll taken last month showed that 88 percent of African-Americans approved of Mr. Clinton, compared with 51 percent of whites.
"Look, Bill Bradley is a fine fellow and he has a good record," said Bill Campbell, the two-term mayor of Atlanta, who is black and a longtime backer of Mr. Gore. "But I don't understand how anyone would imagine that black voters would desert a vice president who has been so remarkably supportive of the African-American community. When a constituency is appreciated and respected and assisted on critical issues, that ought to count for something, and it does."
Representative John Lewis of Georgia, a black Democrat who supports Mr. Gore, echoed Mr. Campbell's remarks. "There's a loyalty to Gore that Senator Bradley cannot shake," Mr. Lewis said. "It's just impossible. There's a hold there and he cannot pull it away."
Mr. Lewis and Mr. Campbell are far from alone. Mr. Gore has been endorsed by 29 of the 38 black Democrats in Congress, while Mr. Bradley has yet to be endorsed by any. In addition to Mr. Campbell, Mr. Gore has the backing of the black mayors of Cleveland; Houston; Jackson, Miss.; Macon, Ga.; Memphis; Minneapolis; Newark; New Orleans; Savannah, Ga.; St. Louis, and Washington, as well as of a number of influential black state legislators.
Because presidential primaries typically draw a low turnout, and are usually dominated by party activists, such endorsements can be critical if elected officials mobilize their political machinery on behalf of a candidate. Some Gore organizers in the South, and even some unaligned party leaders, predict that blacks could make up 35 percent to 40 percent of the Democratic primary electorate in states like Georgia, Louisiana, Mississippi and South Carolina. Mr. Gore, himself a Southerner, should win the overwhelming majority of those votes, they say.
"I'd say if the election were held today, clearly Gore would get 80 percent" of the black vote in Louisiana, said Ben Jeffers, an African-American who is that state's Democratic chairman.
In 1992, Bill Clinton captured huge majorities of the black vote in Democratic primaries in key states, winning at least 70 percent in Alabama, Florida, Georgia, Illinois, Louisiana, Mississippi, North Carolina, Pennsylvania, Tennessee and Texas, according to surveys of voters leaving the polls.
"That was key in terms of Clinton's strategy, and it's one of the reasons why I really don't think, unless Gore has some kind of meltdown, that Bill Bradley has any chance of beating Al Gore," said David A. Bositis, an expert on black voting trends with the Joint Center for Political and Economic Studies. Three recent national polls all showed that blacks favored Mr. Gore over Mr. Bradley by margins of between two and three to one.
Mr. Bradley's list of notable African-American supporters features only a smattering of local elected officials, including three state assemblymen from New York City and the minority leader of the Ohio State Senate. The most prominent names belong to Mr. Bradley's former colleagues in the National Basketball Association, like Julius Erving and Willis Reed, and entertainment figures like the film director Spike Lee and the actor Lawrence Fishburne, and academics like Prof. Cornel West of Harvard and the historian Roger Wilkins of George Mason University, who is misidentified in a Bradley campaign release as a law professor at George Washington University. They are men with fans, but not with political organizations.
The Bradley campaign has made it transparent that its insurgent strategy depends on breakthrough victories in northeastern states like New Hampshire and New York that aides believe will catapult him with tornadic velocity into a newly reordered political universe. Under those circumstances, the campaign reasons, black voters, like all voters, will be compelled to give Mr. Bradley a fresh look. Bradley aides acknowledge that the task will not be easy, and that they will have little time to gain traction.
"The black community votes in such a unified fashion that it has become a tradition that we stick together," said Jacques A. DeGraff, a black Baptist minister who serves as senior adviser to the Bradley campaign. "Traditionally, we deliver 80 percent to the candidates we get behind. So it takes a great deal of activity to begin the shift. At first it will be imperceptible. Then it will be a trickle. And then I believe it will be a flood."
Similarly, Sheriff Nat Glover of Duval County, Fla., a black Bradley supporter, said that Mr. Bradley would be able to sell himself to black voters once he had a chance to make contact. Mr. Glover, who only met Mr. Bradley four months ago, said he was impressed at how Mr. Bradley's experience as a teammate and roommate of black basketball players seemed to have shaped his racial sensibilities.
But Mr. Glover also said he knew of no other black elected officials in Florida who were supporting Mr. Bradley. "I've been in the company of individuals who are certainly considering supporting Bill," said Mr. Glover, whose county includes Jacksonville. "I haven't noticed a ground swell, but I have noticed quite a bit of interest."
As the race has tightened, Mr. Gore has found countless ways to send messages to black voters. He campaigned in November at the Memphis church where Dr. King spoke the night before he was killed. Last month, he staged an "African-Americans for Gore" rally in Atlanta, declaring that "anyone who says affirmative action is no longer needed because we've reached the promised land has confused wilderness with Canaan." He regularly recalls the civil rights legacy of his father, Senator Al Gore Sr., while neglecting to mention that the elder Gore voted against the Civil Rights Act of 1964, a year when he faced re-election in Tennessee.
The vice president hired a black woman, Donna Brazile, as his campaign manager, and when Ms. Brazile suggested in a recent interview that the Republican Party used black partisans like Gen. Colin Powell and Representative J. C. Watts Jr. of Oklahoma as window dressing, Mr. Gore soothed Mr. Powell with a phone call. But he was careful to neither criticize his aide nor dispute her point.
Ron Lester, a Democratic pollster who is not working for either candidate, said polls he had conducted in Chicago, Miami, Atlanta and North Carolina showed that Mr. Bradley had picked up support among white Democrats but had not gained on Mr. Gore with black voters.
"In order for blacks to take a second look at Bradley, not only would he have to have momentum but he would have to blow Gore out in the early states," Mr. Lester said. "As long as Gore is standing, I don't see any compelling evidence that black voters will leave him."

HEADLINE: Sisterhood Recruits for a Next Generation

BYLINE: By LISA W. FODERARO

DATELINE: HARTSDALE, N.Y., Jan. 15

 BODY:
For young women in a culture saturated with alluring images of riches and sensuality, it is an unlikely advertising come-on. Turn your back on money and men and spend your life helping people who are sick, poor and uneducated.
It's the ultimate tough sell, but the message is: Forget Madonna. Become a nun. 
 These days the Sisters of Mercy of the Americas, one of the nation's largest orders of Roman Catholic nuns, are making the pitch with a vengeance, and they are using all the tools of the modern age: test markets, target audiences, catchy graphics and, new this month, a Web site. One recruitment poster that was sent this week to college campuses shows a close-up of God's hand reaching out to Adam's from Michelangelo's "Creation of Adam." Adam is holding a cellular phone, and the text reads: "Do you have a call waiting?"
The nuns have no choice. For more than three decades the number of Catholic nuns in the United States has fallen, to about 83,000 last year from about 180,000 in 1965. Compounding the decline is the aging of their population; the median age of American nuns is 68. The result has been a draining of resources from the many charities and institutions the nuns helped create.
"It is a personnel crisis," said Scott Appleby, director of the Cushwa Center for the Study of American Catholicism at the University of Notre Dame. "Sisters really did build the American Catholic Church through their teaching in the parochial school system and their staffing of Catholic hospitals. They have been the backbone of the church in this century, and it's absolutely critical to address the question of the next generation and who will succeed them."
In the recruitment campaign, the New York, New Jersey and Brooklyn chapters, or communities, of the Sisters of Mercy teamed up to create the posters and brochures, which are aimed at women 21 to 35. "If you appear old and nonvibrant, that becomes an obstacle to anyone wanting to enter religious life," said Sister Patricia Wolf, president of the New York community, adding that the images showed a "connection to the world and also to humor."
Scholars and the nuns themselves point to a number of factors responsible for the dwindling population of nuns, a decline far more precipitous than the corresponding drop in the number of Roman Catholic priests.
The women's movement and cultural revolution of the 1960's opened up a world of new opportunities for women, from careers in law to stints in the Peace Corps. Moreover, where it was not uncommon in the 1950's and 1960's for Catholic women to join the ranks of nuns if they were not yet engaged to be married by their college graduation, in the 1970's and beyond it became more acceptable for women to marry later in life. And given the booming economy of recent years and a return to family values, taking vows of poverty and chastity is, in some sense, a countercultural, even radical, move.
As laypeople steadily replace nuns on the staffs of Catholic schools and social service agencies, young women are losing their exposure to nuns and the more modern ways in which they live today -- wearing street clothes, often residing in apartments and holding down demanding jobs.
"The conundrum," said Professor Appleby, "is that as the number of sisters falls and the ones who remain are drawn into leadership positions, there is less opportunity for that personal contact that was so effective earlier in the century."
Other religious orders now are trying to turn the tide by injecting some of that face-to-face contact. The Religious of the Sacred Heart of Mary, an order with 1,100 members worldwide, is taking advantage of its Hamptons real estate by holding "Come and See" weekends several times a year at its retreat house in Sag Harbor in eastern Long Island.
"It's a chance to come and get to know us in an informal setting," said Sister Mary Alice Young, director of development for the order on the East Coast, based in Tarrytown, N.Y. "The sisters talk about their own experience, and people can ask questions without being embarrassed."
Like the Sisters of Mercy, the Religious of the Sacred Heart of Mary last year created a Web site, and for the last two years the community has run advertisements in Catholic newspapers. "One of the things you're constantly hearing is that the baby boomers and generation X are totally separate entities, and you have to learn to reach the generations differently," Sister Mary Alice said. "It's speaking to a whole different world than the one I grew up in."
Across the country, there are similar efforts. In Indiana, the Sisters of Benedict assembled a lay committee of professionals with experience in marketing and communications. The order now has a toll-free number, a Web site and advertising. One ad beckons with the cheeky line: "You don't have to be perfect to be a nun. God knows we're not."
And in California, the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Los Angeles has made the recruitment of nuns and priests a high priority. Later this month, the archdiocese will invite 150 to 250 people to its annual "7 to 11 Day." Starting at 7 a.m., the men and women trail the priests and nuns as they go about their day. Later they are treated to dinner with Cardinal Roger M. Mahony and a talent show. Past acts have included comedy and line dancing.
There is hope among nuns that they can tap into this millennial moment, when gift shops sell nothing but angels, and best-selling books, rock songs and television shows unabashedly deal with issues relating to religion, the soul and the afterlife.
"I think that probably more than at any recent time, there is a real quest today for spirituality," said Sister Patricia of the Sisters of Mercy. "The media gives evidence of that. You have something like 'Touched by an Angel' on television and other shows. So an attraction to religious life is perhaps even more possible than it has been at other times."
A sampling of reactions on two traditionally Catholic campuses in Westchester County, however, found that for most students, the idea of becoming a nun was just short of unthinkable. Jessica Hogan, a senior at Iona College in New Rochelle, said: "I never considered it. It seems outdated and old-fashioned."
But Mary Delia, a 29-year-old graduate student at Mercy College in Dobbs Ferry, who is from a "very strong Catholic family," and attended Catholic schools, said she had considered the profession as a girl. Ms. Delia's mother was a nun for seven years before leaving, and both her aunt and cousin are nuns. "I've grown up around nuns, so I have a different outlook than a lot of people," Ms. Delia said. "You can be part of a religious order and still be a human being."
Ultimately, she decided the religious life was not for her. The recruitment posters might help, Ms. Delia said, but she believes that the reason young women have shunned the sisterhood is the diminishing power of the Catholic Church over their lives. "The problem is young people don't stay in the church," she said. "You have to have that belief."
Becoming a nun is a lengthy affair. At the Sisters of Mercy, an international order with 5,700 members in 12 countries, first there are periodic discussions between a prospective nun and a vocation director for six months to a year. A formal application is then made to the leadership team.
If accepted, the candidate lives with other nuns for two years but retains her outside job and assets. For the next two years she is a "novice," giving up her job and pursuing spiritual development. Then, just before taking her first vows, she disposes of her assets and begins a ministry in keeping with the order's mission. Three to five years later, she takes her final vows.
"It's a long process because it's a big step," said Sister Theresa Condon, who works with new members for the Sisters of Mercy. "What we're looking for, basically, is: Are they happy, and will there be a good fit?"
The New York, New Jersey and Brooklyn regional communities of the Sisters of Mercy are also determined to increase the minority representation among their members, who are overwhelmingly white. One of the posters shows an African-American woman in prayer.
"We don't reflect as a community the ethnic background of New York City," Sister Patricia said in her spacious office on a former estate here. "Just walk around. We have a significant amount of work to do."
Sister Barbara Ann Catherine Gourdine, 40, is a relatively new -- and young -- member, having made her temporary vows two years ago. She is also African-American, one of only two in the New York community, which has 187 members. She actually joined the order at 21 but left in 1988. "In leaving it gave me a chance to grow and find out who I was as a person," she said.
She has had to adjust to living with three women in a house after years of living alone in an apartment, and she recently took a job teaching in a Catholic school after 10 years in a public school. "It's not what I expected," she said, "but I am happy."
With members from Staten Island to the Adirondacks, as well as the Worcester, Mass., area (the result of a merger), the New York community of the Sisters of Mercy is spread thin. The order sponsors two high schools, three health-care centers and three social-service agencies. There are pastoral duties and community outreach as well, but half the members are retired.
Sister Patricia frequently finds herself saying no to people who call to inquire whether a nun might be available to fill a teaching position, say, or simply to lead a retreat day. "There are days when I say, 'How can we do that?' " she said. "You would die to have someone for that."
Yet nuns resist the idea that they face extinction, and they look to their history for solace. "In some ways, you could say, 'Well, it's dying out and the last person should turn out the lights,' " Sister Mary Alice said. "But we were founded by only six sisters 150 years ago. So what you need are committed women."
And, she said, there will always be those.

Chechnya Arms Smuggling

HEADLINE: U.S. Courting India in Hope Of Restarting Trade Talks

BYLINE: By JOSEPH KAHN

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15

 BODY:
Despite nuclear tensions and diplomatic false starts that have dogged United States relations with India in recent years, the Clinton administration plans to court India as an ally in trying to restart global trade talks that collapsed in Seattle last month.
The hope is that closer cooperation might help defuse disputes between rich and poor countries that undermined the Seattle meeting. 
 Few expect the United States and India, the world's two largest democracies, to forge a close friendship overnight, but administration officials hope that coming high-level visits can send the message that the rift between developing and developed countries was confined to the chaotic Seattle meeting and did not reflect a broader breakdown in globalization.
Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers will visit India next week for talks with senior Indian leaders on a range of international economic and financial issues, including the best way to restore confidence in the World Trade Organization. Mr. Summers will also pave the way for a visit to India by President Clinton, now tentatively scheduled for March, administration officials said. It will be the first time a sitting American president has visited India since Jimmy Carter made the trip in 1979.
"After Seattle, there's definitely an economic challenge in managing the integration between industrial and developing countries," Mr. Summers said before leaving for India today. "India has had a major voice from the developing country perspective. It's natural that the two largest democracies should consider ways in which integration can be managed."
Though the administration is playing down the possibility of tangible progress during Mr. Summers's trip, officials talk privately of hopes that they are laying the groundwork for a "quantum leap" in relations, forging a third-world/first-world democratic alliance that could potentially prove warmer and more stable than American ties with China and Russia.
Ideally, these officials say, diplomats from the two sides would jointly find ways to move globalization forward, a strategic dialogue that would go beyond the often testy bilateral talks on regional stability and nuclear proliferation in South Asia.
"We feel that if we can find a meeting of the minds with Delhi, that's a strong place to work the third world," an administration official said.
India, though also eager for better ties with the United States, seems less optimistic about a breakthrough in the short term. Some Indian officials are still smarting from what they characterized as American pressure tactics at the Seattle talks.
"Both sides agree that the time is ripe to create a more positive atmosphere," said Naresh Chandra, India's ambassador in Washington. "But I think the U.S. will find that things move much faster when we're not pushed."
The difficulty of working out a new relationship with India was on full display in Seattle. Apparently convinced that India might back the United States trade agenda and help break an impasse with other third world countries, the administration put on a full-court press.
Mr. Clinton, who visited the World Trade Organization negotiating session to give a lift to the talks, seated himself next to Murasoli Maran, India's commerce minister, at a business lunch. Mr. Clinton also phoned Prime Minister Atal Behari Vajpayee during the negotiations, and Mr. Summers cajoled his Indian counterpart.
In the end, India stood four-square against the American negotiating position, deeply disappointing some American officials. India was among the developing countries that cried foul when the administration pushed hard to link new trade talks with labor rights, a position many developing countries viewed as a disguised effort to protect workers in wealthy countries from competition.

HEADLINE: Push for Powerball: High Odds, but Don't Count It Out

BYLINE: By WINNIE HU

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 15

 BODY:
Would anyone turn down a lottery jackpot worth $124 million a year? Certainly not all those frenzied New Yorkers who flock to Connecticut for a shot at a bank-busting payout from the Powerball lottery.
And not Governor George E. Pataki either, even though by most accounts, he is not a betting man himself. 
 Mr. Pataki, a Republican, lobbied again this week to bring Powerball to New York even though a similar effort last year failed to win support in either the Republican Senate or the Democratic-led Assembly. His proposed budget counts on $124 million in revenue from ticket sales in a multistate lottery game that would, at least on paper, support education initiatives.
But so far, the Legislature has resisted buying into multistate lotteries, putting New York at odds with its neighbors, Connecticut and New Jersey, and a growing number of places across the country where sky-high jackpots generate revenue for everything from new schools to highways. Indeed, in recent years, lawmakers have repeatedly rebuffed Mr. Pataki's overtures to expand gambling in the state.
Mr. Pataki's proposal for a multistate lottery is part of a running budgetary numbers game in the back rooms of the Capitol, where lawmakers hold out for their pet programs and then shuffle around millions -- even billions -- of dollars to pay for everything. During the 1995 budget crisis, for instance, Mr. Pataki won approval for a Quick Draw lottery game from reluctant legislators with the promise of new revenue. In the last four years, Quick Draw, a keno-style game that is played on video monitors in bars and delis, has generated more than $470 million for the state.
But last year, the law creating Quick Draw got caught up in a budget battle and expired on March 31. Although lawmakers eventually resurrected it, they passed on his request to expand Quick Draw into more bars and delis. And in 1997, they turned down a constitutional amendment that Mr. Pataki backed to allow casino gambling in the state.
Mr. Pataki's odds at getting Powerball this year may not have improved much as a resilient economy pumps dollars into the state's coffers and lawmakers are loath to alienate the powerful base of conservative and religious voters fiercely opposed to gambling.
Still, no one is counting Mr. Pataki out just yet.
A multistate lottery would provide an influx of new money for education programs, which are the cornerstone of the governor's proposed budget and potentially the most divisive issue between Republicans and Democrats this year.
"I'm not going to discount anything," declared the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, the powerful Republican from the Albany area, when asked whether he would support the governor's proposal.
Although New York has the highest lottery sales in the nation, those sales have flagged in recent years, in large part because of fierce competition from multistate lotteries and casinos. For example, tickets sales for the 34-year-old New York lottery declined 7.5 percent to $3.69 billion in the 1999 fiscal year from $3.99 billion in 1997.
Every year, countless New Yorkers jettison state loyalty and take their dollars to Connecticut in search of $1 Powerball tickets. Powerball, which is sponsored by 20 states and the District of Columbia, has become wildly popular since it began eight years ago, and its huge jackpots can make a million-dollar payoff seems downright paltry. The Powerball jackpot starts at $10 million and climbed as high as $296 million in August 1998.
But critics say the high stakes are addictive and cause people to waste money on something they have little chance of winning. "People have only so much money," said Senator Frank Padavan, a Republican from Queens who opposes expansion of the lottery. "When people gamble, they're not spending their money on goods and services which create jobs and income for the local government."
Just what are the odds of hitting the Powerball jackpot, anyway? Try 1 in 80 million (compared with, say, 1 in 18 million for the New York State Lottery). George Wandrak, who oversees lottery operations in Connecticut, said the long odds don't drive away the players -- in fact, quite the opposite. His state added Powerball in 1995 after years of waning lottery ticket sales. Last year, Powerball tickets raked in $124.5 million in sales in Connecticut, or 14.3 percent of the state's total revenue from gambling, including casinos and dog tracks.
"As with any product, there are choices -- you have Coke, classic Coke, diet Coke, caffeine-free Coke, caffeine-free diet Coke," Mr. Wandrak said. "The lottery gets a bit stale, so we try to freshen up the game and give them what they want -- higher jackpots."
Connecticut has sold three winning tickets in the Powerball jackpot -- including the $10.3 million windfall that went to Sergio and Elena Martini, of Brewster, N.Y., in January 1997. Mr. Wandrak estimated that 10 to 15 percent of his state's Powerball tickets are bought by New Yorkers and other out-of-staters.
Since multistate lotteries were introduced in the mid-1980's, state officials have come to depend on the high-profile games to plug holes in their budgets. They typically share operating and advertising costs for the lottery, and then keep a part of the proceeds from ticket sales. In Powerball, for instance, the state keeps half and the rest goes back for prizes.
Thirty-one states currently take part in one of three multistate lotteries, said David Gale, executive director of the North American Association of State and Provincial Lotteries. Last year, these games helped propel ticket sales for all lotteries nationwide to a record $36.5 billion.
New Jersey, for instance, joined its first multistate lottery in May after a slump in its Pick 6 Lotto sales. Since then, lottery players have spent more than $126 million for a crack at the Big Game, which is also sponsored by Michigan, Maryland, Massachusetts, Virginia, Illinois and Georgia.
Powerball remains the undisputed king of lotteries with average ticket sales of $1.2 billion a year, said Charles Strutt, executive director of the Multi-State Lottery Association, which oversees the game for the sponsoring states. Mr. Strutt predicted that New York, with its 18 million residents, would fatten the jackpots even more.
"That would be very good for the game," said Mr. Strutt, who has already been in touch with New York lottery officials. "It would increase sales in every state."
But no bets yet, please. Almost as soon as Mr. Pataki revived his proposal for the multistate lottery last week, his opponents were loudly protesting what they described as a major expansion of gambling.
Thomas Grey, a United Methodist minister and executive director of the National Coalition Against Gambling Expansion, said he was surprised and disappointed that Governor Pataki had again raised the issue.
"In good economic times, with no one clamoring for it, this seems to go against what other politicians are doing," he said. "In an election year, to vote to expand gambling will only cost you voters."
And Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, the influential Democrat from Lower Manhattan, could barely wait to express his disapproval.
"I'm once again troubled by the re-emergence of the Powerball lottery," he said at a news conference in the Capitol building after the governor unveiled his budget.
Even Senator Bruno, Mr. Pataki's staunchest ally in the Legislature, said that he was not optimistic about its chances.
Without endorsing the governor's proposal, Mr. Bruno pointed out only that another source of money would have to be found if the multistate lottery were scratched.
"You either cut something or do something to replace the revenue," he said.
But other lawmakers were not swayed by that argument.
"That's always a straw man," Senator Padavan said. "We're talking about a $77 billion budget -- this amount is infinitesimal."

HEADLINE: F.A.A. Reviews Differing Rules for Business Aviation

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15

 BODY:
The runway is 4,300 feet long, and the pilot's manual says the corporate jet needs 4,000 feet. Can it land there?
That depends on how the plane is owned, and even federal regulators say the rules governing questions like these no longer make sense because of widespread changes in the financial arrangements that people make when they fly in business jets.
Under a decades-old rule, charter operators follow one set of guidelines, and corporate jets follow another. But a new class of owners has suddenly blossomed that does not fit either category, and that is causing an uproar in aviation safety circles. 
 Charter flights -- air taxis, in effect -- must operate under strict, airline-style rules. Charter clients are not expected to know enough to make their own decisions about runway lengths, weather or how tired a pilot might be. And the plane must be able to land without using more than 60 percent of the runway's length.
The company plane that ferries executives, on the other hand, has looser rules; the owner is supposed to know more about safety, and to take on more responsibility.
But in the last few years, 1,600 companies or individuals have bought "fractional shares" in business jets, an ownership arrangement akin to buying a week at a time-share condominium. And no one is sure what rules should apply to them.
The Federal Aviation Administration, scrambling to keep up, has set up an industry advisory panel to draft new rules by the end of the month. Agency officials are determined to change the safety rules for business jets now, and to stay on top of the new economic arrangements, before a high-profile crash forces them to act.
People in the industry say that the crash of such a plane would hurt business aviation, even planes operated as charters.
Shared operations now rival airlines, in the number of planes and pilots. Some say they adhere to airline-style rules, but they do not get airline-style oversight from the Federal Aviation Administration, and critics say that some operators, especially smaller ones, may take advantage of looser rules. Those rules include these:
*Charter and airline pilots may work 14 hours a day, including no more than 10 hours at the controls; corporate pilots have no limits.
*Charter pilots must have a weather report from the ground before they may begin an approach; corporate pilots may begin the approach, take a look and make their own judgment. Corporate pilots also have looser limits on weather acceptable for takeoffs.
*Charter operators must have a maintenance plan approved by the F.A.A., with work done by mechanics screened for drugs; corporate pilots may use any licensed mechanic.
To some, the new type of ownership has meant more flexibility in flying. Mark Fruchter, an air charter operator in Reading, Pa., had two clients who wanted to charter his Beechjet to Hilton Head, S.C., which has a 4,000-foot runway. He flies that plane there with his family, but his customers were stymied by the rule about runway length. Now they are fractional owners of an eight-passenger corporate jet offered by one of Mr. Fruchter's competitors, and make the flight routinely.
To others, the looser rules may have brought too much freedom. A fractionally owned Learjet 60, operated by Bombardier Aerospace on a flight from Dulles International Airport outside Washington, had brake trouble while landing at Hyannis, Mass., and ran off the runway, destroying the plane. No one was hurt.
The crash is still under investigation, but an F.A.A. official studying safety issues for corporate aviation pointed out that if the flight had been a charter, it would never have been allowed to land at Hyannis, because the runway is shorter than the length called for under charter rules.
To charter a plane, said Jack Olcott, the president of the National Business Aviation Association, all you need is "a credit card and a Yellow Pages." Such people should be protected from risk, Mr. Olcott said. People or corporations who own their own planes are much more sophisticated, and have earned the right to decide what is an acceptable level of safety, he added.
"Your lawyers get very deeply involved," he said. "As an owner, you're liable for that airplane even though you're not in it. Nobody goes into fractional ownership with the same degree of naivete that they book a charter flight."
But others in the industry say that people who used to charter planes but now own fractional shares to fly 100 or 200 hours a year probably know little about the details of operating the aircraft. In fact, Bombardier, which sells fractional shares under a program called Flexjet, advertises to potential customers, "Leave the details to us."
Corporate-type aviation, whether by charter or under fractional ownership, is extremely safe. No passengers have died in fractionals in seven years, and other than the Payne Stewart crash last year, no deaths have occurred on charter trips in the period.
And the web of rules about safety, financing and ownership can have perverse complications. A company bringing Mr. Stewart to Dallas said it would pay for his flight. Even though he was a fractional owner of a Learjet, he could not use it for hire -- it would then have to meet the stricter rules for charter operations. So Mr. Stewart chartered a different plane, which crashed.
The advisory group's meetings have been bitter at times, participants say, with huge financial stakes apparent to all sides. Charter operators contend that management companies for fractional owners have prospered under looser regulations. Fractional advocates say they actually operate at a high level of safety, with potential purchasers often sending in auditors to evaluate safety programs that are in many ways stricter than those used by corporate flight departments or airlines.
Some participants say that the panel is developing a hybrid rule, borrowing some sections from the rule on charters and airlines, and some from the section on private planes. Whether this will pass muster with the F.A.A. remains to be seen; some officials there have said they would be uneasy about adopting the lowest common denominator.
But all sides agree that the way the rules are finally written and put into effect will be an important test for the industry and the regulators, who often find themselves racing to catch up with new economic models for aviation that have an unexpected impact on safety.
