HEADLINE: MAN IN THE NEWS: Ricardo Lagos Escobar;
A Chilean Socialist in the Clinton-Blair Mold

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS 

DATELINE: SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 17

 BODY:
As President-elect Ricardo Lagos Escobar mounted the stage on Sunday night to celebrate his victory with a throng of his supporters, Socialists in the crowd chanted a leftist slogan that was a favorite when Salvador Allende wore the presidential sash back in the early 1970's: "The people united will never be defeated!"
At another point in the festivities, the crowd called on Mr. Lagos to bring Gen. Augusto Pinochet to justice after his expected eventual return to Chile from Britain, where he has been under house arrest on human rights charges for 15 months. 
 But after the 61-year-old economist and lawyer acknowledged the presence of Dr. Allende's widow, he delivered a carefully crafted message that struck more moderate chords than at least some in the crowd had come to hear. It was the speech of a veteran politician whose politics have long been more moderate than those of his fellow Chilean Socialists.
On the subject of the former dictator, Mr. Lagos interrupted the crowd's chants by promising to let any future prosecution of General Pinochet run its course in the courts without his interference. He warmly complimented his adversary, Joaquin Lavin, a former aide to General Pinochet. And he promised to forge a government that is tolerant and respects the human rights of all.
"This is not a defeat for anyone," Mr. Lagos said. "I will be the president of all Chileans. I want to resolve the pains that still remain from the century that just ended."
Mr. Lagos will be inaugurated in March as the first Socialist president of Chile since Dr. Allende was overthrown in the violent coup in 1973 led by General Pinochet and backed by the United States. His presidency will almost certainly be very different from Dr. Allende's.
In part that is because he will be governing in a coalition with the more conservative Christian Democratic Party; Dr. Allende's coalition included the Communist Party. But Mr. Lagos has long been a Western European-style social democrat, even through the 1970's and 1980's when other leaders of his party embraced Marxism and the Cuban revolution.
To some extent his moderation is grounded in the Keynesian lessons he learned while earning a doctorate in economics from Duke University in the 1960's. But it is also seems to be a product of his sober personality and what his friends characterize as a distaste for impulsiveness.
Mr. Lagos was born to a middle-class family on March 2, 1938. His father, a small landowner, died when Mr. Lagos was 8. His mother, Emma Escobar y Froilan Lagos, a retired teacher, cast a vote for her son on Sunday -- at the age of 103.
Before going to the United States for graduate studies in economics, he earned a law degree at the University of Chile. He is a weekend gardener, an avid reader of histories and loves Brahms and Mozart. Unlike so many Chileans, he does not smoke. But he does like to take a siesta whenever possible.
Since 1971 he has been married to Luisa Duran de la Fuente, with whom he has a daughter. He also has two children from an earlier marriage.
He plays tennis and does light rock-climbing for exercise, but his ample waistline suggests that he is not a fanatic of either. And when he talks of politics, compromise and consensus appear to be uppermost on his mind.
"What is our goal now?" Mr. Lagos asked rhetorically during an interview on the campaign trail last year. "Without affecting investment, savings and growth, we need to produce a society a little more just with less of a gap in the inequality of opportunity."
During the Allende years, Mr. Lagos served as secretary general of the University of Chile and was Dr. Allende's choice to be ambassador to Moscow at the time of the coup. But after the coup, when many top Chilean Socialist leaders went to East Germany, he chose exile in the United States and was a visiting professor at the University of North Carolina in 1973-75.
He said he enjoyed his time in Chapel Hill, although he added with a smile, "I had real problems when North Carolina played basketball with Duke."
From 1976 to 1984 he worked as an economist for United Nations agencies, but then devoted himself increasingly to opposition politics.
Mr. Lagos spent only 20 days in General Pinochet's jails, in 1986 during a crackdown after an assassination attempt, but he played a key role in the 1988 plebiscite campaign that led to General Pinochet's defeat.
In a television interview that year, Mr. Lagos had the gumption to point his finger at the camera -- as if to point directly at the dictator -- and told him that the country had had enough of his repression, torture and executions.
It was that brave moment of defiance that made him the leader of Chile's Socialists and a future presidential candidate.
In 1990 a Christian Democratic-Socialist coalition took power, and during the next eight years Mr. Lagos served as education minister and then public works minister, positions in which he sought not only to help the disadvantaged but also to improve his relations with the business community and the military.
He expanded the influence of military academies by permitting them to grant master's degrees to civilians. And he made sure to complete General Pinochet's pet public works project, a highway connecting Tierra del Fuego and the lake-dotted Patagonia region.
During the recent presidential campaign, he and Mr. Lavin studiously avoided mentions of either Dr. Allende or General Pinochet as both focused on the future.
Mr. Lagos promised to create 300,000 jobs and bring modern health care to the poor, but he also made a concerted effort to calm the concerns of domestic and foreign investors. He sought out George Soros and David Rockefeller to appear with him in photographs published in the Chilean press and told a conference of local business leaders that he would work hard to keep the budget deficit in check and interest rates and inflation low.
"I know the limits of the possible," he told business executives last November, "and I know my responsibility to be a leader who orients the public responsibly."
The speech was meant to reassure the private sector that he would continue the current administration's economic policies and not encourage workers to strike, as President Allende's government had done.
Mr. Lagos's moderation through the campaign frustrated leftists in his own party and particularly angered Communist Party leaders who were allies of the Socialists during the Allende era.
But his moderation was mirrored by Mr. Lavin, who called for cuts in military spending and said he would not stand in the way of a future trial of General Pinochet if he was not extradited to stand trial in Spain.
"Lagos is close to the third way of Blair and Clinton," said Ricardo Israel, a political scientist at the University of Chile. "As president, you'll hear a lot about an ethical foreign policy, but you'll probably see more privatizations than you did under the two Christian Democratic presidents. And he'll be very careful with the army."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Brazil's Economy Is Better, But Is the Recovery Lasting?

BYLINE: By SIMON ROMERO 

DATELINE: SAO PAULO, Brazil, Jan. 17

 BODY:
A year after Brazil's currency crisis took damaging hold, Belarmino Iglesias is toasting his good fortune. Business has rarely been better at his steakhouse, Baby Beef Rubaiyat, an old establishment here where businessmen put together deals over Argentine sirloin and French wine.
"I guess the business lunch proved immune to the crisis," Mr. Iglesias said in a room of crowded tables peppered with conversations in half a dozen languages. "Twelve months ago I was fearful, but hyperinflation didn't materialize and our clientele even expanded." 
 It is not just good food that weathered the 32 percent devaluation of the Brazilian real. Buoyed by a record $28 billion in foreign direct investment in 1999 and a 12-month stock market rally of 164 percent in local-currency terms, the Brazilian economy is a different beast than it was a year ago.
Growth this year is forecast at 3.5 percent, compared with a rise of perhaps 1 percent in 1999. A handful of other indicators, like unemployment, inflation and car production, also show signs of improvement.
And with concern over the Year 2000 computer problem washed away, there has even been some calm in the currency markets, with the Brazilian real strengthening 10 percent in recent weeks to settle in the region of 1.79 to the dollar.
Yet while almost no one expected Brazil to bounce back so quickly, people here are beginning to look ahead in an effort to gauge whether there is still the risk of a return to the uncertainty, even panic, that gripped the country a year ago.
Judging from some of the challenges ahead, the kind of lasting stability enjoyed by rich industrial nations still seems somewhat elusive.
"We Brazilians tend to have a short memory, but it's not that short," said Oswaldo Castro Jr., sales director of Expresso Aracatuba, one of the nation's largest trucking companies. "You'd think it's about time we reach the point where we can stop managing our business from one crisis to the next."
One big doubt about a departure from crisis mode has to do with the country's banks and their willingness to increase borrowing in a credit-starved economy. After the real was floated a year ago and doomsday predictions about a debt default were common, Brazilian banks held firm and continued to buy government bonds. And although the prescience of this strategy proved a windfall for these institutions, with high-yield debt portfolios fattening profits, banks made few moves to increase lending to individuals or companies. Even with interest rates more than halved by the end of 1999, to 19 percent, loans remained rare.
"For the recovery to be consolidated, interest rates must come down and consumer credit expanded," said Walter Molano, Latin America economist at BCP Securities in Greenwich, Conn.
Yet because of possible interest rate increases in the United States and the European Union, there may not be much room for the central bank to lower rates. Economists see key rates declining to perhaps 14 or 15 percent, but not much further.
Still, that might be enough to kick-start Brazilian companies into again seeking domestic financing, said Carlos Novis Guimaraes, head of Latin American investment banking at Lehman Brothers. "Once you start lowering rates, that creates advantages for local companies to finance acquisitions and other expansion," Mr. Guimaraes said. "This means there will be more advisory work. The outlook for investment banks has certainly improved."
As in the past, interest rate cuts will largely hinge on government efforts to contain spending. Improvements in corporate-tax collection and belt-tightening steps have started to pay off, with Brazil surpassing most budget goals agreed to with the International Monetary Fund.
According to Raul Velloso, a Brasilia-based specialist on public spending, the government's surplus before paying interest on its debt rose to an estimated $13.2 billion in 1999, compared with $2.74 billion a year earlier. He said this measure of surplus could further improve this year.
After interest payments are taken into account, however, the numbers look a lot worse, with a deficit in 1999 of roughly 11 percent of the gross domestic product, one of the highest in the world for an economy the size of Brazil's. The government could succeed in lowering that to the equivalent of 3.8 percent of output, according to Salomon Smith Barney.
While efforts to reduce spending continue, it is widely believed that medium- or even long-term economic stability is unreachable without increasing exports.
Partly because its domestic market is so large, Brazil still has one of the world's lowest ratios of exports to its output -- at 7 percent, according to Jeffrey Sachs of Harvard University. While this puts Brazil ahead of the weakest economies, it is far behind the largest emerging-market economy -- China, with an export-to-G.D.P. ratio around 25 percent.
There are signs that exports are finally starting to surge a year after the devaluation made Brazilian products less expensive abroad. In December, a month in which imports traditionally generate trade deficits, Brazil had a trade surplus of $249 million. And during the first two weeks of January, exports rose an estimated 30 percent compared with the similar period a year earlier.
Part of the improvement has to do with more vibrant markets for Brazilian goods in Asia and Europe. But while a healthier global economy holds promise for Brazilian companies, perhaps the greatest risk for recovery also comes from abroad. "We are in a rising global interest rate environment," said Geoffrey Dennis, Latin America equity strategist for Salomon Smith Barney. "How Brazil will weather an increase in American or European rates, no one knows."

HEADLINE: Agua Prieta Journal;
Boom Turns Border to Speed Bump

BYLINE: By SAM DILLON 

DATELINE: AGUA PRIETA, Mexico, Jan. 14

 BODY:
United States Border Patrol agents have been detaining so many Mexicans crossing the border illegally that when they flushed the Guzman family and 20 other shivering migrants out of the Arizona mesquite near here last week, they had to fill out the forms sending them home by flashlight.
They did the paperwork under the desert sky because the 1,410 undocumented immigrants rounded up that same night would not have come close to fitting inside the nearest Border Patrol station at Douglas, Ariz. 
 Since 1998, Agua Prieta, a gritty desert town that shares the border with Douglas, has been the busiest border crossing area along the 2,000-mile dividing line between Mexico and the United States. And January is busy season here as thousands of undocumented Mexicans have attempted to cross into Arizona since the New Year's holidays, provoking detentions on an industrial scale.
Along the 26 miles of frontier stretching east and west from here, the Border Patrol has already detained 14,664 undocumented migrants this month, nearly twice as many as were detained during the same period last year.
The January rush for the border is part of a yearly cycle; thousands of Mexicans who work illegally in the United States travel south to spend the Christmas holidays in hometowns across Mexico, and employers all across America are now waiting for them to return. But this year is busier than usual because of the booming economy up north.
Enrique Guzman, 22, earned $50 a week running errands for a congressman in Mexico City. But since a relative in Los Angeles persuaded him that he could earn eight times that as a construction laborer in the American economy, Mr. Guzman has been determined to reach California. Not even his family's humiliating detention on Jan. 12 changed his mind.
"We'll try again," Mr. Guzman said after agents released him, his teenage wife and their baby boy back into Agua Prieta.
Thousands of migrants with the same idea loiter in Agua Prieta's streets by day, awaiting their chance to make an illegal crossing. Across a new steel-barred fence in Douglas, a once sleepy town of 15,000 residents, reinforcements have swelled Border Patrol ranks to nearly 500 agents from 2 in the early 1980's; it now rivals the school district as the largest employer. Hundreds of Border Patrol vehicles prowl the streets, helicopters clatter overhead and stadium floodlights illuminate the border fence like the walls of a prison.
"Douglas has become a garrison for a federal force fighting an immigration war," said Ray Borane, the town's mayor, who wrote letters to President Clinton and Vice President Al Gore recently asking them to rethink border policy.
Douglas-Agua Prieta became Ground Zero in the conflict over worker migration because the Clinton administration has reinforced the Border Patrol to more than 9,000 agents from fewer than 4,000 in the mid-1990's and deployed many of them to detain illegal crossers in the border area's largest cities.
Demographers say the crackdown has not slowed the river of humanity crossing the southwest border but has rechanneled it. In 1993, 9 of 10 undocumented migrants crossed at border cities. Today, 2 of 3 cross in remote areas like Agua Prieta.
Robert L. Bach, associate commissioner at the Immigration and Naturalization Service, said the toughened policies have reduced the chaos in border cities like San Diego, where crowds of migrants used to run through residents' yards and across freeways.
"We want a labor market that plays by the rules," he said. "Nobody says we've controlled the whole border. But we're accomplishing that piece by piece."
Rechanneling the flow into remote areas has made it more dangerous, however.
Migrants now die in greater numbers than previously, of thirst, hunger, sunstroke or cold. Others drown in irrigation canals. According to Mexican government figures, 717 undocumented Mexicans have died trying to cross the border since 1995.
"I feel for these aliens," said Larry Vance, an employee of a Douglas utility company, recounting how several Mexicans have been run down by cars near his 20-acre property a mile north of the international line. Anger overwhelms his sympathies, however, because mobs of migrants cross his land each day, bending his fences and dumping diapers and empty water jugs.
"The Border Patrol is nothing more than a speed bump for these people," he said.
Pat Buchanan, who is advocating tougher border controls in his pursuit of the Reform Party's presidential nomination, is scheduled to meet with Mr. Vance when he visits Douglas on Wednesday. But illegal immigration is not the explosive issue it has been in past presidential campaigns, apparently because America's economic boom has created labor shortages.
Never has the United States spent so much to keep undocumented workers out, nor the economy needed them more.
"Mexican immigrants are filling niches that employers can't even try to fill with American workers," said Wayne A. Cornelius, director of the Center for Comparative Immigration Studies at the University of California at San Diego. "So even though migrants must expose themselves to life-threatening hazards, they'll keep trying until they get across. Economically, that's still their most rational option."
In a Jan. 3 editorial, The Denver Post criticized a crackdown on migrants by the I.N.S. in Colorado, arguing that "undocumented foreigners are keeping our strong economy afloat." The paper urged policy makers to allow some Mexicans to work in the United States legally.
Similar proposals are gaining strength south of the border. Francisco Labastida, the presidential candidate of Mexico's governing party, says he will press for a new, expanded bracero program, which gave Mexicans legal, temporary jobs in the United States a half-century ago.
But for now, people here are learning to live with the arriving masses of undocumented workers. Businessmen have converted dozens of Agua Prieta clinics, auto shops and stores into makeshift hotels, charging $25 to $40 for a bed and hot shower.
"I can tell you the most lucrative illegal contraband here now is not drugs, but people," said Efrain Martinez, the Agua Prieta city manager.
Some migrants grow despondent. In October, a man who had been turned back five times at the border began hurling himself in front of traffic in Agua Prieta. After the police arrested him, he hung himself in his jail cell.
Yet every evening after sundown, thousands of Mexicans march east and west out of Agua Prieta in columns, some 100 or more people long, led by professional guides. Miles out in the Mexican desert, they head north over the international line, seeking to rendezvous with vans hired to ferry them to Phoenix or Tucson.
Waiting to intercept them one recent night was Fred Esquivel, a supervisory Border Patrol agent. Parking his truck along a railroad trestle, he scanned the horizon with an infrared camera that allowed him to peer through the Arizona darkness as though it were high noon. Within minutes, he identified six columns of migrants moving across his screen, their heads bobbing above shoulder-high sagebrush. His radio crackled with a dispatcher's chatter as dozens of agents swarmed along the borderline, detaining hundreds of Mexicans.
"You have to sympathize with these people," Mr. Esquivel said, small-talking through the night. "They're coming from nothing, and they've got nothing to lose. They'll try again and again to get across. I'd do the same thing if I were in their shoes."

HEADLINE: Financial Woes Cloud Pathmark's Future in Poor Areas

BYLINE: By JAYSON BLAIR 

 BODY:
For the last decade, Pathmark has sought to expand its established presence in low-income neighborhoods, where other chains declined to venture. It has been a successful part of its business, despite perilous predictions.
But now the chain's future in poor urban areas has been cast in doubt by mounting debt, a failed merger attempt and other financial problems, according to market analysts and company officials. 
 As a result, they say, Pathmark's efforts to build additional supermarkets, including one in Harlem that is considered a centerpiece of the area's economic redevelopment, are in jeopardy.
"We would still like to work with the people of Harlem," Harvey Gutman, a senior vice president at the supermarket giant, based in New Jersey, said when asked about the prospects of building the Harlem market.
The worries about Pathmark's financial health come a month after a failed corporate marriage that promised to erase much of the company's nearly $2.5 billion debt and to guarantee its presence in low-income areas, where stores have generally been profitable for Pathmark.
The problems could force the company to retrench in many neighborhoods, both rich and poor. But the concern among advocates for the poor is that no other supermarket company will take the risk to invest in low-income neighborhoods.
"The market niche they carved was borrowed from 'Star Trek,' " Paul G. W. Fetscher, a market analyst who is the president of Great American Brokerage in Manhattan, said, referring to the show's theme of boldly going where no one had gone before.
"They did an excellent job of going into minority areas and developing excellent stores," he said.
Pathmark is sagging under the huge debt that it incurred when it was taken private in 1987 by an investment group headed by Merrill Lynch. Because heavy interest payments burned up much of its cash, the company was unable to expand quickly enough, fiscal analysts say.
So, for two years Pathmark has been searching for a suitor that could acquire the company and much of its accumulated debt. Last March, Pathmark thought it had found one: Royal Ahold, an aggressive Dutch food retailer, which offered to take on its debt and buy the company for $250 million.
Royal Ahold officials said publicly many times that they admired Pathmark's ability to do so well in poor communities and planned to continue those efforts. But nine months later, the deal fell apart, under objections from the Federal Trade Commission. Federal officials, while not specifically barring the merger, expressed strong reservations about allowing Royal Ahold, which already owned Edwards supermarkets, to have such a hold on the New York market.
Privately, Pathmark officials have said they fear that their financial troubles have placed them in a position with limited options: being acquired by another company, a drastic refinancing and reorganization, or bankruptcy. It is a position that is supported by market analysts, like Mr. Fetscher.
"They really only have three choices," Mr. Fetscher said, adding that the trade commission decision, ruling out competitors in the New York market, made it tough to find a company to acquire Pathmark.
The best case, those officials said, would be for another company to acquire Pathmark and take on its debt, but few larger food retailers seem to be in a position to make such a purchase.
This year alone, Pathmark is scheduled to make a $116 million debt payment, a position that places the company's plans for a supermarket at 145th Street and Bradhurst Avenue in jeopardy, company officials said.
A number of other companies are bidding for the 30,000-square-foot project, but, given its track record, Pathmark had been seen as the leading contender. The market is seen as important to the neighborhood, because aside from Pathmark's East Harlem store, the only other large market is a Fairway on 133rd Street, which caters as much to Upper West Siders as to Harlem residents.
Pamela J. Fairclough, the director of the supermarket project for the Community Food Resources Center, an advocacy group for the poor, said, "We've worked consistently to get larger supermarkets into low-income neighborhoods, and it is a loss for New York City if Pathmark stays in a holding pattern or has to retrench."
Advocates are equally concerned that Pathmark stores may decline in quality or that they could be taken over by a company with a different set of corporate values. "Pathmark is really the only supermarket chain that has made a commitment and taken the risk to develop in low-income neighborhoods," Ms. Fairclough said.
Pathmark's future has also become a concern for C. Virginia Fields, the Manhattan borough president.
As a city councilwoman, Ms. Fields helped the company overcome objections from local retailers who did not want the 53,000-square-foot supermarket built five years ago on 125th Street in East Harlem, and she considers the store one of her more important accomplishments.
Lisa V. Daglian, a spokeswoman for Ms. Fields, said the borough president's office was still working with Pathmark and was optimistic about the proposals for the 145th Street store.
"It took a lot of work to get Pathmark to the 125th Street location, and they have shown a lot of tenacity in the face of a lot of adversity there," Ms. Daglian said. "We would hope ultimately that if they are taken over by another corporation, the values and the interest that Pathmark has shown in investing in lower-income communities are still reflected."

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE VICE PRESIDENT;
Gore Blends His Campaign With Service For Dr. King

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Jan. 17

 BODY:
On the dais of Ebenezer Baptist Church, what he called "the high ground" of the civil rights movement, Vice President Al Gore clasped hands today with Coretta Scott King and swayed as the choir hummed "We Shall Overcome."
It was an election-year bonus, this observance of the birthday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., an "official" tableau provided to Mr. Gore by dint of his position as vice president and one he used to advance his platform in the race for the Democratic presidential nomination. 
 He extolled the record of the Clinton administration in furthering the prosperity of African-Americans and their appointments to federal positions. He called for affirmative action, recalled his tie-breaking vote in the Senate in favor of gun control and lamented the Republicans' failure to confirm Bill Lann Lee as chief of the Justice Department's civil rights division.
Repeating Dr. King's summons to build "a greater economic base," Mr. Gore echoed phrases from his stump speech: "We must keep our prosperity going, not for the primary benefit of those who already have the most, but to profit at last those who as yet have so little. Like Dr. King, we do not seek to comfort the comfortable; we do not seek to give away our hard-won surplus to the powerful few, but to use it to establish justice and opportunity for the many."
Mr. Gore also announced that private donors had contributed half a million dollars to help restore the Ebenezer church, where Dr. King preached, and that the Clinton administration would seek $1.5 million in next year's budget to preserve and maintain Dr. King's birthplace.
Mrs. King, whose husband would have been 71 on Saturday, hailed Mr. Gore as "a compelling advocate for racial justice." She praised him for denouncing the Confederate battle flag, which flies over the capitol of neighboring South Carolina, and recalled that his father, the late Al Gore Sr., a longtime senator from Tennessee, had opposed the poll tax and the Vietnam War.
The three-hour service featured two of Dr. King's children, Dexter Scott King and the Rev. Dr. Bernice Albertine King, who offered a fierce and passionate tribute to her mother. ("Thank you, Bernice," Mrs. King said upon taking the pulpit, "but I can take care of myself.")
The audience of a few hundred people included Alexis M. Herman, the labor secretary, as well as John J. Sweeney, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., which has endorsed Mr. Gore, and James P. Hoffa, president of the Teamsters union, which has made no endorsement. Both served as grand marshals in a King parade here.
Gore advisers have said the votes of African-Americans are crucial to his campaign, especially in the South, and Mr. Gore has made frequent appearances here to rally blacks on his behalf.
Mr. Gore has referred to the assassination of Dr. King as an important event in his young adulthood. He was driving from Boston to Washington on spring break in 1968 when he heard the news on the car radio. He said he drove to downtown Washington to pick up his mother at a store, where protesters were smashing the windows. He described the assassination as one of the factors contributing to his disillusionment with politics. He has said he became more optimistic about the system after he worked as a reporter.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE DIE-HARD;
Forbes, 'Your Next Commander in Chief,' Presses On

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE 

DATELINE: DES MOINES, Jan. 17

 BODY:
Even though Steve Forbes has been dismissed as a realistic presidential contender by most political pundits, the Forbes campaign continues its seemingly never-ending swing through Iowa, filled with the enthusiastic belief that one day, if the breaks just fall its way, Mr. Forbes might actually occupy the Oval Office.
Mr. Forbes himself peppers his stump speech, which has not varied in months, with phrases like "as your commander in chief" and "when I am president," and his hard-core followers reward him with standing ovations and murmured amens. 
 From now until the Jan. 24 caucuses, Mr. Forbes is leading a highly visible and heavily orchestrated bus tour of Iowa, drumming up support in the one state where he has a shot at a fairly respectable showing. That, of course, is because Senator John McCain of Arizona has decided not to compete here, making Mr. Forbes a virtual shoe-in for the No. 2 spot behind the Republican front-runner, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas.
Mr. Forbes needs a strong showing in Iowa to propel him into New Hampshire. And to that end, his legendary organizational prowess and lavish spending are on display as his two-bus cavalcade, blaring Willie Nelson tunes, pulls into small towns. Mr. Forbes, a gawky but effective speaker, and his entourage put on a spectacle filled with power-point presentations, a plea for followers to create a "family and friends" network of additional supporters and plenty of free food and gifts.
No one goes away empty-handed or unfed. Gifts include a copy of Mr. Forbes's book, a 15-minute biographical video, a bright orange long-sleeved T-shirt with the campaign logo to wear on caucus night, a blue computer mouse pad emblazoned with his name, campaign buttons, campaign literature and a list of caucus sites in every Iowa neighborhood. And wherever Mr. Forbes goes, the crowd is typically already seated at tables where chili and potato soup, turkey sandwiches and vegetable soup, individual crocks of cheese soup or, in one case, a pork dinner, have been served.
The campaign is so organized that at each stop two young men rush out of the bus before Mr. Forbes, carrying American and Iowa flags to set up on the podium, where a huge Forbes sign already hangs. Those who attend have either been called directly by the Forbes campaign or drawn by an advertisement in the local newspaper or on local radio. When they sit down, a packet of Forbes information identifying their caucus site is already at their seat.
Crowds of 100 to 300 greeted Mr. Forbes at each stop on a recent two-day Iowa swing, many saying they were little concerned that his chances of winning were slim.
"Nothing is a sure thing in Iowa to my way of thinking," said Don Hahn, a retired farmer in Keota.
Denise Stockland, an assistant manager of a grocery store in Washington, Iowa, said: "I like what he says about the family and the flat tax, and I don't care what anyone else thinks. You are supposed to vote for who you think is the best, no matter what."
Lorna Shepherd, an Ainsworth farmer, added: "I don't vote to be part of a bandwagon; I got to like what I hear. That's why we have the caucuses."
What is particularly surprising about Mr. Forbes is how little his basic stump speech has changed in months of campaigning and how programmed his presentations are. Even his jokes do not vary. His reference to "the Infernal, oops, I mean Internal Revenue Service" is a consistent laugh-getter.
This consistency and these traditional themes are what his followers have come to hear: a presentation against abortion, in favor of a flat income tax and in favor of more choices in education, health care and Social Security investments. He continues to play the role of Washington outsider -- "Washington special interests have no hooks in me" -- and he puts down the tax plans of Mr. Bush and Mr. McCain, whom he refers to as the "timid twins on taxes."
For his campaigns, Mr. Forbes has spent $62 million from his own fortune of over $400 million: $25 million in 1999 and $37 million in his 1996 bid. That money has poured into the setting up of a powerful organization for a caucus competition where a strong organization often matters more than a winning message.
Mr. Forbes has 4,000 caucus captains in the state's 99 precincts and has identified 88,000 "Forbes-friendly" households. Those captains, along with everyone else who attends Mr. Forbes's appearances, are being asked to bring five people each on caucus night and are given cards to identify them to the Forbes campaign. Around 100,000 of the state's 500,000 Republicans typically attend the caucuses.
The goal is for Mr. Forbes to do better than he did in the Iowa straw poll last August, when he received 20 percent of the vote to Mr. Bush's 31 percent. (The rest was scattered over 10 other candidates, with Elizabeth Dole, who has since dropped out, finishing third, with 14 percent.)
The core of Mr. Forbes's support is made up of social and economic conservatives: the Christian right of the party and those who want less government and lower taxes. But to succeed, Mr. Forbes has to go beyond that and gain a share of Iowa's undecided vote.
"There are lots of undecided," said Steve Grubbs, former chairman of the Iowa Republican Party and head of the Forbes Iowa campaign, "and we've got to have those undecided break our way on caucus night."
The view from the Forbes campaign is that Mr. Forbes needs a strong showing in Iowa to give him momentum for the New Hampshire primary, just eight days later. "We don't have to win," Mr. Grubbs said. "Our job in Iowa is to get Steve Forbes to New Hampshire."
While Mr. Grubbs declined to say how much of the Iowa vote Mr. Forbes needed, he said, "South of 20 percent, he goes wounded. We need to be north of 20 percent, there's no doubt about that."
Most local polls show Mr. Forbes taking around 20 percent of the Iowa vote.
Still, for all the campaign ebullience, there is a defensiveness over Mr. Forbes's low standing in polls and his dismissal by the political establishment. A piece of campaign literature distributed at Forbes events says: "With George W. Bush weakening in the early states -- and John McCain unprepared to run a full 50-state presidential campaign -- Steve Forbes is now in a position to surprise everyone and win the G.O.P. nomination. That's what the media isn't telling you."
For all the Forbes talk about bold ideas, it often seems that he is not so much running for president as he is running to stop Mr. Bush, whom Mr. Forbes portrays as a latecomer to his anti-tax crusade, though in a weaker form.
"Now that Bush is the front-runner, he's trying to portray himself as a tax cutter," Mr. Forbes said, seated in his campaign bus one dark Iowa night. "I'm delighted that others are beginning to evolve to where I am. Bush will have a fight on his hands and it will be a long one. He tried to shut us down at the straw poll and it did not work. I'm in for the duration. The Republican Party wants to anoint Bush, but I don't think they will be able to pull off their coronation."

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE COMEDIAN;
And Now (Drumroll), Heeeere's Johnny (McCain)

BYLINE: By JODI WILGOREN 

DATELINE: HOPKINTON, N.H., Jan. 14

 BODY:
Heard the one about the trees chasing the dogs? If you were at Senator John McCain's recent town hall meeting in Merrimack, N.H., you would have. Twice.
It's a little weather joke Mr. McCain likes to tell. So little water in Arizona, the trees chase the dogs. Ba-dum-bum.
Pretty amusing the first time, and it typically gets a chuckle when the Republican presidential candidate uses it in his opening remarks on the campaign trail. But even his staff was silent when Mr. McCain recently offered the line a second time to the same audience. Oops. 
 "I noticed that as soon as I said it," a sheepish Mr. McCain said later. "They didn't laugh."
Most candidates have a stump speech. Mr. McCain, who favors endless question-and-answer sessions with the public and the press, has more of a stand-up routine. His mix of dry sarcasm, terrific timing and a sweet rasp of a voice is reminiscent of Johnny Carson (they also have similar hair). He can be funny off the cuff, but the cuffs are a little worn during long days riding around New Hampshire in a campaign bus. So he relies on some old standbys:
On who will play him in the movie version of his book, "Faith of My Fathers," a memoir of three generations of McCain military men: "I want Tom Cruise; my kids want Danny DeVito."
On his book: "I'm not here to hype my book. I would never do that. $24.95, Random House. It's been four months on the best-seller list, available on Amazon.com. But I wouldn't hype it."
On politicians taking credit for things they did not do: "The vice president invented the Internet. I invented television."
On young voters' cynicism about government: "There's a study out that says more young people believe Elvis is alive than believe they'll ever get a Social Security check."
On early polls in New Hampshire: "We were at 3 percent. The margin of error was 5 percent."
And then there's the story of Mr. Tillotson. That would be 101-year-old Neil Tillotson of Dixville Notch, N.H., who came up with the idea of having his northern hamlet be the first to count its ballots in this "first in the nation" primary, making the burg a must-stop on every presidential candidate's tour.
Seems Mr. McCain, in his self-described desperation for votes -- including all 29 in Dixville Notch -- has visited with Mr. Tillotson not once but twice this campaign season. Asked who his favorite Republican was, out of all the candidates he had met, the old man replied, "Theodore Roosevelt." Ba-dum-bum.
"I think humor is really important," Mr. McCain said. "I've thought it was important all my life. I think it's important in these kind of, what sometimes get to be high-pressure situations."
Like when he was a prisoner of war in North Vietnam, tapping out jokes about Hanoi Hannah, a piece of radio propaganda, in code through the cell walls. And now in the heat of the presidential race, where he tells audiences -- over and over and over again -- that his only problem with an advertisement that shows Bill Clinton's face morphing into his is "that it's the ugliest picture of me I've ever seen."
There are self-deprecating lines about how, with white hair at 63, people think he is his school-age children's grandfather. He makes jabs at the press ("they go from liberal to Communist") and his staff ("most of them are on work-release programs"), and he offers a riff on Harry S. Truman's quest for a one-armed economist "because economists always say, 'On the one hand, on the other hand.' "
His audience eats this stuff up.
"Some of them just talk serious and serious, but he's with the people," said Caroline Jowders, 78, who has heard the routine at four campaign events. "He always has a sense of humor."
In Keene, N.H., the other night, the crowd was cracking up as if it were a comedy club.
"He was very entertaining," Barbara Hecker said afterward. "There aren't too many politicians that I think are funny."
Mr. McCain also does a mean Bob Dole impression (though he refused to offer a rendition of the Viagra commercial), and freely admits that most of his humor is borrowed. ("The trees chase the dogs" is a Barry Goldwater original, and many others belonged to Morris K. Udall, the late Democratic congressman from Arizona.)
Which brings us to one of the candidate's favorite closing lines. Something about how Mr. Goldwater, Mr. Udall, and Bruce Babbitt, all Arizonans, all trod this path before him.
"Arizona may be the only state where mothers don't tell their children they can grow up to be president," Mr. McCain cracks. "I want to change that."
Ba-dum-bum.

HEADLINE: Texans Split Over Plan To Reopen a Pipeline

BYLINE: By ROSS MILLOY 

DATELINE: SUNSET VALLEY, Tex., Jan. 15

 BODY:
Sandwiched between the sparsely populated Texas Hill Country and the sprawling city of Austin, this community of 327 people sits on the line between new and old versions of the Lone Star State. To the east rise the office buildings of an urban high-tech center; to the west, rolling ranch land stocked with cattle, and beyond, the flat prairies of Big Oil.
And just beneath the limestone soil of Sunset Valley's quiet suburban neighborhoods runs another line, a 50-year-old, 700-mile-long oil pipeline that some say represents a grave environmental threat and others contend holds environmental and economic benefits just waiting to be tapped. 
 The differing views say much about how Texas has changed since the pipeline was built, and about the oil industry's declining influence.
For more than five years, the Longhorn Partners Pipeline Company has been trying to convert the pipeline from its former function, pumping crude oil from Houston to West Texas refineries, to a new use, carrying cleaner-burning gasoline to El Paso, a city under federal air quality sanctions. From there, the gasoline would go to New Mexico and Arizona. The result, Longhorn says, would be cleaner air for El Paso and reduced fuel costs for Southwest motorists who have historically paid some of the nation's highest gasoline prices.
The pipeline has been dormant since it was bought for $325 million in 1995 by Longhorn, a partnership of Exxon, Amoco and other oil interests.
But critics say moving gasoline rather than less-volatile crude oil through the aged line poses risks of explosions and fires for thousands of people living near it. They also say spills from the pipeline could threaten lakes and the ecologically fragile Edwards Aquifer, an underground network of spring-fed catacombs that provides water to 45,000 Central Texas residents.
"This is all about pitting one area against another," said Jeff Jacks, an Austin neighborhood leader. "El Paso needs cleaner gas for their air quality problems, and so we end up shipping gasoline across our aquifer. None of it makes much sense."
J. J. Pickle, a Democrat who represented this area in Congress for 31 years, until 1994, says he cannot remember a similar controversy.
"Fifty years ago things like this pipeline were just automatic," he said. "People didn't think there was another side to putting in pipelines."
Longhorn has agreed to a long list of protective measures as a condition for reopening the line. But officials here have vowed to fight the move, insisting that the line be rerouted around the Edwards Aquifer.
"My message is very direct: Put this pipeline somewhere else," Representative Lloyd Doggett, a Democrat who replaced Mr. Pickle, said this week at a meeting that drew 2,000 people.
Oil and Texas have been synonymous since the Old Spindletop field was discovered in East Texas in 1901. The state has 250,000 miles of underground oil and gas pipelines, more than any other, said Gene Acuna of the Texas Railroad Commission, which regulates the network.
Local sensitivities to pipeline safety were heightened by an explosion on a pipeline in Bellingham, Wash., that killed three people in June 1999. And on Thursday a $35 million settlement was announced between the federal government and Koch Industries of Wichita, Kan., arising from oil spills in rural areas. Texas will receive $17.5 million of that settlement.
Between 1993 and 1996 there were 614 incidents involving pipeline safety along the 150,000 miles of intrastate lines regulated by his office, Mr. Acuna said, and three reported deaths.
With high technology now driving the Texas economy, oil is no longer king. In the 1950's, when the Longhorn pipeline was built, oil represented over a quarter of Texas' total economic output and employed 233,000 Texans, more than 10 percent of the state's work force.
Oil and gas have slipped to 11.9 percent of the state's gross product and 3 percent of the work force. By comparison, the high-tech industry employs over 100,000 in Austin alone and more than 500,000 statewide. The technology industry has surpassed oil's role in the economy and now totals 12.5 percent of the state's gross product, the State Comptroller's Office said.
"Our real economic resource is not minerals, but our quality of life," Mr. Doggett said. "Our quality of life is what attracts the talented people. And you cannot get those people if you are next to a smelly oil well or a potentially exploding or leaking pipeline."
Don Martin, a spokesman for Longhorn, counters that it would take 12,000 tanker trucks to move the volume of gasoline that would be transported by the pipeline.
"Now you tell me which represents the greater environmental and quality-of-life risk: an underground pipeline that no one ever sees or 12,000 tanker trucks in the street?" Mr. Martin asked.
The dispute illustrates the declining influence of the oil industry, Mr. Pickle said. But just as important, he said, is the growth in agencies and laws to protect the environment. "It's not just that the oil industry has gotten weaker, but that the citizens and the environmental groups have gotten so much stronger," he said.
Another way Texas has changed, Mr. Martin said, is that El Paso and West Texas have become more politically sophisticated. "They are growing and want to be part of the state's economy," he said. "They are the ones who are really pushing for this pipeline."
Mr. Pickle, 86, says the battle over the pipeline reminds him of struggles over prisons in his legislative career: "Everybody wants people to go to jail, but nobody wants a prison built near them."
Opponents of the pipeline are pressing for an environmental impact statement, which could delay the project for several years.
"You are going to see from this an uprising in other parts of the state." Mr. Pickle said. "Houston and El Paso are going to say: 'We need that gas. It gives us jobs, it helps our air, it helps our cities grow.' "

HEADLINE: 46,000 March on South Carolina Capitol to Bring Down Confederate Flag

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

DATELINE: COLUMBIA, S.C., Jan. 17

 BODY:
With a strength and exuberance seldom seen since civil rights days, a crowd of 46,000 marchers pointed to the Confederate battle flag snapping over the state Capitol today and demanded that it be removed from public life.
"The flag is coming down today," they sang in an updated lyric to the tune of "We Shall Overcome," on a sunny anniversary of the birth of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Young people who had never attended a protest strode next to an older generation that knew the drill, waving signs, stomping feet and mock-grimacing at the object of their derision on the dome. Many seemed to act as though their sheer numbers and deafening decibel power alone might shake up the state legislators who have kept it flying. 
 "Not everyone in South Carolina is still living in the 18th century," said James Gallman, president of the South Carolina N.A.A.C.P., standing on the Capitol steps and speaking to a roaring crowd that spread out for blocks around him. "We are going to send a clear message to those who have the authority to deal with the placement of the Confederate battle flag. Let it be clearly understood that we live in the sovereign state of South Carolina, and not in the Confederate States of America."
The march was the largest in the city's history, said Mayor Bob Coble, and perhaps the greatest civil rights rally since the 1960's, said Kweisi Mfume, the national president of the N.A.A.C.P. who was the day's main speaker. Buses rolled all night to bring in marchers from Baltimore and Birmingham, many of whom spent the night with friends to avoid spending a dollar in the state, hewing to the N.A.A.C.P.'s economic boycott of South Carolina that began with the new year.
It had been only a week since 6,000 white supporters of the flag gathered on the same steps to praise it as a symbol of Southern heritage, a reminder of their ancestors' courage in battling to secede from the union. Organizers of today's march desperately wanted to best that number and had predicted they might be able to attract 20,000, thanks to concerted organization by the N.A.A.C.P. and pleas from Southern pulpits.
But no one had truly expected the wave after wave of marchers who came down Washington and Main Streets today to the Capitol. And in particular, no one had predicted that so many white marchers would show up. It appeared that 5 percent to 10 percent of the crowd was white, including large delegations of white elected officials, business leaders and clergy members. That delighted organizers who were working to demonstrate widespread opposition to the flag.
"The Civil War's been over a long time," said the Rev. John Hurst Adams, bishop of the regional district of the African Methodist Episcopal church. "We know you got an inferiority complex because you lost, but you compensated for that a long time ago."
South Carolina is the only state of the Confederacy that still flies the battle flag, although other states incorporate Confederate elements into their flags. The Georgia chapter of the Rev. Jesse Jackson's Rainbow/ PUSH coalition is planning to announce a boycott of Georgia because its state flag includes the battle flag.
South Carolina is also the only state in the country without an official celebration of Dr. King's birthday, which was much noted by many speakers and marchers. State employees here have the option of taking off either today or one of three Confederate holidays scattered around the year, but all state offices were open for business today.
Although bills to remove the flag and add the King holiday have passed the State Senate in the past, they have always died in the House, where districts are smaller and constituencies are often exclusively white or black. Many participants today asserted that the large majority of state residents, white and black, want an end to the divisive issue of the flag.
"The vast majority of South Carolina says it's time to bring down the flag now," said Mayor Joe Riley of Charleston, who is white. "We cannot ignore that the Confederate battle flag was taken by hate groups. It was taken by the Klan. It became a banner of the segregation-forever movement, and we cannot be insensitive in South Carolina to the feelings of our African-American brothers and sisters when they see that flag."
Speaker after speaker derided the six-foot banner flying far above their heads as a symbol of slavery and hatred. Mr. Mfume said it was a reminder that intolerance was still manifest in the form of militia groups and anti-immigrant sentiment. Many in the crowd carried signs that read "Your Heritage Is My Slavery," posters of Dr. King, thousands of American and South Carolina flags, while one marcher carried her membership certificate in the United Daughters of the Confederacy.
There were few spectators along the six-block route of the march, because most got caught up in the spirit of the day and joined in. Police officials said the day was almost entirely peaceful, reporting only one arrest for disorderly conduct. The Department of Public Safety estimated the crowd at 46,000, but organizers said it could have been over 50,000.
Gov. Jim Hodges, a Democrat, did not attend the rally to preserve what he said was the neutrality he needed to negotiate a compromise to move the flag. He said later that the size of the crowd "creates a sense of urgency to get this issue resolved," but some black House members on the Capitol steps said they would be surprised if their white colleagues would actually be impressed by the rally.
"These aren't their constituents," said Representative Walter P. Lloyd, a Democrat from Walterboro.
But political considerations were beside the point for most of the marchers, who found if nothing else in the flag an organizing principle to demonstrate their energy and commitment.
"My little girl has to see that flag every day on her way home from school," said Norma Baggison, a state employee who was marching next to her daughter Sheila, who is 8. "But now she can see that her people is stronger than any flag."

HEADLINE: Doctors Eliminate Wrinkles, and Insurers

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

 BODY:
In the waiting room of Dr. Mark D. Fromer's office in Trump Tower -- not so long ago filled with elderly patients seeking treatment for cataract disease -- young professionals with expensive haircuts whisper into cell phones as they wait for their 15-minute laser eye surgery appointments.
Patients at the SoHo Integrative Health Center in Manhattan can see Dr. Laurie Polis, the center's dermatologist, for a routine skin cancer check, then get the wrinkles in their forehead zapped. Dr. Irwin Smigel, a prominent Manhattan dentist, passes people needing routine fillings on to his associates; he is far too busy applying the latest tooth-whitening concoction on his patients. 
 Until recently, doctors who specialized in so-called lifestyle medicine -- elective and largely cosmetic procedures -- were limited to rarefied corners of the medical profession. But facing declining revenues because of reimbursement cuts by managed care companies, thousands of doctors in New York and across the country are turning to cosmetic medicine to keep their practices lucrative.
The reason is simple: because nearly every elective procedure intended to improve the appearance of a patient is not paid for by insurance companies, patients must pay up front, often staggering sums. Laser eye surgery, for instance, costs about $5,000. For doctors, that means no rejected bills, no paperwork and no reduced payments by managed care companies.
In some practices, cosmetic procedures are supplementing basic care; in others, they are nearly replacing it.
Insurance reimbursement fees to doctors have dropped significantly in recent years, said Timothy J. Murphy, chief executive of QVS Technology Group, a health care consulting firm in Des Plaines, Ill., that helps doctors set up alternatives to their usual business. "And when doctors lost that, like any red-blooded American, they thought to themselves, 'What am I going to do here?' "
And with a strong economy, there seems to be no shortage of deep-pocketed consumers who feel their lives will be enhanced by having fewer wrinkles, perpetually hairless legs and a face free of cumbersome eyeglasses. In turn, explosions in technology have made many of these aesthetic procedures more precise and easier to practice.
Elective procedures make up nearly 25 percent of many medical practices like plastic surgery and dermatology in urban areas, experts in the field said, up from 10 percent five years ago.
The trend is led by laser eye surgery, which in just a few years has transformed ophthalmology; in the last two years alone, the number of Americans who underwent laser eye surgery to correct their vision problems increased more than 500 percent, and doctors who do the procedure are spending hundreds of thousands of dollars marketing themselves.
Doctors in a host of other medical specialties are also joining aesthetics with medicine: dermatologists, especially in major cities, are prescribing more Botox injections for wrinkles than they are acne medicines, and many are selling anti-aging creams and other beauty products in their offices. Dentists are using the latest in super-whitening techniques. And even obstetrician-gynecologists are offering laser hair removal to their patients.
The attraction of cosmetic medicine, with its fee-for-service payment structure and high demand, may mean that many doctors will now shun more basic but less lucrative practices like general eye care and reconstructive surgery for accident victims.
"What you will find is that the supply of the low-profit services will decline," said Dr. David Friend, a health care management consultant with Watson Wyatt Worldwide in Boston. "The result is a tiering effect, where the best doctors are doing the private stuff and doctors unable to succeed in those things will provide the public service care. We have created an incentive for everyone who can to get out of low-margin businesses, and that could have enormous policy implications."
Dr. Alan R. Kling, who has a dermatologic and cosmetic surgery practice on Park Avenue, said that he is one such doctor. "There are certain cases that I am not doing anymore," Dr. Kling said, citing complicated cancer surgeries for which he said insurance companies reimburse him only $100, one-fourth his cost.
Dr. Kling, whose hold music on his telephone is a running ad for liposuction and skin injections, said that in 1996, things like liposuction and Botox accounted for only 5 percent of his business. Now, they are closer to 25 percent. "It used to be when people who came out of school wanted to do cosmetics, they were looked down on," he said. "At Harvard, they called it 'throwing the pearls to the swine.' Now, in terms of survival, it is what you do."
Dr. Fromer, the ophthalmologist, said that five years ago, the core of his business was retina surgery and general ophthalmology. Now, 90 percent is laser eye surgery. He also points to economics. In the early 1990's, he said, Medicare would pay him $3,000 to $3,500 for cataract surgery, but now he receives $750 to $2,000 per case. "I would describe laser as the thing that allows me to offer general care to my patients," Dr. Fromer said.
As it turns out, deciding to offer procedures that cater to vain, stressed out or just very wealthy patients is not a simple matter of buying new equipment and adding another line to a Yellow Pages ad. Doctors find that they have to overhaul their entire practices, from the way their receptionists answer the phone to the couches patients sit on to the length of time they make patients wait for an appointment.
And they often spend thousands of dollars on advertising: anyone listening to AM radio for an hour might think the only things for sale in America are laser eye surgery and auto insurance.
"The demographics for these procedures is much younger, maybe 30 to 55 years old," said Mr. Murphy of QVS Technology Group. "You have to treat them differently than a 70-year-old patient trying to get an appointment because they can't see."
" 'I'll see if we can fit you in in three weeks' won't work with the McDonald's society who wants it hot, wants in now and wants it cheap," he said. "The staff has to give high-class treatment. We compare it to the airline industry: there is a difference between the first-class cabin and the back of the bus."
Dr. Fromer said that he gave his office one such face lift. The furniture and waiting room are turned out in subtle, tasteful tones. The equipment is sleek and spotless, as though it just fell off a space ship.
Patients recovering from their surgery rest in reclining chairs, covered in soft cotton blankets. His office employees look as though they would fit in quite well behind the counter of an upscale gym.
"When a patient walks through the door," he said, "they have to see that the doctor has done this before, that the equipment is top-notch and the office has to be extremely friendly."
At the SoHo Integrative Health Center, atmosphere is taken to the highest level. Patients see an array of specialists on one floor, including an obstetrician-gynecologist, ophthalmologist and internist, and can get their facials, massages, nutritional therapy and Eastern medicine by climbing a winding staircase past the slate waterfall. (Dr. Polis, who runs the center, sent back the slate once when it was not to her satisfaction.)
"It makes coming to the doctor feel more like self care," Dr. Polis said. "So if you include a massage, well, that is self care, too. There is no need to compare the importance of a Pap smear with a facial."
This medical mall of sorts -- where the plain vanilla medical needs can be matched with aesthetic desires all under the same elegant fabric-covered roof -- is driven by consumer demand, she said. "Those doctors who resist the trends in the way they deliver medicine are not in tune to their patients' needs."
When money cannot be made in procedures alone, there are products that can be sold. Dozens of businesses have opened across the country in recent years to provide dermatologists with skin care products. Often, the preparations they sell are similar to those sold in department stores, only at a higher strength.
Dr. Steven J. Pearlman, the director of the Division of Facial Plastic and Reconstructive Surgery at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center, sells alpha-hydroxy creams to prevent skin aging, and bleaching creams for brown spots. "They make up for overhead," he said, declining to specify his exact profit margin.
Offering skin care products and substituting a lot of the ear, nose, throat and cancer-related surgeries he used to do with cosmetic procedures have given his practice a whole new lease on life, Dr. Pearlman said.
"With medical things, first you have to fulfill numerous requirements, like getting precertified," he said. "You get paid way later and have generated a load of paperwork. With cosmetic things, it is, 'Nice to meet you, here is the procedure, let's do it or not do it.' It is how medicine used to be."

HEADLINE: The Debilitated Russian Military

 BODY:
Moscow's recent setbacks in Chechnya suggest that the decade-long deterioration of Russia's conventional military forces has not yet been checked. The Chechnya operations have been characterized by command failures, overreliance on crude and obsolete weaponry and sparing use of regular Russian ground forces, whose combat readiness is uncertain and morale unsteady.
Although Americans may feel relieved that Russian conventional forces are now too weak to pose a serious external threat, there is a worrisome side to Russia's military breakdown. Moscow's defense planners have placed greater reliance on nuclear weapons to resist potential attack. Further, there is a risk that battlefield failures in Chechnya during the coming Russian presidential campaign could spur demands for a costly and wasteful military buildup. 
 Russia needs to repair its armed forces. But it should do so through rational downsizing and modernization, not by a futile attempt to rebuild along cold-war lines. Large-scale remilitarization would draw away resources and energies urgently needed for reviving the economy and reinvigorating government administration.
Moscow has learned some lessons from its first disastrous campaign in Chechnya, from 1994 to '96. In the first phase of the current campaign Russian forces advanced steadily, behind inaccurate but lethal artillery and air strikes, through the lowlands of northern Chechnya. This approach broke down once the war reached its present stage of fighting in the mountains of southern Chechnya and the urban outskirts of Grozny, the Chechen capital. In recent weeks Chechen guerrillas have staged effective counterattacks and even managed to retake some areas from Russian control.
The Kremlin needs to reconfigure Russia's military forces to better fit the country's post-cold-war needs and resources. In the past dozen years, Russian troop strength has shrunk from around five million to about a million and a half. Investment in everything from nuclear weapons maintenance to new aircraft and tanks has dried up. Military salaries are paid erratically, recruits are treated brutally and conscription orders are widely ignored. While Russia's nuclear weapons still appear to be under effective political control, security at nuclear installations has deteriorated and power and communications interruptions are alarmingly frequent.
Nuclear weapons reduction negotiations with the United States must be revitalized. Russia's new Parliament should quickly ratify the long-stalled 1993 treaty with Washington that provides for Russia's present total of some 6,700 nuclear warheads to be cut almost in half. Formal talks should then begin on a new treaty to bring warhead levels well below 2,000. America can encourage Russia to reform its military forces. But the first steps must be taken by Moscow. The place to begin is by disengaging Russian troops from Chechnya at the earliest possible date.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
TheLandgrab.com

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

 BODY:
Just beyond the headlines about AOL merging with Time Warner and the Internet retailers having a blowout Christmas, there is another, more important land grab under way in cyberspace, which by the time it's over could have an interesting impact on the global balance of power.
Let me put it to you this way: If you think the French and other Europeans are annoyed with U.S. economic dominance today, wait until they wake up and see the high ground that some key U.S. companies are seizing in the business-to-business area of cyber-commerce. These companies are creating the global exchanges that are going to mediate a huge amount of industrial e-commerce in the next decade. 
 The closest thing to these exchanges the consumer would see is eBay -- the auction site, where individuals can buy or sell anything from their basements. But imagine eBays for a whole set of industries, where goods and services related to any aspect of that industry can be exchanged between buyers and sellers.
For instance, you already have Metalsite.com and E-Steel.com, where construction companies from anywhere in the world can put out their steel needs to the lowest bidder. There is already E-Chemicals.com and Chemdex.com for chemicals and life science products. And soon, no doubt, e-rubber, e-plastics and e-cement.
In a world without walls, these global exchanges will be the shapers of the rules, standards and technology by which a whole host of goods and services will be bought, sold, auctioned and bartered. Thousands of companies are already throwing away their catalogues and traditional supplier relationships and plugging into these mega-exchanges, where they will buy everything from paper to plastics. Because of America's lead in this cyberspace land grab, these exchanges are being created largely in the U.S.
"Most of this is still happening just below the horizon, and the numbers are still relatively small, so people don't see it yet," said Joel Cawley, director of corporate strategy for I.B.M. "But estimates are that these big exchanges will mediate between 30 and 40 percent of industrial e-commerce by 2004. Once they get on everyone's radar screen, it will be too late. The winners will be established, and the cost of switching from a key site, or starting up a new one, will be very high."
These online exchanges usually start out as spot markets, where excess inventories are sold. But because of their efficiency, and potential to be globalized, they are quickly evolving into worldwide market-makers.
Look at Enron. It has set up an online marketplace through which companies all over the world are now able to buy and sell natural gas, electricity, coal, plastics, pulp, paper and oil -- and, coming soon, bandwidth. Bandwidth is the basic electronic pipe down which companies send their Internet traffic. Through Enron's Pooling Point Operators -- where ties between bandwidth buyers and sellers will be established and monitored -- a school with excess bandwidth capacity during the summer will be able to sell its surplus to a company with rising bandwidth demand. Bandwidth deals that used to take months to close will take seconds.
"We were the first to do this sort of thing for trading natural gas and electricity," says Enron's C.E.O., Kenneth Lay, "but we think the bandwidth market will be the biggest of all. It is now a $30 billion market and in three years or so it should be $90 to $100 billion. And it will be global. We are already operating in the U.S., and will soon be in Europe and Asia."
The Internet economy runs on bandwidth, so if Enron's exchange works, it could be the equivalent of discovering cyber-oil -- for Enron and for the U.S.
"There are strong advantages to being the first mover in these sorts of global markets," said Mr. Lay. "When you are first, you get scale very quickly, and with that comes economies that lower your transaction costs, and that gives you more liquidity and the ability to do more complicated transactions than others. We will have competitors, I'm sure. But it's pretty much a winner-take-all environment. The early entrants into these markets will in large part determine how they are shaped. And once an entity establishes a strong market position in this kind of global market, it is awfully tough to overtake it."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Most Foreign Markets Rise; Dollar Slips Against Yen
Most major foreign stock markets ended higher while United States markets were closed in observance of Martin Luther King's Birthday. The dollar edged up against the euro, but slipped against the Japanese yen in overseas trading. 
 The gains in European stocks were led by telecommunications companies. In Frankfurt, the Dax index rose 85.68 points, or 1.19 percent, to 7,258.90, its second consecutive record close. And, in Tokyo, the Nikkei 225 stock average rose 480.68 points, or 2.5 percent, to 19,437.23, its highest close in two and a half years. The French CAC-40 index and the Ibex 35 index in Spain closed up nearly 1 percent. C16.
 
Bid Made for Japanese Drugmaker
Boehringer Ingelheim, a large German pharmaceuticals company, started a tender offer for shares of SS Pharmaceuticals, a Japanese drugmaker, in another sign of deregulation's ability to pry open the Japanese economy and breath new life into business. C16.
 
Brazil Warily Celebrates Recovery
The Brazilian economy has recovered from its currency crisis of a year ago with record inflows of $28 billion in foreign direct investment in 1999; a 12-month stock market rally of 164 percent in local-currency terms, and growth forecast this year at 3.5 percent, compared with a rise of perhaps 1 percent in 1999. C4.
 
Fighting Securities Fraud in Canada
The Ontario Securities Commission is pushing three high-profile cases, two involving insider trading, into court, where convictions would help reverse a belief that stock market scandals occur frequently in Canada because there is little risk for wrongdoers. C4.
 
Report Challenges Bertelsmann
A year after Bertelsmann, the German media conglomerate, appointed an independent group of scholars to examine its disputed history during the Nazi era, the commission issued a preliminary report that took issue with corporate lore that the Nazis closed the publishing company because of its political opposition. The four-member commission's tentative conclusion was that Bertelsmann was closed simply because its product was not considered critically important for the war effort. E1.
 
American Girl's Retail Play
American Girl Place, since opening in Chicago's most expensive shopping district in 1998, has drawn 750,000 girls and women (and a few men) from around the world, and in its first year in business has made $25 million, more than twice the original projection, for its parent, the Pleasant Company of Middleton, Wis. The store offers not only the wildly popular American Girl dolls and their extravagant accessories, but other distractions like a theater, a cafe and a doll hospital. C2.
 
Using E-Mail to Market Citrus
Growers in Florida are using digital cameras and the Internet to market their fruit far from the citrus groves and to resolve disputes when shipments arrive damaged. C2.
 
Preparing for the 'Dot-Com Bowl'
More than a dozen Internet companies are scheduled to make their Super Bowl advertising debuts during football's championship game on Jan. 30, compared with three in 1999 and one apiece in 1998 and 1997. The eagerness of dot-coms to parade themselves before what is usually the largest viewing audience of the year helped drive ad rates for Super Bowl XXXIV to a record average of more than $2 million for each 30-second spot during the game, at least 25 percent more than the 1999 rate. Some latecomers are paying up to $3 million for their 30 seconds of fame. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. C8.
 
U.S. Financial Markets Reopen
United States financial markets will reopen today. They were closed Monday in observance of Martin Luther King's Birthday.

HEADLINE: In Policy Shift, G.M. Will Rely On Alliances

BYLINE: By ROBYN MEREDITH 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Jan. 17

 BODY:
In the first acknowledgment by the world's largest corporation that it cannot go it alone, the chairman of the General Motors Corporation said tonight that the company would rely more on partnerships and would better be described as "the General Motors group."
"Our approach is to develop long-term relationships with other companies that offer a unique advantage to the General Motors group of brands and businesses," said John F. Smith Jr., chairman and chief executive of G.M., who was speaking at the Automotive News World Congress here. "This alliance strategy is our major thrust, and it is clearly a different approach to growth than most people have associated with General Motors -- or with the rest of the industry, for that matter." 
 The change in philosophy is remarkable for a company so large that its spending seems to dwarf third-world economies, one so big that a factory closing can attract more attention than the closing of a United States military base, and one that can be as difficult to turn as a battleship.
"No automaker today has the resources to achieve leadership in all regions and all product segments on its own," Mr. Smith said, not even G.M., with its global presence and scores of brands -- from the Chevrolet Camaro to the Cadillac DeVille.
G.M. has longstanding alliances with Isuzu Motors, Suzuki Motor and Toyota Motor. But it has recently expanded some partnerships, forged new ones and even formed three-way alliances. It is also employing the alliance strategy with gusto when it comes to Internet initiatives.
Last year, G.M. and Toyota formed a manufacturing partnership to include research and development on fuel cell and gas-electric hybrid vehicles.
About a month ago, it formed an alliance with Fuji Heavy Industries and its Subaru brand. G.M. benefits from Fuji's strength in small sport utility vehicles, continuously variable transmissions and all-wheel-drive systems, while Fuji can look forward to sharing G.M.'s vehicle platforms and other technologies.
G.M. has also cut a deal with the Honda Motor Company in which Honda will contribute six-cylinder engines and transmissions for a future vehicle, and G.M's previous partner, Isuzu, will send Honda diesel engines for European sales.
"We are also discussing collaboration with Honda on other technology and other business opportunities," Mr. Smith said. "We expect the value of the experience of working together, getting to know each other at the individual level as well as companies, to far outweigh the limited scope of this initial agreement."
Just last week, G.M. said it would buy the half of Saab Automobile of Sweden that it did not already own. And it is now among the bidders for most of Daewoo Motor of South Korea.
"We will not rule out acquisitions and mergers as opportunities arise," Mr. Smith said.
Those kinds of alliances will play an important role in G.M.'s Internet strategies, Mr. Smith said. Last week alone, G.M. said it would enter marketing partnerships with Sony, America Online and NetZero.
Tonight, Mr. Smith said that G.M. was working on another alliance that would give customers using G.M.'s Onstar safety and communications program a single bill for that service and for wireless phone service -- most likely a deal with a large telecommunications provider. That deal could comes within days, he said.
While G.M. has already predicted that its Onstar service would have a million customers by the end of this year, Mr. Smith also said tonight that Onstar would have four million customers by 2003. Onstar customers can now call operators, who are able to call tow trucks when needed or even make restaurant reservations. Before the end of the year, G.M. expects 400,000 Onstar customers to have the capability to use voice-recognition systems and cellular phone connections to talk to their cars, and to reach the Internet.
