HEADLINE: Using the Dollar To Hold the Line;
U.S. Currency Becomes Ecuador's

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: QUITO, Ecuador, Jan. 16

 BODY:
Even in the rest of Latin America, this country of 12 million has never been regarded as much of an economic leader. But by deciding to replace Ecuador's currency with the American dollar, President Jamil Mahuad has thrust his nation onto center stage of a heated, continent-wide debate about monetary policy and economic relations with the United States.
Mr. Mahuad's unexpected move, announced on Jan. 9 amid a political crisis that threatened to topple him, is a textbook example of what economists call dollarization, and provides the test case long sought by advocates of that policy, once considered as much a fringe notion across the hemisphere as the flat tax still is in the United States. 
 So for the next few months, both the Clinton administration and its trading partners from Canada to Chile will be watching the experiment here intently -- and with a healthy dose of skepticism.
At the moment, the only country in Latin America that uses the dollar as its currency is Panama, which took that decision almost immediately after breaking away from Colombia in 1903. Because Panama is so small and was so closely linked to the United States by the Panama Canal Zone, the rest of Latin America has traditionally viewed it as a unique and not especially attractive case in which national sovereignty was traded for stability.
But the trend toward regional trading blocs, including the possibility of forming a Free Trade Area of the Americas as early as 2005, has forced a re-examination of that attitude. The success of the euro, especially as it affects the mother countries of Latin America, has also made the notion of a single currency for the hemisphere more plausible and attractive.
"Joining the euro group has been a more secure arrangement for Spain and Portugal, with lower inflation rates" and rapid growth, said Ricardo Hausmann, chief economist of the Inter-American Development Bank. "If a monetary treaty can be negotiated, it could be attractive for Latin America."
Economists and government officials say the nations that would be most tempted to follow Ecuador's example are those of Central America, which already conduct the bulk of their trade with the United States. In El Salvador, for instance, dollar remittances from Salvadorans in the United States are now the principal source of foreign exchange.
In reality, many Latin American nations already rely on dollars, to one degree or another. At the checkout counters of many supermarkets in Peru, for example, the bills given to shoppers are calculated both in dollars and Peruvian soles. Customers pay in either currency.
Other Latin American countries, most notably Argentina, have formally adopted mechanisms that tie the exchange rate of their pesos to the dollar and have made the two currencies fully convertible at that fixed rate. And beyond Latin America, Liberia in Africa and a few tiny island nations in the Pacific have embraced dollarization, while Hong Kong has followed an approach similar to that of Argentina and its currency board since 1983.
Indeed, the consistent popularity of the currency in world markets has meant that most United States dollars can be found in other countries. The Federal Reserve estimates that about $580 billion is in circulation globally, two-thirds outside of the United States.
 "Most countries have a large amount of their debt in dollars, maintain a large percent of their reserves abroad in dollars, and write contracts indexed to the dollar," said a World Bank official. "In a country like Argentina, a lot of the costs of dollarization have already been incurred, so the step to full dollarization would not be that great."
Countries adopting the dollar "may lose some flexibility in domestic policy issues," John S. Reed, the co-chairman of Citigroup, acknowledged in a speech to a Mexican bankers' group last year. But he and several other analysts argue that any relinquishing of autonomy would be offset by increased investment and capital flows and other gains.
"Full dollarization, if credible, eliminates devaluation risk, and, consequently, will likely result in interest rates which are both lower and less sensitive to crisis in other countries," Guillermo Calvo, director of the Center for International Economics at the University of Maryland and a former adviser to the International Monetary Fund, said in recent testimony before Congress. "In other words, the incidence of contagion will diminish."
Those who advocate formal adoption of the American dollar argue that it would also benefit countries in which wage-earners are used to seeing their purchasing power eroded by high inflation and a weak currency. "I don't know of a single worker who would complain if he were paid in dollars," Alberto Fernandez Garza, president of the Mexican Employers' Federation, said recently.
Indeed, some analysts even suggest that dollarization could be a tool to reduce income inequality. Today, Mr. Hausmann said, "workers are paid in pesos and executives in dollars, and workers can see the advantage of that; they want exchange-rate stability, too."
The United States position on the issue is one that former Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin once described as "agnostic." While the Clinton administration sees potential advantages and opportunities to extend American interests and power, it has also expressed concern about the mechanics of the process and the added burdens it might generate.
"We would never put ourselves in a position where we envisioned actions that we would take would be of assistance to the rest of the world but to the detriment of the United States," Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, told a Congressional panel last year. To Latin American economists, that meant Washington is unwilling to extend the safety net of the Federal Reserve system to any dollarized countries that get into economic trouble. Nor would the Fed conduct monetary policy to take account of cyclical differences between Latin America and the United States.
One clear benefit to the United States would come from "seignorage" fees that would have to be paid by countries that abandon their own currencies. Though it costs only pennies to manufacture paper bills, those notes would be sold at face value to nations adopting the dollar, resulting in a substantial profit for the American Treasury.
"By acquiring dollars for use in their domestic economies, dollarizing countries would be extending an interest-free loan to the United States," Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers told the Senate Banking Committee last year.
If the entire region were to adopt the dollar, that would amount to several billion dollars a year, unless treaties waiving such fees could be negotiated, which Latin American countries have said they would want.
In Washington on Friday, Mr. Summers said there was no likelihood of a monetary treaty or any other official accord with Ecuador regarding its dollarization. "No formal agreement is in prospect," he said after a speech at the Institute for International Economics.
Creating a dollar zone would also be likely to accelerate the integration of Latin American economies with the United States and create trade opportunities for American companies. "The United States has a lot to gain, given that these countries are fertile ground for absorbing U.S. exports," Mr. Calvo said.
In times of conflict the United States might even be able to use the dollar as an economic weapon, withholding currency from an intractable government to bend it to Washington's will. Indeed, the Bush administration took just that step against Panama as part of its effort to overthrow Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega.
But Clinton administration officials have made it clear that given the region's long history of political and economic instability, they worry the relationship could become too close. Dollarization in the Americas stands in sharp contrast to the experience of Europe, where a group of countries at similar levels of economic development created a new currency and established a new common central bank to manage it.
"The Federal Reserve would be buying the problems of places like Colombia and Argentina" if those countries were to give up their own monetary system and adopt the dollar as currency, said a senior official of an international lending agency who talks often with American policy makers. "They don't want that headache. Their attitude is 'use your own aspirin.' "
In his testimony to the Senate Banking Committee last year, Mr. Summers suggested as much, saying that "given the political dynamics that play out in those societies at times of economic frustration," resentment "could be vented at us."
He added that if dollarization "led to that kind of sense of eroding national responsibility, it might be unfortunate for the countries involved, and it might be unfortunate for their relationship with us."
Though American officials have thus far refrained from saying so publicly, nothing about the way or the reasons Ecuador has dollarized makes them view it as a model. The economy here is in a deep recession, and output fell by 7.5 percent last year. The nation's inflation was the highest in Latin America, at more than 60 percent, and in September, the Mahuad government defaulted on about half of Ecuador's $13 billion in foreign debt, not exactly a move to build confidence among investors.
Not only is the country's economy in terrible shape, but the decision to dollarize was taken hastily and unilaterally, for reasons more political than economic, catching Washington and international lending agencies completely by surprise. That creates a risk that if the experiment here fails, it will damage the concept's credibility elsewhere in the region.
"Countries can obviously choose to adopt the dollar as legal tender without our assent," Mr. Summers said in his 1999 testimony. "However, such a decision has some consequences for the United States, and we hope and expect that countries would consult with us in advance."

HEADLINE: Annan Picks Ex-Arms Inspector To Head Iraq Monitoring Panel

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Jan. 17

 BODY:
Rolf Ekeus, the Swedish arms-control expert who found and destroyed large quantities of Iraqi weapons after the war in 1991 in the Persian Gulf, was called back today by Secretary General Kofi Annan to lead a new commission created to finish the job more than a year after monitoring broke down.
Mr. Annan made the appointment after a deadline on Sunday came and went for the Security Council to come up with its own nomination. But in selecting Mr. Ekeus without achieving consensus in the council, the secretary general was in effect daring Iraq's supporters on the council, particularly Russia and China, to veto his choice. 
 Iraq has long criticized Mr. Ekeus, who headed the United Nations arms-inspection team from 1991 to 1997, and ridiculed his selection as "old wine in a new bottle."
This evening, Russia formally registered its objection, throwing the nomination of Mr. Ekeus, now Sweden's ambassador to the United States, into doubt and setting up a confrontation between Washington and Moscow. China, increasingly ready to take a cue from the Russians, may also weigh in against the appointment. The French could then break ranks with Britain and other European countries that support the American position.
A new showdown over Iraq is something that the Clinton administration has, by most accounts, sought desperately to avoid in an election year. American diplomats had seemed hopeful earlier today that there would be no serious challenges to Mr. Annan's choice.
The Security Council is to take up the issue at 3 p.m. on Tuesday, diplomats said. There are concerns among council delegations that friends of Iraq, led by Russia, intend to make this into what American politicians would recognize as a filibuster. By stalling action on a new inspection system, they could indefinitely postpone any resolution of the Iraq crisis.
Meanwhile, support for economic sanctions is steadily eroding, most of all in Russia and France, where business interests are paramount.
Iraq has been under United Nations sanctions since the invasion of Kuwait in August 1990. To have them lifted, it has to meet disarmament requirements in biological, chemical, nuclear and missile systems. But officials here predict that additional nations may be tempted to expand commercial interests in Iraq, which is selling oil at record prices under a more generous program intended to provide civilians with needed goods. Iraq's recent history would indicate that it will try to use the cover of civilian imports to acquire material for weapons.
A resolution on Dec. 17 to revise United Nations policy toward Iraq and send arms inspectors back to the country stipulated that a new chief arms inspector be chosen in 30 days. Mr. Annan had spent several weeks steering through multiple objections to a long list of candidates.
"Over 30 days, he raised something like 25 names and could not find one on which all could agree," said Mr. Annan's spokesman, Fred Eckhard. "So he put forward the name of the person he thought best for the job."
Mr. Ekeus was chosen with at least the tacit approval if not the urging of the Clinton administration, some United Nations officials and diplomats say. His appointment was quickly applauded by the State Department.
"We thank the secretary general for his exhaustive efforts to find a candidate who meets the rigorous criteria necessary to carry out this important disarmament mission," said a statement by a spokesman for the State Department, James P. Foley.
Some diplomats and officials, who have watched the administration steadily withdraw from involvement on the Iraqi issue here, said with Mr. Ekeus in place administration officials could assure critics that a credible chief inspector was back on the job, even if sanctions were ultimately lifted in the process.
The administration would be history by the time that happened, given the steps Iraq has to agree to take to meet disarmament requirements.
Both Congress and the administration have had disagreements with Mr. Annan in the past over his handling of Iraq, in particular his trip to Baghdad in February 1998. That was even though the agreement that he signed there ended a stalemate over inspections, sparing the United States from having to take military action then.
Later, Washington also objected to two of Mr. Annan's appointees in Iraq, saying they were too sympathetic to the government.
In recent days, diplomats and arms-control experts have said that Mr. Annan could not afford to be seen as giving in to Iraq on a new inspector.
Managing the issue now lies with the president of the Security Council this month, Richard C. Holbrooke. Today, Mr. Holbrooke, who has largely stayed clear of Iraq since his arrival in August as the American representative, gave council members 24 hours to study Mr. Annan's nomination of Mr. Ekeus and decide whether they would challenge it. Russia was the first to raise an objection.
Had there been no objections, Mr. Ekeus would have automatically become executive chairman of the United Nations Monitoring, Verification and Inspection Commission.
Iraq, too, immediately attacked the nomination. Deputy Prime Minister Tariq Aziz, who is visiting Spain, called the move dishonest. For several weeks, the Iraqis, apparently expecting a more conciliatory gesture from the secretary general, have been harshly critical of Mr. Annan in the controlled Iraqi press. While serving as chief inspector in Iraq, Mr. Ekeus was routinely vilified by the Iraqis, who called him "the damned Ekeus" and accused him of, among other things, causing the starvation of Iraqi children and being an Israeli spy.
In his low-keyed methodic way, Mr. Ekeus kept up the pressure in a protracted game of cat and mouse. He sent divers to the depths of a canal to find illegally imported missile parts that the Iraqis had hurriedly jettisoned. He documented a nuclear program larger than atomic-weapons experts had imagined existed. He badgered Iraq on its unacceptable accounting for biological warfare materials until literally cartons of damning information were suddenly "found" on a chicken farm -- and still he was not satisfied.
In an interview at the end of his tenure in June 1997, Mr. Ekeus said that President Saddam Hussein had never given up plans to build biological and chemical weapons and that the Iraqis were prepared to lie at every step of the inspection effort to conceal and salvage their illicit programs.
"They tell the most incredible stories," Mr. Ekeus said. "It's like the 'Thousand and One Nights,' where every night they tell a different story to save themselves."
Mr. Ekeus was criticized, however, for agreeing in 1996 to Iraqi demands for restrictions on inspections at some sites close to the Iraqi leadership. Some arms-control experts say that from that moment on Iraq steadily widened the wedge of "unacceptable" searches and "off limits" sites, barring inspectors from presidential palaces and ministerial offices where they suspected that documents and equipment might have been hidden.
Richard Butler, the Australian arms control expert who followed Mr. Ekeus as chairman of the first disarmament commission, known as Unscom, inherited a fast-unraveling system and ultimately lost the support of the Clinton administration in efforts to stand up to the Iraqis. Today, Mr. Butler said that the next 24 hours would be critical for the new inspection program.
Mr. Butler, now a diplomat in residence at the Council on Foreign Relations, said in an interview the council was confronted with "the same issue that it was trying to solve with this resolution, namely a recalcitrant state bucking its authority."
"The first specific test," he said, "was the appointment of a new executive chairman, and here the behavior last week of the members of the Security Council who are clearly the spokespeople for Iraq suggests that they are not prepared to see an appointment of which Iraq does not approve.
"By that action, on this issue at least, they are effectively making Iraq the sixth veto power at the council. All of this raises the gravest question about the council's willingness or ability to implement its own law and to protect its own authority.
"In these circumstances, what chance is there that Iraq would agree to the re-establishment of an effective monitoring system if they are being allowed a veto on a matter like who the executive chairman should be? Rolf Ekeus is an admirably qualified person. Probably no one knows more about this subject than he. Maybe that's precisely why they are vetoing him."

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about the choice of a leader for the new United Nations commission that is to monitor Iraq's weapons programs misstated the selection process. Secretary General Kofi Annan named Rolf Ekeus of Sweden after the Security Council failed to agree on any candidate Mr. Annan was considering. The council was not to make its own nomination.

HEADLINE: ARTS ABROAD;
The Fed Grants a Loan to Spain. How Much Cash? None.

BYLINE: By Al Goodman 

DATELINE: MADRID

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve Board in Washington is known for setting monetary policy, not for its modest art collection. But for the first time the Fed has allowed part of that collection, which is dominated by American paintings, to be shown beyond its own headquarters.
Even in Washington, the public rarely sees the Fed's art because it hangs in offices and private reception areas. But 34 of the Fed's 270 artworks are on view in a show through Jan. 30 at the Banco de Espana, Spain's central bank. The exhibition, "Architecture and Paintings From the Federal Reserve Board," includes a 19th-century landscape of New York State by Alexander Lawrie that normally adorns the office of Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, and other works by William de Leftwich Dodge and William Trost Richards. 
 "It's never been done before," said Mary Anne Goley, the Fed's fine arts director, of the overseas show. Although the Fed exhibited 55 recent acquisitions at its Washington headquarters in 1996, this is the first time that any part of the collection has traveled anywhere.
The Madrid show is a double payback to Spain's central bank, which inspired the Fed to build its own collection and lent 13 old masters, including 3 Goyas, for an exhibition at the Fed last year.
Such exchanges are still rare, although several European central banks -- those in Britain and France, for instance -- have collections that dwarf the Fed's. The Bank of Spain owns 3,500 works, including 8 oils by Goya, who was commissioned in 1783 to paint portraits of the bank's senior officials.
In 1971 Arthur F. Burns, then chairman of the Fed and an avid amateur painter, saw the Spanish bank's art treasures during a visit to Madrid and returned to Washington determined to expand the Fed's collection, which then consisted of four paintings.
"We're the central bank of a great democracy, and he wanted to have something that spoke about our culture," Ms. Goley said. With Burns's influence the bank soon borrowed five paintings, three from the Metropolitan Museum of Art and two from a friend.
The Fed acquired its own art slowly after Ms. Goley was hired in 1975 as its first fine arts director. Most of the collection, she said, has come from tax-deductible donations, although the Fed does not accept gifts from those it regulates.
She also made numerous purchases over the years, especially from Manhattan dealers, and these works include some of the standouts at the Madrid show, like the Richards gouache on paper "Entrance to West Cove, Conanicut Island, R.I.," from 1882.
It depicts a rocky green terrain with grazing sheep in the foreground and sailboats in the distance. Ms. Goley said that she purchased it in 1979 from the Manhattan dealer Gil Einstein for $5,000 and that it was insured for $100,000.
She also bought a Dodge oil on canvas, "Midocean." Painted in 1896, it shows the deep-blue sea meeting a sky filled with purplish clouds, a scene inspired by Dodge's crossings between New York and Paris, where he studied art.
Half of the Madrid exhibition features 19th-century American art because it is little known in Spain, said Jose Maria Vinuela, the Spanish bank's curator, who organized the show. "I wanted a representation of the 19th-century landscape, which is really the century of creation of American painting," he said.
For the other half of the show, he chose such works as the richly drawn renderings by the architect Paul P. Cret for the construction of the Fed's current headquarters in Washington in the mid-1930's.
"These architectural drawings are a cut above," Ms. Goley said, "and of a certain date that really fell into the category of art, because of the shading and the projection of shadow."
Several of the renderings show intricate details, including the wall decorations in the Fed's boardroom, a plaster ceiling ornament and the elevations for doors and a fireplace.
Ms. Goley said she would like the Madrid show, which is open daily at the central bank at 50 Alcala Street, to be the start of other tours for the Fed's collection, with certain conditions.
"It's logical to assume that someone else would ask us, and our first question would be about the facility and can they guarantee the safety of the art objects," she said.
She complained that the frames of a few works suffered nicks during transportation to Spain. The Fed's collection is still not large enough to allow for a big loan of works without the risk of bare walls in Washington, she added.
There is no such problem in Mr. Greenspan's office, which sent the Lawrie oil on canvas, "Pleasant Valley," painted in 1867. The Fed chairman replaced it with a 19th-century John Tullidge landscape, "The Great Salt Lake."

HEADLINE: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;
When Corporate Synergy Becomes Manifest Destiny

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN 

 BODY:
It was a scoop for Jim Lehrer. Within hours of the announcement of America Online's agreement to purchase Time Warner, the two chief mergees showed up for an interview. (In an image reversal, America Online's Steven M. Case was the one with the necktie, Time Warner's Gerald M. Levin the one without, inviting speculation that the $165 billion purchase price had included his tie.)
Instead of further torturing the technological ramifications of this marriage of the Internet to an entertainment and information empire and its implications for the stock market, which had been occupying the cable business channels since the announcement, Mr. Lehrer, in his customary common-sense way, wanted to know what the merger meant for the mere television viewer. 
 What difference would it make, for instance, to the PBS "NewsHour" fan who has found that an hour a day of discussion of serious events was worth more than the hours and hours of repetitious CNN reporting, commentary and Larry King, or to people, if there are any, who can't get excited at the prospect of buying twice as much stuff in half the time with a click or two?
Well, what he learned was that the merger had nothing to do with money and power. No, it was a public service, a liberation for consumers that promised to enrich all our lives. "This is not trying to have control for some self-serving reason," said Mr. Case. Mr. Levin was reading from the same inspirational script. "In business," he explained, "you can have a social commitment." He went on, "This company is going to operate in the public interest." He went further, "We want to make a better world."
It was a revivalist sing-along, lacking only the tribute to a higher power. Mr. Case said he was committed to creating "the most respected company in the world." Mr. Levin was carried away by a strange image of gobbling up all the information and entertainment that he foresees flooding America, digitally or otherwise: "I want to ingest it" and "embrace it" and "consume it." He sounded like a commercial for Pepcid AC. He did his own diagnosis and discovered that his genetic makeup assured "first-quality journalism."
You don't have to be a cynic to have trouble swallowing such image-embellishing claims. These advertisements for themselves, after all, come from men running institutions with a record. Time Warner's record these days ranges from respectable but rarely outstanding news coverage that plays hard on diversions like Monica Lewinsky. As for entertainment, it swings between the best of HBO and plenty of pop clutter. (With all appreciation for "The Sopranos," only in the dim world of television can that show have created quite such a sensation.)
As for the Internet, with its grand vision as a fount of information, for America Online subscribers it turns out to be mainly an engine of marketing. The special appeal of Time Warner to Mr. Case is, he confessed, "the power of established media brands and the customer relationships that those brands represent." Will the Internet's much hailed role as an idea exchange be more stimulating than a typical cable call-in show? What can the vaunted promise that consumers will now be able to make their own choices really mean as long as the menus are cooked up by Time Warner and America Online?
In trying to imagine the secret, tough, complex, high-powered negotiations that must have gone into their deal, it is difficult to see Mr. Levin and Mr. Case, not to mention their advisers from Salomon Smith Barney, Morgan Stanley Dean Witter and other bottom-line professionals, pausing to worry about pledges of service to the world. It was complicated enough to figure out how the assets and the control should be shared without taking time out for mutual flattery.
The quotations from lesser corporate players prove more to the point. Executives regaled reporters with the prospect of CNN's cashing in on America Online's 22 million subscribers and America Online cashing in on CNN's "global brand," with Time Warner's enhanced ability to deliver saleable music online and America Online's ability to carry movies and other features concocted by Time Warner. Such are the calculations of a culture in which everything is merchandise.
It is also easy to appreciate the enthusiasm of Ted Turner, Time Warner's vice chairman and its biggest shareholder, who said, "When I cast my vote for 100 million shares, I did it with as much excitement as I felt the first time I made love some 42 years ago." The rise in Time Warner stock immediately after the merger announcement brought him a paper profit of $2.53 billion.
But what will all this do for Mr. Lehrer's viewers? Will the visions being floated by Messrs. Case and Levin include the enrichment and upgrading of the nation's sorry array of television offerings? Will the new megacompany find it economically inviting to compete with "NewsHour" in an upscale interview program? Will it find room for unprofitable documentaries? Will it take more chances on innovative entertainments?
Worries have been voiced by the merger's critics that the movement toward ever larger conglomerates will result in more uniformity instead of the diversity that the Internet is supposed to exemplify. But even if that does not happen, the Case-Levin duet does not inspire confidence. In at least one respect the changes they envision in the way information and entertainment are delivered will probably come to pass: There will be more brand names like Warner and Time, more readily available for Mr. Case to promote. But nothing about this merger offers the likelihood of higher-quality, pardon the expression, merchandise.

HEADLINE: Reckonings;
Dollars and Desperation

BYLINE: By PAUL KRUGMAN 

 BODY:
Ecuador is a small, faraway country of which most Americans probably know nothing. (Hint: it's on the equator.) Last week, amid the hoopla of the AOL-Time Warner deal, one suspects that few noticed the surprise announcement by President Jamil Mahuad that he would abolish his nation's currency and replace it with the U.S. dollar. But there is an important story behind that story, which is not so much about Ecuador as about the great financial crisis that swept Asia in 1997-98, and the continuing debate over what to do when the next crisis strikes.
Everyone agrees that the Asian crisis was, in the first instance, a case of financial panic: basically, after enthusiastically putting hundreds of billions of dollars into Asia in the years before 1997, investors suddenly lost their nerve and began pulling out all at once, with catastrophic consequences. But there is a sharp difference of views over what could have prevented or at least mitigated that crisis. 
 Broadly speaking, one view holds that in times of panic the normal rules of business should be suspended -- that investors should be persuaded, or if necessary forced, to keep their money in place while the authorities get things under control. In the oddly euphemistic jargon of international finance, this is known as "burden-sharing," or even more obscurely as "private sector involvement."
The other view holds that the way to deal with panic is to try to reassure investors that their money is absolutely secure -- and that one way to do that is to offer an ironclad guarantee that their holdings of Korean won, or Indonesian rupiah, or Ecuadorian sucres, will not lose their value in terms of dollars. This can be done by establishing a "currency board," which holds dollar reserves large enough to back the entire national money supply; it can be done even more decisively by "dollarizing" -- that is, abandoning the national currency and using dollars instead.
It is an unresolved debate, because neither approach was given much of a trial. Hong Kong has a currency board, but was never itself the object of investor panic -- it just happened to be living in a bad neighborhood. Malaysia imposed controls on investors, but only after the worst of the panic was past.
And that's where Ecuador comes in. The small Latin nation has the dubious distinction of having plunged into crisis just as Asia climbed out; and as a result it has become a sort of guinea pig for economic nostrums. It is by no means an ideal choice as a clinical model. After all, at the beginning of 1997 Asian economies looked robustly healthy, with their government budgets balanced or in surplus; their crisis came, as it were, out of a clear blue sky.
Ecuador, by contrast, has always been more or less a mess; its plunging currency is only the outward sign of an inward disgrace, of a bankrupt banking system that cannot be rescued by an equally bankrupt government. But nonetheless, Ecuador is the test case we have, and its experience is likely to have a disproportionate effect on how the next big crisis is handled.
Indeed, the tiny nation has already done much to discredit the notion of "private sector involvement." Last September Ecuador decided, with more or less explicit encouragement from the International Monetary Fund, to temporarily suspend payment of some of its foreign debt. The experiment was a failure: while some investors found their money locked up, others continued to flee Ecuador, and the economy's tailspin continued.
Now its government has swung to the other extreme, and is trying to restore confidence in the currency by abolishing it. Observers say that this could work if it is accompanied by extensive domestic reform -- which is a bit like the old line that you can kill someone with witchcraft, if you also give him plenty of arsenic. But if it works, it will do much to make dollarization likely elsewhere (Argentina, for example); if it fails, as is much more likely, it will give dollarization a bad name.
And the outcome matters. Sometime -- almost surely sometime this decade -- there will be another great financial crisis like the ones that struck Mexico in 1994 or Asia in 1997. What will we do about it? Believe it or not, Ecuador may determine the answer.

HEADLINE: Editorial Observer;
Long Days, Short Beds on the Campaign Trail

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN 

DATELINE: DES MOINES

 BODY:
This is the time of year when presidential candidates tramp around Iowa and proclaim their yearning for a better America. For Bill Bradley, that includes better motel beds.
Occasionally in his high-minded stump speeches, Mr. Bradley pauses to complain impishly about the "rubberized pillows" in Iowa's far-flung hotels and motels, and the sheets that "come loose from the mattress every time you turn over." He leaves out that it can't be any easier to sleep in a small bed for someone who is 6 feet 5 inches. 
 From Mr. Bradley's point of view, the bed that doesn't fit is an apt reflection of the Procrustean format of the Iowa caucuses next Monday, where the system so clearly favors Al Gore. Iowans choose their candidates not in a statewide primary but in 2,100 local caucuses, throwing the advantage to the entrenched unions, political clubs and community groups backing the vice president and long accustomed to getting their supporters out. The Bradley campaign compares its troubles to running against the Chicago Democratic machine.
Mr. Bradley's aides say they have no choice but to mobilize people who have never shown up at caucuses before -- kids, idealists, labor dissidents and others inclined toward the former senator's low-key fervor. Since the beginning of the year, he has spent $1.3 million in television advertising. He has devoted 10 days to traveling around the state, slipping into the role of itinerant preacher-like outsiders going back to Eugene McCarthy and Jimmy Carter, who used to quote the theologian Reinhold Niebuhr to the effect that "the sad duty of politics is to establish justice in a sinful world." But while often authentically inspiring, Mr. Bradley's appeals can come across as pious, ethereal and even a little grumpy.
There are of course the standard references to health care, poverty and economics in Mr. Bradley's speeches. But the candidate seems most distinctive when talking about making Americans feel "less lonely, less fearful and less isolated" in a changing world. "The untapped potential of the presidency is to unlock in each of us the capacity for self-fulfillment," he told a group celebrating Martin Luther King's birthday this week. He went on to promise to work for "a world of new possibilities guided by goodness."
Less artfully, Mr. Bradley told a separate group of students that it was not enough to battle bigotry in others. "If you haven't had a conversation about race in a long time with someone of another race, you are part of the problem," he said sternly, and perhaps a little sanctimoniously as well.
The former senator's style does not get much overt audience reaction, but that is O.K. with him. "I don't want applause," he said in a conversation aboard his bus as it rolled across central Iowa. "I want people to listen, and in the process be moved." His style, Mr. Bradley said, is "to lead from idealism and not interest-group politics" and "awaken in people what they believe politics could be." If his approach does not work, he said with a shrug, "I'm out, and life goes on."
By contrast, Mr. Gore seems to revel in his organized support and theatrical applause lines. At the Union Baptist Church in Des Moines, a black congregation in the eastern part of town, Mr. Gore jumped up and down and rolled his head from side to side during a rollicking refrain of "Restore it!" from the choir. At the pulpit he got cheers when he declared, "I am a Baptist," and cascades of applause as he growled out a list of African-Americans who have served in the Clinton administration. When someone shouted, "Run, Al, run!" he threw back his head with a dramatic laugh and shouted back: "I will! I will! I will!"
With less than a week to go before the caucuses, Mr. Gore remains the front-runner while Mr. Bradley hopes to make a showing respectable enough to proclaim a moral victory he can ride into New Hampshire the following week. Both states are getting a close look at two styles of Democratic presidential politics that have been around since Adlai Stevenson, the cool egghead, and Hubert Humphrey, the happy warrior. This year's version is Laconic Bill versus Pumped-Up Al. In a few days, voters will get to decide which style is more attractive -- or at least less irritating. 
http://www.nytimes.com

TITLE: EDITORIAL OBSERVER (TIMES COLUMN)

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (96%); 

STATE: IOWA, USA (96%);

HEADLINE: Banks Post Higher 4th-Quarter Profits

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The Bank of America Corporation, J. P. Morgan & Company and other United States banks posted higher fourth-quarter earnings yesterday, driven by investment-banking fees and trading.
Bank of America, the nation's largest bank, said profit rose 33 percent. Morgan, the fifth-largest American bank, said its profit had increased threefold. 
 The banks, with big securities businesses, either met or exceeded analyst expectations as merger activity and stock indexes rose to records last year. Mergers worldwide rose to a record $3.43 trillion in 1999, generating fees for banks that arranged them. Companies that trade and underwrite stocks also benefited from surging equity markets, led by computer-related shares.
Even so, exceeding profit from a year earlier was relatively easy to accomplish, since stocks and corporate and emerging-market bonds slumped in 1998 after Russia's default.
"The big banks have benefited because they're not relying on traditional banking," said Jack Ablin, managing director of Colonial Asset Management in Ponte Vedra Beach, Fla., which manages $180 million. "The fee side is driving the business."
Even with higher earnings, bank stocks slid yesterday after bond yields rose to their highest level in two and a half years amid concerns that the Federal Reserve may raise overnight lending rates to help cool an economy in its 106th consecutive month of expansion. Higher interest rates can reduce the value of bond holdings and erode earnings growth if the demand for borrowing wanes.
Bank of America shares dropped $2.4375, to $48.00, while Morgan shares fell $4.6875, to $123.3125. Shares of the Bank One Corporation, the country's fourth-largest bank, fell 68.75 cents, to $31.4375, after it reported that its profit fell 13 percent -- in line with expectations that had been guided lower. Wells Fargo & Company shares fell $2.8125, to $38.875, even though it reported that its fourth-quarter profit rose 26 percent.
Bank stocks, no longer the top performers they had been for most of the 1990's, are becoming increasingly volatile as they expand into brokerage, securities trading and investment banking. Morgan, which has been transforming itself from a traditional lending bank into an investment bank, saw equities revenue, including stock underwriting and brokerage commissions, more than double.
Bank of America said that profit from operations rose to $2.12 billion, or $1.23 a share, from $1.60 billion, or 91 cents, in the 1998 quarter, on higher fee income and lower costs. That met the average estimate of analysts surveyed by First Call/Thomson Financial. Fees, mostly from investment banking, trading, mortgage banking and credit cards, fueled earnings growth for Bank of America which is based in Charlotte, N.C.
Morgan's profit gained on fees from investment banking, underwriting stock and managing clients' money. Net income climbed to $509 million, or $2.63 a share, from profit from operations of $175 million, or 86 cents, a year earlier. That beat the average estimate of $2.00 a share. Including charges a year earlier, mostly to pay for job cuts, net income rose almost sixfold from $89 million. Compared with the third quarter of 1999, net income rose 15 percent.
Over all, noninterest revenue rose 44 percent, to $1.83 billion, as investment-banking revenue rose 17 percent, to $309 million, and asset management revenue rose 27 percent, to $352 million.
Bank One, based in Chicago, said its fourth-quarter profit fell 13 percent as its credit card unit lost customers. Profit from operations fell to $904 million, or 78 cents a share, from $1.04 billion, or 88 cents, in the corresponding period last year. Bank One warned last week that its earnings would decline, forecasting profit at 78 cents a share, a penny short of the average analyst estimate at the time.
Including charges in the year-earlier period, net income rose 82 percent, to $411 million, or 36 cents, from $226 million, or 19 cents.
Wells Fargo reported that net income rose to $970 million, or 58 cents a share, from a profit before charges of $768 million, or 46 cents, in the fourth quarter of 1998. Analysts had forecast an average of 59 cents a share in a First Call/Thomson Financial survey.
Net interest income rose 3.9 percent, to $2.41 billion. Noninterest income rose 33 percent, to $2.07 billion.
Bank of New York's fourth-quarter profit rose 4.5 percent, to $327 million, or 44 cents a share. The bank had been expected to earn 43 cents a share, according to a First Call/Thomson survey. Its stock fell $1.75 a share, to $37.375.

HEADLINE: 'Harry and Louise' Return, With Health Insurance Plan

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18

 BODY:
Harry and Louise, featured in television commercials that helped kill President Clinton's plan for universal health insurance in 1994, are back.
They still work for the insurance industry, but now, in a new television commercial, they prod Mr. Clinton, Congress and political candidates to do something about the problem of 44 million Americans without health coverage. 
 "That's huge," Harry says. "An epidemic." And he insists, "We can't leave working families and kids without insurance."
Louise replies that "someone actually has a workable plan," and she praises the plan devised by the Health Insurance Association of America. "It has tax relief for workers and small businesses, and special help for the working poor," she adds.
Charles N. Kahn III, president of the association, said that Republican candidates for president had "basically ignored" the issue of the uninsured in recent months. "Republicans are floundering on the issue, to be frank," he said.
But Mr. Kahn said the Republican nominee would have to address the issue because the Democratic candidates for president, former Senator Bill Bradley and Vice President Al Gore, had made health insurance coverage a defining issue in their campaigns.
The number of Americans without insurance continues to increase by about a million a year, even though the economy is strong and the unemployment rate is at a 30-year low.
The insurance industry's plan would make it easier for people to buy private insurance, with new government subsidies for low-wage workers and new tax credits for small employers. The proposals would amount to a large federal subsidy for the industry, but insurance executives said most of the money would be passed on to doctors, hospitals and others who provide health care. Mr. Kahn said that the industry's plan could cost $40 billion to $50 billion a year, but that Congress could choose elements of it that would cost much less.
Insurance companies see threats from both left and right. They fear that liberal Democrats will try to supplant private insurers with a government-run program. And they say that some conservative Republicans would undermine the employer-based health insurance system by creating tax incentives for people to buy health insurance as individuals, rather than through large groups organized by employers.
Mr. Kahn said the industry was spending $1 million on newspaper advertisements and television commercials, scheduled to run on CNN nationwide and on some network affiliates in the Washington area in the next 10 days.
The industry spent $17 million on the original Harry-and-Louise campaign, which featured 14 television commercials from September 1993 to August 1994. In those advertisements, Harry and Louise criticized Mr. Clinton's proposals as complex and bureaucratic.
The same actors appear in the new spots, which were produced by the same company, Goddard Claussen, now a unit of Porter Novelli, which in turn is a unit of the Omnicom Group. Harry and Louise were catapulted to national fame when Hillary Rodham Clinton attacked their sponsor in 1993.
Ben Goddard, who helped conceive the original campaign, said he married Louise Clark, who starred in those commercials, in 1997.
Mr. Kahn denied that his organization was making a radical shift. In 1993 and 1994, he said, the association supported Mr. Clinton's goal of universal insurance coverage and, at that time, even supported proposals to require employers to provide or obtain coverage for employees.
White House officials said Mr. Clinton would again propose tax credits for people providing long-term care to relatives with chronic illnesses and disabilities. But, they said, the credit would be three times as big -- $3,000 a year, instead of the $1,000 proposed last year.

HEADLINE: Security Council Stalling on Iraq

 BODY:
For the past 14 months the world has been in the dark about whether Saddam Hussein has rebuilt his stocks of biological and chemical weapons. Last month the United Nations Security Council passed a resolution aimed at getting international arms inspectors back inside Iraq. But that goal is now being thwarted by Russia, France and China, which yesterday objected to Secretary General Kofi Annan's able nominee to head the new inspection commission, Rolf Ekeus.
All three countries are permanent members of the Security Council. It will be up to Washington to make sure that Mr. Ekeus or an equally firm and credible chief inspector is approved this month. Richard Holbrooke, America's U.N. representative and council president for the month of January, has the diplomatic skills to be the point man in this effort, but he will need the energetic involvement and support of President Clinton and his secretary of state, Madeleine Albright. Appointing a qualified inspections chief would increase pressure on Iraq to readmit U.N. weapons monitors. 
 Russia and France are the chief obstacles here. Both are putting narrow commercial interests ahead of their broader international responsibilities. Instead of working to ensure that council resolutions are enforced, they are cultivating Baghdad's good will in the hope that Iraq will reward them with valuable contracts once sanctions are no longer in effect.
Mr. Ekeus served as chief arms inspector for Iraq from 1991 to 1997. He was widely regarded as both tough and diplomatic in his efforts to ensure that the disarmament provisions of the peace agreement that ended the Persian Gulf war were obeyed. That agreement requires Baghdad to supply complete information on its programs for making biological, chemical and nuclear weapons as well as longer-range missiles, and to cooperate in shutting these programs down.
Despite the best efforts of Mr. Ekeus and his successor, Richard Butler, Iraq continued to defy its international obligations, exploiting every division in the Security Council to stall, evade and obstruct. The last U.N. inspection team was withdrawn just before the United States' bombing of Iraq in December 1998. Baghdad remains intransigent, saying it has no intention of readmitting U.N. inspectors, although that is the only way it can qualify for relief from economic sanctions.
Before Mr. Ekeus's nomination, Secretary General Annan informally suggested more than 20 other candidates. All of those willing to be considered had been turned down by one or another member of the Security Council, several by countries friendly toward Iraq. As a result, the original Jan. 16 deadline for naming a commission chairman has already been missed. Further delay is extremely dangerous, giving Baghdad additional time to reconstitute its germ weapons and nerve gas programs, undetected and unmolested,
Mr. Holbrooke, working closely with Washington, must now try to reunify the Security Council behind its own Iraq resolutions. The world needs a robust system of international arms inspectors under tough and unflinching leadership to protect itself from the dangers posed by Saddam Hussein's diabolical weapons programs.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE AD CAMPAIGN;
Bush Returns to Tax Plan

BYLINE: By PETER MARKS 

 BODY:
Reflecting a continuing emphasis on tax cuts, George W. Bush began running a new 30-second spot in New Hampshire yesterday emphasizing his plan.
 
PRODUCER -- Maverick Media. 

ON THE SCREEN -- Framed by a window overlooking a gray harbor, Mr. Bush speaks directly to the camera, which is focused tightly on his face. The only graphics used in the spot flash the governor's name, in black lettering. Portrait shots of Mr. Bush alternate with campaign footage from previous commercials, showing the candidate talking to supporters outside a New Hampshire town hall meeting and working a crowd in warmer weather. At the conclusion of the spot, Mr. Bush, with his signature twinkly half-grin, asks the viewers for their votes.
 
THE SCRIPT -- Mr. Bush: "There's a debate in New Hampshire on taxes critical to America. We can cut taxes for working families and protect Social Security. But it takes leadership. Washington politicians want to keep your money in Washington. Not me. I believe taxes are too high. The people of New Hampshire understand that you deserve your money back. And cutting taxes helps keep the economy growing. On Feb. 1, you settle the debate: tax cuts or bigger government. I'd appreciate your vote."
 
ACCURACY -- New Hampshire is indeed in the midst of its own tax debate. In response to a state Supreme Court ruling, New Hampshire lawmakers approved a new statewide property tax last November, a decision that rekindled the state's historic antitax fervor and prompted vows of legal challenges. Mr. Bush's plan calls for $483 million in cuts over five years. His argument that cutting taxes "helps keep the economy growing," originates in a long-treasured tenet of Republicanism. Mr. Bush argues that it was the Reagan administration's tax cuts in the 1980's that fueled the bullish economy of the 1990's, but others give credit to, among other things, the Clinton administration's championing of deficit reduction and the boom in the information and technology sectors. Critics of the Mr. Bush's proposal add that it gives wealthy taxpayers a disproportionate share of the benefit.
 
SCORECARD -- Mr. Bush's return to the airwaves with his tax-cut message is another strategic move in the competition between the governor and his chief rival, Senator John McCain of Arizona, over how best to guide the economy. (Mr. McCain has unveiled his own plan to reduce taxes by about half of what Mr. Bush proposes.) In style, the commercial relies heavily, as have so many before it, on the candidate's easygoing demeanor. It presents him as a folksy tax-slashing Washington outsider, and he comes across as less stern than Mr. McCain and much less stiff than the publisher Steve Forbes. In this sense, the commercial may be more effective as a means of reinforcing his image than in selling his tax plan. Many New Hampshire voters have been telling reporters that they are focusing less on the details of the plans than on the character of the candidates. Still, the commercial looks a lot like Mr. Bush's other spots, and some viewers may not even realize that it is a new one. PETER MARKS
 
The video of this advertisement is available from The New York Times on the Web: www.nytimes.com/politics

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE TAX ISSUE;
Spinning a Tax Web and Trying to Catch an Opponent

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL and FRANK BRUNI 

 BODY:
Senator John McCain of Arizona signed a pledge yesterday never to tax commerce on the Internet and challenged Gov. George W. Bush of Texas to make the same promise, as the two Republican rivals fought over tax cuts two weeks before the nation's first primary, in New Hampshire.
Mr. Bush rebuffed his challenger, saying he wanted to "understand what the world looks like three to five years from now." And he put his own emphasis on the tax debate by featuring two residents in Pittsfield, N.H., whom he said would benefit more under his plan for a $483 billion, five-year tax cut than under Mr. McCain's proposal for a nearly $240 billion reduction. 
 As he campaigned yesterday, Mr. Bush talked causticly about how Mr. McCain put out a tax proposal last summer and then released a revised and more complete plan last week.
"I think it's a Washington mindset that says, I'll lay something out and then, if it takes on a little water, I'll amend it and keep amending it," Mr. Bush said in Concord, N.H. "At least the way I do it is -- I think through all the ramifications."
The day of dueling news conferences showed both men using a signature Republican issue as they fought for advantage in a tight New Hampshire race that could either propel Mr. McCain's campaign or seal Mr. Bush's status as his party's front-runner. Several polls have shown Mr. McCain leading in New Hampshire.
Mr. McCain has long called for a ban on taxes on the Internet. But he highlighted his stand yesterday by signing a poster-sized blowup copy of an "E-Freedom declaration" at a breakfast of the Greater Nashua Chamber of Commerce.
He called technology the engine of the nation's economic growth and warned against harming "this baby in its cradle."
"I challenge all the candidates, including Governor Bush to take the same pledge," Mr. McCain said, "not for a moratorium, not for two years, not for five years, but a permanent, a permanent ban on Internet taxes."
The "E-Freedom declaration," which is being promoted by Citizens for a Sound Economy, an antitax group that often helps showcase Republican antitax efforts, commits signers to a permanent ban on Internet access, sales or use taxes.
Many governors oppose a ban for fear that as more and more commerce goes online, the shift could drain state coffers of sales tax revenues. So the McCain campaign was trying to create a tricky conflict for Mr. Bush, who counts many Republican governors as some of his staunchest supporters.
Mr. Bush has said he favors a moratorium on Internet taxes, and he said yesterday that he would consider extending the moratorium to five years from three years.
"I want to make sure I understand what the world looks like three to five years from now," he said, "before I speak further."
Mr. McCain also said "nobody's predicted where this technology is going correctly for the last few years, so I'm not sure that anything can predict it correctly." But he insisted that the Internet would "churn" the economy and produce a growth in sales, not just a shift from shopping in stores to shopping online.
For a moment on his campaign bus, he seemed to hedge on his pledge, saying that if there were an economic downturn "we may have to look at anything." Then he got back on message, saying, "But I certainly don't believe the Internet is the way to go." He scoffed at the concerns of governors saying, "Mind you, all these governors that don't want to do that are all running surpluses."
Mr. Bush's aides have been combing Mr. McCain's tax plan in search of debating points, and the governor accused the senator of including a hidden increase of $40 billion in his proposal because it would end certain deductions that employers can now take on tax-exempt benefits they give their workers.
"I don't agree with leaving money in Washington, D.C.," Mr. Bush said, "and I darned sure don't agree with saying that you're going to take $40 billion in employer-related benefits and have the people pay tax on them. I think that's a mistake."
The Bush campaign repeated the themes in a commercial that starts today in New Hampshire. While the commercial does not mention Mr. McCain by name, it is Mr. Bush's first one focusing on his leading rival's tax plan.
A spokesman for the McCain campaign called the advertisement a negative attack.
Mr. McCain said yesterday that the governor had repeatedly made accusations about his tax plan "that have proven to be false." He said his plan would close loopholes that allow corporations to deduct such benefits as golf club and spa memberships and parking and would not affect health and education benefits. His aides said the deductions were worth about $4 billion.
For his part, Mr. McCain repeatedly drew applause in Nashua, N.H., when he said his smaller tax cut would help the middle class while still allowing the government to devote much of the federal surplus to shoring up Social Security, Medicare and start retiring the $5.6 trillion national debt.
"I believe from a philosophical standpoint as families and as a nation that it is important for us when we go though bad times and accumulate debts," he said, "that in good times that we as families and responsible citizens repay those debts."
Mr. Bush's swing into New Hampshire was his last before devoting his attention to the Iowa caucuses on Monday.
Mr. McCain also left the state, arriving in New York City yesterday afternoon for three fund-raisers expected to raise about $300,000. The first was at the Luncheon Club on Wall Street. The two other receptions were being held by Edgar Bronfman Jr., the chief executive of Seagram and Michael Bloomberg, the media executive.

HEADLINE: U.S. Asking U.N. to Settle Aircraft NoiseDispute With Europe

BYLINE: By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18

 BODY:
The United States, deadlocked on another clangorous trade dispute with Europe, will ask the United Nations to resolve a battle over aircraft noise that Washington says has already cost American companies $2 billion.
The Clinton administration said today that it would file a complaint with the International Civil Aviation Organization, a United Nations specialized agency that sets global aviation standards. It will seek to force the Europeans to repeal a regulation banning aircraft powered by engines they deem too loud or polluting. The appeal follows a breakdown in two-party talks between the United States and the European Union. 
 The regulations, adopted by the European Parliament last year but suspended pending talks with the United States, are to be enforced beginning May 4. They would crack down on planes that use engine mufflers known as "hush kits." The Europeans say the muffled engines still pollute more than new engines.
Congress and the aviation industry have put pressure on the administration to get the European rule overturned. Companies including Federal Express, United Technologies and Northwest Airlines have complained about lost sales and a plunge in the resale value of older planes after the Europeans adopted the regulation.
The House responded last March with a resolution that would ban the Concorde, the supersonic showcase of British Airways and Air France, from landing at United States airports. That has not become law, but the Clinton administration says it shows how the engine dispute could spiral into a larger trade war unless it is resolved soon.
"We have to defend our interests now," Commerce Secretary William M. Daley said in describing why Washington decided to take the case to the aviation organization. "We all want more quiet aircraft," he said, "but we are not going to let Europe set the standards unilaterally."
Though the United States and Europe trade more than $300 billion in goods annually, they often seem more like adversaries than commercial partners. The two have feuded over steel, farm subsidies, genetically modified goods, enforcement of trade laws and a variety of other things. Last year, the Clinton administration imposed tariffs on Louis Vuitton handbags, pecorino cheese, Scottish cashmere and other luxury goods because the European Union would not change its rules for importing bananas.
Tension between the two economic blocs also took center stage at the Seattle trade meeting a month and a half ago. The inability of the United States and Europe to agree on an agenda for moving trade talks forward was one of the main reasons the talks broke down.
The aircraft dispute also resonates on both sides of the Atlantic. The United States maintains that the European rule focuses narrowly on certain aircraft engines, including many used on older Boeing 727 and DC-9 jets that are prevalent in American fleets but not widely used in Europe.
The European rule, if enforced, would also demolish the market for hush kits used to bring older aircraft into compliance with recent noise regulations, industry experts say. Pratt & Whitney, the aircraft engine subsidiary of United Technologies, is a leading manufacturer of the kits.
The Commerce Department estimates the European rule costs American companies $2 billion, including $1 billion in lost sales of kits and $1 billion in diminished market value of older aircraft, some of which might have otherwise been sold to European airlines.
European officials said the rule protects people who live near the region's congested urban airports and does not discriminate against American aircraft.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Investors Buy High Technology and Shun the Blue Chips

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Stocks were mixed yesterday as investors took profits out of blue-chips even as they continued to plow money into high-technology shares.
The divergent patterns in stocks occurred against a backdrop of rising interest rates, which moved to their highest level in two and a half years. For the first time since 1994, yields on the Treasury's 10-year notes briefly climbed above the yield on benchmark 30-year bonds. By late in the day, both securities were quoted at a price that yielded 6.75 percent. The yield of the 30-year bond was up from 6.69 percent Friday. The 30-year Treasury bond fell 22/32, to 92 3/32. 
 Led by Microsoft, which reported better-than-expected second-quarter profit after the close of trading, the Nasdaq composite index narrowly missed setting a record.
The index gained 66.54 points yesterday, or 1.64 percent, to 4,130.81, just below the Jan. 3 record of 4,131.15.
But investors turned their backs on most of the stocks that make up the Dow Jones industrial average.
The Dow, which set records Thursday and Friday, fell 162.26 points, a drop of 1.38 percent, to 11,560.72. Only 8 of the 30 stocks that make up the index gained in price. Financial service company stocks led the decline.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 10.01 points, or 0.68 percent, to 1,455.14.
The small-cap Russell 2000 index bucked the trend, and maintained its status as the best-performing major market index so far this year. The Russell rose 5.90 yesterday, or 1.2 percent, to 513.46.
"The underpinnings for strength in the market are still there," said Michael Clark, head of United States stock trading at Credit Suisse First Boston.
"But we are going to be in a trading range for the next six to eight weeks, due to worries about the Federal Reserve and a relentless supply of new and secondary stock issues. There is not much reason to take stocks higher until we get a new perspective on how higher rates will impact earnings this year."
Jeffrey Applegate, chief investment strategist at Lehman Brothers, said yesterday that earnings would remain strong this year and that he expected high-flying technology stocks to retain their position as market leaders.
Bond market analysts said the brief inversion between 10-year and 30-year Treasury securities was largely because of technical factors. But there is a broad consensus that the Federal Reserve will be pushing up short-term interest rates very soon.
"The market has built in a half-point increase, whether it comes in one or two moves" by the Fed, said Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management. "If after doing that the economy shows no signs of slowing, they will tighten again."
Members of the Fed's policy-making Open Market Committee are seen as likely to approve a rate increase when they meet Feb. 1 and 2.
For the most part, fourth-quarter earnings reports are living up to forecasts, and in many cases are exceeding expectations. Still, a number of stocks were punished yesterday after reporting strong numbers.
J. P. Morgan, a Dow component, was a case in point. The stock fell 4 11/16 to 123 5/16, even though the big financial services company's fourth-quarter results were better than Wall Street had forecast.
Citigroup, which also posted better- than-expected earnings, was also punished, but not so severely: the stock closed at 57 15/16, down 1/16.
Microsoft was one of the few Dow stocks to show life yesterday, jumping 3 1/16 to 115 5/16 on the expectation that its second-quarter results would be strong.
The software giant did better than consensus estimates, reporting second-quarter earnings of 44 cents a share, compared with an average estimate of 42 cents a share.
Still, the gains were below the 49 cent-a-share "whisper" estimate. In after-hours trading, Microsoft gave up all of its gains and more. Late yesterday the stock was quoted at 112, down 3 5/16.
And Motorola, whose shares rose sharply on Friday on expectations of strong fourth-quarter results, saw investors take much of those gains back yesterday after its numbers failed to meet the rosiest forecasts.
The stock fell 6 3/4, to 144 1/4.

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
New Owner Is Playing An Old Game

BYLINE: By HARVEY ARATON 

 BODY:
NO news was Wood news yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria, where Robert Wood Johnson IV announced that the Jets would remain in a holding pattern on the subjects of the former and possibly future Coach Bill Parcells (until the weekend) and a new stadium (presumably not until 2008).
But along with four AA batteries, Mr. Woody (I am not sure if he prefers his intimate tabloid designation or a more formal appellation, such as did the late Mr. Hess) made it very clear that he is hoping his $635 million toy comes equipped with each. "The Jets have never had their own stadium," Mr. Woody said, without mentioning what he might contribute to help them get one. "They have been in the Mets stadium and now this, since 1984. Every game they played for the last 39-plus years have been away games. They have never had the home-field advantage, so to speak." 
 Is that right? Then why is it that the new owner, despite longstanding connections to the Hess family, not to mention the Johnson & Johnson family fortune, said that Jets' season tickets have been "impossible" for a longtime fan such as himself to obtain?
That's because Jets games have been sold out for years, with a long waiting list of wishful thinkers. These tickets have been purchased by people presumably rooting for the Jets on the days Giants Stadium dresses up in green.
Let's make one thing clear, before the Mayor of New York begins his usual act of supplication, and starts whistling in the West Side wind, bidding taxpayer money against no one. The Jets have not been without a home-field advantage since Leon Hess moved them across the Hudson, while continuing to call them the New York Jets. What they have not had is a home-owner's advantage, the kind of profit-friendly lease arrangement that Hess never worried about because his original $250,000 investment had multiplied like an ant colony over the past three decades.
In a bidding frenzy against Charles Dolan, Mr. Woody emerged as the so-called winner last week in the Jets sweepstakes, paying hundreds of millions more than many industry analysts believed the Jets were worth. "I think," he argued yesterday, "it is worth what I paid for it."
Actually, it was not a very attractive deal, compared to more recent National Football League acquisitions in Washington and Cleveland, which came with sparkling new stadiums, and all the pricey operational amenities such as naming rights. Bill Parcells could promise to coach this team until the Guy in the Glass has a long, white beard, and the Jets would still require financing and land for a new home before they would be worth what Mr. Woody paid.
So here we go again, with another case of a very rich guy buying something terribly inflated and wasting precious little time before asserting that somewhere down the road, he will need bailing out. "Eight years from now, they will be playing somewhere else," Mr. Woody said of the Jets, a motion that was hip-hip-hoorayed by Paul Tagliabue, the N.F.L. commissioner, who rambled on about how a new facility "would energize the Jets' fans even more than they are energized."
The truth is, most Jets' fans wouldn't care if the team played on a landfill in Staten Island, as long as Parcells were still the coach.
Next season is what fans care about, and rightly so. Politicians should see the big picture. If I were negotiating for New York, I would tell Mr. Woody to take a number, and a comfortable seat in the waiting room. If we find a solution to the housing problems currently posed by the Yankees and the Mets, maybe we'll get around to you.
Fred Wilpon, the Mets' co-owner, yesterday threw out the possibility of Shea Stadium being done over for football, after a new baseball park rises next door. A fine idea, as long as the Jets offer to privately finance a healthy portion of the project.
New York shouldn't pay for what it doesn't need. Its economy seems to have survived quite nicely without a professional football team and the eight playing dates that come with it. All of Mr. Woody's Republican donation-making and name-dropping isn't going to make Christine Todd Whitman or any succeeding New Jersey governor throw up another football stadium. He has no leverage, so for what potential benefit other than trophy hunting should the city invest in a team that deserted it 16 years ago?
That was Hess, of course, but Hess's team is what Mr. Woody has bought. For $635 million, he gets the track record, the bad stadium lease and the opportunity to talk Parcells into keeping him company for another year or two. What a steal.
