HEADLINE: University, Mexico's Pride, Is Ravaged by Strike

BYLINE: By JULIA PRESTON 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Jan. 19

 BODY:
One of the first things the administrators of the national university here will have to do, if they ever get it back from student strikers who have occupied it for nine months, is to fumigate. Rats and bugs, even the odd scorpion, have run free on the leafy campus as it sits largely empty.
The battered look of the National Autonomous University of Mexico, with its walls tattooed in insurrectionist graffiti and its courtyards converted to tent camps for strikers, are only the most visible signs of deterioration during the months of paralysis. 
 Once a proud symbol of publicly financed education for the masses, this immense university -- with 275,000 students the largest in Latin America -- has suffered losses in students, research, finances and especially academic stature that it will probably never recoup.
The strike began last April as a limited student protest seeking to preserve free tuition and open admissions. But it soon exploded out of the control of the administrators, President Ernesto Zedillo and even the broad-based student organization that initiated it, crippling the school.
It has dragged on because of a tough, anarchic leftist movement that took control of the student revolt, akin to the radicalism that clashed with the police at the World Trade Organization meeting in Seattle last month. Its larger sworn enemy is the globally intertwined economy and the competitive, free-market policies that are changing Mexico.
The demand of the strikers for a free higher education for working-class children was not extreme. But they ran headlong into a new world and a new Mexico, where shrinking public spending can no longer promote social mobility through a huge and generous institution like the national university.
This week, the administration and the strikers are headed for a showdown. Dueling referendums will allow each side to gauge its support. A 48-hour vote organized by the students on their platform ended today. A separate "plebiscite" on a counterproposal by the university president, Juan Ramon de la Fuente, takes place Thursday.
The strike at the UNAM, as the university is known by its Spanish acronym, was begun April 22 by students who rejected a plan by its president at the time, Francisco Barnes de Castro, to raise tuition to about $75 a semester from a mere two cents.
The strikers also demanded that open admissions for all students from a number of public high schools, which had been canceled in 1995, be reinstated and that a general congress of faculty, students and workers be held to reorganize the university from top to bottom.
Along the way the strikers won battle after battle, and always came back asking for more. In June Mr. Barnes scrapped his tuition plan. In November he resigned in defeat. But the strikers pressed on.
On Jan. 5, Mr. de la Fuente, the former health minister who replaced Mr. Barnes, offered a plan that would suspend all tuition payments indefinitely, cancel most criminal charges brought against students protesters and open the general congress. Although Mr. de la Fuente had ceded practically every point, the strikers rejected his offer on the ground that it came from the administration, not from them.
President Zedillo, who once ran from government troops when he was a student protester during the uprising of 1968, considered sending the police to round up student leaders at several points, senior officials said. So far he has favored negotiations, fearing that any bloodshed would reawaken the trauma that still lingers from the government's brutal suppression of the students 32 years ago.
According to the treasurer of the university, Jose Manuel Covarrubias, the strike so far has cost it about $205 million, mainly in salaries paid to 30,000 teachers and 28,000 workers when no classes were under way on campus.
About half of all the scientific research in Mexico is done at the university, and with strikers camped out in the science department and many laboratories, it has been greatly impaired. Libraries and archives are barricaded shut. In the huge central campus vandalism and looting, probably by outsiders, has taken a toll the authorities will be able to calculate only after the strike ends.
Students have fled by the thousands to other universities, mostly outside of Mexico City. However, while at least 20,000 UNAM students supported the strike, more than 228,000 registered for classes last fall. Professors held classes in rented nooks, on athletic fields, even in their cars.
At the beginning the strike had broad student support. But as time wore on one faction, dubbed ultras by their fellow students, rose to dominate the movement.
Marathon verbal battles in the students' steering committee often raged for 24 hours and beyond. Once the ultras gained the upper hand they purged their opponents, sometimes in fistfights. At the height of the confrontation, protest leaders surrounded the stage where they presided with barbed wire to block dissenting students from storming it.
Sergio Humberto Abreu Cruz, 27, a political science student, was squarely behind the strike at first. His family's only income comes from the sale of pies baked by his mother. The $140-a-year fee the administration wanted to impose was going to drive him out of school.
But after Mr. Barnes withdrew his tuition plan, Mr. Abreu thought the strike should end.
"What the ultras' position came down to was that if the president says yes, we say no," Mr. Abreu said. "They wouldn't let me talk in meetings. They said my word was worthless. They banned me."
The strikers displayed the trappings of revolutionary Marxism, adorning their meetings with posters of Che Guevara, Stalin and Abimael Guzman, the imprisoned leader of the extremist Shining Path guerrillas in Peru.
But they know little about these men or their ideas. They are driven instead by the feeling of betrayal by the Mexican government, which has withdrawn its unconditional promise to educate them. They have a foreboding about their future in a tight and competitive economy where their first career step could well be unemployment. The vast university is their safe haven.
"This university gave me everything I am, my knowledge, my friends, my girlfriends," said Hugo, 20, a student on strike duty by the dry fountain in the center of the science complex. He withheld his last name, saying he feared that the police might come after him.
"It never asked me any questions about who I was," he said. "That's why we can't end the strike without winning all of our demands. The future of people like me in this university depends on it."
The movement was hard to bargain with because it was a many-headed body with arms in every one of more than 30 departments, schools and research institutes. When the new president, Mr. de la Fuente, agreed to talk with the strikers, they insisted on sending 120 delegates.
"Our leadership is horizontal," said Victor Barboza, 25, a music student. "Our movement is a chaos of ideas. We are looking for an anarchic utopia far away from any political theory. We want to practice pure democracy without any theories."
The movement fought even with those who initially supported it. Strikers had violent clashes with the press and fell out with the left-of-center city government.
One group of strikers assaulted a professor who tried to hold an open-air class outside the campus. A demonstration in front of the United States Embassy on Dec. 11 turned into a stone-throwing melee in which 98 strikers were arrested for property destruction. On Jan. 2 two students who were apparently trying to make small bombs were seriously injured when the explosive powder accidentally ignited.
The strikers also faced violence that reaffirmed their distrust of the authorities. Alejandro Echavarria, a political science student who was one of the strike's main strategists, said he was kidnapped and beaten by unknown captors.
At the recent meeting of the student strike council where the students rejected Mr. de la Fuente's proposal, they seemed not to have noticed that its terms meant they had won. Called for noon in a dim and chilly auditorium, the session finally got under way after dark and ended after dawn. The camraderie was strong, but one speaker after another denounced the president's offer as a plot to lull the strikers and prepare for police to storm the campus.
The strike has left many taxpayers disenchanted with the university, compounding Mr. de la Fuente's difficulties in retaining government support for the old university model.
"The society is doubting the university," Mr. de la Fuente said in an interview. "When the strike ends, we will have to prove to the public that it has not exhausted its usefulness."

HEADLINE: Fed to No Longer Adopt Policy Bias Toward Rates

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve said today that it had dropped its practice of adopting a policy bias toward raising or reducing interest rates, and that from now on it would signal its assessment of inflation risks through a formulaic public statement after each meeting.
The central bank said it was making the changes in response to "unanticipated confusion" among investors and economists over its previous practice, put into effect last spring, of disclosing whether it was formally leaning toward a shift in monetary policy. 
 Disclosing the bias was initially seen by the Fed as a way of transmitting to the financial markets its short- to medium-term outlook for the economy, and therefore reducing the risk that any change in monetary policy would destabilize the markets.
But in a number of cases last year, financial markets read too much into the announcements, sending stock and bond prices gyrating on the assumption that the Fed's policy stance implied a preordained outcome to the central bank's next policy-setting meeting.
As the problems became evident, Fed officials said last year that they would study how the disclosure policy -- adopted initially as part of a gradual effort to become less secretive -- might be changed to avoid knocking the markets off balance.
The solution announced today seeks to maintain continued public disclosure of the Fed's economic outlook without suggesting that a change in policy has been all but decided. It was developed by a working group headed by Roger W. Ferguson Jr., the Fed's vice chairman.
Under the new procedure, the Fed will make a public statement after every meeting of its Federal Open Market Committee. Under the old procedure, the Fed was committed to making a statement only in the event of a policy change or a major shift in its economic outlook.
The public statement will contain a passage setting out the Fed's assessment of the relative likelihood that inflation will increase or that the economy will become weaker over the subsequent several months. The Fed said the time frame covered by the statement was specifically intended to extend beyond the time of the next policy-setting meeting, and therefore not to imply that an immediate policy shift was a sure thing.
The statement would contain wording chosen from among three options. If the committee views the likelihood of growing inflation pressures to be equivalent to the risk of a slowing economy, the statement will state that the risks are "balanced with respect to prospects for both goals," the Fed said.
If the Fed is clearly more concerned that a strong economy might generate rising prices, the statement will state that the risks are "weighted mainly toward conditions that may generate heightened inflation pressures."
Should the Fed be concerned mainly that the economy is slowing to a rate below its capacity for noninflationary growth, the statement would read that the risks were "weighted mainly toward conditions that may generate economic weakness," the central bank said in a statement.
"A committee view that the risks are unbalanced would not necessarily trigger either a current or a subsequent policy move," the Fed said. "Given the inherent uncertainty about future developments, policy actions often importantly depend on the flow of new information and the committee's judgment about its implications."
Not only will there be no mention of a formal policy bias in the public statement, but the Fed will no longer vote on such a policy formulation and will not include any bias in the document it prepares at each meeting specifying how the Federal Reserve Bank of New York should carry out monetary policy through its open- market operations.
The bias was originally intended to suggest the direction that the Fed might move if it were to shift policy before the subsequent meeting, a rare event. The Fed said today that even though it was dropping the bias as a policy tool, it still had the ability to raise or reduce rates between meetings, though it stressed that it would do so only in "exceptional circumstances."

HEADLINE: Congress, Preoccupied by Elections, Shows Signs That Debt Reduction Will Be Its Main Goal

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19

 BODY:
As Congress prepares to convene for an election-year session likely to be distinguished by an even greater degree of partisanship than usual, the two parties seem headed toward deadlock on most issues other than dedicating the federal budget surplus to reducing the national debt.
Speaker J. Dennis Hastert of Illinois called on Republicans today to develop and enact a plan to pay off the main portion of the debt -- the $3.6 trillion in Treasury bonds owned by the public -- within 15 years. 
 In doing so, Mr. Hastert countered a similar initiative set out last year by President Clinton and illustrated again how both parties had found debt reduction to have a powerful appeal to voters.
Yet, among Republicans, the goal is as much to keep the growing federal budget surplus off limits to Democratic spending proposals as it is to reduce the debt. And among Democrats, dedicating much of the surplus to debt reduction is popular in part because it leaves that much less money on the table for Republican tax-cutting plans.
Some members of both parties are holding out hope that the budget surplus will be so big -- and that the political imperative to bring some concrete accomplishments home to voters will overcome the impulse to block the other side's agenda -- that there will be room for compromise on a variety of issues.
President Clinton is pushing big proposals to improve access to health care, add prescription drug coverage to Medicare and expand the tax credit for the working poor. Republicans plan to put forward a series of narrowly drawn but politically appealing tax cuts, and to try to complete work on a number of bills left over from last year.
"We're very confident this will be a year of legislative accomplishment," Joe Lockhart, the White House spokesman, said today.
But the Republican leadership is playing down expectations for any major legislation this year, hoping that they will be able to work with a Republican president a year from now. Moreover, they said, Congress will have relatively little time this year because members will spend extra time at home campaigning.
"Everybody needs to acknowledge and not apologize for the fact that it will be a shorter year," said Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the majority leader, referring to the truncated election-year schedule. "There won't be a lot of time for big, new initiatives."
To the degree the two sides thwart each other on other issues, they are that much more likely to fall back on eliminating the national debt held by the public as their major goal.
"By controlling spending and wisely investing our current tax surplus, it is my personal view that it is possible to reach this goal by the year 2015," Mr. Hastert said today in a speech in Albuquerque, N.M.
Mr. Hastert directed Representative John R. Kasich, Republican of Ohio, the chairman of the House Budget Committee, to produce a plan for debt reduction.
Mr. Kasich's goal, Republican aides said, is to make sure as much money as possible is locked away for debt reduction, while still leaving enough of the surplus available next year to enact the $483 billion, five-year tax cut proposed by Gov. George W. Bush of Texas if Mr. Bush should be elected president.
Mr. Clinton has made eliminating the debt by 2015 a central part of his economic policy, and Vice President Al Gore has put it at the heart of his presidential campaign.
But Republicans create a quandary for themselves in setting a goal of eliminating the debt by 2015. To do so would almost certainly require using all or nearly all of the portion of the projected surplus generated by excess Social Security revenues.
By using that money for the debt, Republicans would be unable to use it for another cherished goal, creating a system of private investment accounts within Social Security as a means of shoring up the retirement system's financial condition.
The Congressional Budget Office and the White House's Office of Management and Budget will publish new projections on the surplus in the next few weeks. Last year both agencies predicted that Social Security would generate $2 trillion in excess revenue over the next decade, while general tax revenues would exceed spending by $1 trillion.

HEADLINE: Growth in Unions' Membership in 1999 Was the Best in Two Decades

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
Union membership nationwide rose faster last year than at any time in the past two decades, a development that labor experts called the strongest sign yet that John J. Sweeney, the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s president, was succeeding in his efforts to reverse the labor movement's lengthy slide.
The Bureau of Labor Statistics announced yesterday that union membership climbed by 265,000 last year, to 16.5 million, with growth coming not just among government workers, but also in the private sector, where union membership has plunged in recent decades. 
 "It's quite significant," said Kent Wong, director of the Center for Labor Research and Education at the University of California at Los Angeles. "After a decline that had been continuing for several decades, the labor movement has finally begun to see a rise in union membership."
Labor leaders said the growth stemmed largely from stepped-up organizing efforts by individual unions. They said a secondary factor was that some growth in the unionized work force came about when unionized employers hired additional workers as the booming economy added 2.7 million jobs last year.
Even some fierce critics of unions acknowledged that last year's growth was impressive. Leo Troy, a Rutgers University economics professor who is writing a book he plans to call "The Twilight of Unionism," said: "My first reaction is it's definitely a surprise, and a positive step for organized labor. Whether it represents a real turnaround, we have to wait and see. What's the biggest surprise is it's the first increase in a long time in private-sector union membership, and that's very good news for the labor movement."
With union membership falling by one-fourth since 1980, Mr. Sweeney hailed the new numbers as showing that his push to get the nation's unions to devote more resources to recruitment was paying off.
"These numbers show we've gotten this train rolling, and it's picking up speed, but we're not at our destination yet," Mr. Sweeney said.
He noted that many workers who had long shunned unions were now seeking to join them to get more voice in their workplace, including doctors, software workers, graduate teaching assistants and even many workers in the anti-union South.
Mr. Sweeney said unions needed to show gains for several more years before labor began to regain some of the formidable strength it once had. In the 1950's, unions represented 35 percent of the nation's work force, but last year they represented just 13.9 percent -- a figure that remained unchanged from 1998.
Since Mr. Sweeney took the helm of the American Federation of Labor-Congress of Industrial Organizations in late 1995, he has not just increased labor's focus on organizing, but expanded its political clout by getting unions to devote more effort and money to electoral campaigns. Any future increases in union membership could further strengthen labor's influence in politics and collective bargaining.
Labor leaders pointed to several major victories in last year's efforts, among them organizing 74,000 home health aides in Los Angeles in the biggest successful organizing drive since the 1930's, and unionizing 5,200 Pillowtex-Cannon textile workers in North Carolina after nine decades of failed efforts.
In recent decades, union membership among government workers has soared as many state and city governments gave civil servants the right to join unions. At the same time, membership in the fast-growing private sector fell steadily as the nation's heavily unionized manufacturing sector shed jobs and as many companies battled organizing drives.
Mr. Sweeney said that in 1999 the nation's unions organized 600,000 additional workers, the most since the 1970's. But growth in labor's ranks was far smaller than that, union leaders explained, because of layoffs of unionized workers.
The Bureau of Labor Statistics said unions added 112,000 members in the private sector last year, the biggest increase in two decades. It reported that 9.4 million private-sector workers were unionized last year, representing 9.4 percent of the private-sector workforce. The bureau also found that 7.1 million government employees were unionized, 37.3 percent of public-sector employees.
The United Auto Workers has focused on organizing auto parts plants while construction unions have mounted their biggest efforts in decades to organize work sites.
"The private-sector growth is a clear sign that our efforts to think strategically and creatively are beginning to bear fruit," said Kirk Adams, the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s organizing director.
Mr. Adams announced last week that he would soon leave that post to take a job as a top assistant to the president of the Service Employees' union.
Many labor leaders cite the Service Employees International Union as a model for organizing. That union said it organized 155,000 workers last year, mostly health care workers, and said it spent $70 million on organizing, accounting for 47 percent of the union's budget.
Elaine Bernard, director of the Harvard University Trade Union Program, said the ambitious plans Mr. Sweeney announced in 1995 to expand labor's ranks seemed to be succeeding.
"You're turning an oil tanker around, and it takes a long time to turn it," Ms. Bernard said.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE REPUBLICANS;
McCain and Bush Find a Fight in the Details of a Tax Cut

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL with FRANK BRUNI 

DATELINE: BOSTON, Jan. 19

 BODY:
With The Republican battle over tax cuts escalating daily, Senator John McCain demanded today that Gov. George W. Bush stop running a commercial attacking his tax cut plan, while Bush advisers visited McCain headquarters to scrutinize his tax calculations.
Those were the highlights of a campaign day that veered from the serious to the surreal to the silly. 
 The commercial at the center of the controversy repeats the line of attack against Mr. McCain that Mr. Bush began on Saturday at the Des Moines debate when he asserted that one small aspect of Mr. McCain's tax-cut proposal, which would repeal tax exemptions for certain employer-provided fringe benefits, would in effect raise taxes by $40 billion and hurt working people.
Mr. McCain, who hopscotched from campaign events in New York to Hartford to Boston across the day, insisted that this was not true and called on Mr. Bush to stop running the commercial.
"It may be a sign of some desperation because they are looking at the same polls we are," he said of the Bush campaign. "They know it's inaccurate and we know it's inaccurate so it should be taken down." He also released a letter from outside fiscal experts to back his contention that his proposal would cost less than $4 billion and would affect employers, not employees.
But Mr. Bush, campaigning in New Hampshire, did not back down. "All I'm doing is talking about what he put down on paper," he said.
At a news conference at a high school in Plaistow, N.H., Mr. Bush also sought to raise doubts about Mr. McCain's grasp of domestic policy, saying, "If in fact he's changed his plan I look forward to seeing what the change is -- for the third or fourth time. I believe it's important when someone runs for president to lay out a plan that is consistent, that will stand the test of political scrutiny." He added, "That's what I've done. That's what a leader does."
The events capped a day that brought a sharp new tone of acrimony to the struggle for the Republican presidential nomination just before the Iowa caucuses and the New Hampshire primary. It narrowed the race to one issue: taxes and how best to cut them. In fact, there are large ideological differences behind the competing tax-cut policies of the two rivals who have emerged as the leading candidates in the Republican race.
Like his party's most avid tax-cutters, Mr. Bush has proposed a sweeping five-year, $485 billion tax cut that reduces tax rates across the board. Mr. McCain, betting that even Republican primary voters no longer favor tax cutting during prosperous times, has called for a tax cut of just under $240 billion to allow billions of dollars of the federal surplus to be devoted to Social Security, Medicare and reducing the national debt.
But the big ideas were not at the center of the debate. Instead, the Bush campaign has shifted the focus to a more arcane dispute. Mr. McCain included in his plan measures to close or eliminate corporate tax benefits worth more than $151 million over five years. And Mr. Bush picked one of these to fight over, the tax treatment of some fringe benefits -- how much money it would raise and who it would affect.
"What this is a sign of is an attempt to divert the debate from what it is really about," Mr. McCain said in New York City, "what do you do with the surplus." Later in the day, he said that Mr. Bush had reneged on their handshake agreement not to run negative ads. "I think it's a negative ad," Mr. McCain said carefully, "but I don't think it's an attack ad. That's parsing, I know."
The senator got some unlikely support from the Democratic National Committee, which said that Mr. Bush had "repeatedly whined" about attacks from Steve Forbes and was now using "the exact same type of attack on McCain."
Mr. McCain had left himself open to criticism that his numbers did not add up by providing little detail in his proposals. Mr. Bush's aides said that if Mr. McCain's fringe benefit proposal did not raise $40 billion, his plan would not work.
Mr. McCain says that education and health benefits were exempted and that the change would stop employers from deducting the costs of such things as golf clubs, spa memberships and parking.
Not only did Mr. Bush repeat his charges, he also pointedly used people from Mr. McCain's home state to amplify them. The campaign released attacks on the McCain plan by five Arizona state senators.
"Maybe if Senator McCain spent a little more time at home he would understand that we are not talking about country club memberships -- the government already taxes those -- but rather an education for a single mom or a life insurance policy for a hard-working father," said State Senator Rusty Bowers.
Perhaps the oddest political theater of the day came about after Rick Davis, Mr. McCain's campaign manager, told Karl Rove, the chief strategist for the Bush campaign, on "Good Morning, America" that the McCain campaign would be glad to answer any lingering questions the Bush camp had about his tax plan.
That resulted in two of Mr. Bush's tax advisers, Lawrence Lindsey and Representative Rob Portman of Ohio, traveling to Mr. McCain's national campaign headquarters in Alexandria, Va.
Dan Schnur, the McCain campaign spokesman, welcomed Mr. Lindsey and Mr. Portman with doughnuts and a sheaf of economic proposals, and he gave each of them a copy of Mr. McCain's autobiography. Mr. Lindsey and Representative Portman then argued in front of television cameras with Mr. Schnur and John Raidt, another McCain aide.

HEADLINE: A Tall Order On the Hudson;
Rural Area Looks Skeptically At Friary's Development Plans

BYLINE: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD 

DATELINE: GARRISON, N.Y., Jan. 14

 BODY:
For 70 years, the brothers and priests in training at the Mary Immaculate Friary of the Capuchin Order here lived an unremarkably quiet existence of prayer and Bible instruction on wooded grounds overlooking the Hudson River.
They volunteered with the local fire department. They opened their gymnasium to the 2,500 townsfolk. And on Sundays they fanned out to local parishes to help with Mass. But mostly the Capuchins (pronounced CAP-uh-chins) kept to their land, a 93-acre jewel hugging the eastern bank of the river 55 miles north of New York City. 
 So what are they doing at the center of a land dispute with such disparate if intriguing elements as West Point, land preservationists and Tibetan Buddhism -- all in the backdrop of the rustic hamlet Gov. George E. Pataki calls home?
It turns out that not even Capuchin-Franciscan friars can escape the emotions and controversy in New York City's exurbs when it comes to the prospect of commercial development, particularly one that would be among the largest ever built in Putnam County. There is little to do here but hike, and that is the way residents, many of them escapees from New York City and its suburbs, like it. Excitement? "If you want to do something around here you have to go to Peekskill or Poughkeepsie," one said, with pride in her voice.
And so, two years have passed since word got out that the Capuchins were selling to a developer, who has pitched the Town Board two proposals that would use 20 acres for the conversion of the gothic brick friary into a five-star hotel and the construction of retirement housing marketed to West Point alumni. The developer, Schwartzberg Associates of White Plains, has submitted the draft of its third proposal, each one scaled back to answer community resistance. The Town Board plans to discuss the latest proposal at a meeting next month.
The Rev. Anthony Vetrano, one of 3 friars still on grounds that in the early 1960's thrived with nearly 200, said all the order wanted to do was give up some unneeded land and make some sorely needed money in the process, to carry out its mission of helping the poor around the world. The Capuchins, who live at other seminaries in the area but still use the grounds for retreats and other activities, pay heating and insurance on buildings that have been empty for more than a decade, costing hundreds of thousands of dollars a year.
"We were look for something that was going to help the community," Father Vetrano said. "We wanted to be good stewards of the property."
The Capuchins put up "for sale" signs along Route 9D and in short order were negotiating with prospective bidders, including Harris Schwartzberg, a principal of Schwartzberg Associates who recalls being floored at the beauty of the 1928 friary and even more excited at its view of the United States Military Academy at West Point across the river.
On a recent blustery afternoon, Mr. Schwartzberg walked the grounds, the wind lending a ghostly air to the well-maintained but abandoned buildings. With the golden sunlight streaming into the main chapel of the friary, he looked around and spoke of the banquet hall he envisioned would take its place. The wings that give the friary its E shape would house 100 rooms.
Outside, a distance away, a "village" of 196 upscale housing units marketed to, but not exclusively for, military retirees would rise, about 100 of them "assisted living" apartments for people who do not need round-the-clock care but may need help taking medication or bathing. The regular housing, cottage-like town houses, would sell for more than $250,000, and the assisted living units would lease for $2,000 to $4,000 per month, Mr. Schwartzberg said.
The name: the Village and Lodge at Point Lookout.
The latest proposal, he said, reduces the housing units to 196 from the originally proposed 425. Mr. Schwartzberg said the changes were the "bottom line" to make the project economically feasible.
In all, Schwartzberg Associates would invest $40 million to $50 million, making the project the largest in recent memory in Putnam County, according to Ross Weale of the county's economic development office. Mr. Schwartberg said his accountants projected that the town could receive about $1 million a year in tax revenue.
But William Mazzuca, the town supervisor of Philipstown, of which Garrison is a hamlet, said that figure probably overstated things. Mr. Mazzuca said he had tried to be fair in a dispute that is turning nasty.
Mr. Schwartzberg has derided opponents as elitists bent on keeping out outsiders, especially those with lower incomes who would commute to Garrison for the 150 staff positions and 1,200 construction jobs the project would create. He said he and his associates had met repeatedly with environmentalists and town officials to hear their concerns and write the proposals in a way that would satisfy them.
The project would not be visible from the road -- no building will be taller than the five-story friary -- and it would use the existing water and sewer system, with some modifications, Mr. Schwartzberg said.
Mr. Schwartzberg said he was getting exasperated at the pace with which the town had considered the proposal and would not rule out filing a lawsuit if the board went against him. In an interview, he also suggested that if the board rejected his current proposal, his firm might still buy the land and then resell it to an unspecified Brooklyn college that has expressed interest in opening a campus upstate.
Opponents, in turn, accuse Mr. Schwartzberg of insensitivity toward the town's character and exaggerating the benefits of the project while playing down or misleading people on its effect on traffic, town services and the environment. Although the town may derive some property tax benefit, opponents say, much if not all of it would be eaten away by the need for more fire protection and other services.
Suzie Gilbert, a writer who moved here 10 years ago to escape the hassles of New York City, said Mr. Schwartzberg and his representatives had adopted a patronizing attitude toward residents, who fear that allowing this development will open the gates to the suburbanization of a rural community proudly lacking malls or fast-food restaurants.
"They have put this forward as a charitable thing," Ms. Gilbert said. "This is a very high-end development. It will destroy the town."
When news broke that the Capuchins rejected an offer from the not-for-profit Open Space Institute to buy the property for $5 million, many expressed vague feelings that there must be something more to the deal. Open Space said it would buy the property in conjunction with Jewel Heart, an organization based in Ann Arbor, Mich., that organizes retreats and spiritual gatherings for adherents of Tibetan Buddhism.
But the Capuchins said Schwartzberg presented a more attractive deal that included rebuilding the youth and family ministry building on another parcel the order owns down the road, and honoring the history of the friars by opening a museum in the hotel and producing a documentary on the order. If the development is approved, the Capuchins would live in the new ministry building.
Both sides of the dispute have invoked the name of Mr. Pataki, who has spoken both of the need for more housing for retirees and the need to preserve open space. A spokesman, Michael McKeon, said "the governor's interest in protecting open space and protecting the quality of life in the Hudson Valley is well known and speaks for itself."
"But the governor does not believe it would be appropriate to weigh in on this project," Mr. McKeon added. "It's best for the locals to resolve."
(Democrats hold a four-to-one advantage on the town board, an anomaly in predominantly Republican Putnam County.)
West Point graduates have responded strongly to the idea.
Paul Bucha, a 1965 graduate of the academy and president of the Congressional Medal of Honor Society, said he had spoken to scores of graduates who would love to retire in the shadow of the academy to which they maintain strong emotional bonds.
"There is a mountain of West Point interest," said Mr. Bucha, who lives in nearby Somers and considers himself a friend of the environment who finds no harm in this project. "All you have to do is go to a West Point football game in the fall or a parade in the spring and ask the retirees if they would like access to a house with a view of West Point."
What chance they get depends on the five-member Town Board. Mr. Mazzuca said he and the other members would carefully review the proposal, but he did not have high hopes it would eventually pass. Either way, he said, the town is likely to face a lawsuit, something he hopes to avoid.
"I have never seen anything quite like this," said Mr. Mazzuca, 53, who grew up in and around Philipstown. "I thought the cell phone towers were a major issue. This is really something to behold."

HEADLINE: The Neediest Cases;
A Young Girl's Smile Is Undiminished by a Serious Affliction

BYLINE: By AARON DONOVAN 

 BODY:
Gertrude Atkinson's baby appeared normal, though she was underweight -- just 4 pounds 12 ounces when she was born -- and threw up nearly every day.
"There was no explanation," Ms. Atkinson said. "My obstetrician said I wasn't feeding her enough." 
 In fact, Ms. Atkinson's daughter, Jennifer, had a rare and incurable genetic disorder called Cornelia de Lange Syndrome, which is identified by a number of symptoms that can include mental retardation, low weight and height, and difficulty eating.
Though the syndrome is genetic, it is rarely passed directly from one generation to the next, Ms. Atkinson said. It is almost always caused by a randomly occurring genetic mutation that is believed to occur in 1 out of every 10,000 to 30,000 live births, according medical experts. No test can determine whether a person has the syndrome, but it is diagnosed when a person demonstrates a number of its characteristics. Cornelia de Lange was a Dutch pediatrician who was among the first to notice the symptoms.
Ms. Atkinson, who was a medical research technician for nine years at Mount Sinai Medical Center, said she never suspected what was wrong with her daughter until she discovered it on her own in May 1998.
She would spend hours after work pouring over medical documents and books, hoping to find symptoms similar to her daughter's.
"I felt a bit like a fiend or a weirdo," Ms. Atkinson said. When she finally found something that looked similar, at first she felt sadness, she said. "I said, it just couldn't be so, but it looked a lot like her."
Jennifer, now 14, is 4-foot-8 and weighs 71 pounds. She lives with her mother and her 16-year-old sister, Gertrude, in their two-bedroom apartment near Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx. Her head and hands are smaller than those of most people her age. Though she is aware of what is going on around her, and responsive in nonverbal ways, she rarely speaks.
To find out more about the syndrome, Ms. Atkinson contacted the Cornelia de Lange Syndrome Foundation, which is based in Avon, Connecticut, and learned that a conference in Dallas was scheduled in June 1999 for the parents and families of those afflicted with the disease.
Ms. Atkinson, a single mother of two who earned about $34,000 a year and had to pay for afterschool daycare for Jennifer, desperately wanted to attend the conference but did not have enough money to pay for it, she said. So she contacted the Community Service Society of New York, one of the seven local charities supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, which had helped her earlier by paying for Jennifer to attend summer camp.
"This was kind of a unique request that came to us," said Sanford Lewis, Ms. Atkinson's case worker. "I could just tell by talking to Ms. Atkinson that this would be a tremendous benefit."
The society paid $840 in air fare for Ms. Atkinson and her two daughters to fly to Dallas and attend the three-day conference. While there, Jennifer was treated by the world's foremost experts in the syndrome, and her mother made lifelong contacts with parents of other children with the syndrome from around the world.
"I'm a single mother, living in one of the most expensive places in the world," Ms. Atkinson said. " Taking a trip like that was not possible for me."
Ms. Atkinson said she was given peace of mind knowing that experts were studying Jennifer's condition, and concluded that her case was relatively mild. "It took a lot of anxiety away," she said, "and also just to have met the doctor firsthand, who has seen hundreds of children with the syndrome, it made me feel more sure that that's what she had after all."
Most children who have the syndrome die by age 6, and many of those who live beyond that have physical deformities. The only medication Jennifer takes is a double dose prescription of Pepsid, which helps her digest her food.
Ms. Atkinson, 43, who has a bachelor's degree in biology and psychology from Fordham University, was laid off from her job in September. She said she was collecting unemployment benefits but wanted to get back into the workforce to ensure that her daughters get the best care they can.
She said finding a job now was much harder than it was when she was a recent college graduate. But she would do whatever it takes to support her children, she said, including leaving her profession in the sciences.
Jennifer smiles so easily and warmly that the foundation chose to use her portrait in literature it published about the syndrome.
"They said she would make a good model," Ms. Atkinson said, looking at her daughter.
Jennifer looked into her mother's eyes, and then looked about the room and just smiled at the compliment.

F.C.C. Plans to Authorize Low-Power Radio Stations
Moving to open the radio airwaves to hundreds of small broadcasters, the federal government is planning to approve rules to allow educational, religious and community groups to run inexpensive, low-power FM radio stations. 
 Government officials say the rules, proposed a year ago, hold great promise to transform the airwaves at a time when the rise of broadcasting conglomerates has sharply reduced the diversity of voices. Page A1.
 
Apple Profits Increase 20 Percent
Apple Computer said its earnings rose 20 percent, to $183 million, or $1.03 a diluted share, surpassing analysts' estimates. Apple's board thanked its chief executive, Steven P. Jobs, who has been working for $1 a year, by giving him a $45 million Gulfstream V jet and options for 10 million Apple shares. Shares of Apple rose $2.625, to $106.5625. C8.
 
Nasdaq Up Again as Blue Chips Fade
Stocks were mixed as the Nasdaq set another new high for the year, but blue chips fell. The Nasdaq composite average gained 20.48 points, to 4,151.29, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was up 0.76 point, to 1,455.90. The Dow Jones industrial average declined 71.36 points, to 11,489.36. C15.
 
Home Building Rose in December
Construction of new housing rose 7.1 percent in December, closing the best year for housing since 1986. In a separate report, the Federal Reserve said its latest "beige book" review of the economy showed strong business activity throughout the country. C8.
 
A Gift for Reading from Barksdale
Continuing a surge in Internet philanthropy, James L. Barksdale, the former president of Netscape Communications, and his wife, Sally, plan to give $100 million to promote the teaching of reading in their home state of Mississippi, which suffers from the nation's lowest literacy rates. A13.
 
The Advertising Woman of the Year
Abby Kohnstamm, a senior vice president and a member of the executive committee at I.B.M., is one of the few women to reach the higher echelon's of corporate America. Ms. Kohnstamm, who oversees a $1 billion ad and marketing budget, is being named the Advertising Woman of The Year by Advertising Women of New York. Advertising. C13.
 
America Online Doubles Its Income
America Online said its profit more than doubled, to $271 million, or 10 cents a share, beating analysts' forecasts of 8 cents and matching the whisper number. C2.
 
I.B.M. earnings fell 11 percent, but Wall Street had expected even worse and the company's stock moved up to more than $120 in after-hours trading. C2.
 
Changes in Zuckerman's Empire
Mortimer B. Zuckerman and Fred Drasner have made changes at The Daily News and other publications. B14.
 
Suitors for South Korea Automakers
Two insolvent South Korean automakers that spent the 1990's building costly factories, running them inefficiently and wrecking their balance sheets with enormous debts have emerged as sought-after acquisition targets in the latest round of consolidation in the global auto industry. C4.
 
Rosenthal Joining The Daily News
A. M. Rosenthal, who left The New York Times last November after 55 years as a reporter, foreign correspondent, editor and columnist, will be writing a column for The Daily News starting next month. B3.

SECTION: Section A; Page 18; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 517 words

HEADLINE: Helmut Kohl, Humbled

 BODY:
Former Chancellor Helmut Kohl's resignation as honorary chairman of his beloved Christian Democrats was forced on him by his own embattled proteges. But it will not stop the unraveling of his own reputation or that of his party. By defiantly flouting his legal obligation to reveal the names of donors to a secret campaign fund, Mr. Kohl compounds the damage he has already caused.
For 16 years Mr. Kohl dominated German politics. He guided the peaceful reunification of his country, helped fashion the political framework for a united Europe and led the way to economic cooperation on the Continent and the adoption of a common currency. But his admission that for years he operated a system of secret accounts to handle undeclared cash donations to his party has dealt a heavy blow to his formidable reputation. Now it threatens to consume the party as well. 
 Prosecutors in Bonn last month opened a preliminary criminal investigation of Mr. Kohl, who has acknowledged that he received more than $1 million in undisclosed political contributions while in office. The former chancellor had stunned Germans in November when he admitted, after previous denials, that he had used illegal bank accounts to channel secret political contributions to local branches of his party. But he has refused to disclose the names of the contributors, citing his "word of honor" not to do so. Mr. Kohl's image as a statesman is rapidly degenerating into that of a corrupt and arrogant machine boss.
The Kohl affair is a reminder that the United States is not the only advanced democracy where the insatiable demands of campaign finance threaten to undermine democracy. Since the reckless fund-raising of the 1996 American presidential campaign, France, Spain, Italy and Britain have all been rocked by fund-raising scandals. It is troubling that this huge scandal is occurring in Germany, which has the most generous system of state financing of political parties in the world -- a result of similar scandals in the 1980's. Clearly, public financing of elections has to be linked to vigorous enforcement.
The current scandal grew out of a public prosecutor's investigation into cash payments of a half-million dollars to party officials linked to an arms export deal with Saudi Arabia. Party officials also allegedly received large sums of money from a French oil company that took over a chemical plant in eastern Germany in 1992.
The widening investigation has exposed extensive deceit in the upper reaches of Mr. Kohl's party. Last week his protege and successor as party leader, Wolfgang Schauble, admitted accepting $52,000 in cash from the same fugitive arms broker who gave secret donations to Mr. Kohl's intermediaries. And yesterday the party said that $4.5 million more in apparently illicit funds had been uncovered. Nobody has yet alleged that the former chancellor benefited personally from secret accounts. But he must not be allowed to hide behind his stature as a statesman. If Mr. Kohl is to salvage his diminished reputation -- and his party's -- he should disclose what he knows.

HEADLINE: PRO BASKETBALL;
A Newcomer Hits Washington

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19

 BODY:
The grand entrance amounted to the capital city's biggest executive deal since the impeachment of President Clinton.
"I have an attitude about the way I win," Michael Jordan said as he took over as president of basketball operations for the struggling Washington Wizards, gleaming with the sort of self-confidence that most politicians can only envy or feign. 
 As Jordan waxed inspirational about "the beauty of trying," the occasion, crammed with more than 35 television cameras and an international press corps, offered the aura of an inaugural, providing this scandal-tattered city a spiritual lift that spread far beyond basketball.
Mayor Anthony Williams was at Jordan's side, emphasizing the civic boost.
"Not just snowstorms, but good things blow in from Chicago," the mayor gratefully declared as the news delighted neighborhoods far and wide where basketball has long been the ultimate street game.
"Michael's coming here, and that's just explosive for this city," said Terence Hobbs, a Jordan wannabe since his grade school labors at backing into imaginary defenders for his version of the 180-turnaround fall-away jump shot that became part of the Jordan signature of pre-eminent success in much more than basketball.
"I'm still doing Mike's stuff," said Hobbs, a 20-year-old point guard on his church league team, the Scripture Cathedral Knights.
"I'll be doing Mike's stuff in Saturday's game," he said, as if Jordan were coming to personally look over his shoulder, not just the collective shoulders of the sagging Wizards.
The city's exuberance at the news that Washington had landed the legendary competitor was no less intense in the downtown office warrens.
"Sports always seems to unite this city and its people of all colors and all backgrounds," said Jimmy Dickson, a building manager two blocks from the White House.
Far more than a mere sports world bulletin, Dickson took the news as a fresh touch of class for the city.
"Imagine a scene where the Russian ambassador gets introduced to Michael Jordan!" he said, fantasizing a new world order.
"Michael's right for this city," he added, grinning happily across a desktop bowl of candy for all the bike messengers who come and go through the day, talking with Dickson of the resilient Redskins, the sorry Wizards and the power of Michael.
"All rise!" someone joked at the MCI Center news conference at premature word of Jordan's advent, as if Chief Justice William Rehnquist were doubling back on some unfinished bit of impeachment.
North of the city's official downtown capital, Tony Mallara hailed the news on Sixth Street with a grin and a pantomime of a Jordan dunk shot. "Mike is ballet; he thinks he can fly and so he can," the 24-year-old pickup player said. "Mike teaches attitude, you know what I'm saying? He is from the heart and we want to see him strong in D.C., talking with the kids and opening a job fair."
Television stations went live to the news conference, as if still another House Speaker were resigning in the face of peccadilloes. Official Washington paused as Jordan was introduced to this city as "the best winner in the world" and "the guy who refuses to lose."
"I used to shoot a basketball through a rim pretty decent," Jordan said as he faced a mob of capital news media and carefully showed the successful candidate's talent for keeping initial expectations within bounds.
At Scripture Cathedral, Bishop Clarence Long, the senior pastor and chief spiritual strategist of the Knights church team, watched the Jordan arrival with open joy.
"This is one of the greatest things that ever happened to D.C.," he said, speaking from 40 years as a neighborhood shepherd. "Michael will bring a lot of excitement to this town. And I'm hoping he will do something special for our youth. I'm talking about 300 to 400 young people, 18 to 30 years of age, in our neighborhood alone. The economic boom has not been grabbing them."
To the side, Bishop Long's son, Ed, grumbled more about the losing state of the Wizards. "They need something," he said, openly wondering whether Jordan might not be miracle enough at the rate the league's better teams have been feeding on the Wizards. "The games lately, I just turn them off. I'd rather watch cartoons."
Bishop Long, entirely up to speed on the street speculation about Jordan making an early deal to send Rod Strickland to the Knicks, cautioned his son against underestimating one of life's true spiritual leaders.
"I think Mike's success will happen instantly," the bishop said.
Then he raised the possibility of the Long family going to a Wizards game some time soon.
"No one else can do it like Mike," he said.

HEADLINE: Ex-Official of Netscape Starts $100 Million Drive for Literacy

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK 

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Jan. 19

 BODY:
Continuing a surge in Internet philanthropy, James L. Barksdale, the former president of the Netscape Communications Corporation, and his wife, Sally, plan to give $100 million to promote the teaching of reading in their home state, Mississippi, which has the nation's lowest literacy rates.
The gift, which the Barksdales will announce on Thursday, is thought by authorities on philanthropy to be by far the largest ever made in the field of literacy. Because the donation will establish an institute at the University of Mississippi, it is also one of the five largest donations by a private individual or foundation to a public university, according to rankings maintained by The Chronicle of Higher Education. The Barksdales are graduates of the University of Mississippi. 
 The Barksdales' gift will transfer some of the immense wealth being generated in Silicon Valley to a region that has largely been left behind by the vibrant new economy of the information age. And it will seek to redress the persistent failure of government to overcome the poverty and racial inequity that have led to decades of social and economic stagnation in Mississippi.
The gift places Mr. Barksdale, who is 56, in the company of a growing number of technology entrepreneurs and financiers who are embracing philanthropy at a relatively young age. The group is led by the Microsoft Corporation chairman William H. Gates, 44, the world's richest man and the benefactor of a $17 billion charitable foundation. It also includes Jim Clark, 55, the founder of Netscape; Steve Kirsch, 43, the founder of Infoseek, and Jeff Skoll, 34, the founder of eBay.
The Barksdales' money will create an endowment that will finance a variety of reading programs for Mississippi children in kindergarten through third grade. It will provide intensive training in reading education to current and aspiring elementary school teachers at universities around the state. It will also be used to provide special help to underachieving students in the state's most needy schools, often by holding classes after school, by offering summer classes and by training parents in reading instruction.
In addition, proceeds from the endowment will enable elementary schools to buy books, software and instructional materials for several proven reading programs. Within five years, 200 of the state's 521 elementary schools are expected to benefit from the money, said Dr. Richard L. Thompson, Mississippi's superintendent of education.
"This really is an incredible shot of adrenaline for our state," said Dr. Thompson, who noted that the state did not have compulsory school attendance or publicly financed kindergarten until 1985. "This is going to give us hope for that jump start where we can make an incredible amount of improvement."
Mr. Barksdale, a native of Jackson, Miss., said in a telephone interview that he hoped his gift would inspire philanthropic efforts to create similar programs elsewhere.
Mr. Barksdale, who characterized his net worth as "north of $700 million," said he and his wife, who have three children, planned to donate all their wealth, adding, "When we die, if there's a dollar left it's because I've miscalculated."
The Barksdales have been generous contributors to the University of Mississippi in recent years. In 1996, they gave $5.4 million to start an undergraduate honors college at the main Oxford campus. Last year, they gave $2 million for scholarships to blacks attending the university's medical school. The literacy gift, however, will be the largest ever given by the Barksdales and the largest ever received by the university.
"What makes me tear up," said Robert C. Khayat, the university's chancellor, "is that this really does address one of the major challenges we face as a society, and that's what higher education should be doing and what private wealth should be doing. My sense is that the measure of wealth is moving from how much is a person worth to how much does a person give."
Mr. Barksdale made most of his money last year when Netscape, the maker of the Internet browser, was sold to America Online. He had held top jobs at Federal Express and McCaw Cellular Communications.
After enjoying remarkable growth in the mid-1990's, Netscape faltered in its competition with Microsoft, making it an appealing target for acquisition. It was Mr. Barksdale's Netscape that first petitioned the Justice Department in 1996 to investigate whether Microsoft had created an illegal monopoly by packaging its own browser for free with its Windows software. Last year, a federal judge issued a preliminary ruling against Microsoft after a lengthy trial in which Mr. Barksdale was the government's lead witness.
Mr. Barksdale now works from his home in Aspen, Colo., helping to manage a new California venture capital firm that invests in Internet projects. The Barksdales, who have three children, are building a house in Jackson, Miss.
Like many counterparts in the technology sector, Mr. Barksdale became deeply concerned about the country's schools after struggling to find qualified workers for his companies. . "Our core problem with our children learning," he said, "is that they don't know how to read. That's true all over the country."
The literacy problem in Mississippi is stunning even to state officials. A 1998 study conducted for the National Institute for Literacy concluded that 30 percent of the state's population, age 16 and above, would have significant difficulty locating an intersection on a street map, filling out a Social Security card application or finding two pieces of information in a sports article.
That rate was the highest for any state of what the study classified as Level 1 literacy, the lowest of five possible levels. An additional 34 percent were classified as Level 2, with just marginally higher skills.

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Landmark to Be Repaired

BYLINE: AP 

 BODY:
A developer has signed an agreement to renovate part of the abandoned G. Fox building, one of Hartford's best-known structures and a symbol of the city's economic plight.
The developer, 960 Main L.L.C., made a $425,000 purchase deposit to the city on Tuesday and committed to the state to do the renovations, removing what appears to be the last obstacle to Capital Community College's relocating from the West End to the G. Fox building, said Chuck Sheehan, deputy commissioner of the State Department of Public Works. 
 The developer still has to sign a contract with the city to buy the rear 60 percent of the building, but Kevin Dubay, Hartford's corporation counsel, said he expected both sides to sign it within days.
Mr. Sheehan said the agreements meant that the college project was on schedule for a fall 2001 opening on Main Street.
The city, which took ownership of the old department store after it closed early in 1993, has been eager to find a private buyer.

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
State's Jobless Rate Drops

BYLINE: AP 

 BODY:
New Jersey's unemployment rate dipped to 4.1 percent in December, from 4.4 percent in November, capping a year in which the rate never topped 5 percent, the State Labor Department reported on Tuesday.
The December rate matched the 4.1 percent national unemployment rate, a goal Gov. Christine Todd Whitman had set. It also matched February for the lowest rate of 1999. Before that, New Jersey unemployment had not dipped to that level since July 1989. 
 State employers also added 9,400 jobs to their payrolls in December, seasonally adjusted, making it the year's best month for job growth. That brought the total number of new jobs last year to 65,300, a strong figure but still below the 76,200 created in 1998.
Of the 65,300 increase in jobs for 1999, 36,100 -- about 55 percent -- were in the generally lower-paying service sector.

HEADLINE: Canada's Full Hospitals

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Your Jan. 16 news article about Canada's overflowing hospitals suggests that the problem could be cured simply by spending more money on health care. If, like Americans, Canadians devoted 14 percent rather than 9.5 percent of their gross domestic product to health care, they could have anything Americans have in health care, and more. 
 One must wonder, though, whether Canadians are making good use of the hospital beds they have. Roughly 12 percent of the population in Canada and in the United States are hospitalized every year. Canadian patients, however, stay in the hospital much longer per admission (12 days in Canada versus 7.8 in the United States). A first step toward ridding the Canadian hospitals' hallways of waiting patients might be to use the existing bed-capacity more smartly.
UWE E. REINHARDT
Princeton, N.J., Jan. 16, 2000
 
The writer is a professor of economics at Princeton University. 
http://www.nytimes.com
