HEADLINE: MOVIE GUIDE

 BODY:

Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on Page 10.
 
Now Playing
 
* "AMERICAN BEAUTY," starring Kevin Spacey, Annette Bening, Chris Cooper, Wes Bentley and Thora Birch. Written by Alan Ball. Directed by Sam Mendes (R, 116 minutes). With heavenly finesse Mr. Spacey plays a buttoned-down 42-year-old suburbanite who flips his lid for a teenage cheerleader. And he never gets it back on. The midlife crisis motif is familiar, but the stage director Sam Mendes brings terrific visual flair and dry humor to this barbecuing of the bourgeoisie. All the actors display coolly expert timing, especially Ms. Bening as the antihero's grasping wife. Although the story spreads itself thin among many characters, the film coalesces for a devastating finale (Janet Maslin). 

"ANGELA'S ASHES," starring Emily Watson, Robert Carlyle, Joe Breen, Ciaran Owens and Michael Legge. Directed by Alan Parker (R, 120 minutes). Anyone who thinks poverty is not pretty would have to think twice after seeing this artfully desolate-looking film version of Frank McCourt's boyhood memoir. The movie describes dire suffering alongside inspiring, uplifting episodes. Directed reverently by Mr. Parker, it parades forth a series of familiar anecdotes from Mr. McCourt's book without taking on much weight. This is the kind of film about hardship in which nobody has indoor plumbing, but everybody has clean hair (Maslin).
 
* "ANY GIVEN SUNDAY," starring Al Pacino, Cameron Diaz, Dennis Quaid, James Woods and Jamie Foxx. Directed by Oliver Stone (R, 160 minutes). Mr. Stone's brawling, hyper-macho professional football film has enough in-the-thick-of-it playing-field action to satisfy the fantasies of most armchair players. In the style of Mr. Stone's "Wall Street," the movie is also a crude morality play that pits the old ways against the new with the veteran coach Tony D'Amato (Mr. Pacino) embodying tradition and a young hotshot quarterback, Willie Beamen (Mr. Foxx), the new. Although the acting is uneven (Ms. Diaz is disappointing as a tough team owner), and the final scenes are shamelessly "Rocky"-ish, the movie delivers a credible, action-charged vision of the frenzied world of professional sports as a metaphor for the volatility of American culture (Stephen Holden).
 
"BICENTENNIAL MAN," starring Robin Williams, Embeth Davidtz, Sam Neill and Oliver Platt. Directed by Chris Columbus (PG, 132 minutes). This gushy Robin Williams star vehicle follows the 200-year quest of a household robot named Andrew to become human. Directed by the schmaltzmeister Chris Columbus, who steered this star through "Mrs. Doubtfire," the movie is a joke-strewn, sentimental man-machine allegory determined to make us feel good about being human. Corny speeches exalting freedom, the joys of sex and the mystery of mortality punctuate the tale. Except for Mr. Williams, the acting is strictly of sitcom caliber (Holden).
 
* "BOYS DON'T CRY," starring Hilary Swank and Chloe Sevigny. Directed by Kimberly Peirce (R, 114 minutes). This stunning debut feature tells the strange and resonant story of Brandon Teena, who despite being born Teena Brandon went on to create a charismatic identity as a young man. Brandon's ultimately wrenching tale may sound tabloid-ready, but on screen it turns into Theodore Dreiser's idea of American tragedy. The film makes it hauntingly real and even tenderly romantic, with the astonishing acting needed to make it work. One of last year's best (Maslin).
 
* "THE CIDER HOUSE RULES," starring Tobey Maguire, Charlize Theron and Delroy Lindo. Directed by Lasse Hallstrom (PG-13, 125 minutes). Radically downsized in scope, and its examination of the issue of abortion greatly softened, John Irving's sixth novel (with a Dickensian screenplay by the author) has been turned into a lovely World War II-era fable about a young man venturing out into the world. Mr. Maguire is Homer Wells, a doleful innocent raised in an orphanage by Dr. Wilbur Larch (Michael Caine), who performs abortions. Fleeing the institution with a golden young couple (Ms. Theron and Paul Rudd), he becomes an apple picker. Sentimental but smart, the movie has the sweetness and narrative drive of a 1940's "David Copperfield" (Holden).
 
"CRADLE WILL ROCK," starring Emily Watson, John Turturro and Vanessa Redgrave. Written and directed by Tim Robbins (R, 132 minutes). This huge Depression-era story features well-known figures from Orson Welles to Nelson Rockefeller to Diego Rivera, and it works them into an ambitious "Ragtime"-like tableau. Though too many figures in this landscape are reduced to naive caricature, Mr. Robbins and his impressive cast bring strong passions to bear upon this (mostly) true story of a legendary event: the trouble-fraught production, by Welles and John Houseman, of Marc Blitzstein's banner-waving 1936 agitprop musical "The Cradle Will Rock." Mr. Robbins and his cast play out all sides of this event with the certitude that its importance lives on (Maslin).
 
* "THE END OF THE AFFAIR," starring Ralph Fiennes, Julianne Moore, Stephen Rea and Ian Hart. Directed by Neil Jordan (R, 105 minutes). Mr. Jordan's intoxicating version of Graham Greene's 1951 novel, in which an illicit affair becomes a far greater gamble than either lover could have imagined. For this fearlessly eclectic filmmaker, this is one more intelligent, brooding love story with a secret twist. Mr. Fiennes and Ms. Moore breathe life into it with a dreamy, erotic intensity that in no way trivializes the film's underlying ideas about religious faith. Period detail (the setting is London in the mid-1940's) is sumptuously heightened by the inspired costume designer Sandy Powell ("Shakespeare in Love") (Maslin).
 
"FANTASIA/2000," with James Levine and the Chicago Symphony Orchestra and introductions by Steve Martin, Bette Midler, Mr. Levine, Itzhak Perlman, James Earl Jones, Angela Lansbury, Quincy Jones and Penn and Teller. Various directors (G, 75 minutes). The new millennial version of Disney's 1940 groundbreaking fusion of animation and classical music includes seven new segments and keeps one from the original film (the wonderful "Sorcerer's Apprentice," starring Mickey Mouse). Despite the science-fiction title and the Imax-size screen on which it is shown, "Fantasia/2000" is more backward-looking than futuristic. The two best segments are "Rhapsody in Blue," a witty Manhattan-in-the-Jazz-Age homage to the caricaturist Al Hirschfeld set to the music of Gershwin, and the finale (set to Stravinsky's "Firebird Suite") in which a cometlike sprite whooshes around the globe explosively creating, destroying and renewing the planet's life forms. Movie star introductions lend the film the feel of a deluxe corporate promotion. At the Sony Imax Theater, Broadway at 68th Street, Manhattan (Holden).
 
"GALAXY QUEST," starring Tim Allen, Sigourney Weaver and Alan Rickman. Directed by Dean Parisot (PG, 102 minutes). Whether you love "Star Trek" or laugh at it, your starship has come in, docking in the form of this amiable comedy that simultaneously manages to spoof these popular futuristic space adventures and replicate the very elements that have made them so durable. The film spins out of a single joke, about a bunch of washed-up actors from a canceled television series who are enlisted by some credulous interplanetary simpletons to champion them in a conflict with a scaly, bellicose villain who has all but exterminated their people. And soon they are off on a genuine space adventure. If "Galaxy Quest" never attains consistently giddy heights as it plays out its combination of knowing satire and heroic adventure, it keeps its tongue firmly in its cheek, offers a few genuine laughs, moves swiftly if not at warp speed, and is led by a talented cast (Lawrence Van Gelder).
 
"GIRL, INTERRUPTED," starring Winona Ryder and Angelina Jolie. Directed by James Mangold (R, 120 minutes). Except for being several years too old for the role, Winona Ryder, an actress who oozes high-strung intelligence, is ideally cast as Susanna Kaysen, a precollege-age girl who lands in a Cambridge mental institution in 1967 after a halfhearted suicide attempt. (The movie is based on Ms. Kaysen's memoir.) The period details are perfect, and Ms. Ryder has the courage to make her character a pain in the neck. But the small, introspective movie is nearly stolen by Ms. Jolie as a charismatic, brutally truth-telling sociopath who becomes Susanna's best friend (Holden).
 
"THE GREEN MILE," starring Tom Hanks, Michael Clarke Duncan, David Morse, Doug Hutchison, Sam Rockwell and Bonnie Hunt. Written and directed by Frank Darabont (R, 180 minutes). In adapting the death row drama that Stephen King wrote in multiple installments, the director of "The Shawshank Redemption" could have managed more economy and fewer talky bits of business around the cellblock. Still, this lengthy film is vivid and well played. Smooth ensemble acting builds up to the discovery that a gigantic condemned man (Mr. Duncan) is a prisoner with very special abilities, which gives the film its mixture of religious overtones and mild horror. Mr. Hanks, as a wry Southern prison guard, is so unaffectedly good that it's redundant to say so (Maslin).
 
"HOLY SMOKE," starring Kate Winslet and Harvey Keitel. Directed by Jane Campion (R, 95 minutes). Having roamed so gorgeously through North Africa as a young hippie mother in "Hideous Kinky," Ms. Winslet this time appears in India as Ruth Barron, a headstrong young Australian seeking enlightenment. Eventually Ruth's mother coaxes her home, where a "cult exiter" named P. J. (Mr. Keitel) is waiting to wean Ruth away from her Indian guru. But as the film moves from its early mix of rapture and humor into this more serious, confrontational stage, it runs into trouble. It doesn't help that Ms. Winslet's obvious strength and beauty leave Mr. Keitel's P. J. looking overmatched (Maslin).
 
* "THE HURRICANE," starring Denzel Washington. Directed by Norman Jewison (R, 120 minutes). The life story of Rubin (Hurricane) Carter, a middleweight contender who spent nearly 20 years in prison for a triple murder he didn't commit, is a big, schmaltzy ballad of a movie redeemed by Mr. Washington's moving, bone-deep portrayal of the boxer from Paterson, N.J. But the movie plays fast and loose with the facts, giving far too much credit to the members of a Canadian commune who took up Mr. Carter's cause and all but eliminating his heroic codefendant John Artis from the story. And the minor characters are either saints or monsters. Yet the story of a man heroically fighting his demons and winning his freedom is still inspiring (Holden).
 
* "THE INSIDER," starring Al Pacino, Russell Crowe and Christopher Plummer. Directed by Michael Mann (R, 155 minutes). Mr. Mann directs this taut thriller about the tobacco industry whistle-blower Jeffrey Wigand with pulse-quickening panache. And he illustrates why, in the corporate climate of the 90's, truth-telling is a riskier business than it was circa "All the President's Men." While Mr. Pacino delivers galvanizing moral outrage as a producer for "60 Minutes," and Mr. Plummer wickedly mimics Mike Wallace, Mr. Crowe movingly captures the complexity of Mr. Wigand's situation. Shaky docudrama ethics cloud the film's take on "60 Minutes." But this is an inordinately well-played thriller, with Mr. Mann's stylistic brio at its best (Maslin).
 
"MAGNOLIA," starring Tom Cruise, Melinda Dillon, Philip Seymour Hoffman, William H. Macy, Julianne Moore, John C. Reilly and Jason Robards. Written and directed by Paul Thomas Anderson (R, 180 minutes). In "Magnolia" the colossally talented Mr. Anderson has set up an artfully orchestrated symphony of intersecting L.A. stories, with many of the cast members from his "Boogie Nights" assembled to form a charismatic ensemble. The movie is saved from its own worst ideas by the intimacy of the performances. Its single biggest surprise is Tom Cruise in the role of a strutting, obscenity-spouting cult figure named Frank Mackey (Maslin).
 
"MAN ON THE MOON," starring Jim Carrey and Danny DeVito . Directed by Milos Forman (R, 118 minutes). Andy Kaufman: genius or creep? This biography takes the more positive view and minimizes the kinkier aspects of Kaufman's misanthropic performance art, preferring a big, vibrant collection of greatest hits. Mr. Carrey channels his character brilliantly and makes his material funnier and tighter than it was in fact. And Mr. Forman directs with the same enthusiasm for outlaw Americana that he brought to "The People vs. Larry Flynt." But the writers, who also wrote that film and "Ed Wood," can't easily find an unself-conscious side of the late comic artist to work with. This feels like the authorized version. It has no real answer to the question of who Kaufman was and how he got that way (Maslin).
 
"SNOW FALLING ON CEDARS," starring Ethan Hawke, James Cromwell and Max Von Sydow. Directed by Scott Hicks (PG-13, 130 minutes). This director's follow-up to "Shine" is the cinematic equivalent of an arty coffee-table book. It is so busy illustrating the story (with elaborate flashbacks and montage sequences) that it forgets to be dramatic. Set in the Pacific Northwest in 1950, the movie looks back to World War II and the charged relationships between Japanese-Americans and whites on an island north of Puget Sound. Mr. Hawke is the brooding reporter covering the trial and Mr. Von Sydow the defense lawyer who is the film's official conscience. Robert Richardson is responsible for the gorgeous cinematography (Holden).
 
* "STUART LITTLE," starring Geena Davis, Hugh Laurie and Jonathan Lipnicki. Directed by Rob Minkoff (PG, 92 minutes). E. B. White's 1945 children's classic has been adapted into a lovely family film about a little mouse (with the voice of Michael J. Fox) who is adopted by humans but runs afoul of their fluffy white Persian cat, Snowbell (Nathan Lane). The movie creates an enchanted storybook version of New York and has what may be the most exciting toy-boat race (in Central Park) ever filmed. Thanks to Mr. Lane's sly, wise-guy vocal impersonation, Snowbell nearly steals a movie that is funny and sweet but never cloying (Holden).
 
"SWEET AND LOWDOWN," starring Sean Penn, Samantha Morton and Uma Thurman. Directed by Woody Allen (PG-13, 95 minutes). In homage to the kind of jaunty 1930's jazz that has been heard on many of his other films' soundtracks, Mr. Allen imagines a consummate jazz character: Emmet Ray (played with gusto by Mr. Penn), who can play the guitar as gorgeously as Django Reinhardt but lacks certain interpersonal skills when it comes to his private life. Borrowing attributes of various real musicians, the film turns Emmet into another one of Mr. Allen's cad-geniuses and gives him a long-suffering mute laundress as a sweetheart. (Ms. Morton works miracles in her wordless role.) But on the storytelling level, the film remains flimsy. It's the musical interludes, frequent and lovingly presented, that keep it alive (Maslin).
 
* "THE TALENTED MR. RIPLEY," starring Matt Damon, Jude Law, Gwyneth Paltrow, Cate Blanchett and Philip Seymour Hoffman. Written and directed by Anthony Minghella (R, 135 minutes). There are diabolically smart surprises wherever you care to look in this glittering thriller. Proving that the brilliance of "The English Patient" was no fluke, Mr. Minghella shapes a hypnotic, sensually charged adaptation of Patricia High smith's fascinatingly reptilian murder story. The traffic-stopping cast includes Mr. Damon as the dangerous chameleon of the title and, in a star-making role, the English actor Jude Law as a rich dilettante who exerts a homoerotic magnetism. Ms. Paltrow plays the odd woman out with the shrewdness of a fine character actress, while Ms. Blanchett makes the delirious most of her role as a needy American post-debutante. As the story's odious playboy-snob, Mr. Hoffman is scene-stealingly wonderful. Gorgeously photographed in Italy by John Seale (Maslin).
 
* "TITUS," starring Anthony Hopkins, Jessica Lange and Alan Cumming. Directed by Julie Taymor (R, 160 minutes). Ms. Taymor, the theater director and puppeteer who created transfixing stage pictures in "The Lion King" and "Juan Darien," has turned Shakespeare's goriest tragedy, "Titus Andronicus," into a powerful contemplation of murderous revenge enacted throughout history. Mr. Hopkins is ghoulishly funny and tragic as the title character, whose political stupidity sets in motion a devastating chain reaction of killing, torture and retaliation. Ms. Lange is Tamora, the captured Goth empress who strikes back. Although the movie's British theatrical and American film acting styles don't mesh, Ms. Taymor's vision is realized with a shattering force in time-traveling imagery that blends ancient Rome with Mussolini's Italy and contemporary cyberpunk flash (Holden).
 
* "TOPSY-TURVY," starring Allan Corduner and Jim Broadbent. Directed by Mike Leigh (R, 161 minutes). Mr. Leigh's grandly entertaining "Topsy-Turvy" is one of those films that create a mix of erudition, pageantry and delectable acting opportunities, much as "Shakespeare in Love" did last year. Instead of a love-struck young playwright, it presents the curiously matched personalities of the librettist William Schwenk Gilbert and the composer Arthur Sullivan in the midst of a robust, knowing, frequently hilarious look at the musical theater over which they held sway (Maslin).
 
* "TOY STORY 2," with the voices of Tom Hanks and Tim Allen. Directed by John Lasseter; a Pixar Animated Studios film (G, 98 minutes). A wonderfully playful sequel, sustaining the first film's wit and novelty while bringing new sophistication to computer-generated animation. And here is welcome proof that Hollywood can still make movies to please audiences of any age or persuasion. From its opening (a perfectly adorable "Star Wars" parody) to its Capra-esque conclusion, this is a seamless work with more metaphorical cleverness than that usually found in the toy bin. Colorful new characters and more adventurous action enhance the story of how Woody falls into the clutches of a sleazy toy dealer, experiences newfound celebrity and needs to be rescued by his old friends (Maslin).
 
Film Series
 
"THE AMERICAN PLACE: LANDSCAPE IN THE EARLY WESTERN (AND A FEW LATER CLASSICS)." An opportunity for a new look at the Old West is at hand at the Museum of Modern Art, where a monthlong series highlighted by early westerns began yesterday. Spanning the history of the genre, the series features more than 50 films in 30 programs, including works that extend from Edwin Porter, D. W. Griffith, Thomas H. Ince, John Ford, Charles Chaplin and Allan Dwan to Victor Fleming, Victor Seastrom, Sam Peckinpah, Mel Brooks, Clint Eastwood and Jim Jarmusch. One half of a choice double bill this weekend consists of "The Great Train Robbery" (1903), Porter's 11-minute seminal work about a deadly holdup, with the woods of New Jersey substituting for the wild West. The other half is "The Wild Bunch" (1969), Peckinpah's violent chronicle of the adventures of a band of outlaws who have outlived their time. The films will be shown at 2 p.m. on Sunday. Continuing through Feb. 24, at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53rd Street, Manhattan, the series is free with museum admission: $10 for adults, $6.50 for students and people 65 or older; free for visitors under 16 accompanied by an adult. Pay what you wish on Fridays from 4:30 to 8:30 P.M. Information: (212) 708-9400 (Van Gelder).

HEADLINE: FAMILY FARE

BYLINE: By Laurel Graeber 

 BODY:

The Artist As a Young Girl
Like beauty, art is often in the eye of the beholder. For adult artists -- say, those represented in the Saatchi Collection -- this is a lesson to take in stride. For a fourth-grade painter, however, it's difficult. 
 Take the heroine of "Noonie's Masterpiece in Purple." Noonie says she is a misunderstood genius whose art will be celebrated in a hundred years. But while Noonie may sound egotistical, she needs approval, and long before the next century.
It's not hard to see why. Noonie's mother died years ago, and her father is busy traveling. In the meantime, Noonie lives with relatives who seem to have come from a Roald Dahl novel. Her Uncle Ralph is a smarmy unemployed car salesman; her Aunt Sylvia is an obsessive dental hygienist who could have had a supporting role in "Marathon Man." Her sadistic cousin, Junior, "thinks he's an action figure," and her babysitter, Beverly, prefers doughnuts and soap operas to Noonie.
"Noonie's Masterpiece," by Lisa Railsback, which won several regional awards in children's theater, explores how Noonie learns to be true to her art and to herself. Entering a school contest, Noonie enthusiastically paints her bizarre clan not as they look but as she sees them. "They'll love it, and then they'll love me," she proclaims.
Her philistine relatives loathe the portrait. But with help from the spirits of Picasso, van Gogh and Georgia O'Keeffe, Noonie gains the confidence to be unafraid not only in her art but also in her relationships.
Presented by the Looking Glass Theater under Jennifer Goodlander's direction, "Noonie's Masterpiece" is an engrossing hour for children over 6. (It's far too cerebral for preschoolers.) The issues are poignant, and although the adult characters sometimes seem like cartoons, the children are sympathetic. This is especially true of Noonie, played by Madeleine Mager. She's one artist I'd be happy to have in my family, not to mention on my walls.
"Noonie's Masterpiece in Purple," through Feb. 20 at the Looking Glass Theater, 422 West 57th Street, Manhattan, (212) 307-9467. Saturdays and Sundays at 2 p.m.; Mondays and Tuesdays at 7 p.m. Adults, $8; children, $5. Reservations advised.
 
In Good Company
Just when you thought all the hoopla was over, another Y2K celebration is about to take place. But there's good reason: this event heralds something that is almost as rare as the arrival of the new millennium.
The Y2Kids' Cafe Intergenerational Festival 2000, tomorrow and Sunday, will be the debut of Kids' Company, a children's repertory dance troupe that is neither the junior division of an adult company nor the offshoot of a classical ballet school.
Founded by Dancewave Inc., a Brooklyn organization, the company will focus on modern dance, working with professional choreographers.
"We want a company rooted in who kids are -- not exact technicians who come from a ballet school," said Diane Jacobowitz, the director. "In that sense, I think this company is totally unique to New York City."
In its first venture, Kids' Company has found the ideal iconoclastic mentor: Mark Morris. This weekend, it will present excerpts of his "Allegro il Penseroso ed il Moderato," choreographed to a score by Handel.
The other performers will include Movin' Spirits Dance Theater; Risa Jaraslow and Dancers; and Dmitrij and Diniil Simkin, a father and son from Germany. The Circus Amok Band will play, and Hilary Chaplain, a clown, will provide light moments.
Y2Kids' Cafe Intergenerational Festival, tomorrow and Sunday at 3 p.m. at the Brooklyn Music School and Playhouse, 126 St. Felix Street, Fort Greene. Tickets, $10. Reservations required, (212) 924-0077.
 
Pridelands Revisited
There's another Lion King in town. And his name isn't Simba.
Still, "Sundiata, the Lion King of Mali," a new musical from Theaterworks/USA, won't disappoint Disney fans. Like its predecessor, this "Lion King" features fraternal rivalry, family betrayal and a reluctant young heir to the throne. It even has splendid animal masks and puppets, designed by Barbara Pollitt.
But while Disney's "Lion King" has often been described as a child's version of "Hamlet," "Sundiata," based on a West African legend, is more like a sunny "Macbeth."
At the play's start, the Lion Spirit prophesies that the aging king of Mali will have a new son who will triumph over the evil sorcerer Sumanguru. When the strange child, Sundiata, is born -- he has a lion's head and a human body -- his ambitious older brother, Dankaran, despairs. Sumanguru, disguised, appears to Dankaran and tells him that he is destined to be the true ruler.
No one, however, is pushed off a cliff. Dankaran uses Sundiata's natural shyness and timidity to convince his brother that he doesn't have what it takes to be king. But after wandering among some real lions, Sundiata learns that the courage to lead isn't based on empty displays of power.
Directed by David Schechter, who also wrote the book, "Sundiata" has a talented cast and a score that's pure energy (in contrast to Elton John and Tim Rice's pure pop). Scott Davenport Richards's music (with additional songs by Kirsten Childs) offers African drumbeats, jazzy riffs and rhythms to get children on their feet. This may be a small-scale "Lion King," but it still knows how to roar.
"Sundiata, the Lion King of Mali," tomorrow and Sunday (and March 11 and 12) at 12:30 p.m. at the Auditorium at Equitable Tower, 787 Seventh Avenue, between 51st and 52nd Streets, Manhattan, (212) 627-7373. For children over 5. Tickets, $19.

HEADLINE: Greenspan Speaks Softly, With Big Stick

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
PITY Alan Greenspan. Suddenly the talk around Wall Street is that the Federal Reserve just doesn't have the power it once had over the economy. The Fed has raised interest rates three times, and the economy -- and the stock market -- just keep rolling along. Interest rates are no longer important.
If such talk brings on a feeling of deja vu, it may be because you remember the days of 1991 and 1992, when this economic expansion was young and widely derided as weak and fragile. Then the talk was of "profitless growth" and "pushing on a string." The Fed's efforts to stimulate the economy were faltering. 
 In fact, the economy has changed, and there probably is a longer lag before the Fed can have a major impact. But the Fed is far from impotent. If Mr. Greenspan and his colleagues really want to slow the economy, they can. And it appears that Mr. Greenspan wants to do just that; he just doesn't want to take the blame for it.
At least that is the way I read the most intriguing part of his speech to the Economic Club of New York a week ago. In it he pointed out that consumption is rising much faster than incomes or productivity, and attributed a large part of that to the booming stock market and the feeling of wealth that it has produced.
That cannot last, he said: "What will stop the wealth-induced excess of demand over productivity-expanded supply is largely developments in financial markets."
In other words, it is the markets that will slow the economy, not vice versa. "He sees rising interest rates as the force that will ultimately cap the equity market's advance, contain equity wealth effects, and thereby rein in excess demand," said Robert J. Barbera, the chief economist of Hoenig & Company.
Mr. Greenspan would like us to think that he is a passive observer, with the market raising long-term rates and the Fed just following along. He would like to avoid being blamed for bringing down the stock market, so he avoids talk about overvaluation and thus reassures investors.
But there are signs that the Fed's medicine (or is it the bond market's?) is starting to work. Much of the stock market is stuttering, although technology stocks have recovered from their early-January swoon and are setting records. There is unprecedented volatility within the stock market, as the Dow Jones industrial average plunges while the Nasdaq composite zooms, or vice versa. There have been just six days in the last decade when one of those indexes rose at least 1 percent while the other fell by that amount. Four of them were in the last two months.
Technology mutual funds have taken in $12.7 billion from investors since mid-November, reports AMG Data Services, while the rest of the equity-fund universe received just $4.5 billion. "I've never seen it this concentrated," said Bob Adler, AMG's founder. "Technology is the only focus." The trade deficit sets new records each month, as wealth-effect-driven consumption pulls in imports.
The yield on 10-year Treasuries has climbed from 5.9 percent to 6.8 percent since mid-November, while the Nasdaq composite is up 30 percent. You can take that as evidence that the Fed cannot stop this runaway economy, or the technology bull market. Or you can agree with the wisdom of the late economist Herbert Stein, as quoted by Mr. Greenspan: "If a trend cannot continue, it will stop."
Mr. Greenspan thinks interest rates will rise enough to offset, if not end, the wealth effect. Do you want to bet he is wrong?

LENGTH: 709 words

HEADLINE: Public Interests;
That Forbes Allure

BYLINE: By GAIL COLLINS 

DATELINE: BOONE, Iowa

 BODY:
A minor mystery in the current presidential campaign involves the people who turn out to listen to Steve Forbes's speeches.
The mystery would be why. 
 As a candidate, Mr. Forbes is a guy in a suit who works a room as if he were proctoring a test. Thanks to his extraordinarily immobile features, he always looks precisely the same from nose upward, no matter what his mood. Offstage, he hardly seems to exist. His staff sort of carts him away when the speeches are over, and there are no Steve Forbes anecdotes, either charming or chilling. He has spent more than $60 million over the last four years trying to buy his way into the presidential race, but he doesn't even seem to dabble in conspicuous consumption. During his most recent Iowa swing, he and his wife were spending their rest times at the neighborhood Econo-Lodge.
But no matter how remote the town or treacherous the weather, there's a roomful of people waiting patiently to hear him speak. It's hard to explain what brings them out, since I have finally and reluctantly accepted the fact that he is not hiring them. None of his issues seem to have much pull. The polls show voters are apathetic about tax cuts of any size, let alone one as complicated and controversial as Mr. Forbes's pet proposal.
He's trying to appeal to the Christian right -- this week he said George W. Bush was a "timid" abortion opponent, while he was "bold." ("Bold" appears to be the adjective of choice this year. Perhaps this race, lacking any other focus, will be remembered for recycling old laundry detergent names. Let's call the Bush tax cuts "fab.") But dissatisfied social conservatives seem to yearn for a candidate with fire in the belly, and they can get more passion than Mr. Forbes is offering in Alan Keyes or Gary Bauer. Or the telephone book.
Still, the sight of all those upturned faces has energized the candidate, sort of. "I'm pumped up!" Mr. Forbes keeps saying, with exactly the same expression he uses when vowing to drive a stake through the tax code, or inquiring whether everybody liked the free chili. The newly peppy speeches sound like an infomercial, in which Mr. Forbes explains how we can all become winners in the game of life by instituting a flat tax and privatizing Social Security. ("You take someone on minimum wage their whole lives. They'll have upwards of $200,000 when they retire!")
The serious presidential candidates generally ignore the Forbes campaign, but in Iowa the Republican establishment has been attempting to demonize him as an archfiend of negative advertising. Senator Charles Grassley is on the radio warning the public to beware of possible anti-Bush ads as if they were radioactive. At the first sign of negativity, he urges, "hang up the phone, throw the mail out and change the station." While Mr. Bush was busy hammering on John McCain in New Hampshire, his staff in Iowa was complaining that a Forbes pamphlet had been rigged to make Mr. Bush's ears look big. If this keeps up, Mr. Forbes may actually qualify for the sympathy vote.
His organization, which is the best money can buy, may compensate for his lack of pizazz. But Americans still prefer presidential candidates who seem to have at least a modicum of an idea what they're getting into, and the Forbes people want the nation to entrust its security to a guy whose chief claim to fame is that he once ran a business his father gave him. You can't spend your way around that problem.
The campaign, however, is selling his lack of credentials as his big strength, and his supporters seem to agree. Almost invariably, they say they are in his corner because "he's not tainted," or "he doesn't run with the ones in Washington." Maybe the mysterious Forbes audiences are made up of voters who believed the Gingrich revolution would refashion America in their own image. When things sort of fizzled out, perhaps they gave up on politicians completely, and decided to place their bets on someone so uncharismatic he could be trusted not to trick them the way politicians did.
Or, on the other hand, it could just be that people who live in Iowa in the winter have a lot of time on their hands.
"It was either come here or go to exercise class," one elderly woman said.

HEADLINE: Official Says Fed Should Slow U.S. Growth

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve needs to slow the pace of United States growth to prevent strong domestic demand and a tight labor market from overheating the economy, a governor of the Fed, Laurence Meyer, said today.
Mr. Meyer's remarks to economists in Washington seemed to confirm what is already widely expected -- that the inflation-wary Fed is on course for another interest rate increase at its next policy-setting meeting, set for Feb. 1 and 2. 
 Mr. Meyer, the Fed's keenest inflation hawk, told the National Economists Club and the Society of Government Economists that the economy's performance in recent years has been exceptional and that inflation remained modest.
But growth and output are running in excess of what the Fed considers their trend, or the sustainable long-term pace, and this will eventually drive up costs throughout the economy, he said.
"Given how low the unemployment rate is already, the first order of business is ensuring that we at least slow growth to trend and prevent the output gap from getting any bigger," Mr. Meyer said.
The Fed's major concern at this stage is that robust demand for goods and services from both businesses and consumers is outpacing supply, a recipe for inflation, Mr. Meyer said.

HEADLINE: A Clinton Initiative in a Science of Smallness

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF 

 BODY:
The Clinton administration plans today to announce an ambitious program to accelerate basic research in the field of nanotechnology, the design and fabrication of devices of ultramicroscopic size.
Nanotechnology is widely considered an extremely promising area of science and engineering, but it has realized only limited commercial success to date. 
Today, in a speech at the California Institute of Technology in Pasadena, President Clinton will stress the importance of expanding basic research in both the physical and biological sciences. As part of the speech, he will announce plans to ask Congress to finance a National Nanotechnology Initiative to encourage basic research in the field.
The president will set out these "grand challenges": Shrinking the entire contents of the Library of Congress into a device the size of a sugar cube; assembling new materials from the "bottom up" -- from atoms and molecules; developing ultralight materials that are 10 times as strong as steel; creating a new class of computer chip millions of times as fast as today's Pentium 3; doubling the efficiency of solar cells; using gene and drug-delivery technologies to detect and target cancerous cells, and developing new technologies to remove the smallest contaminants from water and air.
The initiative will double federal spending in the field over the next five years. The plan calls for an increase in nanotechnology research spending to $497 million in the coming fiscal year, about 70 percent of which will go to university scientists for basic research.
Thomas A. Kalil, special assistant to the president for economic policy, said: "Nanotechnology is a perfect example of the kind of investments that President Clinton and Vice President Gore believe are necessary for America's future. It's long term, high risk and high payoff."
Nanotechnology -- broadly defined as the ability to manipulate and move matter -- is rapidly developing as a promising approach to a wide range of sciences and technologies. For example, researchers at both corporations and universities have made significant strides in the last year toward building computers that would be several orders of magnitude smaller and more powerful than today's silicon-based machines.
Moreover, nanotechnology is believed to have great potential in biomedicine in applications ranging from improved drug delivery to disease detection.
In the world of mechanical devices, nanotechnology has already created billion-dollar markets for devices like ink-jet printer heads and accelerometers for automobiles. But researchers are optimistic about even bigger payoffs. For example, researchers believe they are on the track of new materials that are as much as 10 times as strong as steel, yet weigh only a fraction of it.
Currently the National Science Foundation, the Pentagon, the Energy Department, NASA, the Commerce Department and the National Institutes of Health are all financing nanotechnology research. The National Nanotechnology Initiative calls for increasing spending by these agencies -- as much as 400 percent in the case of NASA -- in next year's budget.
There has been an explosion of nanotechnology-oriented research proposals coming from university campuses in the last year, a government official said, and it has only been possible to finance a fraction of them under the current spending limits.
Spending under the new program will be broken down into financing long-term fundamental research; support for grand challenge efforts; the creation of new research centers; the establishment of a research infrastructure, and the study of ethical, legal and societal implications of nanotechnology.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Blue Chips Drop on Interest-Rate Worries

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Blue-chip stocks fell steeply yesterday on concerns that rising interest rates would ultimately cut into corporate earnings, while signs of strong growth from leading technology companies pushed the Nasdaq further into record territory.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 138.06, to 11,351.30. The blue-chip average rose as much as 68 points in early trading and plunged as much as 214 at midday. 
 The Nasdaq composite index rose 38.22 points, to 4,189.51, extending the record high reached just Wednesday. Broader stock indicators were mixed. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index declined 10.33, or 0.7 percent, to 1,445.57.
Stocks rose at the opening bell after I.B.M. easily beat Wall Street's profit forecasts with quarterly results it released after the close of trading on Wednesday.
While company officials warned that lingering concerns will continue to take a toll on sales in the current quarter, they encouraged analysts to leave their profit forecasts for 2000 intact. I.B.M.'s stock rose 5 1/2, to 121.
Alcoa fell 4 7/16, to 73 11/16, as the company announced plans to restart primary aluminum production to meet growing global demand. The announcement ignited fears that aluminum prices will drop, hurting Alcoa's bottom line.
Consumer products companies also fared poorly. Procter & Gamble fell 2 5/8, to 112 9/16, and 3M dropped 3 11/16, to 95 1/8.
Analysts said lingering worries that the Federal Reserve would raise interest rates this year are affecting blue-chip stocks more than technology companies. Higher rates can cut into corporate profits by making it more expensive to borrow money.
"Investors seem to feel that as long as the technology companies are projected to grow 40 or 50 percent per year, who cares about interest rates?" said A. C. Moore, chief investment strategist for Dunvegan Associates in Santa Barbara, Calif. "More mature companies can't possibly grow at that rate."
Indeed, investors rewarded several technology leaders for their strong growth today.
On the Nasdaq, Apple Computer soared. Apple said late Wednesday that it earned $183 million, or $1.03 a share, in its most recent quarter, and its stock rose 6 15/16, to 113 1/2.
Engage Technologies rose 20 9/16, to 97 9/16 after buying two online advertising businesses from its parent company, CMGI Inc.
Not every technology leader was rewarded for strong profits. America Online, which has had a tumble in its stock price since it announced its intentions to merge with Time Warner, fell 3/16, to 64 1/4. AOL said late Wednesday that it earned $224 million in the quarter ended Dec. 31, more than double the $86 million in the period a year earlier.
The Russell 2000 index of smaller companies rose to a record. The index, which lagged in 1999, has surged so far this year and has set records in four consecutive sessions.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Treasury Prices Fall
 By Bloomberg News
 Treasury bond prices fell as a report of record-high imports and exports underpinned expectations that the Federal Reserve would raise interest rates more than once in coming months to slow consumer demand and curb faster inflation.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 7/32, to 92 8/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 6.74 percent, from 6.71 percent on Wednesday.
"The Fed has got to be displeased with consumer confidence and the rate of spending, and I full well expect them to continue to raise rates until they get what they desire," and higher bond yields will follow, said Kevin Perry, an adviser at Jurika & Voyles, a unit of Nvest Companies in Boston.

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate;
Mixed-Income Rental Units Planned for Chelsea

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
A small wedge of Chelsea is being transformed into a 98-unit mixed-income rental complex made up of a 13-story apartment building nearing completion on Eighth Avenue and two five-story prewar brownstones that turn the corner on West 21st Street.
The $21.5 million project, called Chelsea Arms, is to be completed in May. Its new building, one of the last to rise in the neighborhood under zoning that allows taller buildings than are now permitted under a recent rezoning, is to contain 70 studio to three-bedroom apartments. There will also be 28 one- and two-bedroom renovated units spread through the two brownstones. 
 Each of the three buildings will have an entrance on 21st Street, with the one for the new structure formed by a walkway carved through the smaller corner bronwstone building, knitting together the project. There will also be 9,000 square feet of street-level retail space along Eighth Avenue next to the Bendix Diner, which will remain at the corner of 21st Street.
Eighty percent of the rentals will be leased at market rents. For the new units, the monthly rents are expected to be from $1,950 for studios of 600 square foot to $5,000 for two-bedroom apartments of 1,100 to 1,200 square feet. Two three-bedroom duplexes with 1,800 square feet each will rent for $7,500 a month.
Monthly rents for the existing 670-to-1,075-square-foot units in the brownstones, which will be renovated, are to be $2,100 to $2,800, said Andrew S. Heiberger, president of CitiHabitats, the project's exclusive leasing agent. Leasing of those units is expected to begin by April.
The remaining 20 percent of the units -- 14 in the new building and 6 in the existing ones -- will be rented at $342 to $559 a month to people with annual incomes of $12,436 to $26,700, depending on family size. There are 12 existing rent-stabilized tenants in the smaller structures who may meet the income requirements.
Otherwise, said Avery B. Seavey, a principal of the Seavey Organization of Manhattan, which is developing the project, existing tenants will remain in their apartments or move to comparable ones within the complex, which, if they choose, will be renovated, without resulting in an increase in their monthly rents.
The renovation of the two existing buildings will include upgrading the mechanical systems and hallways as well as giving the vacant apartments new kitchens and baths. The work is expected to begin by the middle of next month.
Because this is a so-called 80-20 project, the Seavey Organization got $18 million in tax-exempt bond financing from the New York State Housing Finance Agency. It also secured a letter of credit from Chase Bank and is investing $3.5 million of its own money in the project, which is also eligible to receive a 20-year tax abatement from the city.
Mr. Seavey said his company bought the Chelsea properties -- the new building replaces two empty three-story commercial structures -- to produce "new as well as affordable housing in a neighborhood that needs both."
Edward Kirkland, chairman of the Chelsea preservation and planning committee of Community Board 4, said the project's affordable component made it a good fit for his gentrifying neighborhood.
It is one of several such 80-20 projects under way or proposed in the area covered by the community board that could generate roughly 100 more affordable units, he added. Another is a 365-unit project planned by the Rockrose Development Corporation on a long-empty blockfront on the west side of Seventh Avenue between 25th and 26th Streets.
"Maintaining an economically integrated community," Mr. Kirkland added, is one of the main goals of what he called the Chelsea Plan.
The plan, implemented through zoning changes approved by the City Council last fall, is also intended to maintain the neighborhood's historic character and scale and discourage displacement. Mr. Kirkland said "the history of the Seavey Organization gives us confidence that it will keep the substance of its promises to its existing tenants, and I am sure there would be screams from them and their advocates if that was not happening."
The rezoning affects an area of Chelsea from West 14th Street to north of 23rd Street, between the Avenue of the Americas and 10th Avenue. Among other things, it restricts the heights of new buildings in the area, decreasing it to roughly seven stories in and near the Chelsea Historic District.
Chelsea Arms, which is near the historic district, was approved before the rezoning. "I have mixed feelings about the new building's scale," Mr. Kirkland said, "but otherwise the project is O.K."
To lessen its impact, changes were made to the new 13-story building, which is designed "to recall traditional older New York buildings," said Stephen B. Jacobs, the project's architect. It was given setbacks "so the increased height from the shorter buildings to the new one is gradual rather than abrupt, and clad in two-tone beige and brown bricks to break up the scale," he said.
Most of the apartments in the new building will have two bedrooms to meet the demand for family-size units, said Mr. Heiberger, who noted that the rental vacancy rate in Chelsea was less than 1 percent.
Planned amenities for the complex include a 24-hour doorman and a common roof deck. As part of its purchase of the property, the Seavey Organization gave the seller, the Red Apple Company, a supermarket operator that owns both the Gristedes and Red Apple chains, the right of first refusal to occupy the new commercial space for an upscale food store.
Occupancy for the residential tenants is expected to start by June.

HEADLINE: OPEC Strategy Is Beginning To Be Noticed By Consumers

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
When you pay home heating oil bills this winter, pump gasoline into the family car or buy airline tickets to a sunny climate, you will see just how much OPEC's game of chicken is costing consumers.
With OPEC vowing to continue restraints on production, oil prices have begun surging again in the last two weeks. The price of crude oil is now $29.20 a barrel and headed to $30 or more, many commodity analysts say. Gasoline prices are at 77.33 cents a gallon in the futures market and heading to over $1.30 at the pump. And the near-term home heating oil futures contract is up to 86.46 cents a gallon, after climbing 8.6 percent yesterday. All these prices, except gasoline at the pump, are the highest since the run-up to the Persian Gulf war in January 1991. 
 The price jumps are now spilling over into financial markets. Concerns about oil's impact on inflation have sent bond prices lower and yields higher. Airline stocks have dropped sharply as fuel costs have risen. Major airlines are now adding fuel surcharges of $10 each to their tickets.
The arctic air in the Midwest and Northeast is responsible for some of the increases. But the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries is really calling the shots. Production cuts by the oil-producing nations last March caused crude oil prices to double in 1999. Then last week, OPEC officials said there was a consensus to extend current production cuts -- amounting to 4.3 million barrels a day below their levels a year earlier -- beyond the March expiration date. So the question is, if the price of oil tops $30 a barrel, will OPEC keep squeezing? Or is it just talking tough?
"I don't take any announcement as final," said Irene King, senior oil market analyst at J. P. Morgan Securities, referring to last week's comments about extended production cuts. "But it is scary." Two weeks ago, she said there was a 70 percent to 80 percent chance that OPEC officials would decide to increase crude oil production to ease price pressures when they meet at the end of March. Now she says the odds are 50-50.
If OPEC does not relent, the relatively low levels of oil inventories and strong demand mean that prices will move higher.
According to the Energy Information Administration and the American Petroleum Institute, total United States inventories of crude oil are now at their lowest level since the end of 1996. At the same time, demand in December was 19.8 million barrels a day, the highest for the month since 1978. The International Energy Agency forecast yesterday that worldwide demand will rise 2.4 percent this year, the biggest gain since 1997, as global economic growth continues to pick up.
Because of OPEC production cuts last year, crude oil inventories, excluding the nation's Strategic Petroleum Reserve, fell in the week ended Jan. 14 to 293.3 million barrels, from 324 million barrels a year earlier, according to the Energy Information Administration. The A.P.I. figures are about the same.
Gasoline supplies are tight, having dropped below 200 million barrels, to 198.3 million barrels, from 222.6 million barrels a year ago. Distillate stocks, which include home heating oil, are also low, having fallen to 118.8 million barrels from 152.6 million barrels.
Ms. King is most worried about the low gasoline stocks as refineries head into a period when they normally shut down for four to six weeks for maintenance and upgrades. She said that if inventories remained at these low levels in the spring, "then we are in trouble." That is because demand for gasoline picks up drastically during the peak summer travel season.
Trouble could mean gasoline lines, she said. But, "that is the extreme case," she noted, adding, "I don't think we are going to get there."
Despite last week's comments from OPEC, many analysts do not expect OPEC officials to risk pushing the price of oil too far above $30 a barrel. If the price goes higher, leaders of the United States, Europe and Asia may well begin to fret about the possible impact on their economies.
"I'm concerned about the increase in oil prices, and I'm going to be discussing this with my counterpart ministers from Saudi Arabia, Norway, Mexico and Venezuela very soon," the secretary of energy, Bill Richardson, said Wednesday.
So what OPEC probably wants to do is orchestrate a soft landing for the price of oil. That means the group needs to talk tough for a while longer. Holding out would reduce inventories further as oil is bought in anticipation of higher prices. With lower inventories, the downdraft in oil prices would be much weaker if OPEC increased production. Last week, some OPEC officials said worldwide inventories of crude oil were not yet low enough.
"They don't want people to anticipate production increases," said Michael Rothman, senior energy analyst at Merrill Lynch. "They don't want a production increase to lead to a crash in the oil price."
Frederick P. Leuffer, senior energy analyst at Bear, Stearns & Company, said crude inventories were so low now that OPEC would have to increase production to prevent prices from skyrocketing and the threat of gasoline lines. "We're within two days of what the industry considers a minimal operational level," which is crude oil inventories equal to 12 to 13 days of demand.
"If inventories decline from this level, OPEC won't be able to do what they say they will do," Mr. Leuffer argued. "This is simply an effort to talk up the price. The last thing they want to do is alienate consumers and force governments to dip into strategic petroleum reserves."
Some analysts expect Saudi Arabia to take the lead in pushing for a March agreement that will ease price pressures. Because there is no agreement yet on how long to extend the production cuts, there is room to maneuver. For now at least, Saudi Arabia is talking tough. But some see political motivations for it to do so. Any switch to supporting lower oil prices now could undermine the chances of victory for the moderates in the Iranian elections in February, these analysts say.
Politicians in the United States, meanwhile, are beginning to protest the higher prices. Senator Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, wants the government to dip into the Strategic Petroleum Reserve to help push prices lower. "They have been saying that OPEC would relent for months," Mr. Schumer said. "The best way to jawbone them is to say that we are going to sell some oil from the Strategic Petroleum Reserve."
This all means that crude oil, gasoline and home heating oil prices are going to be higher than anyone expected just two weeks ago.
And that raises a bigger question: When will the American consumer get mad? Probably pretty soon. Gasoline pump prices have risen much more slowly than crude oil or the cost of gasoline before taxes are added in. But at $1.27 an unleaded gallon yesterday, the average countrywide price is just a penny away from its 1996 high.

HEADLINE: Trade Deficit Set Record In November

BYLINE: By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20

 BODY:
The insatiable American appetite for German cars, French perfume and Japanese televisions has helped the world's wealthiest countries grow faster than at any time since the mid-1990's, but the United States is warning that its allies need to join in the gluttony.
The United States trade deficit with the rest of the world set a new high in November, statistics released today show. Led by purchases of autos, electronics, oil and clothing produced abroad, the United States posted a monthly trade deficit of $26.5 billion, a nagging indicator that not everything is perfect in America's otherwise rosy economic picture. 
 Based on November's numbers, the United States deficit was on course to reach $267 billion for all of last year, about $100 billion more than 1998, which was itself a record year. The momentum is also worrying. Imports grew at double the rate of exports.
Reducing the swelling trade gap is the Clinton administration's top priority at a gathering of finance ministers from the Group of Seven in Tokyo this weekend. Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers, speaking in advance of the meeting, said Europe and Japan needed to start thinking big and growing fast, much like the United States.
"In both Europe and Japan, there's a complacency of low expectations," Mr. Summers said. "The world cannot indefinitely sustain the present level of imbalances."
America's stellar growth means that it is consuming more than its share of world output. Europe and Japan have the potential to grow faster if they loosen up the reins on their economies and worry less about inflation, Mr. Summers said. Ideally, both major trading partners would then buy more American goods and help to even out global trade.
The United States trade deficit has been a persistent concern for years, of course. But American policy makers are frustrated by its stubbornness during a period of relative prosperity abroad.
The deficit was supposed to level out, or begin contracting, now that the rest of the world has started growing again after the slump that began during the global financial crisis of 1997. Instead, it continues to set new records, month after month.
Though the deficit is a bigger burden on the economy now than it was in the 1980's, it has a lower political profile. Few economists or politicians question the competitiveness of the United States now as they did then. With inflation staying low and the government running a budget surplus, the United States is better equipped today to handle a big deficit than it was 15 years ago.
Some even argue that a surge of inexpensive imports from abroad have helped propel the United States economy to its current heights. Imports seem to have helped keep inflation down, allowing the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates less than it otherwise would. And by buying manufactured goods abroad for less than they can be made here, capital has been freed up for investment in the hottest sectors of the American economy, like technology and the Internet.
Still, the swell in the trade gap poses some dangers. It reveals a persistent weakness in American manufacturing industries, like autos.
Despite the fact that German and Japanese automakers have invested billions of dollars in this country to build cars here -- meaning that the Toyota, Honda and even BMW and Mercedes-Benz brand names no longer always signal an import -- the American passion for high-end, foreign-made cars remains one of the biggest overall contributors to the trade deficit.
A larger concern, at least for economists, is the challenge the deficit poses to the dollar. Through the record economic expansion of the 1990's, the United States has sought to keep the dollar strong. But the ever-widening trade deficit needs to be paid back, sooner or later, by a surge in exports or a decline in the value of the dollar relative to other currencies, or both.
"Every time we have run a big deficit we have ended up with a big decline in the dollar, and that is bound to happen again," said C. Fred Bergsten, who runs the Institute of International Economics. "The real question is whether the dollar decline is hard or soft. The administration is doing what it can to make sure it's soft."
The dollar has already lost about a third of its value against the Japanese yen in recent months. It has remained strong against the euro, Europe's single currency, but many economists see the dollar weakening sharply if the trade gap persists.
Predicting the demise of the United States economy has been a fool's game in recent years. But one possible course leading to the end of the long expansion begins with a steep fall in the dollar. That would probably prompt a surge of inflation, causing the Fed to increase interest rates, choking growth.
If Europe and Japan were to start investing more in their own economies, and buying more abroad, some pressure on the dollar would ease, padding the ground for a soft landing, the thinking goes.
Mr. Summers's not-so-subtle plea to allies abroad is for them to raise the speed limit on economic growth by setting aside, as the United States has in recent years, the idea that it is better to keep growth well below its potential than to risk even modest inflation.
Europe and Japan are both growing "well below their potential," Mr. Summers said. "Having achieved a cyclical expansion does not constitute the basis for relaxation."
Though Japan has made a huge injection of public capital into its economy and lowered interest rates to near zero, Mr. Summers argues that it must continue to do so. Japan could also do more to stoke its moribund economy by lowering barriers to investment, trade and labor mobility.
Europe is a bigger problem for the Clinton administration. Led by France, many economies there are growing faster now than in recent years. But central bankers have quickly raised interest rates to head off potential inflation and keep the newly unified currency strong, disappointing the United States.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Group of Seven Is Gearing Up for an Expected Nonevent

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Jan. 20

 BODY:
The meeting here this weekend of the men who chart the financial and economic policies of the Group of Seven industrialized nations may turn out to be a nonevent.
At least, that's what their Japanese hosts are hoping. 
 Compared with the last two years, the global economy is in a relatively serendipitous state. Europe is enjoying a strong recovery, the Asian economies have rebounded from crisis to post impressively high growth rates and the United States economy continues to defy the naysayers.
Even Japan, often treated as the naughty child of the international economy, is feeling rather prosperous. The economy appears to have bottomed out for now, and criticism from the United States is likely to be subdued, thanks to a hefty package of pump-priming measures Japan approved last fall and followed up with a generous budget proposal for the coming fiscal year.
"In general the global economic situation has improved, so we may not have difficult or -- how shall I say it? -- adversarial discussions this time," said Haruhiko Kuroda, vice minister of finance for international affairs at the Ministry of Finance.
Nonetheless, the Japanese may pay a high price for harmony. The advance teams that have been working to hammer out language for the communique that will be issued at the end of the meeting have failed to reach an agreement on a statement about foreign exchange.
The Japanese have been pushing for a reiteration of the statement issued after the last G-7 meeting in September, when the yen's rapid appreciation was perceived as a threat to the feeble economic recovery here. The yen fell to a low of 124.32 against the dollar last year, and stands now at 105.29 to the dollar. "We shared Japan's concern about the potential impact of the yen's appreciation for the Japanese economy and the world economy," that statement said.
Although the rise of the yen has abated somewhat since then, Japanese officials are still concerned that a failure to acknowledge some concern about its level will lead to a renewed effort by traders and speculators to increase the value of the currency.
"It's a tricky thing," said one senior official at the Ministry of Finance. "If the market expects there to be some strong language on exchange rates and that doesn't happen and there is disappointment, the reaction could be to force an appreciation of the yen."
But the Europeans are pushing hard to exclude any mention of exchange rates in the statement this time, fearing that would turn attention to what many regard as the weakness of the euro, which now stands at 1.0166 to the dollar. Some in the American and Japanese contingents suspect that the Europeans are quietly fostering a weaker euro to avoid more painful economic changes.
Those who have been trying to work out the language of the final ministerial statement are still wide apart on the issue, with the Japanese pushing for strong language on exchange rates or at least the yen and the Europeans arguing for no mention of exchange rates at all.
The Americans are in the middle, and may agree to make at least a nod toward Japan's concerns. In exchange, they would expect yet another promise from Japan to continue to work hard to encourage domestic consumption and to stop flirting with the notion of raising interest rates.
The United States delegation, too, is piqued at Europe's seeming lack of concern over the value of the euro and may use Japan's concerns as leverage to gain a compromise.
But many think a statement does not matter one way or the other, since the Group of Seven is not likely to back its words up with action. "There's a lot of talk about whether the G-7 communique will include any expression of concern over a strong yen, as it did in September," Marshall Gittler, a currency strategist at the Bank of America, wrote in a report today. "We expect that it will, but we don't think it matters because we don't expect the G-7 to act on those concerns."
As various Bank of Japan officials have pointed out, the stronger yen has not wreaked the havoc that many predicted it would. Japanese companies have managed to post profits despite the yen's higher value, and corporate sentiment continues to improve.
The ministers will also discuss Russia's economic situation, although they are not likely to come to any conclusion about whether the International Monetary Fund should resume its lending. American concerns about Russia's role in the war in Chechnya and the interim nature of the current Russian government are hurdles most consider too high to surmount.
Jockeying to promote various candidates to replace Michel Camdessus as head of the I.M.F. is likely to generate considerable interest, although the topic is not part of the agenda. "Formally, of course, the subject is not up for discussion," Mr. Kuroda said. "Anyway, with so many potential candidates among the participants in the meeting, how can we discuss it except in the corridors?"
Japan will be pushing its dark-horse candidate, Eisuke Sakakibara, the outspoken former occupant of Mr. Kuroda's office. He is considered a long shot, but Japan is still lining up support for him from its Asian neighbors and others.
Officials at the Ministry of Finance acknowledge that if the fund's European shareholders stay united, a European candidate will be unbeatable since those countries control more than 30 percent of the voting shares.
But the Japanese have taken heart in the European failure thus far to coalesce around a candidate, in spite of the stepped-up lobbying efforts by the Germans to promote Caio Koch-Weser, a senior bureaucrat in that country's finance ministry.
The post has traditionally gone to a European, but the Japanese are pushing against convention. "We have significant support for Dr. Sakakibara, and we will not be embarrassed to offer him as a candidate," one Finance Ministry official said. "It's very important to make the point that this is not a decision that is only to be made by the Europeans."

HEADLINE: South (Jersey) Beats North as Retirement Home for Decommissioned Battleship

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS 

 BODY:
Capping a spirited and politically accented competition between Bayonne and Camden, the Department of Defense yesterday chose Camden as the new home port for the decommissioned battleship New Jersey.
In choosing the city in South Jersey, the secretary of the Navy, Richard Danzig, was sending the ship to a berth near the old Philadelphia Naval Shipyards, where the 45,000-ton ship was built in 1942. 
 The existence of a "developed waterfront location with cultural and tourist attractions" at the Camden site played a crucial role in its selection, Mr. Danzig said. Although supporters of the Bayonne site, in the shadow of the Statue of Liberty and Ellis Island, had worked to get the ship for more than 20 years, ultimately they lost out because it was essentially in an industrial area with few other possible tourist draws.
Representative Jim Saxton, a Republican of Mount Holly, a ranking member of the House Armed Services Committee and a major supporter of Camden's bid to be home port, applauded the decision in a news conference at the Camden waterfront with the ship in the background.
Noting that Camden has been dogged by a sagging economy for years, he said that the new ship museum would become a part of a "tourist renaissance."
Farther north, in Bayonne, Assemblyman Joseph Azzolina, chairman of the New Jersey Battleship Commission, which had worked for 20 years to attract the most decorated ship in the American fleet, took the decision with equanimity.
"I said, 'Aye, Aye, sir,' " Mr. Azzolina said, referring to the conversation in which Mr. Danzig delivered the news. "I congratulate Camden and want them to know that the state battleship commission will remain on board to do yeoman service in providing whatever they need."
The decision capped what Cmdr. Brian Cullen, a spokesman for the Navy secretary, called an "enthusiastic, very aggressive and vibrant" regional competition between the two cities for the naval prize. It was a "dynamic situation" that they said they preferred to one in which there was only mild concern about the country's naval heritage and only narrow local support, since shipboard museums must be financially self-sustaining and are viewed by the Navy as recruitment aids.
After Mr. Azzolina's battleship commission was poised to submit a single Bayonne request to the Navy to house the ship at the 437-acre former Military Ocean Terminal, it was Mr. Saxton and others in the Camden area who mounted a determined last-minute campaign.
Mr. Azzolina, a Republican, wondered aloud yesterday whether the "dynamic situation" that Commander Cullen referred to was essentially a political situation.
Mr. Azzolina noted that a combination of Mr. Saxton's prominence on the House Armed Services Committee in the Republican-controlled Congress and the clout with the Democratic Clinton administration of such Camden supporters as Andrew M. Cuomo, the secretary of Housing and Urban Development, and former Mayor Edward G. Rendell of Philadelphia may have worked in favor of Camden and against Bayonne.
He noted that Gov. Christine Todd Whitman, after originally promising to support whatever proposal Mr. Azzolina's commission chose, suddenly declared herself neutral when the Camden supporters, citing concerns about the less populous southern part of the state losing out to the more populous north, pressed the Navy to consider them as well.
In that neutrality, he recalled, she appropriated $6 million in state money for whichever city was successful in getting the New Jersey, thereby suddenly giving Camden a potential pool of money that came close to matching the $8 million in private and local funds that Bayonne had raised over 20 years.
"Some Camden supporters were boasting that politically they had it locked up, but Secretary Danzig assured me that the decision was not political," Mr. Azzolina said. "And I accept that."
The ship, which is about 3 football fields long, 108 feet wide at its beams and sits 6 stories above the waterline, had been in Bremerton, Wash., until last year. It was towed the 5,800 miles to South Jersey, making its 10th passage through the Panama Canal just before control passed to Panama.
"It's truly a proud day for South Jerseyans," Mr. Saxton said. "The U.S.S. New Jersey, which was built by many South Jersey residents on the Delaware River, is returning home."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

F.C.C. Adopts Hiring Rules For Broadcasting Industry
The Federal Communications Commission adopted new rules intended to increase job opportunities for minorities and women in the broadcasting industry, replacing previous guidelines that a federal appeals court said had unconstitutionally imposed quotas.
The new rules, adopted by a vote of 4 to 1, are a carefully fashioned effort by the commission and its chairman, William E. Kennard, to retain some kind of pressure on the broadcasting industry to seek members of minorities and women as job applicants without violating the court's 1998 ruling. Page A16. 

Profits Up 16% at General Electric
General Electric said its fourth-quarter profit rose 16 percent, to $3.09 billion, driven by sales of service contracts at industrial businesses and advertising at its NBC television network. Revenue rose 15 percent, to $32.9 billion. G.E.'s earnings were a penny better than the 92 cents expected by Wall Street analysts, but its shares fell $2.78125, to $145.9375. C2.
 
Blue Chips Fall Again; Nasdaq Gains
Blue-chip stocks fell while signs of growth at technology companies helped push the Nasdaq composite index to another record. The Dow Jones industrial average was down 138.06 points, to 11,351.30. The Nasdaq composite index was up 38.22 points, to 4,189.51. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index declined 10.33 points, to 1,445.57. C5.
 
President Seeking a Tax Change
President Clinton moved to revise a tax that was intended to ensure that wealthy Americans pay some income tax but that has become a fast-growing burden on the middle class, particularly families with children. C2.
 
World Bank Sells Notes on Internet
The World Bank marked two firsts with its sale of $3 billion in three-year notes. It sold them directly to retail investors and offered them over the Internet. C5.
 
Lucent's Profit Down as Forecast
Lucent Technologies said it earned $1.25 billion in its most recent quarter, less than half of its profit a year earlier, as the company delivered the disappointing results it had forecast two weeks ago. C16.
 
Overture by Vodafone Is Rebuffed
Vodafone AirTouch said it was prepared to offer a modest sweetener to its all-stock bid for Mannesmann, now valued at $155 billion, but the German company spurned the overture as "wholly inadequate." Christopher Gent, Vodafone's chief executive, said his own stockholders would not countenance a bigger increase. Vodafone's hostile takeover attempt, the largest ever, was begun on Nov. 19. C3.
 
Split of a Chicago Exchange Urged
Responding to the growing threat of competition from electronic trading systems, the directors of the Chicago Board of Trade voted overwhelmingly to split the exchange into two for-profit companies. The plan is subject to approval by its members. C5.
 
Coca-Cola Forms Units in Europe
Coca-Cola, grappling to restore its image after product-contamination troubles last year, formed two units to manage its business in Europe, Russia and Turkey. C5.
 
G.M. Profit Better Than Expected
General Motors said it earned $1.15 billion in the fourth quarter, topping Wall Street's expectations, as its sales increased 3.7 percent, to $46 billion. C4.
 
Intel Announces Education Program
Intel announced a three-year $100 million program to help 100,000 elementary and secondary school teachers integrate computers and the Internet into their classrooms. A16.
 
Global Trade Group to Meet in Tokyo
Currency exchange rates are likely to be a much-disputed issue when ministers from the Group of Seven industrialized nations meet this weekend in Tokyo. C3.

HEADLINE: Jobless Claims Continue to Drop

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20

 BODY:
The number of Americans filing new claims for unemployment benefits fell last week, while continued claims were at their lowest level in 11 years, the government said today in a report that indicated hiring remains robust.
First-time claims for state jobless benefits dropped 39,000 in the week that ended last Saturday, to 272,000, from 311,000 the week before, the Labor Department said. The drop was steeper than had been expected by economists, who had predicted an average 295,000 new claims in an informal survey. 
 Continued claims -- the number of people who have already claimed a week or more of benefits -- fell to 2.009 million in the week that ended on Jan. 8, the latest week for which figures were available.
It was the lowest level since 2.006 million in the week ended Dec. 3, 1988.
The closely watched four-week moving average, which smoothes out weekly fluctuations, fell to 292,000 for the week that ended last Saturday from 294,750 for the prior week, extending its run of less than 300,000 to 26 consecutive weeks, the longest such period since one that ran from July 29, 1972, to Jan. 5, 1974.
In the week ended Jan. 8, the latest week for which state-by-state figures were available, the department said 32 states reported an increase in claims exceeding 1,000 or more, led by California with 21,599 more claims.
That state attributed its rise in claims to a return to a five-day work week after the New Year's holiday.
In the same week, the Labor Department said six states reported a decrease in claims exceeding 1,000 or more, led by Wisconsin with 6,862 fewer claims in the construction and service industries, and manufacturing.
