HEADLINE: In Remote Alaska, Counting Begins for the Census

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES 

DATELINE: UNALAKLEET, Alaska, Jan. 20

 BODY:
Stanton Katchatag, an 82-year-old Inuit, answered a knock on his door here today at 10:50 a.m. and found himself facing Kenneth Prewitt, the director of the Census Bureau. Mr. Katchatag invited him in and offered him a chair.
Mr. Prewitt, who rode a dog sled into town at the end of a trip that took him across four time zones, got right down to business. Pulling out the census short form, he asked Mr. Katchatag his age, how he spelled his name, and his race. (American Indian or Alaska Native is the term the Census Bureau uses for Inuits, an ethnic designation now preferred by many of the native people once known as Eskimos.) 
 Describing the scene to reporters afterward, Mr. Katchatag said Mr. Prewitt asked for similar information about the only other person living in the one-story cedar-frame house, Mr. Katchatag's wife, Irene. When the 15-minute interview was over Mr. Katchatag, whose ancestors were among the first people to inhabit the North American continent, became the first person to be officially counted in the 2000 census.
Displaying plenty of excitement but only a vague grasp of population figures, Mayor Henry Ivanoff of this tiny fishing village on the Bering Sea said, "That means that over 225 million people will be standing in line behind him, including the president of the United States and the vice president, including the governors and lieutenant governors of all the 50 states, including Michael Jordan."
The interview here began the 2000 census, an effort to count the population of the United States and find out where every one of the estimated 275 million Americans are living on April 1. The Constitution calls for a count every 10 years to fix the number of House seats for each state, and states use the number to draw legislative districts. In addition, billions of dollars in federal aid will be distributed on the basis of how the population is counted.
The operation will send census takers to impoverished villages on the Mexican border, to islands off Maine and to shifting groups of shanties erected by homeless people in the nation's large cities.
This critical count is taking place in a nation that is more diverse than ever and that has often been termed less cooperative than ever. It is also taking place when political power between the major parties is balanced on a razor's edge.
Forms will be mailed to more than 120 million households, and about half a million census takers will be dispatched to interview the roughly 40 percent of households that do not return the forms. Census statisticians will then tabulate the results for months.
"Census 2000 is the opportunity to paint a picture of the country at one of its most dynamic periods in its history," said Mr. Prewitt, who began the count going from house to house past aluminum-frame fishing boats set on blocks in front yards.
Ten years ago, the Census Bureau began the 1990 census in remote parts of Alaska in the dead of winter two months before forms are mailed out to the rest of the country. Bureau officials say it is more cost-efficient to try to count in person the estimated 50,000 people, mostly Inuits, who are scattered throughout the 250 million square miles of Alaska's most remote areas. In the winter, census takers can travel by snowmobile and dog sled before people scatter to even more isolated hunting and fishing camps in the spring.
Over all, the logistical, demographic and political challenges facing the Census Bureau are as daunting as the trackless wilderness outside Unalakleet, a village of 800 people 450 miles northwest of Anchorage.
This years' census is by far the most expensive in the nation's history, even taking inflation into account. So far, the cost of the 2000 census is estimated at $6.8 billion, a huge increase over the $2.6 billion spent in 1990. Yet, all the expense will not protect the Census Bureau from challenges in the political arena and the courts.
"We're living in a period with very balanced political control between Republicans and Democrats," said Margo Anderson, a professor of history at the University of Wisconsin, Milwaukee, who is an expert on the census. "So both parties see opportunities in the census, the redistricting process and the presidential election to resolve the current stalemate to their advantage."
The bureau is hoping it can slow a decades-old decline in the proportion of people who take the time to fill out their census forms and mail them back. In 1990, 65 percent of American households that received the form completed and returned it, down from the 78 percent that did so in 1970. This year, the bureau is planning on a 61 percent return rate.
In Alaska, only 52 percent of the households that received the forms sent them back in, the nation's lowest return rate.
Census Bureau officials are planning a $102.8 million advertising campaign -- the largest ever for a census -- aimed at members of minority groups, people who rent and those living in mobile homes who tend not to return their census forms. Executives of Young & Rubicam, which is handling the advertising campaign, estimate that many African-Americans will see the census commercials as many as 120 times, and that some Hispanics could see them as many 105 times by the end of April.
The bureau is also working with local governments and community groups in an effort to convince people to return the forms.
Starting on March 27, a short time after the forms are first sent out and running until April 11, the bureau will post on the Internet the mail-back rate for every city, town and village in the country, hoping that publicizing the response rates will spur competitions among municipalities.
Still, not everyone is pleased with the Census Bureau's efforts. William E. Spriggs, director of research and public policy at the National Urban League, said that beyond informing community groups of the importance of the census, the bureau has come up with few concrete ideas on how community organizations can help.
"In many cases they have not done more than visit our affiliates and say the census is important," Mr. Spriggs said. "We've known that for five years. So we are left relying on them because we're not really in the process."
The census bureau will also try to hire more than 500,000 temporary workers, in an economy with a jobless rate of 4.1 percent, the lowest it has been since the 1960's. Because there is such a high turnover in these jobs, the bureau says it will need an applicant pool of about three million people.
Census officials are also trying to improve on their performance from 1990 when, according to later studies, more than eight million people were missed and four million other people were counted twice. The undercount was particularly severe among children, African-Americans living in major cities and Hispanics living in rural areas.
"The thing that we're worried about is that the causes for the undercount in 1990 haven't gone away -- in some ways they've increased," said Marisa Demeo, regional counsel for the Washington office of the Mexican American Legal Defense and Education Fund. "So we know there still will be an undercount, even with the bureau's best efforts."
To avoid a large undercount, officials plan to conduct a nationwide survey of a randomly selected sample of 300,000 households. It will use the results to adjust population counts in geographic areas containing an average of 100 people.
That statistical sampling, while scientifically sound, has run afoul of partisan politics. Because a large percentage of those missed, mainly racial and ethnic minorities, tend to live in Democratic areas, adjusting their population totals upward will give Democrats an advantage when states draw new boundaries for Congressional and state legislative districts for the new decade.
Oblivious to the concerns of the Census Bureau, the residents of Unalakleet were thrilled to be the first place to be counted. Scores of schoolchildren greeted Mr. Prewitt's flight from Anchorage on Wednesday with handmade welcome signs. He was given a traditional parka trimmed in wolverine fur, and mittens fashioned from the heads of wolves. On a snowy tarmac, the census director exchanged his black wing tips for white insulated boots and was whisked into town by dog sled.
Census officials selected Unalakleet to start the new census because the town has a reputation for welcoming outsiders. Indeed, it is a stop every March on the Iditarod dog race, and the townspeople are used to the presence of the news media and celebrities.
"In the old days we used to get folks like Terry Bradshaw and Lynn Swann," said Tim Towarak, the city administrator. "But this is much more exciting. They concentrated on the dog mushers. They've got their own little world. This is affecting the whole community."

HEADLINE: New Jersey Plans Grand Makeover for Ellis Island

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HALBFINGER 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Jan. 20

 BODY:
New Jersey officials sketched a $300 million vision today for the redevelopment of Ellis Island, most of which has been concealed behind overgrown weeds and chain-link fences from the millions who visit every year.
They hope the plan will turn the long-neglected island in New York Harbor into a setting for meetings, including local corporate conferences and global peace talks, with new museums devoted to America's immigrant heritage and the study of public health. 
 As a more urgent -- and realistic -- first step, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman said that $8.6 million had been secured from state, federal and private sources to stabilize dozens of decrepit buildings around the island, especially on its tumbledown southern half, what is known as the sad side, where immigrants too sick to be allowed entry were housed in hospital wards until they recovered, or died. The total needed for this step is $10.9 million, she said.
"As New Jerseyans, we take great pride in our history," the governor said today at a news conference. "But we must also take care of our history so that future generations can share our pride and visit these landmarks of our national journey. We owe it to our future to preserve our past."
The announcements today marked a dramatic and, by governmental standards, rapid turnabout in the status of Ellis Island, which after decades of neglect by the federal government was labeled one of the country's most endangered historic places in 1997 by the National Trust for Historic Preservation.
In 1998, the Supreme Court ended a long border dispute between New York and New Jersey by awarding Trenton sovereignty over most of the island's 27.5 acres.
New York's share includes the main immigrant museum and Great Hall, although the border passes through parts of buildings and grounds.
Although the island remained under federal control -- the National Park Service owns and operates it -- Governor Whitman immediately asserted herself in determining its future. An 18-member committee she appointed quickly ruled out a commercial project, cheering those who had feared that the island would be used for hotels or a theme park.
Preservationists greeted today's news with enthusiasm. "I think New Jersey has been a wonderful thing to happen to Ellis Island," said Peg Breen, president of the New York Landmarks Conservancy. She added, "They understand the importance of the heritage of Ellis Island and have respected it with these recommendations."
Ms. Breen noted that New Jersey prison inmates began pulling up weeds and carting away garbage from the overgrown parts of the island last April, saving hundreds of thousands of dollars in contracting and hauling fees. "With all due respect to New York," she added, "New York never did any of this."
In its final report to the governor today, the committee recommended three main uses for the island.
A Center for Immigrant Contributions and Ethnic Learning would research and mount exhibitions celebrating the immigrant experience, encompassing not only those Americans who passed through Ellis Island, but also those who arrived in slave ships from Africa and the Caribbean, and more recent immigrants from around the world.
One objective of the center would be to illuminate "the nation's seemingly contradictory practices of ethnic exclusion, discrimination, pluralism, assimilation and tolerance," the report says.
Though the report states that the center would avoid "overly focusing on specific immigrant or ethnic groups," Finn Casperson, the committee's chairman, said many ethnic groups could be expected to help in either lobbying for money or contributing it, among them the descendants of Irish, German, Scandinavian, African and Asian immigrants.
The second use, a Public Health Learning Center, would build upon the island's history as the birthplace of the United States Public Health Service. Dr. C. Everett Koop, the former surgeon general, is leading an effort to build a public health museum in Washington, and Representative Robert Franks, a Republican from New Providence, N.J., has introduced legislation that would create a satellite of that museum on Ellis Island.
Third, an International Conference Center would be the first in the United States on a publicly owned, nationally recognized site, according to the report. The committee went so far as to suggest that the island's proximity to New York City and its "insulated and tranquil" atmosphere could place it in the elite company of Versailles and Geneva as a suitable setting for peace talks or global economic meetings.
The center would be publicly developed, but financed largely with private money, Mr. Casperson said. New Jersey's many pharmaceutical companies, "who are renowned for their conferences," could be expected both to pay for its construction and to make use of the center, he added. Hotels could be built on available land in Jersey City.
Nevertheless, Mr. Casperson, a prominent Republican contributor who is a former chief executive of the Beneficial Corporation, said much of the $300 million it would take to fully rebuild Ellis Island would have to come from Washington. "I strongly believe, and maybe I'm naive, but this happened on the federal government's watch," he said. "They were the ones who let the buildings go."
The financing announced today was paltry by comparison, but of no small importance, officials said. Governor Whitman said she would include $1 million in her proposed budget, which is due soon, to preserve the baggage and dormitory building, the largest on Ellis Island and the one in the gravest danger of collapse. The National Park Service will provide another $1 million.
Of the $6.6 million needed to stabilize the hospital buildings, Congress has contributed $2 million and Trenton $2.3 million, and the rest is still being sought. A $2.3 million project to save the pedestrian passageway is fully financed, officials said, half from the federal government and half from a private donor they would not yet identify.
"Time is of the essence," Mr. Casperson said. "The buildings are falling apart. They need to be restored. We have momentum, but we must act now. We cannot afford to put it off for another decade."

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE IOWA EQUATION;
Ethanol, for All Its Critics, Fuels Farmer Support and Iowa's Role in Presidential Races

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF 

DATELINE: ROCK RAPIDS, Iowa, Jan. 14

 BODY:
One of the oddest features of the presidential selection system is the way the candidates troop to Iowa and rave about corn alcohol.
The brew is not moonshine, but ethanol, a gasoline additive that here in the heartland is as American as hogs. 
 Marvin Flier, a hefty and amiable 44-year-old who grows corn and soybeans on his 650-acre farm near Rock Rapids, in the northwestern corner of the state, has watched with a bit of satisfaction as the presidential candidates have come to Iowa, seeking support in the Jan. 24 caucuses, and solemnly declared their support for tax breaks for ethanol.
"Sometimes I think they just come out and pander to us," Mr. Flier reflected. Then he added, "Of course, that may not be the worst thing."
Ethanol, introduced after the 1973-74 oil crisis, is hailed by its supporters as a way to avoid dependence on foreign oil and, because it is clean-burning, as a solution to air pollution. But many experts have been unimpressed, and a 1997 study by the General Accounting Office, a research arm of Congress, concluded that tax breaks for ethanol had cost the Treasury $7.1 billion while having "little effect" on the environment or on American energy independence.
In Iowa, though, ethanol plays a critical role in the agricultural economy. So perhaps it is not surprising that every candidate who is campaigning in Iowa supports tax breaks for ethanol.
Former Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey, who is challenging Vice President Al Gore for the Democratic nomination, has even reversed his longstanding opposition to ethanol, saying that farmers he has talked to changed his mind. Only Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, has denounced tax breaks for ethanol. But Mr. McCain is not campaigning in Iowa.
"McCain's a good man and has a strong character, but what he said about ethanol -- that probably cost him my vote," Mr. Flier said. "Now I'm leaning to Bush."
The ethanol debate underscores the peculiar effects of the nation's presidential selection system, for Iowa's role as the first state to vote in the presidential nomination process is perhaps one reason the ethanol tax break has survived for more than two decades.
The longtime support of former Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, a powerful farm-state politician and three-time presidential contender, buttressed the tax break for ethanol.
But ethanol is less a partisan issue than a regional one; it is supported by Democrats and Republicans alike in major farm states. And wherever they are from, ambitious politicians who see themselves as presidential timber may feel inclined to support ethanol just to preserve the option of campaigning in Iowa.
"Given that the logic of ethanol is more about politics than environmental protection, the fact that Iowa has an early caucus looms large," said Daniel C. Esty, director of the Center for Environmental Law and Policy at Yale University.
In the 1970's, ethanol seemed an answer to energy and environmental problems alike. It is clean-burning and is produced from home-grown corn, so the federal government instituted a series of tax breaks to encourage ethanol production. Ethanol-blended gasoline is taxed 5.4 cents less per gallon than pure gasoline, and most experts agree that the ethanol industry would disappear without that advantage.
To critics, ethanol is a prime example of an infant industry that never grows up to become competitive on its own. In addition, ethanol evaporates more easily than gasoline, and so in the hot summer months this can create its own pollution problems of ozone, or smog.
"Ethanol helps with some air pollution problems and worsens others," said A. Blakeman Early, an environmental consultant with the American Lung Association in Washington. "You begin to wonder whether it's really worth it to have a subsidy when in some circumstances it can make air pollution worse."
While making it clear that he did not condemn ethanol, Mr. Early said that if the goal was to improve air quality, one might accomplish more by using the money in other ways.
Critics also often note that it takes a tremendous amount of energy just to produce ethanol -- plowing the fields, planting the seeds, harvesting the corn, trucking it -- and some even suggest, without much evidence, that ethanol may take more energy to produce than it supplies. Moreover, almost half of the capacity to produce ethanol is owned by Archer Daniels Midland, the huge agricultural conglomerate that is a heavy campaign contributor to Republicans and Democrats alike. Some critics see the ethanol program as returning a favor.
"This is a classic case of a corporate welfare-style giveaway," said Scott Harshbarger, president of Common Cause, a public affairs lobbying organization.
So it might meet seem odd that the presidential candidates would be rushing around Iowa praising tax breaks for an alcohol fuel that does not much impress many experts. But that is to miss the point, because regardless of whether ethanol is a great fuel for cars, it certainly works wonders in Iowa campaigns.
The one thing that everybody agrees on is that the ethanol tax break raises corn prices, and in the Midwest, where family farms are struggling to survive desperately low prices for their products, that counts for a lot. Farming has been left behind in the great economic expansion of the Clinton administration; in Iowa alone, thousands of farmers have been forced out of business.
The toll hangs heavy over entire rural communities as farmers delay purchases and their families wonder which would be worse: for the children to pack up and leave the farm or to stay on and risk impoverishment. By some calculations, without ethanol, corn prices would be 20 percent lower than they already are.
Mr. Flier recalls that when he began farming in 1975, he was getting $2.40 a bushel for his corn. This year the price was about $1.40. Yet he said the same tractor that he bought in 1975 for $18,000 would now cost $75,000. And his other costs have also increased enormously.
"If we didn't have ethanol, that would take a lot of our earnings away," Mr. Flier said. "Ethanol allows us to maintain our standard of living."
Don Breuker, a farm manager here in Rock Rapids, put it more starkly.
"You start peeling off another 20 or 30 cents a bushel out of farm incomes," Mr. Breuker said, "and there'd be a whole lot of hurt right now."
The farmers also dispute many of the points made by ethanol's critics.
Trevor Guthmiller, executive director of the American Coalition for Ethanol, says the tax break was deserved because ethanol did not entail the cleanup costs of gasoline pollution and did not involve the expense of maintaining the military capacity abroad to ensure steady supplies of imported petroleum.
Both the farmers and the ethanol industry view the Iowa campaign period as a rare opportunity to make their case.
"Part of our work is educating people," Mr. Guthmiller said, "and we can do that because whether they're Democrats or Republicans, they need to come through Iowa. And that's our chance."

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Office Space Sought

 BODY:
Senator Charles E. Schumer announced yesterday that he had formed a blue-ribbon panel to address what he described as the greatest obstacle facing New York City's economy: a lack of office space for the financial services, high technology and biotech industries.
Mr. Schumer, corporate executives and developers say that the dearth of space is forcing many of the city's most dynamic companies to move elsewhere and is undercutting the growth of the local economy. Goldman Sachs, the investment bank, recently bought land in Jersey City after it was unable to find development sites near its corporate campus in Lower Manhattan. 
 The panel, called the Group of 30, is to issue a report in six months with recommendations for initiatives by the state and city.
Mr. Schumer said a starting point could be developing office projects outside Manhattan through partnerships between government and private companies.
"The fact is that too many dynamic growth businesses which New York is spawning are landing someplace else once they need to grow," he said.
Mr. Schumer and Robert E. Rubin, the former Treasury secretary, will lead the panel, whose members include Fernando Espuelas, president of Starmedia.com; Gerald Levin, chief executive of Time Warner; Arnold Levine, president of Rockefeller University; and Brian McLaughlin of the Central Labor Council.

Jobless Rate Is Down

BYLINE: AP 

 BODY:
New York's unemployment rate fell to 4.8 percent in December, the first time since 1988 that joblessness in the state has dipped below 5 percent, state labor analysts reported yesterday. 
 Unemployment dropped 0.2 percentage points between November and December, and last month's rate was 0.6 percentage points less than the December 1998 rate.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE ORGANIZATION;
Bradley's Most Influential Adviser? Bradley

BYLINE: By MELINDA HENNEBERGER 

DATELINE: DES MOINES, Jan. 20

 BODY:
Bill Bradley does not have advisers in the traditional sense -- and does not need any, according to many of those who are acting, as the candidate's friend Dan Okimoto put it, "more as a sounding board, raising doubts here and there."
"His mastery obviates the need for close policy advisers," said Mr. Okimoto, a college buddy, now a professor of international relations at Stanford University, and someone with whom Mr. Bradley discusses a number of matters, including foreign policy. "There is no such structure in place on foreign policy or any other issue. The candidate is in charge of tone, direction, vision, and those around him provide support. Both in a political sense and on policy, Bill Bradley is his campaign." 
 But his campaign -- that is to say, Mr. Bradley himself -- is perceived to have made several missteps recently. Mr. Bradley seemed to flub a presidential debate on agriculture here. And his decision to spend so much time in Iowa, where his campaign appears to be lagging, instead of concentrating on New Hampshire, where he is in a tight race, has been widely questioned.
Now, even some supporters say the holes in the campaign are starting to show.
Joe Trippi, an unaligned Democratic consultant who ran Walter F. Mondale's Iowa campaign in 1984 and has had generally positive things to say about the Bradley campaign, said: "He really is running his campaign the way he wants to run it, and I'm not sure he's taking any advice. That's always a bad sign. The move to Iowa definitely was a risky gambit, and I don't think I would have advised it."
Still, Mr. Trippi said, it is only after next Monday's caucuses that "we'll see if Iowa was a big mistake -- or brilliant."
Meanwhile, one of Mr. Bradley's sounding boards, his wife, Ernestine Schlant, a professor of comparative literature at Montclair State College, has a theory about politics that might apply: Any candidate's greatest asset almost always turns out to be his greatest liability as well, she said in an interview last summer, citing Bill Clinton and his personal warmth and empathy as a case in point.
And while both Mr. Bradley's broad knowledge and his determination to "run a different kind of campaign," as he likes to say, have been keys to his appeal, his deep involvement in every aspect of his campaign has also left him vulnerable.
Both his Democratic opponent, Vice President Al Gore and the Republican front-runner, George W. Bush, have been criticized for relying too much on consultants of all sorts. But those in opposing camps -- advisers themselves, of course, with a clear interest in the perceived importance of their work -- insist that the lack of a more formal advisory structure in the Bradley campaign is a problem. And they say a truly smart candidate is smart enough to know he needs help.
"The truth is that politics is a team sport," one Bush adviser said. "The quarterback gets the credit, but you still need a defensive line, and I haven't seen that in Bradley's camp, which is a huge problem."
Critics have called Mr. Bradley glacially slow in responding to attacks, particularly on his health care plan, leaving Mr. Gore's assertion that it would hurt poor people virtually unchallenged for a long while.
And when he finally did fight back, for example by raising Mr. Gore's complicated history with tobacco companies, what may have been perfectly legitimate questions were seen as out of bounds because he had set himself up as a candidate who was above that kind of give-and-take.
On those and other campaign decisions, it is not that Mr. Bradley listens to no one, but that, on the contrary, he listens to a great number of people -- and then makes the important calls himself. It was Mr. Bradley who chose child poverty, health care, race relations and gun control as the central issues in his campaign. And who, to a surprising degree, mapped out the plans he wanted to see put in place.
His staff insists that he does not micromanage, and is happy to leave to others the mechanical, logistical details like booking planes and deciding which field directors go where. Even in this, though, "he does like to be keep informed, and will tell us if we're going the wrong direction," said his campaign chairman, Douglas Berman.
And the list of ways Mr. Bradley is in control of his campaign is staggering.
Back when nobody but Mr. Bradley, Mr. Berman and a couple of other Bradley die-hards thought it was possible to raise even a fraction of the money the campaign has raised, the senator showed how it could be done, by pulling in people who had not been politically active before.
Marcia Aronoff, his adviser on policy, said he had been refining ideas for a health care plan for years and reached out to hundreds of people.
"I don't think you're going to see every decision coming back through him, but on health care -- the cornerstone -- or child poverty, he takes an active interest. Or improving race relations. Or key economic and foreign policy decisions."
David M. Cutler, a Harvard economics professor considered one of the chief architects of Mr. Bradley's health care plan, said, "I don't consider myself to be an incredibly important adviser." Told that nobody else seemed to, either, he said, "I had a sneaking suspicion that was true.
"He's a very intelligent man, so he didn't need the getting up to speed that a lot of candidates need."
The association is so loose, Professor Cutler added, that "I don't think I've ever actually met him. And I don't know if he's ever made a formal decision that, 'Oh, now you're X adviser.' I found him very impressive -- and I don't know him well, so it's kind of the same way I find the pope, impressive -- but he listens to a lot of voices."
Dr. Alan Garber, a Stanford professor who said he was one of those "putting the details together" for the health plan that Mr. Bradley wanted, said the most surprising part of the process was the lack of dissension among those discussing the options. "Everyone liked Bill's idea, and it really is his plan," he said.
On political strategy, too, Mr. Bradley is the final arbiter.
And his staff includes a core group that has been with him so long that its members often reflect the way he thinks. His campaign chairman, Mr. Berman, met Mr. Bradley when he was an adoring high school senior, on the morning after the Knicks won an N.B.A. championship, and has been with him since his first Senate campaign in 1977. His finance director, Rick Wright, played basketball with Mr. Bradley at Princeton 35 years ago. Ms. Aronoff was his longtime chief of staff in the Senate.
Of these, a friend and former aide to Mr. Bradley says, "It would only be a slight hyperbole to say Doug is the first person he calls in the morning and the last one he talks to at night. On political strategy, it's Doug and Bill."
Yet Mr. Berman describes his job this way: "If I have a role," he said, "it's being clear and helping people understand the values that course through the organization as a reflection of Bill."
He said the proof that Mr. Bradley was not too much of a one-man show was in the campaign's organizing successes: 'We filed in 31 of 31 districts in New York, he was first to file in Oklahoma, we raised twice as much money as the vice president in the fourth quarter, and more people in California signed up to be delegates for Bill Bradley than the vice president."
And Mr. Berman suggested that the campaign had taken some hits on purpose.
When Mr. Bradley gave a confused response to a question about whether he had voted against flood relief -- in fact, he had voted for the bill, but against an amendment -- there was some delay before the campaign clarified the facts.
Asked why, Mr. Berman said campaign staff members never spoke publicly about how specific decisions were made. Then he went on to say, "But Bradley has said, 'I want to run a campaign as an extension of the way I want to govern, to restore trust and bring back civility.' And if you say that, you have to operate that way. It's not that at times there's not the impulse to operate at a different level. But those who elevate tactics, we disagree with."
To some degree, of course, the Bradley campaign's position that it is above all that is itself a tactic. Whatever advice Mr. Bradley does receive is purposely underplayed by the campaign, which does not want to be seen as doing much of anything in the usual way. "Advisers," Mr. Berman said, "are never the story."
And Richard Ravitch, a leading New York Democrat who has gone over ideas about housing and urban development with Mr. Bradley's staff, suggested that the status of some advisers was still a bit of a mystery, even to them.
"Where'd you get my name?" Mr. Ravitch asked. Told he was considered someone Mr. Bradley listened to, he said, "Glad to hear it."

HEADLINE: Talking Back On Black Talk Radio;
A Roiling Conversation on the Air That Can Amuse or Embolden

BYLINE: By MONTE WILLIAMS 

 BODY:
It is midafternoon, two days before Y2K, and Sarah from Brooklyn is calling WLIB, the city's premier black talk radio station. She is dismayed about Rudy Crew's exit as the schools chancellor, and she has her own take on the reason for it.
"I strongly believe this, and I told this to a number of educators the day after the Board of Education raised Crew's salary to over $200,000," Sarah said, just getting started on her, um, unique theory. 
 "That was more money than the president of the United States of America makes. Did one African-American really think that that amount of a raise was really for a black man in office? That amount of money was raised because the mayor knew Rudy Crew's time was short, and that raise was secured for the next Caucasian female, who is an educator and who I happen to know and I happen to believe will be the next chancellor."
Minutes before, Puffy Combs was the subject on WLIB, and the phones were ringing as if the station were conducting a cash giveaway. Several callers were supportive of Mr. Combs, the rap star and record promoter who was arrested late last month on a gun charge. But one listener was riled at the self-described "ghetto fabulous" impresario.
"A man of Puffy's caliber, his status, which they allege that he has millions of dollars, shouldn't he get security and not these nitwit brains he has securing him?" the caller sniffed. "A gun in the car. I mean this is really ridiculous, and you see it over and over again with these so-called millionaire rappers."
Mark Riley, the host of "Politics Live" on WLIB-AM (1190), agreed. "If you're going to have somebody who's going to be armed, have somebody who's licensed, a professional," he said. "What happens is these guys pick the biggest cat they used to run with."
And so it goes, day after day on WLIB and a handful of other stations that broadcast talk shows geared to the full range of the city's black listeners. On some shows, the talk can be angry and conflicted, with hosts and callers tackling everything from trouble hailing cabs to Amadou Diallo to the use of the word "niggaz" on a popular DMX record. Other conversations can be more mainstream, where, for instance, one might hear sad, knowing talk about the people from Princeville, N.C., the nation's first black-governed town, which was ravaged by rains last fall.
"Black talk radio is the drum of the community," said Imhotep Gary Byrd, a popular former host at WLIB.
But if much of the city, black or white, is aware of black talk radio's existence, its various conversations -- irreverent, emotional, academic and, yes, sometimes conspiratorial -- are not regularly heard by the city's mainstream.
Several weeks of sustained listening, then, revealed a rich and varied dialogue, one that made it easy to understand why black talk radio has long functioned as a roiling, playful and galvanizing lifeline for blacks in New York City.
State Assemblyman Roger Green of Brooklyn was recently a guest on "The Open Line," a Sunday morning talk show on WRKS-FM (98.7), better known as KISS-FM. Mr. Green compared the current foster care system to chattel slavery.
"We have mothers who are coming into my office on a weekly basis who have literally had their babies in some cases torn from their breasts," he said. He also called "the prison-industrial complex" a menace to black children, "who are being picked like cotton and being shipped upstate."
In New York State last year the only growth in the governor's budget was in prisons, he said. "There's no question that people come to Albany to lobby to create prisons," he said. "It's become a perverse economic stimulus package for poor whites in rural white areas." In reality, the governor did propose modest spending increases in other areas.
Such conversations have been going on a long time. Black talk radio had its genesis in Chicago in 1948 on WSBC, where Jack I. Cooper was the host, said Bob Law, a veteran of both talk and rhythm and blues radio. Mr. Law, now on WWRL-AM (1600), a black-owned-and-operated station in Woodside, Queens, recently wrote a book about black radio, "Voices for the Future," published by African-American Images. Mr. Law said another show, "Brown America Speaks," emerged on WDIA in Memphis that same year. The host was Mat D. Williams, a popular newspaper columnist.
"Black talk was the only outlet for the frustration and the attainment of information," Mr. Law said.
"Without black talk," he added, "the community becomes voiceless. White talk is not neutral or impartial. It's Eurocentric. White talk raises no critical questions. Right now, Clinton has encouraged European countries not to buy bananas from Caribbean farmers. He wants them to buy only from Chiquita or Dole. The bananas they were selling to European countries were just enough to sustain them. This issue is never examined on white talk."
In the early days at WLIB, talk radio was an outgrowth of public affairs requirements imposed by the Federal Communications Commission. "There was no real energy in it," Mr. Law said. "It was not a priority. Some of the disc jockeys had to come back and do these public affairs shows about health, housing and education."
Today, four New York City stations have black talk shows. Judy Ellis, the general manager at KISS-FM, said "The Open Line" had 139,200 listeners, while the station's Sunday night show, "The Week in Review," had 36,300 listeners. (KISS's overall listenership for people 12 and older is 1,288,500, which places it in the top 10 in the New York market.)
WLIB management said it did not have figures for individual shows, but the mostly talk radio station has a listenership of 280,300 for people 12 and older. WBAI-FM (99.5), which has five black hosts, including Elombe Brath, the activist and artist, has about 200,000 listeners, according to management. And WWRL, which has a show by Tony Brown, a well-known broadcaster, has 250,000 listeners.
James Mtume, a member of KISS-FM's talk team and a Grammy award-winning composer, said there was tremendous growth potential in black talk radio. "Given the landscape, I think black talk radio is a sleeping giant ready to blow up," he said. "People would love something else other than the next love songs. Blacks are starved for information."
Black talk radio has not been without controversy over some of its content. In the early 1990's, for example, the Jewish Action Alliance held protests over comments made during the Crown Heights riots. "On WLIB and WWRL there was an unbelievable amount of anti-Semitism," said Beth Gilinsky, president of the group. "We held demonstrations. It was 1991, during the year of the Crown Heights riots. We located their sponsors and they started pulling ads."
But employees of black-owned and black-programmed stations say their shows are held to a different standard than the white mainstream. Steve Rendall, a senior analyst at Fairness and Accuracy in Reporting, a national media watch group, echoed the sentiment.
"We've noted and quoted the occasional black talk radio host," said Mr. Rendall. "But in New York City, the irresponsible comments from black radio hosts are nothing compared to the torrent of bigoted talk that comes from white hosts on big mainstream radio stations."
Undeniably, black talk radio is chiefly driven by the city's great engine of emotional discourse: race. And virtually every week brings a new framing question.
After the actor Danny Glover's problem getting a cab in New York in the fall, the mayor's offensive on cab drivers who bypass blacks dominated the shows. At KISS-FM, a panel of pundits discussed the improvements they had already witnessed since the mayor announced that he would revoke the hack licenses and impound the taxis of drivers who whiz by blacks.
"Friday was one of the days that a brother could get out there and put his arm out and a cab would stop," said Bob Slade, a talk radio veteran and the moderator of the Sunday night show, "The Week in Review." "You could be talking, making an expression and the arm would accidentally go up and the cab would stop."
Meanwhile on WLIB, Mr. Riley, the host of "Politics Live," discussed Dr. Lenora Fulani, a black radical former presidential candidate who has endorsed Patrick Buchanan, the Reform Party candidate, for president. "What some people thought was the strangest match in this century or in any other century, for that matter," Mr. Riley began, "was Pat Buchanan and Dr. Lenora Fulani, late of the New Alliance Party, but obviously functioning now within the Reform Party.
"Obviously, she is Buchanan's most prominent black backer. She has promised to take him to Sylvia's and some other places. Somehow Pat Buchanan and soul food don't work well with me. But I have an open mind. Hey, Dr. Fulani could have him rioting before this is all over."
But if there was something loopily hilarious about Pat Buchanan eating at Sylvia's in Harlem, things got heated when Minister Conrad Muhammad took over the mike at WLIB last week during his show, "One on One." Mr. Muhammad, the minister of Mosque No. 7 in Harlem, had Karl Evanzz as a guest to discuss his book, "The Messenger: The Rise and Fall of Elijah Muhammad." The author made a case for the Nation of Islam leader's resilience in the face of years of monitoring by the Federal Bureau of Investigation. But then, Mr. Evanzz, as others have, accused Elijah Muhammad of being the father of several illegitimate children.
A livid caller lashed out at Mr. Evanzz, an on-line editor at The Washington Post. "The Messenger was 100 percent true to what he taught until his departure in 1974," the caller said. "This F.B.I. business about producing children at Temple 2, a temple which is full of hypocrites since the 1930's, making children by sisters and charging the messenger with this evil. So this person writing this book does not have his facts. Stop slandering the Honorable Elijah Muhammad."
Callers on black talk radio stations, not unlike on other radio stations, can be unpredictable. Several months after the fact, Mark from Brooklyn wanted to talk about the Klan's anemic march in downtown Manhattan, although Utrice Leid, the host of Talk Back, a call-in show on WBAI, was discussing Hillary Rodham Clinton's run for the United States Senate.
"When the Klan was marching I didn't see no responsible black leadership speaking against the Klan," Mark said. "Did you notice anybody?
"I mean, maybe it's just me. Those same voices that said, 'Oh, no, Khallid this, Sharpton that, and Farrakhan, the other one' and always the ones denouncing. I ain't seen those same voices saying no they shouldn't march. It's just one of those things that make you say hmmmm."
Laughing, Ms. Leid said: "Did you say hmmmm?
"I said hmmmm," Mark said.
And on to the next caller.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS;
Is the Internet Endangering Sales Jobs?

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
For Joe Moriarty, a computer consultant from Parsippany, N.J., it was as easy as point and click to buy his small share of the $3 billion in three-year notes sold by the World Bank yesterday.
The new issue, with lead underwriters from Goldman, Sachs & Company and Lehman Brothers, broke more Internet ground by taking a global bond offering to the retail investor for the first time. 
 At the same time, the use of the Internet for bond issues, which is the direction the corporate bond market is moving, is raising a question about the future role of sales representatives on Wall Street -- the people who have dealt with customers for years, providing information and points of view, taking orders and sometimes just holding their hands.
Victor Simone, Goldman's managing director for e-commerce, said: "We do not envision a world without salespeople. We don't want our customers to order on the Internet and then not hear from them again."
But Tim Bacik, a fixed-income portfolio manager at Alliance Capital who bought World Bank notes through the Internet yesterday, said, "It appears that the role of the salesperson as it currently exists will be diminished by the Internet." One of the key roles that would be cut out is the provider of information on a bond sale, because all of that can now be posted on an Internet Web site.
In explaining why Alliance used the Internet rather than the traditional phone dealings with a sales representative, he said, "We believe that the corporate bond market is moving in this direction and we want to keep on top of this development." He did say that because Wall Street was still learning about Internet sales, his transaction was backed up by a call from a sales representative.
About one-third of the new World Bank notes were sold over the Internet, bought by the traditional large institutional investors that always show up and the middle-level institutional investor, including insurance companies and banks, and the retail investor, which the World Bank was making an extra effort to reach to broaden its audience.
The retail sales were done through www.schwabbondsource.com, the bond Web site for Charles Schwab. A Schwab spokeswoman said that about 400 customers ordered the notes, with a third of those coming over the Internet. The total sales were about $100 million.
Mr. Moriarty, who said he was buying notes to help rebalance his equity-heavy portfolio to 50 percent stocks and 50 percent bonds, said he would not have bought the World Bank issue any other way. "I don't have a financial relationship with any financial house dealing in bonds," he said. He got his information on the bond sale, including the expected yield, from the same Web site. But he was informed of the coming sale, he said, by postcard.
The World Bank notes, which are rated AAA, were priced to yield 7.122 percent, 48.5 basis points, or hundredths of one percentage point, over the comparable Treasury issue.

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Jan. 21 about the sale of $3 billion in notes by the World Bank misidentified the first issuer of a debt offering to retail investors through the Internet. It is Fannie Mae, the former Federal National Mortgage Association.

HEADLINE: He's a Gadfly Who Stings Right and Left With Passion

BYLINE: By CHRIS HEDGES

 BODY:
Like the liberals he often excoriates, the economist Jagdish Bhagwati passionately deplores child labor, inadequate wages and the failure to enforce antipollution laws in the developing world.
At the same time, Mr. Bhagwati, a committed free trader, opposes the enforcement of intellectual property rights -- software copyrights, for example -- in countries like India and Brazil. And he argues that laws against illegal immigrants already inside the United States are "pointless." Leave them alone if they are already here, he says; immigrants help the United States maintain its edge in technology. 
 Forget political or ideological labels. Mr. Bhagwati, a professor of economics and political science at Columbia University, prefers to consider himself "a public nuisance," challenging established policies, stirring up protests and picking apart conventional beliefs.
He has never been shy about wading into the public arena. Most recently, Mr. Bhagwati, 65, gathered a group of scholars, labor leaders and activists from Africa, Latin America and Asia to sign a statement protesting the inclusion of labor and environmental standards in trade deals before the World Trade Organization met in Seattle last month.
In 1994 he organized a similar signature campaign on the eve of President Clinton's summit meeting with the Japanese prime minister, enlisting leading economists, including several Nobel Laureates, to urge Japan to reject United States demands for import targets. (Japan did just that.)
He has written or edited 40 books, written hundreds of articles, and founded and edited two journals, Economics and Politics and The Journal of International Economics. He is a favorite on evening news programs like ABC's and on talk shows like PBS's DebatesDebates, where he delights in skewering Ross Perot, Pat Buchanan and fellow economists with pointed one-liners. "If the W.T.O. is dead, then necrophilia must be breaking out," he said during a taping of DebatesDebates last week.
Wearing an olive green shirt open at the neck and a blue Kenzo designer suit coat, Mr. Bhagwati spoke with flamboyant animation in a makeup room after the taping.
Profits are fine, but not enough, he said. Mr. Bhagwati also says he wants to make the world a better place. Born in Bombay, he studied economics at Cambridge and Oxford universities. He said his older brother, P. N. Bhagwati, retired chief justice of the Supreme Court in India and a human rights advocate who supports stricter child labor laws, has had a lot of influence on his thinking; they still speak frequently.
Mr. Bhagwati believes that together democracy and free trade can deliver both economic growth and social reform, although he concedes that growth is not inevitable in a democracy.
He presents himself as the human face of global laissez-faire economics. Open societies can be created without using trade sanctions as a weapon, he insists. He places his faith in "voluntarism," which would rely on the global communications network and nongovernmental organizations to shame companies and governments into, for example, paying workers a living wage.
"Modern civil society, modern technology has made possible alternative instruments, other sorts of teeth," he said.
"Teeth doesn't mean just trade sanctions. People underestimate the potential of what can be done. Multinationals don't tend to abuse, to indulge in a race to the bottom. They don't exploit every loophole to damage the local guy in terms of their health and standards."
That's why he led the writing crusade before the World Trade Organization meeting in Seattle, arguing that the group should be able to oversee trade without sticky intrusions that would force it to impose sanctions on countries that abuse workers rights. The spreading of wealth, he argues, along with these private efforts, will eventually create the working conditions and educational advancement common in the industrialized nations.
He works closely with Corporate Social Responsibility Standards, an organization that seeks to give public seals of approval to corporations that meet norms of social responsibility in their employment practices. "If you do anything egregious, all these lies will come out," he said. "People will write about, agitate about it. Big firms can not afford it anymore."
He adds that global standards, like environmental controls, don't make sense for other reasons as well.
Admitting that he has no good answer to Mexico City's pollution ("forget about Mexico City, which has horrible environmental problems"), he proceeds to argue that different countries have the right to set different priorities.
"Take the rest of Mexico that has very bad water, but the environment is a lot cleaner," he said. "We have it the reverse way. All our children carry around Perrier bottles. Our water is a lot better, but our air is not necessarily that good. Our priorities are different, exactly the opposite. Even if we attach the same preference to environmental spending, it is conceivable that the Mexican priority will be to clean up water while we would want to clean up air."
To Mr. Bhagwati's critics, however, he is less of an original thinker than a confused one. "His departures from laissez-faire economics make him inconsistent," says Robert Kuttner, the co-editor of The American Prospect magazine. "Why is it that money is not seen by him as another commodity? Why does he oppose the standard view on intellectual property rights? All this is rooted in a real concern for the third world, but does not in the end make him a high theorist."
Mark Levinson, the chief economist at Union of Needle Trades Industrial and Textile Employees, said: "He opposes linking labor rights or environmental protection to trade and investment agreements. In a global economy that is becoming increasingly integrated, this position is irresponsible. Wages are not rising in the many parts of the developing world because workers are denied the right to organize.
"Trade and investment by itself will not raise living standards," he continued. "Look at El Salvador, Honduras, Sri Lanka and Bangladesh. These countries have posted high employment gains in the apparel industry while real wages have declined. In China, foreign investment in the apparel sector has lowered wages and working standards. The suppression of wages and failure to enforce environmental standards creates a powerful incentive to move jobs overseas."
Mr. Bhagwati is unfazed by criticism. He goes out of his way to avoid simmering fights, often calling critics after reading an attack on his work to compliment them on their good points and assure them that he was not offended.
By the same token, he has not curbed his own sharp tongue. He admits that, like many good rhetoricians, he plans his verbal thrusts in advance. (He said he regretted that in Seattle he was unable to chide Ralph Nader, the leader of a campaign against the World Trade Organization and the author of "Unsafe at Any Speed," for believing that "the W.T.O. is unsafe in any form.' ")
To Mr. Bhagwati, many people in the United States have fallen prey to what he calls the "diminished giant syndrome": a fear that free trade accelerates the flight of jobs. Blue-collar jobs, he says, have been lost primarily to new technologies.
He warns that the overheated American economy is headed for a dislocation, in part because surges and dips in the market "are built into human nature. "I am more than a little worried," he said. "There is so much consumption being built on this. It is really going to take a big tumble, because people are building capacities based on this." He attributes the success of vaunted huge investors like George Soros to "good luck" and the ability to "take big bets," dismissing any formula to understand the ultimate workings of financial markets.
Still, he adds: "The economy that really worries me is China. As they get into more democratization, as they are bound to, they can't resist these pressures. There is going to be some upheaval within the Communist Party. It will spill over into extensive fights about things like privatization. It will be much more difficult to handle."
As for his own role in such debates, Mr. Bhagwati says: "If you want to be in the public domain, you need the courage to be unconventional. Logic is not enough. You need wit, irony, good anecdotes and sarcasm. It always works."
"I have been alone, but I hang in there," he said, adding with his familiar mischievousness, "Usually the world comes around."

HEADLINE: Helping Cuban Families Is in America's Interest

BYLINE: By Bernard W. Aronson and William D. Rogers; Bernard W. Aronson and William D. Rogers, former assistant secretaries of state, are co-chairmen of a Council on Foreign Relations task force on American-Cuban relations.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Elian Gonzalez's fate whether he returns to his father, possibly with his two grandmothers, who are now on American soil, or remains with relatives in Miami -- may be decided by federal courts, ruling on the Immigration and Naturalization Service's determination that only the father in Cuba speaks for the son. Whatever the outcome, we hope that the two families will be able to carry out the will of the court peacefully and privately, in the best interest of the child.
But Elian's case also offers an opportunity for the president and the secretary of state to adopt a comprehensive policy of family reunification for divided Cuban families, easing the plight of many whose stories are less visible but whose suffering is just as real. Four steps should be taken. 
 First, the United States should lift all restrictions on travel to Cuba by Cubans living in the United States. Cuban-Americans are the only immigrant community in the United States subject to government regulation of their relations with families in their home countries. If the I.N.S. decision is upheld and Elian returns to his father in Cuba, under current American policy his Florida relatives will only be able to visit him in a humanitarian emergency, and then only once a year.
Many Cuban-Americans do travel more than once a year to Cuba, but they are forced to choose between maintaining family ties and flouting American law. The policy of the United States government should be to strengthen family ties, not to weaken them.
Second, the United States should do more to facilitate visits by Cuban citizens with their relatives here. Current policy on temporary visas treats Cuban applicants like those from other foreign countries, using criteria like salary, types of bank accounts and property ownership to estimate their likelihood of returning home voluntarily. The nature of the Cuban economy makes these standards prohibitive for most Cuban applicants.
Recent spot checks by the United States Interests Section in Havana have found a surprisingly high rate of return to the island among those who visit here -- a finding that should ease the anxiety of consular officials who are trained, perhaps correctly, to assume that most visitors from poor countries will try to remain here. Cuban applicants with letters of invitation from relatives in the United States and with no criminal records should be processed as quickly and favorably as possible.
Third, we can reduce the incentive to enter this country illegally by forcefully prosecuting the burgeoning smuggling business. Smugglers take advantage of the 1966 Cuban Adjustment Act that allows any Cuban reaching our shores the right to work upon arrival and to permanent residence after one year. Agreements reached between Cuba and the United States in 1994 and 1995 call for Cuba to police its borders and for the United States to send back any Cuban intercepted at sea. Good-faith adherence to these agreements requires the United States to crack down on the callous smugglers who extract huge fees from desperate Cubans, too many of whom are lost at sea in the passage, as Elian Gonzalez's mother was.
Of course, the problem of illegal flight from Cuba today derives, in essence, from Fidel Castro's failed economic policies and repression of human rights. Ultimately, only a democratic Cuba with an economy open to the global marketplace will allow Cubans to face the future at home with hope.
But the United States could help the Cuban people now with a fourth action: raising the cap on remittances that Cuban-Americans can send their island relatives from the current $1,200 a year overall to $10,000 per Cuban household. Access to more dollars would reduce dependence on the Cuban state and provide greater opportunities to build up the small private sector on the island.
All of these family-first changes in United States policy would remove obstacles between Cuban families long divided by history. Taken together, they would be comprehensive and mutually reinforcing, substantially reducing the prospect that Cubans will risk their lives to seek our shores in greater and perhaps unmanageable numbers. Because they advance both good diplomacy and our national interests, we think they reflect a bipartisan consensus developing in Congress and the executive branch.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
It Seems to Be U.S. vs. the Other Six at the Group of 7 Meeting

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

DATELINE: TOKYO, Jan. 21

 BODY:
Against the backdrop of the record $26.5 billion United States trade deficit, the meeting of officials of the Group of Seven industrialized nations that will take place here Sunday has shaped up as a conflict between the United States and the others.
During a press briefing this evening, Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers repeatedly if diplomatically suggested that Japan and Europe were not pulling their weight in the global economy. "You can't have a balanced global economy without more growth in Europe and Japan," he said repeatedly. 
 Mr. Summers sought to portray the huge trade deficit as an endorsement of the United States economy, saying it was a demonstration of the financial strength of American companies and consumers as well as a result of capital inflows from abroad drawn to attractive American investment opportunities.
The economies in Asia and to a lesser extent Europe have pulled out of the economic doldrums through exports to the United States, running up huge current account surpluses in the process.
Mr. Summers called for a reversal of that trend. "For that to happen, it is important that all regions pursue appropriate economic policies, both in the macro-economy and structurally," he said.
Suspicion is rising among United States officials that their European counterparts are deliberately turning a blind eye to the weakness of the euro, which makes European exports to the United States cheaper, rather than adopting more politically difficult policies like altering their social welfare benefits and their labor laws.
The Japanese have the opposite problem: The yen is strong, at least in part because of the United States trade deficit. They are thus pushing the officials at the meeting to issue a statement of at least mild concern about the current relationship between the world's three dominant currencies.
The Europeans, on the other hand, do not want to see the phrase "exchange rates" at all in the communique that will be issued after the meeting.
And neither Europe nor Japan, which is slowly crawling out of a deep recession, has much sympathy for the United States, with its strong dollar, booming stock market, low unemployment and low inflation.
The Treasury Secretary also met today with Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi of Japan and commended him on Japan's nascent economic recovery, although he reiterated longstanding demands that Japan do more to encourage domestic consumption and promote structural changes in its economy.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Blue Chips Falter as Nasdaq Sets Another Record High

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News

 BODY:
The stock market diverged yesterday for the fourth time this week as consumer and industrial companies faltered while telecommunications and computer-related shares rallied, sending the Nasdaq composite index to another record high.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell, led by Procter & Gamble, after a report that the consumer-products company's board would consider buying the drugmakers American Home Products and Warner-Lambert. 
 The Nasdaq climbed, led by the computer networking equipment maker Cisco Systems and the semiconductor maker Intel. The Nasdaq stock market had its busiest day ever, topping Thursday's record, as 1.91 billion shares changed hands, according to Nasdaq. The Nasdaq composite index rose 45.89 points, or 1.1 percent, to 4,235.40.
"The earnings growth for Nasdaq companies is higher than Dow companies," said Christian Koch, senior market analyst at Trusco Capital Management in Atlanta. "Some Nasdaq companies are growing at high double digits or even triple digits."
The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 99.59 points, or 0.88 percent, to 11,251.71. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 4.21 points, to 1,441.36.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 14/32, to 92 22/32, on speculation that interest rate increases by the Federal Reserve in coming months will curb inflation. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 6.70 percent from 6.74 percent on Thursday.
Procter & Gamble, the maker of household goods, fell 9 5/16, to 103 1/4. The company is considering buying American Home and Warner-Lambert, which have agreed to merge even as Pfizer tries to acquire Warner-Lambert.
Procter & Gamble has dropped 8.8 percent since reports Wednesday that Warner-Lambert had approached the company about a merger.
"Investors are scared that P.& G. will take its eye off the ball in terms of Pringles and Tide and get into a business" that is not its specialty, Mr. Koch of Trusco Capital Management said. "The market's saying that it's diluting its core business."
Warner-Lambert fell 7/8, to 92; American Home climbed 1 7/8, to 48, and Pfizer fell 11/16, to 35 1/8.
PMC-Sierra jumped 16 3/4, to 191 1/4. The maker of chips that run networking and telecommunications equipment reported fourth-quarter profit that exceeded the average estimate of analysts surveyed by First Call/Thomson Financial. It also plans a 2-for-1 stock split.
Oil stocks, including Exxon Mobil and Royal Dutch Petroleum, jumped as crude oil climbed for a ninth consecutive day. Frigid weather in the Northeast increased demand for heating fuel even as producers are restricting oil supplies to refiners.
Exxon Mobil rose 1 5/16, to 85, and Royal Dutch gained 1 3/8, to 59 3/4. Schlumberger advanced 1 7/16, to 66.
 Cisco was up 2 7/8 at 115 1/4 and Intel gained 2 5/16, to 97 15/16.

HEADLINE: Caterpillar Earnings Off 21%, Clouding theOutlook for This Year

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Jan. 21

 BODY:
Caterpillar Inc., the maker of construction and earth-moving equipment, said today that its fourth-quarter profit fell 21 percent from a year earlier largely because of slowing demand in North America and Latin America.
The company, which had warned of a fourth-quarter profit slowdown in November, said that it now expected a modest recovery this year. 
 "In 2000, we anticipate sales and revenues and profits will improve, with higher sales expected in every region of the world except North America," Glen Barton, the chief executive at Caterpillar said in a statement. "We'll continue to carefully manage costs and move forward with our growth initiatives while delivering solid financial results."
Wall Street analysts, however, said that company executives encouraged them to lower their 2000 earnings expectations today and that the company is now expecting a sales and profit gain of up to 7 percent this year, not the 20 percent gain analysts were projecting.
"They had given overly optimistic guidance in 1998 and 1999 and then the stock underperformed for two years because of quarter after quarter of profit slowdowns," said David Bluestein, an analyst at Prudential Securities.
Shares of Caterpillar rose 25 cents today, to $47.375, on the New York Stock Exchange. For the week, shares of Caterpillar were down 8.7 percent.
The company, which has repeatedly warned of earnings slowdowns in the last year, said that it earned $239 million, or 67 cents a diluted share, on revenue of $5.02 billion in the fourth quarter of 1999. The results were slightly above Wall Street's reduced expectations of 64 cents a share. In the fourth quarter of 1998, Caterpillar had profits of $301 million, or 83 cents, on revenue of $5.4 billion.
For the year, Caterpillar earned $964 million, or $2.63 a share, on revenue of $19.7 billion, down from $20.9 billion a year ago, when profits topped $1.5 billion.
Besides the slowdown in the Americas, the company blamed a strong dollar, weaker sales of more expensive machinery and efforts to trim inventory as the cause for the decline.
Caterpillar did, however, have record demand for its truck engines in 1999 and strong growth in its financial products division, like its insurance offerings.
Weaker commodity prices and a slowdown in construction and the home building boom in the United States are expected to be offset this year by a global recovery creating stronger demand for construction and earth-moving equipment.
Caterpillar, which is based in Peoria, Ill., had been suffering from an Asian recession and a drop in demand for its mining machinery in 1997 and 1998. But executives said that a recovery in the rest of the world, which began in 1998, will more than offset a slowdown in North America, where about 50 percent of its products are sold.
Analysts say a sharp drop in truck sales could also clip strong truck engine sales at Caterpillar this year.
Wall Street analysts, who just over a year ago were forecasting profits of about $5 a share in the year 2000, are now expecting gains of about $2 to $3 a share, down from estimates earlier this week of about $3.20 a share.
Yet Wall Street is holding out hope for a stronger-than-expected recovery at Caterpillar.
"Generally speaking, the market for construction equipment in America is not very good," said Tobias Levkovich, a Salomon Smith Barney analyst. "But international sales may come back and mining may come back. The earnings estimates will come down, but I think the company is being very, very conservative."

HEADLINE: The Big City;
Urban Sprawl As a Way To Save Trees

BYLINE: By JOHN TIERNEY

 BODY:
IF you are a lover of wilderness, you may have a hard time appreciating the ecological beauty of Co-op City. You probably have a hard time imagining Donald Trump as a savior of species, or seeing Ben and Jerry as environmental menaces.
But you might reconsider after reading Peter Huber's new paean to nature, "Hard Green: Saving the Environment from the Environmentalists" (Basic Books). If your highest priority is to save the wilderness and preserve species, Dr. Huber argues, you have to move people off the land and pack them into cities. 
 "It is greener to live in Trump Tower than on a 40-acre farm in Vermont," said Dr. Huber, a former professor of engineering at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology who is now a senior fellow at the Manhattan Institute, a conservative research organization. "The only way to save the wilderness is reduce the human footprint on the land by living vertically instead of horizontally."
Dr. Huber calls himself a Hard Green to distinguish himself from mainstream environmentalists. He shares their desire for bigger national parks, but he thinks they're unwittingly hurting their own cause. "If we followed the Soft Greens' policies for renewable energy and agriculture," Dr. Huber said, "most of New York State would have to be covered with organic farms and solar cells in order to support New York City. To live vertically, you need food from compact high-yield farms and fuels from below the surface."
Vast forests in New York and other states were felled by pioneers, the original organic farmers, to feed their families and their livestock. More than a quarter of the farmland was devoted to turning solar energy into the renewable fuel powering their transportation system: the grasses and grains eaten by horses.
But in recent decades, many of those fields have reverted to wilderness because they are no longer needed to grow food or fuel. Over the past quarter-century, Dr. Huber estimates, the country has gained 70 million acres of wilderness, more than all the land occupied by cities, suburbs, roads and any other kind of development.
Where Soft Greens see "urban sprawl" destroying the countryside, Dr. Huber sees cities absorbing the farmers who once destroyed the wilderness. "It's true that we lose a little green space at the edge of cities as suburbs grow," Dr. Huber said, "but that loss is more than offset by all the wilderness gained from the farms abandoned farther away." You might think of New York City and its suburbs as the antidote to rural sprawl.
WHERE Soft Greens fret about the risks from factory farms and pesticides and genetically engineered plants, Dr. Huber exults in the land saved by new technologies. "If you care about the open range, you should recoil from free-range chicken on the menu," Dr. Huber said. "You should prefer chickens living in the agribusiness equivalent of Trump Tower. If you care about seeing more of the Vermont woods of Robert Frost, you should think twice about eating Ben & Jerry's ice cream."
Ben & Jerry's prides itself on getting milk from small family farms in Vermont, and it opposes the use of a synthetic growth hormone to increase each cow's output. "If farmers used that hormone, they wouldn't need so many cows," Dr. Huber said, "so some of the farms could revert to forests. There would also be fewer cows emitting methane, which is one of the most powerful greenhouse gases."
His argument did not impress Liz Bankowski, the senior director for social mission development at Ben & Jerry's. "We think the hormone could have negative consequences for the cows," she said, "and we don't want to increase milk production if it puts family farms out of business. Losing small farms is not in the environmental or economic interest of Vermont."
Dr. Huber acknowledges that Hard Green technologies pose social and environmental problems. "You have to deal with pollution and other issues," he said, "but the costs are vastly outweighed by the benefits of creating so much new wilderness. You have to keep things in perspective."
Similarly, he said, Soft Greens ought to keep the big picture in mind when contemplating proposals to stop urban sprawl.
"You may want to stop someone from building new homes near you because the extra crowding reduces your quality of life," he said. "But it's a fraud to confuse your self-interest with what is good for the planet. If you make it harder for people to move to cities and suburbs, they'll end up in places where cougars and eagles could be living."

HEADLINE: Clinton to Seek U.S. Subsidies To Help the Poor Get Online

BYLINE: By MARC LACEY

DATELINE: PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 21

 BODY:
President Clinton has decided to seek federal subsidies to help the poor buy computers and connect to the Internet, one of a number of initiatives to be included in his State of the Union address to narrow what many call the digital divide, White House aides said today.
Although the program is still being put together, the White House is considering an initiative to offer roughly $50 million in competitive grants to local communities and organizations that are involved in efforts to help low-income families go online. 
 Mr. Clinton set a goal last year of connecting everyone in the United States to the Internet, in schools, libraries and businesses as well as private homes. Later this year the president plans to take a third "new markets" tour to highlight communities left behind in the nation's economic boom. The trip will focus on the digital divide and involve leaders in the computer industry.
The initiative to increase computer usage among low-income families is not intended to create more video game addicts or chat room participants. Instead, as Mr. Clinton said in December, connecting more Americans to computers would help "to link children and adults to a lifetime of learning, to provide access to distant medical care, to empower parents, to assist job-seekers, to enhance safety and foster economic development."
The president is relatively new to the Internet himself. In a speech today announcing increased financing for scientific research, he told students at the California Institute of Technology that he was technically challenged but was trying to get in touch with his "inner nerd."
"My staff challenged me to actually order Christmas gifts over the Internet, and I did that," Mr. Clinton said. "And while doing that, I learned that with just a click of a mouse, I could actually order -- and I did this, I'm embarrassed to say -- I ordered Arkansas smoked ham and sausage delivered to my door."
Computer executives in the Silicon Valley have proposed a program called ClickStart, with the goal of connecting millions of impoverished Americans to the Internet.
The initiative, which the company officials pushed in a meeting with presidential aides last month, proposes to subsidize through a voucher system both computer hardware and Internet access.
Each recipient would pay about $5 a month and get a $10 monthly federal subsidy in the form of a voucher that could be used to buy hardware and Internet access from any vendor participating in the program, organizers said.
"This is all clearly self-serving at some level because all of us in the industry benefit by having more customers," said Eric Schmidt, chief executive of Novell and an organizer of the program. "All technology literacy programs have a self-serving component to them, and if I state that up front it takes that off the table. I happen to believe it's good for society, and for our industry."
A Commerce Department study made public last year found that black and Hispanic families were only two-fifths as likely to have Internet access as white households. Families with incomes of $75,000 or more in urban areas are more than 20 times as likely to have Internet access as the poorest households. Rural areas feature the lowest percentage of connected households.
Education is another big factor. People with a college degree are more than eight times as likely to have a computer at home and nearly 16 times as likely to have home Internet access as those with an elementary school education.
The administration says more than half of the nation's schools and more than 80 percent of its classrooms are wired for the Internet. The goal is to have all schools connected by the end of this year.
"Every day that passes, there are children not being exposed to PC's and the Internet," said Nick Grouf, chief executive of PeoplePC, a company in San Francisco that sells low-cost computer systems. "That means they are de facto being left out of the economy 10 to 15 years from now, and that's a very frightening prospect."
