HEADLINE: Bush Firms Up 'Soft' Anti-Abortion Stance

BYLINE: By FRANK BRUNI with LESLIE WAYNE

DATELINE: COUNCIL BLUFFS, Iowa, Jan. 21

 BODY:
Attacked by his more conservative opponents as being equivocal on abortion, Gov. George W. Bush declared today that the Supreme Court in its landmark Roe v. Wade decision had "stepped across its bounds and usurped the right of legislatures."
Although the comment itself was not a striking shift for Mr. Bush, who has always been opposed to abortion, it came on the second day in a row in which he has been pressed to discuss the issue, and it seemed to highlight the influence that social and religious conservatives have traditionally held in the Republican caucuses here. 
 With the caucuses only three days away, both Mr. Bush and his main challenger here, Steve Forbes, made strong appeals to conservatives, with Mr. Bush delivering pious remarks to recovering drug and alcohol abusers as Mr. Forbes continued to attack Mr. Bush's abortion positions as not strong enough.
Standing in the pulpit of a chapel at a faith-based rehabilitation center in Colfax, Mr. Bush told several dozen men that he once had his own problems with alcohol and had moved past them with the aid of his religion.
"I'm on a walk, just like you are," Mr. Bush said this morning. "I'm on a walk. And it's a never-ending walk, as far as I'm concerned."
Then, referring to one of the nation's most prominent Christian preachers, Mr. Bush added: "I used to drink too much, and I quit drinking, and I believe it was because Billy Graham planted a seed in my heart one time. It wasn't Billy; he was the messenger. So I want you to know your life's walk is shared by a lot of other people, even some who wear suits."
Mr. Forbes, the wealthy magazine publisher who is running second to Mr. Bush in polls in Iowa, continued, meanwhile, to present himself as the voice of true moral conservatism.
Speaking in Cedar Rapids, Mr. Forbes complained that Mr. Bush was a "strong moderate" who "would not give a direct answer" on such conservative goals as the repeal of Roe v. Wade. And he criticized Mr. Bush for not pledging to have an anti-abortion running mate or appoint only anti-abortion judges.
"Bush won't give a real answer on Roe v. Wade, " Mr. Forbes said. "He ducked on that and he ducked on the judges."
The dynamic between the two men illustrated the rightward tilt of the Republican debate as the candidates focus their time and energy in this state over the days leading up to the precinct caucuses on Monday.
In New Hampshire, which holds its primary on Feb. 1, Mr. Bush generally pays slightly less heed to moral issues and more to economic ones, engaging, for example, in a duel over tax cuts with Senator John McCain of Arizona, who has done almost no campaigning in Iowa.
But the altered tenor of the Republican appeals in Iowa is likely to repeat itself in South Carolina, the next major contest after New Hampshire. Like Iowa, South Carolina is fertile soil for socially conservative views. Campaigning there today, Mr. McCain was sharply questioned about his position on abortion at a town-hall meeting.
The senator called the Supreme Court decision that created a legal right to abortion "overreaching" but said his opposition to abortion would not extend to cases of rape and incest.
On the related issue of fetal tissue research, Mr. McCain said he had voted in Congress for a ban on such research but changed his position after Representative Morris K. Udall, his friend, died of Parkinson's disease and Mr. Udall's daughter told him that fetal tissue research might help find a cure.
Mr. Bush, too, has been pressed about abortion in the last few days, in part because of statements that Mr. Forbes has made on the stump. And Mr. Bush has made it clearer than he has on some other occasions that he strongly disapproves of the 1973 Supreme Court decision in the case of Roe v. Wade, which established the right to abortion.
"I felt like it was a case where the court took the place of what the legislatures do in America," Mr. Bush said in Colfax today, repeating his comments of Thursday. "That's the case where the court stepped across its bounds and usurped the right of legislatures."
But when asked whether he thought the decision should be overturned, Mr. Bush said, "It should be up to each legislature."
The answer seemed to reflect Mr. Bush's carefully calibrated position on a constitutional amendment to ban abortion: he favors one, but has said he would not fight for it because the requisite public support does not exist.
Mr. Bush's response also underscored the challenge he faces as he navigates the primaries. If he veers too far to the right, he risks losing the kind of centrist appeal he will need to win the general election.
Mr. Bush seems acutely aware of that, although his advisers say he is simply holding to his longstanding views.
In the Republican debates over the last few weeks, he has resisted rightward tugs from his rivals on several issues. He declined to call for a reinstatement of the ban on gays in the military, nor would he vow that any judges he nominated to the Supreme Court be opposed to abortion.
But Mr. Bush's pitch in Iowa this week has been undeniably different from his appeal in New Hampshire, whose voters love a good tax cut. There, Mr. Bush put the bulk of his oratorical muscle into selling his plan to slash taxes by $483 billion over the next five years. Here, Mr. Bush has discussed that proposal less thoroughly, and used some of the time left over to talk about morality and family.
The difference has been fairly subtle; most of Mr. Bush's campaign appearances here since he arrived on Wednesday night have not had religious overtones. But his aides here have distributed a pamphlet that calls attention to Mr. Bush's support from the National Right to Life Committee. The pamphlet includes an open letter from Mr. Bush, in which he reflects on religion and on his friendship with Mr. Graham.
Mr. Bush writes: "My faith frees me; frees me to put the problems of the moment in proper perspective; frees me to make decisions that others might not like."
At the center in Colfax, before Mr. Bush proceeded to the chapel to make his remarks, he talked with several men in the program in a room dominated by an enormous, brilliantly colored mural featuring an image of Jesus Christ, whose outstretched arm hovered almost directly over Mr. Bush's head.
Mr. Bush may need the votes of many Christian conservatives to meet or exceed the lofty expectations for a resounding victory here. But several other candidates, including Mr. Forbes, Gary L. Bauer and Alan Keyes, are relying principally on these voters and wooing them more aggressively.
Mr. Forbes, seeking to establish himself as the sole conservative alternative to Mr. Bush, has called Mr. Bush a "pro-life pacifist" in public comments here this week and is running a television commercial in which a woman says: "If someone kills a pet, it's called a crime. If someone aborts a child, it's called a choice."
The potential power of religious voters was demonstrated in a recent poll by The Des Moines Register, which showed that over 40 percent of Iowa Republicans identified themselves as "born again" Christians. To succeed, Mr. Forbes must hold off Mr. Bush in his efforts to grab part of this bloc while not losing votes to candidates like Mr. Bauer and Mr. Keyes, who are perceived to be even more conservative than Mr. Forbes by many on the religious right.
Clearly aware of that possibility, Mr. Forbes urged conservatives here to rally around him as the conservative alternative to Mr. Bush.
"Since I have the strongest message, the broadest-based message," he said, "it is going to happen. We will do it. On Monday night, we will bring conservatives together."

HEADLINE: Plan to Invest Pension Funds Is Abandoned

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI

 BODY:
Trying to defuse a bitter standoff with the Giuliani administration, the Fisher real estate family and Morgan Stanley Dean Witter have abandoned plans for a private fund to invest $1 billion of public-employee pension money in New York real estate projects.
The Fishers and their partners decided it was better to cut their losses after administration officials denounced their proposed Knickerbocker Fund and threatened to make trouble for a separate deal: the Fishers' pending purchase of nine acres for a luxury project on the East River, near the United Nations. The Fishers, Morgan Stanley and the developer Sheldon Solow are currently negotiating a contract to buy the land for $630 million from Consolidated Edison. 
 While no one at City Hall would say so directly, people involved in the dispute suggested yesterday that the decision to abandon the Knickerbocker Fund appeared to have had the desired effect. City Hall officials were calling the Con Edison deal a private business matter that did not concern them. And one person involved with Knickerbocker said: "The word we got back was that the mayor was very pleased -- come home, all is forgiven."
Beyond the high financial stakes, the battle that erupted earlier this month quickly became embroiled in conspiracy theories and political charges and countercharges.
Administration officials accused City Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi, who oversees the pension funds, of promoting what they called a risky investment on behalf of the Fishers, who had contributed more than $92,000 toward Mr. Hevesi's probable mayoral campaign. Mr. Hevesi has angrily denied the assertions.
For their part, some supporters of the fund and aides to Mr. Hevesi suggested that the Giuliani administration cared less about the investment fund than about helping Mortimer B. Zuckerman, the developer who also owns The Daily News, try to wrest control of the Con Edison deal from the Fishers. Giuliani aides and Mr. Zuckerman dismissed that notion.
Whatever the source of the problem or the merits of the fund, the Fishers and Morgan Stanley had no stomach for a public brawl and quietly let City Hall officials know in recent days that they would kill the Knickerbocker Fund. "We're focused on the Con Edison project," Richard L. Fisher said in a terse statement yesterday.
The Fishers may have achieved peace with the Giuliani administration, but union leaders, who have long sought to invest pension funds in New York real estate projects that could generate jobs and tax revenues as well as profits for the funds, are angry about the outcome.
"The dissolution of this fund demonstrates gutter politics at work here," said Nick Mancuso, a pension fund trustee and secretary-treasurer of Teamsters Local 237. "We want to get a decent return and put some funds into the economy of New York. Why wouldn't we want to put money into New York City to preserve and protect our jobs?"
Both Mayor Giuliani and the comptroller have representatives on the boards of the police, firefighters, teachers and city employee pension funds, which have set aside 2 percent, or $1.8 billion, of their $92 billion in assets for so-called alternative investments -- like the Knickerbocker Fund -- that are intended to achieve a social purpose as well as a profit. Although the Giuliani administration initially favored the idea of alternative investments, it has in recent years tried to block them.
Deputy Mayor Joseph J. Lhota declined to discuss the Fishers yesterday, saying the Knickerbocker proposal was an issue between the developers and Mr. Hevesi. But he said he was dismayed by what he said was an effort to ram the Knickerbocker proposal through without sufficient review or a competitive bidding process.
Given the boom and bust nature of real estate, he also questioned the wisdom of the fund's exclusive focus on New York City. "I'm totally confused about how the comptroller handled this entire issue," Mr. Lhota said yesterday. "The absence of process is a mystery."
But the comptroller's office and union pension trustees have said that the Giuliani administration has been involved in discussions about the Knickerbocker proposal over the last five months. Internal memos from the pension funds' adviser, Pacific Corporate Group, indicate that the review of the Knickerbocker proposal began last September.
Mr. Mancuso said he first talked to the Fishers about a real estate fund focused on New York City in early 1999. "I mentioned that for all the development going on in New York City, no developer had come to the pension funds. Maybe seven or eight months later, they put together a proposal."
Union leaders said the Giuliani administration had criticized the investment from the start. The dispute did not boil over, however, until the police pension fund tentatively approved an investment in Knickerbocker on Jan. 4, over the objections of the Giuliani representative.
The administration took action the next day, when Joseph B. Rose, the city's planning director, called Con Edison to say that the city's cooperation on rezoning the nine acres on the East Side would cease if the Fishers used pension money to buy the land. The Fishers said they had never intended to use money from the Knickerbocker Fund for the Con Ed project, but administration officials said they were concerned about that possibility.
"They realized they couldn't defeat the investment by voting, so they went to Plan B," said one executive who worked with the Knickerbocker Fund. In any event, anxious Con Edison executives told the Fishers to make the problem "go away."
Other pension fund advocates and members of the comptroller's staff suggested that the Giuliani administration was trying to help Mr. Zuckerman, with an eye toward gaining his support for the mayor's likely Senate campaign.
For his part, Mr. Zuckerman said he was oblivious to the dispute. "We made a very serious bid for the Con Ed land," he said. "Some very capable competitors won. I wish them well."
Since the telephone call by Mr. Rose came to light, the Giuliani administration has played down the Con Ed connection. "I don't care what happens between Con Ed and a consortium of private investors," Mr. Lhota said. "This is not connect the dots."
The contretemps stunned the Fishers, who have contributed more than $76,000 to Mr. Giuliani's political committees and enjoyed an especially good relationship with City Hall. Last week, the family decided to close down the Knickerbocker Fund, only days before the pension funds' adviser completed its review and recommended an investment in it.

HEADLINE: Surging Profits May Indicate a Longer Lifefor the Bull Market

BYLINE: By ALEX BERENSON

 BODY:
American companies are reporting a surge in profits, giving investors reason to hope that the aging bull market may have more life left.
With companies from Warner-Lambert to America Online turning in strong results, overall earnings growth for the Standard & Poor's 500 is on track to exceed 17 percent in 1999. The trend accelerated in the second half of the year. Earnings rose more than 22 percent in the third quarter and are now estimated to be up about 21 percent for the fourth, although many companies have not yet reported. 
 That growth rate is three times the long-term average of 7 percent, and a sharp increase from 1998, when earnings barely rose in large part because of the Asian financial crisis and the strike against General Motors. Furthermore, fourth-quarter results have handily surpassed the expectations of industry analysts on Wall Street, indicating a stronger economy than expected just a few months ago.
Those same industry analysts are projecting 17 percent growth in earnings in 2000, said Charles Hill, director of research for First Call/Thomson Financial, which tracks analysts' estimates. "I think the die is cast through at least the first half of 2000 that we're going to get good earnings reports," he said.
For investors, who are increasingly nervous about lofty stock prices and rising interest rates, the earnings growth provides reason for optimism. Although even bullish stock market strategists say that rising interest rates may well crimp stocks for the next couple of months, stocks track corporate earnings over the long run.
In the short term, "you've got the classic tug of war with worries over rising rates against better-than-expected earnings," said Jeffrey Applegate, chief investment strategist for Lehman Brothers. "But basically at the end of the road, you've got a very strong set of fundamentals that leads to a bull market that is now 10 years old."
Mr. Applegate, who for the last five years has been one of Wall Street's most consistently bullish -- and correct -- strategists, remains a bull. He says stocks should turn in double-digit percentage gains for the year, although there could be a sharp sell-off along the way because of interest rate fears.
Rising interest rates are considered bad for stocks, because they raise the cost of doing business and depress corporate earnings and because higher yields make bonds relatively more attractive than stocks to investors. As the rate on the 30-year Treasury bond has risen from less than 5 percent in 1998 to 6.7 percent today, the gap between bond yields and stock prices has loomed ever larger. Stocks are trading at historically high multiples of earnings, with the S.& P. 500 now selling for 25 times its estimated 2000 earnings.
Put another way, investing one dollar in a Treasury bond guarantees a return of almost 7 cents next year, while investing one dollar in the stock market buys only 4 cents of earnings. Of course, the stocks could appreciate far more, but generally speaking, stock investors are buying a stream of earnings.
Over time, the earnings streams on bonds and stocks have been roughly comparable. When they diverge, investors generally see opportunity in the cheaper asset, which in this case is bonds.
So far, investors are staying in stocks, counting on future earnings growth to make up the difference.
On the Nasdaq composite index, which is rich with technology companies, the relationship between earnings growth and valuations is even more striking. After gaining 86 percent last year, the Nasdaq stock basket trades at 125 times its companies' earnings of the last 12 months, according to Joseph Abbott, senior equity strategist at I.B.E.S. International.
That level is roughly eight times the historical average, leading some investors to worry that the United States is in a Japan-like stock market bubble. Japan's stock market roared ahead in the 1980's, fueled by a real estate frenzy and a belief that Japanese companies were far ahead of their foreign competitors, before crashing in 1990 as interest rates rose. A decade later, the stock market remains 50 percent off its 1989 peak.
Though the Nasdaq composite is extremely expensive, its companies are expected to grow 63 percent in 2000, about nine times the average growth in corporate earnings for the last 50 years recorded by First Call. Strong productivity increases, fast economic growth in the United States and huge investments in technology are driving the increase, said Robert Froehlich, chief investment strategist at Kemper Funds, which manages $40 billion in stocks.
"There's an unbelievable amount of pent-up demand for technology," Mr. Froehlich said. "In addition, productivity is increasing, and that's not going to slow down."
The strength in earnings sweeps across almost every sector of the economy, said Mr. Hill of First Call. Helped by high oil prices, energy companies have reported fourth-quarter earnings about double their 1998 levels. Financial companies are showing gains of roughly 30 percent, while technology companies, which were expected to be slowed as big customers cut spending in the fall because of fears of year-end computer problems, are reporting gains of 20 percent or more.
Mr. Abbott of I.B.E.S. said he was particularly impressed that fewer companies than usual had warned of earnings disappointments for the fourth quarter, while more companies had surpassed analysts' estimates. Although some major companies, notably Lucent Technologies, came in far short of expectations, the overall number of negative announcements was the lowest in the five years that I.B.E.S. has tracked quarterly warnings, Mr. Abbott said.
Another especially promising sign is the amount by which companies have exceeded analysts' expectations for the fourth quarter. Companies often guide Wall Street analysts to slightly lower profits than their internal expectations. As a result, companies typically report earnings gains that surpass analysts' estimates by about 3 percent, according to First Call.
In the fourth quarter, corporate results so far have been 7 percent ahead of expectations, Mr. Hill said. "It's clear we're going to beat the numbers by more than we normally do."
Still, some strategists remain wary that high interest rates may derail the stock market. Christine Callies, chief United States market strategist at Credit Suisse First Boston, predicts that the Federal Reserve will continue to raise short-term rates until stocks fall because the Fed is very concerned that market gains have led consumers to increase spending and overheat the economy.
In addition, some investors are worried that companies are pumping up their earnings by taking some profits on successful venture capital investments.

 BODY:

Procter & Gamble Meets In Pursuit of Drug Merger
The board of Procter & Gamble is considering pursuing merger talks with American Home Products and Warner-Lambert that would create one of the world's largest consumer products and drug companies.
It was not clear last night whether the Procter & Gamble board would decide to pursue talks with either of the companies. But several people close to the talks said they anticipated that the board would allow the three companies to continue discussions that started this week. As with any negotiations, no deal is guaranteed. If Procter & Gamble combined all three pharmaceutical businesses, the new drug business would be the second-largest prescription drug seller in the United States, behind the proposed combination of Glaxo Wellcome and SmithKline Beecham. Page A1.

Consumer and industrial stocks continued to falter, while the Nasdaq climbed again, led by telecommunications and computer shares. The Nasdaq composite index was up 45.89 points, to 4,235.40, as the Nasdaq stock market had its busiest day ever with 1.91 billion shares changing hands. HEADLINE: Germans Push Their Man To Lead I.M.F.

BYLINE: By JOSEPH KAHN

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21

 BODY:
German officials have stepped up a campaign to install one of their own as head of the International Monetary Fund, using a lukewarm endorsement by President Clinton to rally support and break a three-month deadlock on selecting a new leader for the global financial institution.
The Germans have been citing a private telephone conversation between Chancellor Gerhard Schroder and Mr. Clinton as evidence of growing international support for Caio Koch-Weser, a technocratic deputy finance minister. 
 During a discussion about the succession at the monetary fund, Mr. Clinton gave Mr. Schroder the impression that the United States would not veto the German choice, provided that Germany persuaded all the other Europeans to back its candidate, German officials said.
In recent days, Mr. Schroder has put his prestige on the line to win backing for Mr. Koch-Weser, whom many European and American financial officials say they regard as a competent but uninspired choice for the job. The German leader has called in ambassadors based in Berlin and lobbied with his own counterparts worldwide, starting what some diplomats called an uncharacteristically aggressive German campaign for a key international post.
As with much else in the opaque process of selecting a leader for the monetary fund, American support was hardly clear-cut. Clinton administration officials confirm that the president did not threaten to veto Mr. Koch-Weser's candidacy when he spoke with Mr. Schroder, but said that should not be misread as indicating he backed the German for the job.
American officials say privately that they would prefer Europe to put forward another candidate.
The direct involvement of Mr. Schroder and the parsing of diplomatic conversations shows how sensitive the succession process at the monetary fund has become. In recent years, the fund has become a global political and financial force, negotiating with Russian and Indonesian leaders during crises in those countries and serving as the West's financial ambassador to developing nations.
But world leaders have had a difficult time agreeing on people to lead global institutions. Asian and Western nations argued for months over who should head the World Trade Organization before agreeing to split the term so that the rival candidates could serve successively.
European countries failed to back a single candidate to head their new central bank and eventually agreed to allow two contenders to serve truncated terms, as well. The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development went without a chief for nine months while countries debated who should lead it.
Some fear that Germany's steadfast lobbying for Mr. Koch-Weser could produce a similarly muddled result for the monetary fund. Berlin has extracted commitments from several European partners to back Mr. Koch-Weser, people involved in the process said. But the commitments are often contingent on Germany's lining up support elsewhere.
Michel Camdessus, the Frenchman who currently heads the fund, leaves the post in mid-February, having announced his retirement in November. While it is still possible that a consensus candidate will emerge by then, it now seems more likely that the post will remain vacant for a time. That would leave Stanley Fischer, the No. 2 official and a naturalized American citizen, in charge.
German officials are determined to break the deadlock with their public lobbying effort. They say they are increasingly optimistic that Mr. Koch-Weser can get the necessary support.
Among big European countries, only France, which has had one of its own as head of the monetary fund for most of the fund's history, including the last 13 years, has declined to offer support to Mr. Koch-Weser, the officials say. Mr. Schroder was planning to meet with President Jacques Chirac and Prime Minister Lionel Jospin in Paris to try to change their minds.
"It's too early to say for sure, but there is a quite positive feeling now," a German government official said. "Chancellor Schroder has upped the ante -- this is his choice for the job."
Germany, which has only recently begun pushing for a share of leadership posts at European and international institutions, views Mr. Koch-Weser as a logical choice for the monetary fund leadership.
Trained as an economist, he served as an officer at the World Bank, the fund's sister institution, for 26 years, specializing in health and development projects. One of his responsibilities was coordinating the World Bank's poverty-relief programs with similar efforts at the I.M.F.
For American officials, that is part of the problem. Secretary of the Treasury Lawrence H. Summers has pushed to change the way the monetary fund operates, urging it to focus largely on managing financial crises, instead of relief for all but the poorest nations. Mr. Koch-Weser is not the ideal person to carry out such changes, the American thinking goes.
Some European officials also say they wonder if Mr. Koch-Weser has the stature to go head-to-head with the likes of Boris N. Yeltsin, the former Russian leader, or former President Suharto of Indonesia. Both their governments resisted the application of economic reforms urged on them by the monetary fund in return for foreign aid -- requiring regular intervention by Mr. Camdessus.
Still, the vigorous German backing for Mr. Koch-Weser has given his candidacy an air of inevitability. Germany would be reluctant to step aside, and fellow Europeans would be reluctant to openly challenge the German choice, unless a rival who clearly outranks Mr. Koch-Weser -- like a seasoned central banker, a finance minister or a prime minister -- threw his or her hat into the ring.
Such an outcome is still possible. Britain's Chancellor of the Exche-
quer, Gordon Brown, has been widely mentioned as an alternative, but has not publicly shown interest in the job. Several Italian leaders, including the country's foreign minister and treasury director, have also been named as possible monetary fund chiefs, but are regarded as unlikely to enter the race unless Germany backs off.
The only other publicly declared candidate for the job is Eisuke Sakakibara, a former vice finance minister of Japan. Though highly regarded in Tokyo, he is given little chance of winning. Europeans have traditionally led the monetary fund, as Americans have led the World Bank, and Europe is not seen as ready to cede the post.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE BUSH RECORD;
With Help From Democrats, Bush Managed a Coup on Abortion Bill

BYLINE: By MELINDA HENNEBERGER

DATELINE: DES MOINES, Jan. 21

 BODY:
Maybe the most surprising thing George W. Bush accomplished last year had nothing to do with fund-raising. He got Texas Democrats to pass an abortion bill that they had opposed for decades -- and to effectively help him mollify the Christian right in his state.
At least a few Democrats seem to have pitched in expressly for the good of the governor's political future. "I wanted to help him and his presidential aspirations because I just like him," said one House Democrat, who like others was happy to help but unwilling to be named in print. 
 In the last week leading up to the Iowa caucuses, however, Mr. Bush is being challenged on the abortion issue on a whole new level. The governor's Republican rivals have spent a lot of time trying to outdo one another in branding him as only a halfhearted opponent of abortion rights -- "a pro-life pacifist," as Steve Forbes put it.
And when Mr. Bush answered a reporter's question here about how he would respond to a friend who had been raped and was considering an abortion by saying, "It's up to her," his opponents said the remark had confirmed their suspicions.
In answering the critics, Mr. Bush pointed to his record in his home state, and specifically to his work on passing a parental notification bill.
In Texas, the governor's real coup on the abortion front seems to have been in keeping his position enough of a mystery that both sides remain convinced that in his heart of hearts, he agrees with them.
But even some of the purest anti-abortion crusaders there offer pretty compelling arguments that in practice, Mr. Bush has been on their side. And the fact that even on abortion -- the hottest hot-button issue there is -- he has been able to keep both sides convinced he is in their corner is at least clear proof of his political skills.
Because Democrats control the Texas House, the parental notification bill that was passed last May could not have become law, or even come to a vote, without them. It was the governor, though, who pushed the measure, which requires doctors to notify the parents of minors seeking an abortion.
"It was very high on his agenda," said Representative Patricia Gray, a Democrat from Galveston, who proposed an alternative bill that would have allowed girls to notify relatives other than their parents.
"He wanted a really tough bill that would satisfy those folks on the right," Ms. Gray said, "and now we have the toughest notification bill in the country."
The governor's efforts dramatically buffed his image with the religious right in Texas, a crowd that had never been quite sure he had its best interests at heart.
He got the job done, however, by trading on personal relationships with Democrats in a way that purists in his party never would have. And he was willing to reward Democrats for their cooperation on a number of legislative matters, and let it be known early on that he would not campaign against friendly lawmakers in the other party.
Working in a bipartisan way to further what look like partisan goals left open the debate about Mr. Bush's true motives. Were his efforts on parental notification intended to reward the religious right, as the social conservatives see it? Or were his efforts ultimately supposed to rein them in, by throwing conservatives a fairly meaningless political bone, as many of those who support abortion rights believe?
Bill Price, the head of Texas Right to Life, gushes that the governor has played the other side for suckers -- "pulled the wool over their eyes" -- and given his movement a much-needed boost.
"He has mastered the skill of being able to dig in and yet do it in a way that minimizes the fallout from people who are pro-choice," Mr. Price said of the governor.
"We went through some bad times, with Operation Rescue and some people on the fringe, being associated with people in front of an abortion clinic with policemen on horseback and barking dogs," Mr. Price said. "But just through his manner, he's put forth a good image for the pro-life movement."
Democrats, on the other hand, typically see Republicans as the true patsies, getting nothing more from Mr. Bush than a pat on the head while he winks at them over conservatives' shoulders.
As one Texas Democrat who has worked for Planned Parenthood said, "Bush had to have a parental notification bill to placate the religious right and wave at people in New Hampshire and South Carolina, but he isn't strongly anti-abortion."
The result, however, is not much disputed. And with passage of the bill, Mr. Price said, Mr. Bush "has done more to actually reduce the number of abortions in Texas than all of the guys who are climbing a hill, waving a white flag and declaring, 'I'm the most pure on this.' I'm sure he paid a price."
In an interview, Mr. Bush smiled when asked if he had, in fact, spent a lot of political capital on the bill.
"If I did," he said, "I earned a lot more by having spent it."
Ms. Gray said many Democrats were obviously charmed by the governor on this and other matters.
"It is very difficult for anybody to resist when he comes in," she said. "And he's wonderful when you have a constituent you want him to be pleasant to. It's like that constituent is the only one in the room, and it's him and that constituent against the world. Heck, I like the guy."
The governor's work on the parental notification bill suggests that he is able to communicate an almost Clintonian empathy even to those he is actively working against, and to make the whole question of who won or lost any given legislative skirmish more a matter of interpretation than is usually the case.
Bill Cryer, who worked for the previous Texas governor, Ann Richards, a Democrat, said parental notification "was a big loss for us, the first time in decades that the Legislature had passed any bill restricting the right of a woman to get an abortion, and it could not have happened under Ann Richards." But, Mr. Cryer added, "It's also a nothing-burger in a lot of ways. It's notification, not consent. It clearly had to be given to the religious coalitions, but what it gave them wasn't strong."
Democrats say they went along for a variety of reasons. The bill was overwhelmingly supported by voters. They were tired of fighting over what was a pretty tepid piece of legislation anyway. They had always been just as opposed to abortion, just as supportive of parental rights as the next guy in this overwhelmingly conservative state. When Republicans gained a one-vote majority in the State Senate in 1997, it seemed only a matter of time before the bill would pass, they said, and reforms last year made it harder to block the bill on technicalities, as they had in the past.
And at least some of the Democrats' willingness to go along with the governor should be chalked up to self-preservation. With Republicans here picking up strength consistently through the 80's and 90's, it is now hard for Texas Democrats to be tough on much of anything.
The Texas Legislature is set up to function in a bipartisan way, and the fear of alienating a potential president seems to have increasingly made cooperation an economic issue for Texans, with few Democrats openly criticizing the governor.
"People think they'll have a job in Washington if he wins," said Samantha Smoot, executive director of the Texas Freedom Network, a liberal watchdog group that monitors the Christian Coalition and similar organizations.
Even Democrats think that? she was asked. Ms. Smoot laughed and replied, "Even reporters."
Texas patriotism also seems to be an underestimated factor. "I'm going parochial this year and I'm going to vote for what's best for Texas," said former State Senator A. R. Schwartz, who describes himself as a "lifetime, yellow-dog, brass-collar radical Democrat."
In an interview, Mr. Bush did not dispute the notion that he had not exactly worn any holes in his boots stumping for Republicans against his friends in the other party.
And in a sense the question of whether he would sacrifice Republican lawmakers if necessary has been answered: He already has.
Yet for several reasons, this does not necessarily mean Mr. Bush is likely to sell out Congressional Republicans or their agenda if he is elected president.
Ms. Gray, for one, says he did campaign against her and at least a few other Democrats. "We had worked well with him and had been told the favor would be repaid," she said. "Yet he came into my district with his arm around my opponent."
And it is hard to imagine Mr. Bush cozying up to Congressional Democrats in quite the same way as he has to the populist Texas speaker, Pete Laney, or to the late lieutenant governor Bob Bullock, a Democrat whom the governor hugged before embracing his own father at his second inauguration.
Texas is a state where what is left of the Democratic Party competes with Republicans over the strength of its support for the death penalty and gun owners' rights.
Texas Democrats have a lot in common with Mr. Bush, and increasingly need to prove it to stay in office.
Key Democrats say the governor began pestering them about parental notification in 1997, in at least some cases making clear that he needed their help with conservatives and a presidential run in view. They found him impossible to resist in 1999, when the bill finally passed.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE VICE PRESIDENT;
Stumping as a Knowing Ally of Farmers

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE

DATELINE: BOONE, Iowa, Jan. 21

 BODY:
Vice President Al Gore stumped across farm country in central Iowa today, recalling his days in the 4-H Club, his Angus cattle and how his father had taught him to stop gullies.
"I learned from my dad the respect for the environment that all farmers who farm their own land have," Mr. Gore told a barnful of farmers and their families in Perry, noting that he grew up in a Washington hotel but spent his summers on the family farm in Tennessee. 
 "When I was a young boy, he used to teach me how to stop a gully before it really got started," Mr. Gore said. "At first I couldn't see the lay of the land the way he could and recognize when a gully was starting up there, but I learned from him."
Mr. Gore, seeking the Democratic presidential nomination, noted that farming accounted for only 20 percent of Iowa's economy. But, he said, "the space between the concentrated population in the cities depends upon the health of the farm economy."
Mr. Gore's message of the day was that he would fight for farmers. "I may have been raised most of my life in Washington, D.C., but I spent every summer on a farm," he told an audience at the Elks lodge here, adding, "I know one end of the pitchfork from the other."
He said the next president needed to keep the prosperity going "as the basis for lifting up those who have been left behind, starting first and foremost with the family farmer." He called for enforcing antitrust laws and said the country needed to "bust up some of the concentrated power that's hurting the farmers."
Mr. Gore's bus tour across Iowa was punctuated with brief references to his opponent, former Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey, who said on Thursday that he had experienced four bouts of irregular heartbeat in the last month. Mr. Gore told reporters, "He's in great health, and it shouldn't be an issue."
Of the expectations for his performance in Monday's caucuses, in which polls show him ahead, Mr. Gore said, "After Senator Bradley has spent so much more money -- more money than any other Democratic candidate in history here -- and has invested as much time and people and TV ads and whatnot as he has, I think that if I can get one more vote than he does, that is a win."
Mr. Gore has appeared extremely confident and relaxed in the last few days. He gave interviews on drive-time radio programs this morning, joshing with the hosts and lapsing into a heavy Southern drawl.
The Gore campaign is also broadcasting four new commercials. They emphasize his commitment to "fight for the average working person," as well as testimonials from Senator Tom Harkin, Democrat of Iowa, and Robert F. Kennedy Jr., an environmental lawyer in New York.
At a rally in Ames tonight, Mr. Gore took on the Republicans.
"Every Republican candidate for president is tolerant of intolerance, lest they offend the offensive," he said, referring to their support for the Confederate battle flag in South Carolina. "They are fearful those among their constituents will turn away from them unless they humor the bigotry, unless they humor the intolerance."

HEADLINE: Cardinal's Light Hand as Leader Lets Archdiocese Adapt to Illness

BYLINE: By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO

 BODY:
To New Yorkers accustomed to hearing Cardinal John O'Connor speak out on moral issues, the most glaring consequence of his illness has been his sudden shrinking from the public pulpit he built in his 16 years as archbishop.
But his illness has also touched his other, lesser-known role: administrator of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, a spiritual, educational, social and financial presence. Cardinal O'Connor's style of leadership urged independence on those who worked for him, helping them to soldier in much the same way that the timeworn grooves of the church itself do. 
 Even before the cardinal became ill, running the archdiocese was no simple feat. With 2.4 million members, it covers Manhattan, Staten Island, the Bronx and seven counties north of the city. It includes hundreds of parishes, schools, hospitals, nursing homes, maternity homes, day care centers and shelters that are run directly by the archdiocese or by religious orders that are financially independent but report to the archbishop.
When the cardinal's energy began to wane, he left the details of management and most public appearances to two lieutenants, known as vicars general, and to other bishops, reserving his stamina for the most important issues. The vicars general ran the cardinal's weekly cabinet meetings, during which 25 to 30 department heads gather every Tuesday morning to report on major developments, until last week, when the cardinal returned to the table.
The vicars general, Patrick J. Sheridan and Robert A. Brucato, continued to bring important decisions to Cardinal O'Connor, but the two bishops also reminded those seeking the cardinal's advice to bear his condition in mind and use their judgment before troubling him. Functioning as gatekeepers was not entirely new for them. Normally, memorandums, letters and other communications to the cardinal, whose office is on the 20th floor of the archdiocese's headquarters at First Avenue and 55th Street, come through the vicars generals' offices one floor below.
Over its long history, experts on religion said, the church has established ways to function despite the illness or absence of its leaders, making no single person crucial at any given moment.
"The coming and going of the cardinal doesn't disrupt this machinery," Bishop Brucato, 68, a former chancellor of the New York Archdiocese, said in an interview in the rectory behind St. Patrick's Cathedral. Asked just how the archdiocese keeps functioning in Cardinal O'Connor's absence, Bishop Brucato cocked his head toward Bishop Sheridan, seated next to him, and said, "He growls, and I smile."
Seriously, he said, the two men live in the archbishop's residence behind the cathedral, and have known the cardinal for many years. They eat breakfast together every day. "We know his policies," Bishop Brucato said. "We know his mind. His authority is vested in us, to implement what he would want implemented."
While most dioceses have a single vicar general, New York is one of the few in the United States with two. Bishop Brucato joined Bishop Sheridan, who is 78, in August, working largely on the transition phase of the cardinal's impending retirement. The bishops said the naming of a second vicar general was not related to the cardinal's illness, but as it turns out, they have both filled in for him, as have monsignors throughout the archdiocese.
"It's a vast, vast operation," Bishop Sheridan said.
The operation resembles few others. Despite common perceptions of the Catholic Church as monolithic, its organization in New York is diffuse. Each parish is incorporated as a separate nonprofit entity headed by the archbishop, with the local priest serving as secretary-treasurer. In daily operations, the priest runs the parish, largely without consulting the archdiocese. Each parish is responsible for expenses and projects within its geographic area, and for sending 15 percent of its donations to the archdiocese.
Another factor that has helped tide over the archdiocese during the cardinal's illness is the nature of the Catholic Church, whose role is not to respond to daily political, financial or social dramas, but to stand constant in an ever-shifting world.
"It's not like Microsoft," said Msgr. Philip J. Murnion, who runs the National Pastoral Life Center, a Manhattan office that conducts research on the church. "The very nature of its business depends on changing rapidly. The point of the church is not to change rapidly."
Since becoming archbishop, Cardinal O'Connor has run the complex apparatus of the archdiocese by granting the heads of major departments great latitude and authority. They report major developments to him, and to each other, at the weekly cabinet meetings.
"You don't give piddly stuff, but the important stuff," said Msgr. Thomas J. Bergin, who runs educational programs for the archdiocese. As examples of important matters, the monsignor cited school consolidation questions and labor union negotiations.
The meetings also represent a chance for the different arms of the archdiocese to coordinate their actions, like lobbying on behalf of issues that could affect the archdiocese, said Joseph Zwilling, a spokesman for the archdiocese.
For example, Mr. Zwilling said, "if there's a piece of legislation in Albany that would have an effect on Medicare rates for hospitals, there might be an extended discussion about the legislation, and whether there is something that he as cardinal should be doing about that." The head of hospitals, Mary Healey-Sedutto, "might say, 'Yes, it would be helpful if you called this person or wrote that,' " Mr. Zwilling said.
The cardinal's style of running the meetings has served the archdiocese well during the months that he has been convalescing from surgery to remove a brain tumor and the follow-up radiation treatments, church officials said, because it cultivated their independence. They also say the cardinal has appointed laypeople, more so than his predecessors, to important positions, generally seeking the person best qualified to do a specific job.
The archdiocese's superintendent of schools, Catherine Hickey, said the cardinal had chosen a diverse group of ministries to be represented at the cabinet meetings. "Sitting around that table are people involved in hospital ecumenicism, evangelization, parish councils, ministries for African-Americans and Hispanics," she said.
She added that the Tuesday gatherings were not the only time she could speak to the cardinal, who encourages an open-door policy. "We can memo or talk to him any time of the day or night," Ms. Hickey said.
Until Cardinal O'Connor returned to his office in recent weeks, he worked from his home behind St. Patrick's Cathedral. When he resumed presiding over the cabinet meetings, he listened to updates from the two dozen department chiefs in attendance and surprised them with questions showing that he had kept up with their work throughout his absence, Mr. Zwilling said.
"He's been determined to be, and has been, the archbishop of New York every day," Mr. Zwilling said. "He's never pulled back one little bit from that."
For Msgr. James J. Murray, the head of Catholic Charities, that dedication was most starkly illustrated one morning last fall. Not long before, the cardinal had been released from the hospital, where he had been treated for fatigue. But that morning, he traveled to Wall Street for a fund-raising breakfast.
There, he told Wall Street financiers of the other New Yorkers, the ones untouched by the blessings of an economic boom: families shredded by violence, men cut adrift by drugs, infants with AIDS.
That morning, Monsignor Murray said, Catholic Charities walked away with donations totaling more than $400,000.
On the worst days since his surgery, the cardinal stopped receiving priests at his residence on Wednesdays, a day he had always left open for them to visit him unannounced. He also stopped attending the funerals of priests, which he had done since becoming archbishop.
But in recent weeks, the cardinal has reopened his home to the parish priests, and he works five to six hours a day at his office. When it comes to strategic decisions, however, he has avoided taking steps that would tie his successor's hands in the long run.
When his chancellor, Msgr. Jeremiah P. Monahan, died unexpectedly in October, Cardinal O'Connor appointed Msgr. Edward D. O'Donnell as chancellor for only one year. "He wanted to defer to the next man to renew him or not," Bishop Brucato said.
The next archbishop is likely to be named soon. Last Saturday, Cardinal O'Connor celebrated his 80th birthday at a charity fund-raising dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria. The milestone was especially important because Pope John Paul II has generally not allowed cardinals to serve long past that age, when they lose their ability to vote for the next pope.
In these waning days of his tenure, Cardinal O'Connor's sudden quiet has been striking, Bishop Sheridan said, especially for a leader whose trademark has been speaking out on pressing moral and political issues.
"People all over the place are stopping us and asking us, 'How is the cardinal? Tell him I'm praying for him,' " the bishop said. "They don't know who I am from Tuesday, but this is the public out there reacting that way, so they're aware of his illness and his absence."
He paused, and looked down. "Nonetheless," he said, "his presence is still here."

HEADLINE: Day of Rebellion Ends With Ouster Of Ecuador Leader

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: QUITO, Ecuador, Jan. 21

 BODY:
A junta ousted President Jamil Mahuad tonight, after a rebellion led by Indians and backed by the armed forces.
Throughout the day, Mr. Mahuad had insisted that he would not resign, but he abandoned the palace where he worked and lived in the afternoon after refusing a request from the military high command to step down. 
 Speaking in the name of the junta, Gen. Carlos Mendoza, the head of the joint military command who was named defense minister last week, said: "It is a government of the Ecuadorean people. We cannot speak of left or right."
Shortly before midnight, General Mendoza and the two other men who make up the junta emerged from the national palace to present themselves as Ecuador's new leaders. The others are Antonio Vargas, leader of an Indian federation that organized the protests, and Carlos Solorzano, a former Supreme Court judge.
Thousands of people streamed onto the plaza in front of the national palace, mingling with soldiers and celebrating, some waving the red flag of an extreme-left party. It was a day of political chaos, with Indians demanding Mr. Mahuad's resignation and forcing their way into Congress and the Supreme Court. After first backing Mr. Mahuad, the military later decided to support the protest, saying it was the only way to prevent "a social explosion."
"We are conscious that we must maintain order and discipline in the country," General Mendoza said.
Mr. Mahuad had insisted he would not step down, saying during a nationwide television broadcast that anyone who wanted to overthrow him would have to do it by force. Late tonight, Interior Minister Vladimiro Alvarez said in a television interview that "the president has no intention of leaving the country."
Ecuador's economic woes appear to have led to the unusual Indian uprising. Last year, inflation reached 60 percent, the highest in Latin America, and only one in three workers has full-time work. Most of the nation's 4 million Indians live in poverty.
At an emergency meeting of the Organization of American States in Washington, Ecuador's ambassador, Patricio Vivanco, said Mr. Mahuad had taken refuge at a military base in Quito.
The organization unanimously adopted a resolution condemning the overthrow and expressed support for Mr. Mahuad.
South American leaders also lined up in support of Mr. Mahuad, issuing statements condemning efforts to oust him. A statement issued by the United States Embassy in Lima, Peru, urged Ecuador's armed forces and police to support Mr. Mahuad.
"Whatever regime arises from this unconstitutional process will confront political and economic isolation, bringing more misery to the Ecuadorean people," the statement said.
Earlier in the day in Quito, guards stepped aside when hundreds of Indians accompanied by military officers stormed an empty Congress building, seized the podium and announced that they had created their own "Parliament of the People."
Military leaders said 120 officers were involved in the rebellion, along with an undetermined number of troops.
While downtown Quito was in chaos -- with Indians armed with rocks and clubs paralyzing traffic and menacing pedestrians -- most of the country and much of the city seemed unfazed.
"I am not going to abandon you," Mr. Mahuad, 50, said his nationwide broadcast, his only public appearance of the day.
"If you want to take power through force, gentlemen, take power through force," he said, directing his comments to the military high command, which only a few minutes before had asked him to resign.
Later, he left the national palace with close aides and was being protected by several military officers.
Two men were killed and eight were wounded by gunfire during protests and looting in Quito, Guayaquil and two smaller cities, the Red Cross said. The two men who were killed were shot by merchants while allegedly looting a market in Portoviejo.
Earlier in Guayaquil, 165 miles southwest of the capital, a group of leftist-led unions, student organizations and neighborhood associations seized the provincial government building.
The protesters were also upset about Mr. Mahuad's plans to scrap Ecuador's currency for the dollar. In becoming the first South American country seeking to adopt the dollar, Ecuador was hoping to curb inflation, bring down interest rates to U.S. levels and spur investment to end the country's deep recession.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
PRATT & WHITNEY TO CUT 1,700 ADDITIONAL JOBS

BYLINE: AP

 BODY:
The jet engine maker Pratt & Whitney is eliminating 1,700 additional jobs, mostly from its Connecticut-based manufacturing plants. The cuts are in addition to about 3,500 jobs the company has been eliminating since it started a major reorganization in 1998. A Pratt spokesman, Mark Sullivan, said yesterday that a drop-off in demand for jet engines over the last three years was the primary reason for the job cuts. The company employs 31,000 people worldwide and about 13,000 in Connecticut. Pratt & Whitney is a division of the United Technologies Corporation.

HEADLINE: Kiss My Lips

BYLINE: By M. G. Lord; M. G. Lord is the author of "Forever Barbie."

 BODY:

GEORGE BUSH, DARK PRINCE OF LOVE
 A Presidential Romance.
 By Lydia Millet.
 159 pp. New York:
 Scribner Paperback Fiction/
 Simon & Schuster. $10. 
 Lydia Millet's comic novel, "George Bush, Dark Prince of Love," is a good argument for exposing young people to television instead of books. Millet's narrator, Rosemary, a grossly overweight unemployed ex-convict, was a childhood reader. As a consequence -- one must assume, as the author provides no other explanation -- she speaks and writes like an awkward facsimile of Evelyn Waugh. The disparity between her squalid life and her highfalutin diction, however, does provide some entertaining moments. Had Rosemary's soliloquy not been stretched into a book, it would have made a great piece in, say, The Baffler or The Guardian, journals to which Millet herself has contributed.
Affected language, however, is the least of Rosemary's problems. She is also a stalker, and her target is George Herbert Walker Bush during his term as the 41st president of the United States. Beguiled by his "eternal youthfulness," an attribute that "marks only the scions of the leisured classes and the clinically insane," Rosemary resolves to deliver him from that debilitating shrew, his wife, Barbara, and supplant her as first lady.
Rosemary is an unlikely mix of uncomprehending narrator and razor-sharp political commentator. Millet attempts, and frequently pulls off, the difficult feat of making what is happening clear to the reader when the narrator herself doesn't grasp what she is describing. Yet it's hard to believe that a character who is so thick about her own plight could have such insight into the American electorate.
Rosemary divides the country into three camps: the L.B., or Liberal Bourgeoisie, snotty, educated folk who sneer at Bush; the P.B., or Petty Bourgeoisie, grubby strivers who elected Ronald Reagan; and the G.P., or General Public, who were "illegals, illiterates or didn't have time to vote." She especially hates the L.B., concluding, after a stint in a mental hospital, that psychotherapy is a sinister L.B. plot: "By persuading the P.B. and the G.P. that our problems all stem from ourselves, the L.B. hopes to distract us from the fact that they are quietly leeching all the blood out of the body of society."
Rosemary also blasts the myth of cute old people. "Senior citizens have a reputation for dignity that is largely unwarranted," she observes, and uses the antics of her toothless, sex-crazed, cocaine-addicted geriatric boyfriend to support this thesis. In Millet's second novel -- her first, "Omnivores," was published in 1996 -- the author tells her tale in broad strokes. I particularly liked her gratuitous fixation on grotesque body hair: she describes an unsuccessful suitor who had "a pelt of fur on his back that would have made a mink jealous" and suggests that had Michael Dukakis been less hirsute, he might have become president. What really defeated him were the "two wiry tufts of hair" that had obviously been "pruned from the Dukakis ears." Sometimes, though, Millet swings so wide that she misses. When Rosemary crucifies an effigy of Bush in her basement, the episode left me more puzzled than amused.
In her satirizing of the Bushes, Millet's biggest obstacle is reality, which is funnier than exaggeration. I laughed hardest at the first couple's self-identification on their tax return: "President" and "Housewife." Nor, in terms of dim narrators, has Millet outperformed Barbara Bush, who published two books written in the voices of her dogs. The cocker spaniel that narrates "C. Fred's Story" (1984) is particularly obtuse. He can't understand why the Chinese grumble when he defecates on the Great Wall. "After all, it was outdoors," he says. Millet's novel builds to a slapstick climax in which Rosemary becomes reconciled to her own "people," the General Public. Yet the embrace goes only so far: she never adopts their speech patterns.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 8; Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1424 words

HEADLINE: Masters of the Universe

BYLINE: By Sylvia Nasar; Sylvia Nasar is the author of "A Beautiful Mind," a biography of the mathematician John Forbes Nash Jr., which won a 1998 National Book Critics Circle Award.

 BODY:

The House
 of Rothschild
 The World's Banker, 1849-1999.
 By Niall Ferguson.
 Illustrated. 658 pp. New York:
 Viking. $34.95. 
 As long ago as the 1930's, a member of the American History Association invoked Walter Scott's Dr. Dryasdust to warn that professional historians were losing touch with readers beyond the academy. More recently, new quantitative techniques and the splintering of subjects into ever narrower specialties have revived fears that narrative history -- the readable kind -- is fast becoming, well, history.
Niall Ferguson's brilliant and altogether enthralling two-volume family saga of the Rothschilds proves that academic historians can still tell great stories that the rest of us want to read. Despite its rigorous and sophisticated treatment of the intricacies of finance, economics and diplomacy, "The House of Rothschild: The World's Banker, 1849-1999," the second volume of Ferguson's history, has all the grandeur and sweep of a 19th-century three-decker novel.
Like the fictional Buddenbrooks, Pallisers and Forsytes, the Rothschilds are eminently fascinating subjects. For nearly a century, they were the world's richest family and its most powerful bankers. As one contemporary put it, "There is but one power in Europe and that is Rothschild." Imagine a family firm with the financial muscle of Merrill Lynch, Morgan Stanley, J. P. Morgan, Goldman Sachs and the International Monetary Fund rolled into one.
Whereas many other wealthy European Jews converted, the Rothschilds always remained "confidently Jewish." They were "the nearest thing the Jews of Europe had to a royal family," and were referred to by other Jews as "Kings of the Jews" and "Jews of the Kings." Like the royals, they mostly married each other; as one Rothschild put it, "For us Jews, and particularly for us Rothschilds, it is better not to come into contact with other families, as it always leads to unpleasantness and costs money."
Their dizzying ascent from Frankfurt's squalid Jewish ghetto after the French Revolution has never been matched in the annals of moneymaking. In amassing what may have been the greatest private fortune in history, the Rothschilds created the first global bond market and the first truly multinational bank, with houses in London, Paris, Frankfurt, Vienna and Naples. Commanding unparalleled resources, they operated as the "lender of last resort to the lender of last resort," bailing out the Bank of England. They acted as private money managers for heads of government like Otto von Bismarck and were lenders to the pope.
Their story owes its immediacy to the remarkable resemblance between the Rothschilds' 19th-century world and our own. Then as now, international capital movements dwarfed national economies and the financial resources of governments. Communications dramatically accelerated the speed at which business could be done, and unregulated financial markets were dangerously volatile. The Rothschilds, Ferguson concludes, prospered not so much by maximizing profits during the booms as by riding out storms that sank less prudent and well-capitalized rivals.
Initially scorned as the very embodiment of New Money, the Rothschilds soon acquired the trappings and tastes of monarchs: grand estates and gardens, Dutch masters, entire menageries. A typical Rothschild shopping spree included, among other purchases, a Rubens, a chimney piece by Inigo Jones, a Reynolds, and "last though not least Mr. Russell's long promised Japanese or Chinese collection." One of their less impressive estates boasted among its novelties a "private circus ring, bowling alley, ice-skating rink, indoor swimming pool and Indian pavilion."
They soon became masters of the political universe. They dined with Disraeli and Gladstone, hunted with the Prince of Wales and helped engineer Napoleon III's impetuous marriage to the adventuress Eugenie de Montijo. At the same time, they devoted considerable energy to charitable activity and used their growing influence to advance the civil and political rights of Jews. Indeed, as Ferguson recounts, "the origins of the state of Israel can . . . be traced back to a letter to Lord Rothschild."
In this second volume of "The House of Rothschild" (the first is subtitled "Money's Prophets, 1798-1848"), Ferguson portrays the family at the zenith of its power. But just as in Thomas Mann's chronicle of the rise and fall of a Hanseatic merchant family and firm, "decadence is detectable in the third generation and fatal in the fourth."
In fact, the Rothschild myth peaked just as the family's fortune and power were at a low ebb, in the poisonous political atmosphere of the 1920's and 30's. The family's advocacy of the gold standard in the wake of Black Thursday and the Creditanstalt crisis -- which triggered an enormous flight of American capital from Europe -- helped turn a financial debacle into the decade-long Great Depression.
They had made other strategic blunders before that one. The greatest, according to Ferguson, was an inexplicable failure to establish the bank where opportunity increasingly lay -- in America. At one point, a prescient Rothschild mother wrote to her son, who was working in New York: "Stay in the New World; if the worst comes to the worst, if the old world should fall, which God will not permit, it would become a new fatherland for us." Yet it never happened. J. P. Morgan had already eclipsed the Rothschilds as the linchpin of war finance by the time of World War I, and after the war the Rockefellers took center stage.
Meanwhile, new rivals -- joint stock banks that drew on the savings of small investors -- were stealing the march on the Rothschilds in Europe. And they were being overtaken by new technology as well. Like a Wall Street old-timer bemoaning after-hours and Internet trading today, James Rothschild, as early as 1851, was complaining: "Since the telegraph became available people work much more. Every day at 12 they send a dispatch, even for trivial deals," making their profit "before the Bourse closes the same day." Once upon a time, the Rothschilds had controlled the flow of information as well as money, beating their rivals to the news through a network of couriers and carrier pigeons so effective that Europe's heads of state relied on it. With the telegraph, James ruefully observed, "anyone can get the news."
A gradual loss of entrepreneurial vigor and financial aptitude played the biggest role in the House of Rothschild's decline. By the fourth generation, "the aesthetic had taken over from the ascetic." Asked if he had a formula for financial success, Natty Rothschild habitually replied, "Yes, by selling too soon." Aesthetic diversion and risk aversion went hand in hand.
Privately, "the mores of the previous century were preserved as if in aspic," Ferguson writes. "While Lionel indulged his passion for horticulture with the aid of up to 400 gardeners at Exbury, Edouard had his beloved racehorses at Chantilly. . . . Philippe built himself a seaside villa at Arcachon, the better to entertain other men's wives." Interest in their country houses soon overtook their interest in the House in the City. Back at the bank, cousins and brothers arrived at 11 and left at 2. The industrious habits of the early Rothschilds had degenerated into the lifestyles of the rich and famous.
What a pleasure to read a book in which adroit turns of phrase and witty asides -- as well as the unfolding drama -- make one want to turn the page. But more than a tasting menu, this is a substantial repast. An Alan Greenspan can feast on artfully presented data on bonds and episodes of financial contagion. A connoisseur of politics can savor the machinations of a Neville Chamberlain or Winston Churchill.
Ferguson, who teaches history at Jesus College, Oxford, has decoded thousands of remarkably frank letters written by family members to one another in Judendeutsch (a mix of German, Hebrew and Yiddish) with Hebrew characters to frustrate prying eyes. Equal to Ferguson's mots are the Rothschilds' own, as when they complain about being "stared at by the modern argus, the public," dismiss Queen Victoria's writing as "ten thousand times" less interesting than a newspaper or cynically observe that a country's finances "cannot progress without liberties" but progress "even less with too many." It's delicious bits like these that make the thousand pages of Ferguson's monumental two-volume history not just instructive but positively engaging.

PUB-DATE: January 23, 2000

SECTION: Section 7; Page 16; Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1064 words

HEADLINE: Men Behaving Badly

BYLINE: By Nathaniel Tripp; Nathaniel Tripp is the author of "Father, Soldier, Son: Memoir of a Platoon Leader in Vietnam."

 BODY:

IN GLORY'S SHADOW
 Shannon Faulkner, The Citadel
 and a Changing America.
 By Catherine S. Manegold.
 Illustrated. 330 pp. New York:
 Alfred A. Knopf. $26.95. 
 Visitors to Charleston often remark on the Citadel, and how its severe, fortresslike architecture seems to clash with the otherwise genteel, ornate atmosphere of South Carolina. Vice Adm. James Stockdale, a Vietnam prisoner of war and winner of the Medal of Honor, was eerily reminded of the cellblocks of Hanoi when he first saw the school, on his way to a brief and frustrating tour there as commandant. He was ultimately worn down by what those crenelated walls have so long enclosed. So was Shannon Faulkner, who was accepted for admission in 1993 because her name was mistaken for a boy's. "Then she was rejected," Catherine S. Manegold writes. "After that, she sued." Manegold covered the landmark legal battle over Faulkner for The New York Times; "In Glory's Shadow" takes us inside the Citadel as two great forces maneuvered inexorably toward each other, and asks on which side of the gate danger really lies.
"Cadets were marching for themselves, narcissistically transfixed," Manegold writes, setting the stage for the painful struggles looming ahead. "Outside, in a new age molding itself to subtle and difficult new realities, knights were no longer recognized." Once again, the threat was coming from the North, and from New York in particular. Originally, it had been the fear of a revolt by slaves incited by Northern abolitionists that had prompted the wealthy white citizens of Charleston to build a fortress where their own private police force would be trained. Later, it was the North's economic growth and deep-water ports, and then the Civil War itself, that left Charleston isolated, a backwater, a city preserved in amber. This time New York, a city obsessed with the future, sent lawyers to that city obsessed with the past. They, and the distinctly American middle-class Southern girl they represented, were occasionally greeted by death threats and reviled on bumper stickers and T-shirts. Manegold asks why, what is so important? Shannon Faulkner asked the same question when her admission to the publicly financed military academy was denied, her presence described as "a 'toxin' that would weaken the corps and kill it from within."
"Mom, they think I'm a germ," Shannon joked. The Citadel was always reactive and insular, known among the military academies for its tougher than usual hazing practices -- and laxer academic standards. Calling itself "the West Point of the South," it received more public funds per student than most South Carolina colleges. The Confederate flag and "Dixie" always accompanied public events. "It was destined, each new generation thought, always to be a special place, the city's complement, the center axle in a secret wheel of power," Manegold notes. Yet as our nation began to absorb dramatic social changes, the Citadel became even more isolated. The school's fervent anti-Communism in the 1950's, when J. Edgar Hoover's "Masters of Deceit: The Story of Communism in America and How to Fight It" was required reading, morphed into something darker: a sense that it alone held the standards of purity, of duty, honor and country. The Citadel did not admit blacks until 1965, nearly 20 years after the integration of the military. More ominous, while other campuses endured liberal protest and reform, hazing at the Citadel became tougher still. Nazi paraphernalia and jargon became popular, and one commandant after another was unable to put a stop to it. The professors were frustrated. "Day by day," Manegold writes, "they stood in front of boys more concerned with survival outside class than a good performance in it. The tests and fascinations of barracks life overwhelmed all but the few."
Hazing is central to Manegold's book, and was cited by the Citadel as an important reason women were not admissible. Hazing of first-year cadets, including mild torture, is a grotesque parody of the slave and master relationship of Charleston's past. Those who show weakness, who fail or cry out, are often characterized by obscene names for parts of the female anatomy. Those who pass are admitted to an elite lifelong brotherhood. This holds enormous appeal for boys who otherwise lack direction, just as street gangs do. It creates an obedient and often misogynistic warrior class. At its root is the need to renounce all the softness and empathy one's mother once represented. Its end purpose is to make the inflicting of pain, even death, acceptable.
For two years, as the lawyers battled, Shannon was allowed to attend classes, escorted by federal marshals, but continued to be excluded from the cadet corps. To many at the Citadel, keeping the corps of cadets male was a matter of honor; "duty, honor, country" is the Citadel creed, but of the three, "honor" remains the most ambiguous. In the masculine, feudal sense in which it is presented here, it is ultimately self-defined. It transcends all else, including the law. In isolation and under siege, honor often becomes malevolent. Social scientists have demonstrated that where the culture of honor is strongest, as in the rural South and West, it is closely associated with the culture of violence, high murder rates and weak gun-control laws. It is an artifact of the frontier, of reconstruction, of lawlessness, of deep wounds slow to heal. It is also the culture of losers, but not to be taken lightly, as anyone with an eye on the Balkans can readily see. This, too, is what Shannon Faulkner faced. When her battle was won and she was finally admitted to the cadet corps she lasted less than a week, having lost her taste for the place. More women soon followed, however, and there is little doubt that the Citadel is a better place today, due in part to her courage.
Manegold avoids the broader psychological and social implications of Shannon Faulkner's particular story, focusing on the culture of the Citadel itself and the predominantly male machinations of those defending it. But her book is more than an effective, often mesmerizing, account of one great battle in a long struggle for women's rights. In throwing open the gates of a revered institution and casting light in the shadows, she has forced all of us to take a second look at ourselves and our society.
