SECTION: Section 7; Page 32; Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 830 words

HEADLINE: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks

BYLINE: By Scott Veale

 BODY:

The Orchid Thief
 By Susan Orlean. Ballantine, $14.
The author's first book-length narrative is a journalistic account of a thief caught pilfering 200 rare orchids and plants in Florida, but its true subject is the monomania of collectors and growers, who can wait seven years just to see a new plant bloom. This peculiar mania is revealed as "a small thing of grandeur, a passion with a pedigree," Ted Conover wrote here last year.
 
The Hours
 By Michael Cunningham. Picador USA, $13.
The theme of this Pulitzer Prize-winning novel is the haunting of present lives by memories and books, and it evolves in three connected narratives: that of a New York woman whose life echoes events in Virginia Woolf's "Mrs. Dalloway"; a housewife in 1940's Los Angeles who reads the book; and Woolf herself in 1923, living near London and writing her novel. "The overall impression is that of a delicate, triumphant glance, an acknowledgment of Woolf that takes her into Cunningham's own territory, a place of late-century danger but also of treasurable hours," Michael Wood wrote in these pages in 1998.
 
Rocket Boys: A Memoir
 By Homer H. Hickam Jr. Delta, $12.95.
This nostalgic coming-of-age story is set during the Sputnik era in dreary West Virginia coal country, where the author (a future NASA engineer) and five pals undertook an audacious series of rocket launchings that captured the imagination of a dying region. "He is a very adept storyteller," James R. Gaines wrote here in 1998.
 
Bad Chemistry
 By Gary Krist. Berkley, $7.50.
A headless body, a combustible dog and "The Tale of Peter Rabbit" are among the plot elements in this taut mystery about an ex-policewoman trying to track down her missing husband. "Fascination with the power of secrets . . . holds the book together," David Willis McCullough wrote in these pages in 1998.
 
Inventing Wyatt Earp: His Life and Many Legends
 By Allen Barra. Carroll & Graf, $15.95.
In 1881, a 30-second gunfight helped create an American hero and a stirring myth of frontier justice. It turns out that accounts of Earp's career and the shootout were full of ironies, confusion and outright falsehoods. This "refreshingly pugnacious book" aims to set the record straight, Richard E. Nicholls said here last year.
 
Elegy for Iris
 By John Bayley. Picador USA, $13.
The British literary critic chronicles his long, rich relationship with his wife, the novelist Iris Murdoch, and her descent into Alzheimer's disease. "In its evocation of the lyrical, the comic and the tragic, this splendid book enlarges our imagination of the range and possibilities of love," Mary Gordon wrote here in 1998.
 
There Once Was a World:
 A Nine-Hundred-Year Chronicle of the Shtetl of Eishyshok
 By Yaffa Eliach. Back Bay/Little, Brown, $25.
A historian recreates in intensely rendered detail the daily rhythms of life in her family's shtetl, a town in what is now Lithuania whose 3,500 Jews were nearly all murdered. Her account contains numerous photographs and interviews with survivors. In 1998 our reviewer, Stephen J. Dubner, called this "an exhaustive and kaleidoscopic history." "The Rest of Us": The Rise of America's Eastern European Jews, by Stephen Birmingham (Syracuse University, $22.95), is the final installment in the author's trilogy on Jewish immigrants in America. It is a broad canvas filled with portraits of colorful characters like Irving Berlin, Meyer Lansky and Ralph Lauren. "Trenchant observations permeate this book," Sydney Zion wrote here in 1984.
 
Face-Time
 By Erik Tarloff. Pocket Books, $12.95.
A rising White House speechwriter is horrified when the president takes a shine to his girlfriend. She's flattered, of course, and tempted by the prospect of ultimate insider access. The result is a novel "about sex and power in Washington that goes behind the headlines to a darker place," Patricia O'Brien wrote here last year.
 
Falling Slowly
 By Anita Brookner. Vintage Contemporaries, $12.
This novel focuses on two willfully hermitic sisters torn between a desire for connection with the larger world and a greedy complacency about their carefully sheltered existence. Brookner is "the unrivaled mistress of the stifled life," Claire Messud wrote here last year.
 
Foreign Bodies
 By Hwee Hwee Tan.
 Washington Square/Pocket Books, $12.95.
This first novel is about a young lawyer in Singapore who has nine days to prove that her English boyfriend is not the mastermind of an international gambling ring. "Tan spins out a gripping story," Anderson Tepper wrote in the Book Review last year.
 
Winter Count
 By Barry Lopez. Vintage, $11.
Many of these stories focus on obscure figures and incidents in the Plains and Rockies, and are informed by American Indian culture and mystical wisdom. Each tale "is as economical in design, as painstakingly crafted and as resonant as a good classical guitar," David Quammen wrote here in 1981. Scott Veale

HEADLINE: Travel Advisory: Correspondent's Report;
A Makeover in Anaheim, For Parks and City

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

DATELINE: ANAHEIM, Calif.

 BODY:
THERE is no missing the big changes afoot in Anaheim. For months, no motorist on Interstate 5, the overcrowded freeway that snakes through this aging tourist town, could fail to notice the outline of new ramps and overpasses and seemingly endless construction that herald the biggest development effort here in the 45 years since Walt Disney first built his Magic Kingdom.
Nearly half a century after it opened in a sleepy sea of orange groves, Disneyland is as fresh and spotless as ever, and it remains the single most popular tourist attraction in Southern California, drawing some 13.7 million visitors in 1998, according to Amusement Business, a trade journal. But the urban corridor of strip malls, fast-food outlets and motels that has grown up around it was tired and long overdue for a lift. It is getting one in a big way. 
 Over the next two years, Anaheim will see the fruits of a $4.2 billion public-private redevelopment in the works since 1996. It will bring a whole new theme park called Disney's California Adventure, plus a retail shopping complex, an expanded convention center, and new hotels, roads and landscaping to 1,100 acres surrounding the original park.
Just 12 miles away in Buena Park, Knott's Berry Farm, Orange County's second-most-popular attraction, with some 3.4 million visitors, will open its Perilous Plunge this summer. That ride, featuring a four-and-a-half-story chute down which boats will plunge at a 75-degree angle, is billed as the longest, steepest water ride in the world and is just one part of an overall upgrade at Knott's that will also feature a separate new 13-acre water park called Soak City, U.S.A., scheduled to open on Memorial Day with 21 water rides and attractions.
"It's kind of a different world every day now," said Elaine Cali, the communications director for the Anaheim/Orange County Visitor and Convention Bureau, whose of fice overlooks the changing construction scene.
Disney alone is investing $1.4 billion to expand its original resort and build the new California-theme park -- celebrating beach culture, the redwood forests and other features of the state -- on the site of its former parking lot. It is bridging the two with Downtown Disney, a 300,000-square-foot retail, dining and entertainment complex, like the one at Walt Disney World in Orlando, that will feature outlets of popular spots like House of Blues and the La Brea Bakery, the Los Angeles-based emporium of irresistible breads and pastries.
These expanded attractions, including a 750-room luxury hotel, the Grand Californian, built in the style of Frank Lloyd Wright, are to open early in 2001. A 10,000-car enclosed parking garage is going up adjacent to the parks, and the original Disneyland Hotel is being remodeled.
By December 2000, a $177 million expansion of the Anaheim Convention Center, across the street from the park, is scheduled to be finished, increasing total square footage by 40 percent, to 1.6 million square feet. A major redesign of the former Anaheim Stadium, now known as Edison Field International and home of the Disney-owned Anaheim Angels baseball team, has already been completed.
"The town has not seen anything of this magnitude, certainly since the original Disneyland was built," said Ms. Cali of the convention bureau. "This was truly an agricultural community then, but today it's an urban destination and very built up, so to be able to change the landscape is pretty remarkable."
Together, the new Disney-related attractions are expected to increase the average stay in the resort corridor to four nights, from three now, though some developers have held off building new hotels until they are sure more visitors will come, leading to some predictions of a shortage of rooms in the near term.
In the early 1990's, when the California economy was in a deep recession and the greater Los Angeles area was rocked by riot, fire and earthquake, attendance at Disneyland and other parks fell sharply. Although it has since bounced back, some hotel analysts say lenders remain put off by Anaheim's low average room rate, about $76, compared with an overall nationwide average of $81 through November, according to Smith Travel Research.
All the construction has been a challenge for local hotels, which have struggled to fill rooms in the face of the congestion. While the California Division of Tourism has projected an overall increase of about 6 percent in travel within and to California in 1999, Orange County was expected to end the year with about 38.05 million visitors, up just 0.8 percent from 1998.
At the moment, perhaps the most visible sign of the efforts in Anaheim is the freeway construction, a $1.1 billion makeover aimed at nearly doubling the lanes of a 9.5-mile section that has been among the most congested in the region. Construction has had to allow for the continuing crowds at Disneyland and has required rerouting up to 36,000 vehicles a day. It is scheduled to be finished late in 2000, just in time for the opening of the new Disney park.

HEADLINE: Practical Traveler;
Roman Holiday? Sample Tours

BYLINE: By BETSY WADE

 BODY:
TAKING a trip to Rome during the Catholic Church's Jubilee Year might seem intimidating, particularly to travelers who have never been to Italy. But even for those not religiously motivated, this year provides a good opportunity to see the city spruced up, with many public facilities renovated and transit systems attuned to tourists. The exchange rate is also advantageous, with the lira at nearly 1,900 to $1.
The easy way to do it is with a tour or package, because many causes for anxiety, like getting to the hotel from the airport, are dealt with by someone else, and old hands are ready to offer help. 
 Regular tour operators are not using the Jubilee Year as a selling device, and thus have shunned the big price jumps that upset many consumers about millennium tours and events. Travelers to Rome are still able to look at the choices and seek out the religious component, or bypass it, in selecting a tour.
 "We didn't focus on the Jubilee as an event," said Robert Saccone, director of United States development for Italiatour, a division of Alitalia. "Our job is to promote travel by people of all religions."
Perillo Tours of Woodcliff Lake, N.J., has this to say in its catalog for spring and summer: "Scrub, scrub, scrub. It seems that half of Rome's buildings have shed centuries of grime to happily reveal their original beauty." Steve Perillo, the president, said that his company does not emphasize events like papal audiences, although of course tour officials advise group members of each day's events.
Operators consulted early this month said that they had space on Rome tours scheduled through the end of the year. That includes TourCrafters of Libertyville, Ill., one of two United States operators designated by the Vatican Central Committee as official agencies. The second, the Catholic Travel Center of Burbank, Calif., which designs tours for clubs and churches, said that it had instituted early deadlines and that most of its group capacity for spring and summer was booked, although there were spaces for independent travelers. J. Scott Scherer, the president, said that bookings would be 65 percent above last year -- he anticipates 3,000 to 4,000 clients.
Mr. Perillo, whose company calls itself the world's largest operator of tours to Italy -- with clients numbering "tens of thousands yearly" -- said he was sure that spring and summer would fill up but that at the moment there is space.
 
A Sampling of Packages
Prices on Rome tours take a step up in March, when the weather eases and average sunshine increases to six hours a day from the January-February level of four. Lent begins March 8 and Easter is April 23, and high-season prices are fully in effect by then.
Until then, what would normally be viewed as short-stay winter packages are available. Almost all use Alitalia, but some flights are on British Airways and Sabena. Trans World Airlines dropped its New York-Rome route on Jan. 10, although it still serves Milan.
What follows is a sampling of tours headed for Rome this year:
Until March 10, TourCrafters' economy trip of five nights costs $599 in double occupancy, with air fare from New York, Boston, Miami or Chicago. It uses the Brasile, a three-star hotel, and includes breakfast, hotel service charges and taxes. Transfers are not included; neither are airport taxes and other miscellany, totaling about $75 a person. There may be a $25 extra charge for a departure on Friday, Saturday or Sunday.
CIT Tours Corporation in New York also has a five-night Rome winter special at $599 a person, with two in a room, through March 10. It includes round-trip nonstop Alitalia air fare from New York, Boston, Chicago or Miami, rail transportation to and from the airport, and five nights at the three-star Donatello Hotel on the Via di Porta Maggiore near the train station, with buffet breakfasts. British Airways through London is also offered, for $70 additional. Departure is available any day of the week. Airport taxes are not included.
Italiatour offers Roman Jubilee, a four-night trip. Until March 12, including air fare from New York and Boston, and using the three-star hotels Augustea, Center and Portamaggiore, it costs $689; for the rest of March, it is $769. Three days of tours, including the Christian Rome Tour, are offered. Continental breakfasts, transfers between airport and hotel, and hotel service charges and taxes are included.
Perillo's prices are higher than those given above because the company quotes the same cost for many different departure cities, some as far from the Atlantic as Seattle and San Francisco. The company also uses first-class hotels.
Through Feb. 26, Perillo's six-night packages begin at $1,199 for each of two people in a room in a four-star hotel. The tours leave on Saturday and Thursday, returning the next Saturday or Thursday. The price includes round-trip air fare, transfers from the Rome airport and back, buffet breakfasts, hotel service charges, taxes and tips. A half-day of sightseeing is scheduled, and Perillo provides a host at the hotel at particular hours to give directions and help with activities. A single room costs $329 more. In March, the tour price goes to $1,299.
On April 17 the Perillo schedule shifts to Monday-Monday, and the price rises to $1,799; from June 19 into October, it is $1,999. The hotel for the high season is the new Hotel Empire Palace on the Via Aureliana. Perillo is unusual in not accepting credit cards.
 
Papal Blessing
A six-night package designed for the Jubilee Year by TourCrafters is called "Rome, Home of the Holy Father." It is available until March 31 for $1,099 a person from New York or Boston, with two in a room. The price increases thereafter. This tour includes a Pilgrim's Card allowing entry on Rome's transit system for three days, medical assistance and telephone calls. The tour is open to groups -- which depart on the day of their choice and get price discounts at certain levels of participation -- and to independent travelers, who also may depart any day. The hotel at the basic price is the three-star Centro, on Via Firenze, or a similar place. Breakfasts and dinners are included, also transfers from the airport, hotel service and taxes. Two sightseeing expeditions are included, as well as attendance at a papal audience on a Wednesday, a papal blessing on a Sunday and a Jubilee event. Airport taxes are not included.
All these tours can be booked through travel agents. Here are addresses and numbers for the operators mentioned.

LENGTH: 939 words

HEADLINE: ART;
A Neighborly Thing to Do: Showing Off Library's Works

BYLINE: By WILLIAM ZIMMER

DATELINE: YONKERS

 BODY:
PEOPLE in one town do not always know what gems, or just plain pleasant artwork, their neighbor has, so when one institution shows the collection of another one nearby, the result is an economical, efficient, yet striking way to get acquainted.
The Hudson River Museum here is doing that now. "A Community Collects: Art From the Bronxville Public Library" consists of 26 paintings that the library obtained in 1942 when its trustees asked the community for art to furnish its public rooms. About 100 works of American art were donated, including a large number of Currier & Ives prints. Not surprisingly, most of the collection, including the works in the present exhibition, is on the conservative side: most of it dates from the 1880's to the 1930's, and modernism does not rear its head at all. 
 If the show is not a world beater, it is certainly pleasant and often absorbing. The paintings share many qualities, and viewers can get involved in comparing and contrasting. Wallinformation reminds viewers of Bronxville's contribution to American art. From its beginnings in the 1890's, Bronxville was conceived as a planned community, and artists figured in the plan. Lawrence Park, named for William Van Duzer Lawrence, was the first section to be built. Lawrence thought that if he built it they would come, they being artists from New York who would be attracted to bucolic surroundings. The artists did come, and the Bronxville Artists Colony lasted through the 1930's. Six of its artists are represented in this exhibition.
Impressionism and its more subtle relative Tonalism were still flourishing styles, which depended to a large extent on landscape. Those styles constitute the bulk of the show, but it is also evident that a characteristic of many of the landscapes is broad, lively brushwork. This predilection is announced by "Rocks and Seas" by Frederick Judd Waugh. Waves dashing against rocks is one of the hoariest of subjects, but if done right it produces a visceral thrill. Waugh's treatment does just that because it seems especially fresh; he used colors directly out of the paint tube.
Bruce Crane was one of the Bronxville artists, and his three paintings represent the nuances achievable in Tonalism. Adjacent colors vary only slightly, yet paradoxically the results can be dramatic. "Afternoon Mist" is essentially a quiet mix of green and taupe, but "Passing Shower" is marked by more florid brushwork, especially in the curtain of rain at the right of the canvas.
The best known painter here is Albert Bierstadt, and his small oil on paper evocation of Mount Shasta easily summons up visions of his major outsize mountain landscapes. But Ernest Lawson is a familiar figure, too. He was a member of the Eight, the group of painters who immediately followed the Ash Can School carrying on its tradition of vigorous brushwork. Lawson is represented by two very different paintings, although both are snow scenes, his specialty. "The Harlem River" is set in his favorite locale, upper Manhattan, and there is a marked contrast between the shimmering blue of the water and the snow, which seems to be slashed by equal parts of mud. "Winter Sunset," though, is a clean evocation of a certain time of day. The brush strokes are moderate, and the snow is nearly immaculate. The orange disk in the sky is reminiscent of the one in the first Impressionist painting to be labeled as such, Monet's "Impression, Sunrise."
The exhibition contains many snow scenes. Perhaps the organizers thought they would echo the winter weather that might be glimpsed through the exhibition space's several windows. They might wind up being a surrogate for snow that never comes. "The Rookery in Winter" by William Thomas Smedley is identified as a house in Lawrence Park. What is most impressive here is the way Smedley captured the shivery sensation of blowing snow. The evergreens, whose color persists in Hobart Nichols's "Snow Scene -- Westchester County," are painted as amalgams of quick marks, and were perhaps inspired by Asian art. Everett Warner's "Mill Dam" is characterized by ice floes and also by the intense brush strokes of the water falling over the dam.
Other genres of art are represented. "Chelsea" by Anthony Thieme is set by the sea and is remarkable for the animated way sails on ships are rendered to indicate wind rippling the cloth. This painting is something of an un-still life when compared to the hushed austerity of Soren Emil Carlsen's composition, which concentrates on two teapots and a porcelain cup. Two kinds of flowers, one in a garden and the other in a black vase, are represented in Mary Fairchild Low's "Delphiniums and Butterflies" and Hermann Dudley Murphy's "Pot of Cyclamen."
Four paintings are each devoted to a single, contrasting personality. The prairie scout in William Gilbert's painting of that name stands in an ambience of palpable dry heat. He may have been inspired by Remington. The ambiguous dark surroundings in which Eanger Irving Couse put his "Indian With Blanket" lend a certain gravity to his subject's contemplation of a single woven symbol. The three-quarter-length portrait "Boy in the Red Scarf" is reminiscent of the best paintings of Robert Henri, the founder of the Ash Can School. He also holds a basket of apples, another color note. If only for the intense way he looks directly at us, and probably stared at the artist, William Howe's huge, resting "Norman Bull" is a personality, too.
"A Community Collects: The Bronxville Public Library" is at the Hudson River Museum through May 7. For information, the number to call is 963-4550.

SECTION: Section 2; Page 1; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 2241 words

HEADLINE: Music;
Out of a Rut And Into A New Groove

BYLINE: By BEN RATLIFF

 BODY:
AS found on the Billboard charts and radio stations like New York's Hot 97, today's R-and-B mostly denotes a tight formula: single-string acoustic guitar licks over synthetic blipping beats like an Atari Pong game, the airbrushed vocals of a lead singer indignant over a sexual promise that's been withheld and a bland group of backup singers taking the chorus in unison while the leader sings sub-Stevie Wonder melisma. Sometimes the musical blueprints, as developed by producers like Timbaland and Babyface, are fascinating -- but only until they are copied to death. With such homogeneity, it's becoming very hard to tell one performer from another in mainstream black music.
At the same time, D'Angelo's new single "Untitled" has just been added to commercial playlists across the country, and it sounds nothing like the above description. Slow and insinuating, its vocals violate a cardinal rule of commercial music by being mixed deep into the track. It's based on a live studio jam; it begins with a false start, and it ends with an abrupt cut-off during a crescendo. In the middle of formulaic, machinelike music that sounds as if it was made by committee, you're suddenly presented with a mysterious song, with handcrafted defects all over it. 
 "Untitled" is a signal that can't be missed; something this radical can't just drop out of the sky alone. There's a widening groundswell of R-and-B artists -- and even some who fit more naturally in the category of hip-hop -- who are sounding like an antidote to the sameness problem: their records are more well-rounded, more musicianly, more complete. They make a mature music, and a family music, for living rooms, rather than for the streets. In their subject matter there is room for self-doubt, anger, beatitude, whimsy and religion -- not just slick come-ons or aggressive bluster. It's increasingly album-oriented as opposed to singles-oriented. Importantly, it marks a gradual return in black pop to the use of instruments instead of electronics. And it isn't even always sung in English.
It's not just that some of these performers are infusing their new music with 30-year-old grooves; they are expanding the entire personality of R-and-B. Some, like D'Angelo and Maxwell, are rising to the the challenge of becoming complete singer-songwriters; some are beginning to look beyond the standard sound of American R-and-B, adding jazz elements or reaching out to black music of other cultures. Hip-hop is changing, too, with so-called alternative performers like Mos Def, Q-Tip and the Roots suddenly making the best current albums of the genre. Perhaps you could call it all-natural R-and-B, referring to the patience and wisdom in this new music as well as to the general absence of glossy pop hysteria and to the Afro hair style affected by some of the performers.
If the fluky breakout successes for this kind of music have arrived in a trickle -- Arrested Development in the early 90's, Maxwell in 1996, Erykah Badu in 1997 (Lauryn Hill's success in 1998 wasn't exactly unexpected) -- now seems like the moment for the floodgates to open. Tastes have changed in its direction. Macy Gray's recent debut, "On How Life Is," a lushly produced album rich with 1970's Chaka Khan references -- but also containing strong hints of more underground sources from the era, like the singer Betty Davis -- has just been nominated for two Grammy awards; it's a record for knowledgeable music fans as well as casual radio listeners. Angie Stone's promising debut record, "Black Diamond," has slowly gained sales and radio play since its release four months ago. And D'Angelo's long-awaited new album, "Voodoo" (Cheebasound/Virgin V2-48499), to be released on Tuesday, could be the succes d'estime that proves the force of this new music: it is a largely unslick, stubbornly idiosyncratic and genuinely great album that has already produced two hit singles.
OFFICIAL names haven't stuck to any of these artists who somewhat defy the radio formulas. Neo-soul is too reductive; rare groove, as it's often called in England, is too record collector-ish. "I've been called alternative, retro, all kinds of things like that," said the singer, guitarist and producer Raphael Saadiq, formerly of the band Toni Toni Tone and now of a new band, Lucy Pearl, whose first album comes out in May.
For a decade, Mr. Saadiq has combined old R-and-B with current production sounds and whiffs of hip-hop, and two years ago Toni Toni Tone finally broke up, a victim of radio's narrowness. "Maybe they need to have a new category, 'R-R-and-B,' " he said, "real rhythm and blues, for music that has a lot of feeling going into it, almost like underground R-and-B." Mr. Saadiq's dream for a new radio format is all music by bands, as opposed to music with electronic rhythm sections. "Call it 'hot real music' or something," he suggested. "I think a lot more people would start playing instruments as a result."
Wherever there are twists on the current formulas of black music, there are only euphemisms to describe it. First, there's that umbrella term "urban": no record company or chartmaker wants to own up to segregating music by race, so a sociological category serves instead. One also hears the term "progressive," which means music that can be liked beyond teendom: nobody wants to lose a share of the enormous, heavy-spending youth market for black music by using that taboo word, adult. And, finally, there is the term that has lost all its flavor yet continues to be used in the business: alternative.
Alternative, in this context, denotes music that appeals to black and nonblack, male and female, brand-new and retro tastes. Here you see the first confusion: what's so alternative about a potential audience that wide? But buried deeper in that confusion is some cultural alchemy, a point at which music made by black artists ceases to be "black music" and their songs are not suitable for black radio; performers like Lenny Kravitz, Me'Shell Ndegeocello and Dionne Farris have fallen into this trap.
One ought to avoid calling this music "alternative" outside the argumentative purposes of this article. Black artists tend to distance themselves from the word and its connotations of white performers, rock's musical ingredients and the aesthetic of self-marginalizing. But the word still links to a pressing issue. It remains difficult to get this new between-the-cracks music on the radio and in the hands of mainstream American record buyers. Since the Telecommunications Act of 1996, corporate consolidation within the radio industry has severely reduced adventurous programming. The number of current records on an average commercial black station's playlist, said Tom Bracamontes, senior vice president of promotion at Virgin records, has dropped by nearly a third. "Not only is music on the fringes of R-and-B going to lose out," said Mr. Bracamontes, "but even regular mainstream R-and-B is going to lose out."
Still, there are ways of defeating the rules of the system, through the long-term effort of record labels and performers themselves. Virgin took a year to market the French band Les Nubians to black stations across the country with an adult audience, and the life of the band's single, "Mekeda," has been extended: it's now being pitched to hip-hop mix shows. The Roots continue to perform incessantly, even setting up shop every week in various clubs to present shows that act as workshops. The last few years have also seen a growing number of R-and-B artists turn away from the system and form their own labels to release their new material -- a roll call that includes not only the Artist Formerly Known as Prince, but also Mr. Saadiq, Dionne Farris and the new singer N'Dambi.
The shabby state of live performance is also forcing change. Last year one could witness the spectacle of the singer Ginuwine, who had a top-10 R-and-B radio hit at the time, performing to a half-empty audience at the Manhattan club Tramps. Behind him, an ad hoc band copied his recordings exactly; there was a drummer, but a rhythm machine anchored the grooves. One got the sense that Ginuwine could be an exciting performer if only live performance made more business sense to him, and the club would be full if the audience for black music had a little more faith that live shows in general were worthwhile.
Conversely, the drummer for the Roots, Ahmir Thompson (a k a Questlove), has started to pop up on all sorts of records, from Erykah Badu's "Baduizm" to the Congolese-French group Zap Mama's "Amazone"; his participation seems to ensure that a record will sound both new and different, and there are sure to be others like him in his wake. Truth be told, he's often too metronomic, holding one pattern steady through almost an entire song. But the difference in hearing music with a human drummer again is immeasurable -- it's warmer, more vulnerable, more interesting.
It's Mr. Thompson's drumming that threads together the songs on D'Angelo's "Voodoo." A full five years (an eternity in the career of a black pop artist) after his first album, "Brown Sugar," D'Angelo (Michael D'Angelo Archer) took two years of daily recording sessions to construct his new album, yet anyone who has heard the stories of his studio indulgences may be surprised by the album's streamlined economy. He spent that time establishing a telepathic live feel between the members of his band, which included, aside from Mr. Thompson, the jazz trumpeter Roy Hargrove, the jazz guitarist Charlie Hunter and Mr. Saadiq. At their best, the record's songs begin without fanfare, as if they're drifting into hearing range from the floor below. The main evidence of studio indulgence is the heavy multitracking of D'Angelo's voice: you hear seven or eight D'Angelos, in falsetto, muttering, chanting, out of sync; they soar freely atop the music like doves in an aviary.
The album's first single, "Left and Right," hedged bets: it was the only track that used hip-hop, and it brought in the rap stars Method Man and Redman. Though the song is a shrewd effort to have it both ways, retaining the slinky, subtle feel of D'Angelo's music while incorporating hip-hop in its second half, it's also the album's weakest track. The rest of "Voodoo" is not, per se, an attempt to bring back the music of the 70's; it's an attempt to recall a time when long tracks and unique group sounds were radioworthy popular culture, and pop radio wasn't so segmented by race. In interviews, D'Angelo has described it as evoking the "second phase" of musicians like Marvin Gaye, Sly Stone and Curtis Mayfield -- the point where they had already had success with mainstream pop and were ready to experiment a bit. It says much about today's competitive record and radio business that D'Angelo was ready to make that shift on his second record.
Since the 60's, paradigm-shift moments in black popular culture have frequently been announced. Some of this new ferment seems reminiscent of the late 1980's, when the writer Trey Ellis, in an influential article in the literary journal Callaloo, proclaimed a culturally mulatto "New Black Aesthetic." He pointed to bands like Living Color and Fishbone, filmmakers like Spike Lee and the Hudlin brothers, playwrights like George C. Wolfe -- all of whom expressed a "casually nonchalant" attitude about race; these were artists liberated by the feeling that they did not have to perform according to what was expected from them as blacks. But while the dominant strain of Mr. Ellis's essay is of black artists joyfully crashing the temples of white culture -- Living Color's freedom to play rock 'n' roll, Tracy Chapman's to play coffeehouse folk and so on -- the emphasis of the current crop of "R-R-and-B" musicians is to rediscover what was so good about the black music of their youth, and how it was incorporated into the wider scope of American culture.
BUT one victory begets another, and it seems likely that more barriers will be broken down; possibly the next step for these artists will be to find meaningful ways to connect American black pop with the rest of their cultural heritage, as well as with black music of other cultures. Jazz musicians have already hooked up with Maxwell and D'Angelo; Lauryn Hill has apparently expressed interest in working with the protean Brazilian musician and cultural hero Carlinhos Brown; she and D'Angelo both worked in the studio last year with the Nigerian bandleader Femi Kuti. Instead of dwelling on the limitations and frustrations of the idea of alternative black pop, it might be better to focus on its positive side: its incredible capaciousness.
Imagine a listener-supported radio station or Internet station of the near future that played not only Macy Gray and D'Angelo, but also their sources -- Curtis Mayfield, Jimi Hendrix, Marvin Gaye, Rufus. And also Al Green and Shirley Caesar (gospel music, and in fact all religious devotion, is "alternative" these days); Billie Holiday, John Coltrane and Betty Carter (jazz -- misunderstood and underappreciated, yet one of America's dearest notions -- remains our ultimate alternative music); the sweet Afro-Peruvian grooves of Susana Baca, the Brazilian funk of Jorge Ben; Cassandra Wilson's sophisticated projects of folk Americana.
Black pop has been a producer's game for the last two decades; now it's musicians who are starting to shape a wider aesthetic.
