SECTION: Section 6; Page 30; Column 1; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 3484 words

HEADLINE: The Future Is Now-or Never

BYLINE: By Dan Brekke; Dan Brekke, a freelance writer, was deputy editor of Wired magazine and editor in chief of Wired Digital's daily news service.

 BODY:
Noon, christmas eve, san francisco. in stores on Union Square and on Market Street, registers will ring up sales for another six hours. But in a tower near the western end of the Bay Bridge, in the offices of RedEnvelope, an online gift company that has been up and running for all of 60 days, the holiday is over.
The staff gathers for a toast and sips Champagne from plastic glasses. "Next year it will be crystal," laughs Hilary Billings, the 36-year-old C.E.O. Then everyone clears out. In San Diego, a few agents in the company's customer-care center field the last "Will my stuff make it in time?" calls. In Wilmington, Ohio, the warehouse that has heaved more than 20,000 RedEnvelope packages out the door in the last week is quiet except for a small squad trying to get a final load of parcels out for Christmas Day delivery. 
 RedEnvelope Gifts Online, a showcase for upscale gifts, has gone on to the next selling opportunity, the millennium celebration. The marketing staff is kicking off an expensive Valentine's Day campaign that will feature an un-Net-like paper catalog; the merchandisers are looking ahead to Mother's Day and Father's Day -- and the business staff is revising the 2000 budget for Billings, who knows that the $31 million in venture capital raised in the last six months will take the company only into the summer. RedEnvelope will face a choice: get new investment or go public.
That the company has come this far is kind of amazing. Fashioned from a two-year-old firm called 911Gifts, which catered to anniversary forgetters and other crisis shoppers, RedEnvelope successfully remade itself in less than six months into a top-of-the-line Web retailer. RedEnvelope's sales for its 60-day dash to Christmas easily outstripped everything the company had made in the previous two years.
Of course, the company shelled out about $4 in marketing for every dollar it racked up in gross sales. Still, millions of dollars in merchandise moved: 750 electric full-body-massage mats; 620 Zen tranquillity fountains; 1,400 Japanese body-and-soul bath kits; 1,600 boxes of pistachios and caramels (10 ounces of each for $40); 1,600 amber heart necklaces; 600 antique thermometers; and 1,100 chocolate body-paint kits.
RedEnvelope was one among the hundreds of online retailers that raked in a total of $9 billion during the last two months of 1999. The lesson these companies offer is not so much that there is money to be made online (yet to be proved), but that there are firmly established methods and protocols to get a company running in no time. Web sellers can buy software and services that the first generation of Web entrepreneurs were forced to build themselves. On the operations side, however, a different truth is emerging. Online businesses are increasingly turning to the techniques of old-fashioned merchandising, like high-end service, that were supposed to be left behind in the information age. Success still lies in creating a memorable experience for the customer. E-commerce, it seems, may just be commerce with an extra "e."
RedEnvelope's origins go back to Berkeley. two 1992 graduates of the University of California's Haas School of Business, Scott Galloway and Ian Chaplin, opened a consultancy in San Francisco called Prophet Brand Strategy. After advising companies like Levi Strauss and the Gap about online commerce, they wanted to get into the business themselves.
"We decided that being a consultant was like being a sex therapist who couldn't get a date," Galloway says. "We tried to identify areas in which there were big opportunities. One area we identified was pet products, so we decided we wanted to create the Williams-Sonoma of the pet category." The result was an online store called Aardvark (recently sold to In the Company of Dogs).
The next category they targeted was gifts. The company they founded, 911Gifts, had a weak spot, Galloway concedes: although the service attracted gift givers, recipients simply "didn't love the brand," with its connotations of wailing ambulances. By early 1999, the company was treading water. The site did about $1 million in business in 1998 and had decent demand during holidays. But with two merchants and four customer-service representatives, it was managing to move only 1,000 packages a day, tops. To grow, 911Gifts needed big venture financing.
It also, in Galloway's view, needed to create its own line of products, one that would attract a loyal band of consumers. He called one of his investors, Pat Connolly, a Williams-Sonoma executive vice president. "I said, 'Give me the names of the top six merchandisers in the United States,' "Galloway recalls. "He said: 'Call Hilary. She's the top merchandiser in the country."'
Hilary Billings had worked for Connolly at Williams-Sonoma, joining the kitchen and home furnishings retailer in 1991 and developing its Pottery Barn catalog business. She left in 1996 to work for W Hotels, a new upscale chain. By early 1999, though, she was contemplating a move to online retail and had fixed on gifts.
When Billings looked at 911Gifts before returning Galloway's call, she didn't like the name and wasn't impressed by what she saw. "They were very ordinary products. They weren't well photographed. The site wasn't well designed. It just wasn't inspiring. But what was really great was they allowed you to navigate for any gift by recipient, by occasion, by department -- it was the beginning of an idea." Connolly encouraged her to talk to Galloway. In May she became director of merchandising.
Four months pregnant (and with two young sons), Billings spent her first day on the job putting together a slide show for venture capitalists. On her second day, she began making the rounds of Silicon Valley. Six weeks later, Billings was 911Gifts' C.E.O. Soon the company had the core of a new management team and financing -- $21 million from Sequoia Capital and $10 million from Weston Presidio in exchange for a 30 to 40 percent stake in RedEnvelope.
The company also had a new mission. Instead of selling itself as a center for emergency gifts, RedEnvelope would aim for upscale elegance, an attempt to repeat what Billings accomplished at Pottery Barn. Further, the company would try to broaden the definition of gift-giving opportunities. "Most online retailers are inherently self-purchase," Billings says. They "repurpose themselves just before Christmas as gift companies. There's a big difference between that and being a company that thinks only about gifts."
In contrast to the commodity products that have dominated online commerce -- books, movies, music -- the force driving RedEnvelope and other specialty retailers is margin. The products it sells typically carry markups of 50 percent and higher, a potential offset for lavish spending on customer service, which, in Billings's mind, is unavoidable. "You have to own your customer experience" -- and that comes with a price.
The chief challenge for start-ups is not money -- there's plenty of venture capital to go around right now. The tough thing is to spend it well -- and to make the right decisions. For Billings and Galloway, that started with ditching the name 911Gifts. The staff turned over several possibilities, including "dafina.com." Billings, who grew up in Tanzania while her father worked for USAID, liked that one. "I knew that in Swahili, 'dafina' means an unexpected gift," she says. Before long, however, the suggestion was dropped as "a little too esoteric."
After a brainstorming session in August, Billings and her team, which now included a former Williams-Sonoma vice president, Tom Bazzone, as chief operating officer, settled on an idea from Kristine Dang, 32, the director of merchandising. Dang, whose family left Saigon for the United States the day before North Vietnamese troops entered the city in 1975, told her colleagues about an Asian custom of marking special occasions by giving cash or a message enclosed in a red envelope.
The name had more than a romantic story going for it -- it also suggested a salable method of presenting the gifts: part of the customer experience would be a red gift box with a hand-tied bow.
Of course, RedEnvelope had to come up with gifts to match the name. Somehow, the drugstore back massagers sold by 911Gifts weren't much improved by a nice ribbon. And so Billings went to work upgrading the product line. "What I asked the merchants to do was go through and make sure that their products reflected a high-quality, upscale point of view," Billings says. Their demographic was similar to the one Billings knew from Pottery Barn: high income ($85,000 per year), well-educated professionals, who, surprisingly, were split evenly by sex. Not surprisingly, the focus was on people who already had a history of buying online.
With that target in mind, the company conducted an exercise for the buyers. "We talked about the customer in a very intimate way," Bazzone recalls. "What kind of clothes they wore, what kind of car they drove. We put up a poster with columns labeled 'him' and 'her' and we'd put Post-it notes under each with products we thought they'd want to buy."
911Gifts had been selling about 450 separate products -- SKU's (stock-keeping units) in retail jargon. After a review, about 200 were dropped and another 300 or so were added. RedEnvelope also introduced its first wave of exclusive merchandise: a series of gift baskets and what might be called lifestyle kits.
The product line is built around what Billings and Dang freely say are "guesses" about what's hot -- what appeals at the moment to their upscale target buyer. Last Father's Day, for instance, when the company was still trudging along as 911Gifts, Dang had a hunch about a gift basket for fishing fanatics. "Gift-giving should provoke emotions -- the more experience you can evoke with a gift, the better the gift will be. Fly-fishing is my passion." What came out of that was a fly-fishing basket filled with 12 hand-cut fish-shaped cookies that retailed for $48. It was 911's No. 1 seller for the holiday, and the emotional gift messages buyers submitted showed Dang she had connected with them. "What that allowed me to see was what was hot and why they were buying it."
More people might have bought Dang's gift baskets if 911gifts had had enough cash to build a market identity. But for most of its life, it limped along on seed financing that allowed next to nothing for advertising. RedEnvelope was different. It had cash. Unknown and heading into a season in which established and fledgling e-commerce firms were dumping millions into holiday ad blitzes, the company made a clear decision to devote a third of its money to advertising in order to put its name on the map.
The company considered a TV campaign, which could have been produced more quickly than outdoor and print ads. But the expense was prohibitive, and other media were thought to be more effective in the long run. And so Leagas Delaney, an agency that had worked for high-profile Net firms like Beyond.com and CNET, created a series of print ads for the holiday season. One ad featured a handsome couple in gift-giving ecstasy; running down an envelope flap on the right side were the words "RedEnvelope Gifts Online." The ads appeared on buses, bus shelters, billboards and airport kiosks and in newspapers and magazines that targeted RedEnvelope's demographic. (The company advertised in The New York Times.) RedEnvelope supplemented the campaign with routine plays from the Web commerce manual: e-mail to a list of 125,000 former 911Gifts customers and site visitors who had signed up for sale alerts and Web banner ads.
A crucial piece of RedEnvelope's Christmas strategy was based on partnerships with online hubs (America Online, the Microsoft Network), Web portals (Yahoo, Excite, Go.com and Lycos) and a select group of more narrowly focused sites -- women's sites like iVillage.com and Women.com and occasion-oriented sites like those devoted to weddings and newborns. The company devoted $2 million to these alliances -- paid for through either a flat fee or one based on sales -- for a simple reason: "To be where people are shopping online means being on the portals," says Peter Baltaxe, RedEnvelope's senior vice president for business development.
"When things were fast and loose on the Net, your knowledge of the economics, of the subtleties, if you knew who to talk to, could make a big difference," Baltaxe adds. "That's changed with AOL. They've become a deal machine. To a certain extent they've had to because now they have 300 e-commerce partners." Not that they're complaining. An e-commerce relationship with AOL starts at seven figures, a price that merchants swallow hard and pay because being exposed to even a small fraction of the service's 22 million subscribers could be a boon.
The arrangement with Web portals is different. Merchants don't have to pay nearly as much to get into them -- RedEnvelope pays Yahoo five figures for a three-month slot -- but Baltaxe says they have to battle to build a relationship with the customers there. "What the portals try to do is figure out 'how do we add value to shopping,"' Baltaxe says. One way they do that is by aggregation, bunching stores at one spot and by encouraging customers to shop merchandise rather than merchants.
In October, ads were ready to roll out, business partnerships were in place and hiring was well under way, hastened along by the lure of stock options for all permanent employees. In the San Francisco office, the staff of buyers had grown to 13 from 2, part of an overall increase to 60 from 15 by the end of the year. The acquisition of staff -- following a pattern common to Web start-ups -- was facilitated by assiduous use of headhunters for the top jobs and Web job boards like the San Francisco-based Craig's List for staff slots. New software was running everything -- from tracking orders and customer-care calls to managing inventory. And supplies had arrived: red envelopes and cream-colored gift cards, glossy cardboard gift boxes and matching red wrapping paper, miles of ivory-colored polyester ribbon, bales of periwinkle blue tissue. On Oct. 25, the RedEnvelope name was formally announced and its site went live. First day sales: 110 orders, a little more than $5,000.
RedEnvelope owns its inventory, merchandising, marketing, systems management and customer service. What it doesn't own, despite its best efforts, is fulfillment: physical handling of products and order filling. Lack of time and money meant that Billings and Bazzone weren't able to do what Jeff Bezos did for Amazon.com over the past two years, which was to plow cash into building a network of warehouses. Instead, the company had to find a partner to provide a fulfillment operation -- a warehouse and everything that goes with it, including the workers expected to produce scads of smartly wrapped gifts for Christmas.
911Gifts had farmed out a portion of its order-filling to ComAlliance, a fulfillment firm in Wilmington, Ohio, about 50 miles northeast of Cincinnati. And so when Bazzone was looking for someone to help tackle the Christmas season, he went to Ohio. Conveniently, a big tenant at the ComAlliance facility was vacating its space. Bazzone grabbed it, 32,000 square feet with a one-year lease in the low six figures. With ComAlliance, he designed a workspace -- wrapping tables, conveyors, inventory racks -- that he hoped could handle a holiday siege.
The company, in the midst of changing its name to 3PF.com (for third-party fulfillment), had other allures. In e-commerce terms (read: less than two years) it had experience in providing services to online retailers that couldn't afford or didn't want to be saddled with the job of handling inventory and shipping it. More important, the ComAlliance warehouse lies at the edge of an Airborne Express runway. Consequently, overnight merchandise that leaves the warehouse by 2 a.m. can be in the air by 4:30 and to its destination by noon. The setup allowed RedEnvelope to make a promise that was at the core of its brand-building efforts: Christmas Eve delivery of gifts ordered by midnight Eastern Standard Time on the 23rd.
By early December, sales were doubling every week. Bazzone had been deployed to the warehouse to inspect every package before it went out. In San Diego, two dozen agents were handling phone calls from customers. In San Francisco, Billings convened RedEnvelope's managers for a meeting to focus on which products should be displayed on the home page in the stretch before Christmas.
The offerings had to be balanced in several ways. The page had to include something upscale, a luxury item with gross sales potential. And something for kids. And something relatively inexpensive, because the site didn't want to scare anyone away. And merchandise that was not in short supply. And products that would appeal to men and women.
"Dec. 15," Dang said. "We'll have spa in a box" -- a gift basket in the relaxation category that sells for $190. Women's stuff. "And Vivitar binoculars" -- something for men, also pricey -- and the holiday celebrations basket -- a $75 collection of edible treats." A brief silence hung before Billings said, "There's nothing for kids here." Dang swapped the binoculars for a chess set.
One way a Web site differs from a paper catalog is that it gives a store the ability to track what's selling and then to reformulate the mix of featured merchandise at will. Dang had a planned lineup, but she also had continuous feedback from customers about what highlighted items they were responding to. So the following week when the big wave of buying broke over the site, she was checking sales every hour, and she was ruthless about replacing featured products that weren't bringing in dollars fast enough.
At one point she noticed that a line of wines was not selling as briskly as expected. "It had moved only six units in an hour," she said. "I got it out of there and replaced it with the Zen fountain," which sold reliably at a rate of one every five minutes.
As RedEnvelope shut Christmas down and got set for Valentine's Day, Billings told her staff they had created "an incredible story." But what did the company accomplish beyond riding out a blizzard of orders and slamming millions of dollars of merchandise through the nation's delivery network? A crude report card shows that the season was more exhilarating than perfect.
On the plus side, RedEnvelope demonstrated that once it drove people to its site, they bought something. Billings says 5.8 percent of those who visited RedEnvelope online made purchases. That compares with an industry conversion rate of about 2 percent. The company's Web ads also worked. According to Nielsen NetRatings, an online traffic analysis service, in one week in December, 17.4 percent of those who saw RedEnvelope's animated banner clicked on it; the typical click-through rate on Web banners hovers around 2 percent.
Most important, the company did what it promised customers it would do. Though botched deliveries were not unheard-of, Bazzone says RedEnvelope filled 98 percent of its orders accurately and shipped 99 percent of its packages on time. By early January, only 2 percent of recipients wanted to return gifts (in contrast to an 8 percent average for the online industry).
The minus side is not so clear-cut. The transition from 911Gifts to
RedEnvelope was slow and, Billings concedes, baffling to those outside the company. "We spent the better part of October and November confusing the hell out of our 911 customers," she says.
The performance of RedEnvelope's online partnerships was also mixed. The heavy expenditure to get into AOL's commerce area and make RedEnvelope a keyword for subscribers brought steady but unspectacular sales. On the other hand, a $15,000 investment to set up a presence on Yahoo was a boon, bringing in 600 orders on its best days.
More important than the report card is the e-commerce evolution that RedEnvelope symbolizes. Kristine Dang recalls that when she started with 911Gifts in early 1998, the presence of a product buyer at an e-commerce firm was a novelty. "A lot of companies started with no merchants, just a lot of really smart engineers or people with M.B.A.'s in marketing."
That has changed. Merchandisers like Billings and Bazzone and the old retailing values they live by -- above all else, to your own customer be true -- are ascendant. To see the change, you need look no further than Valentine's Day, for which RedEnvelope is planning to blur the border between electronic and traditional retail by distributing a catalog and encouraging phone and fax orders. Though the company has no immediate plans to make a profit, it is planning, for next Christmas, to open a real store.

HEADLINE: The Way We Live Now: 1-23-00;
Fauxhemian Rhapsody

BYLINE: By Rob Walker; Rob Walker is a journalist living in New Orleans.

 BODY:
Pastis, the Parisian-style bistro that recently opened in New York's meatpacking district, is a restaurant with an idea. The menu is unpretentious, "simple," the owner has explained, and "there will be no reservations." The airy, lived-in design suggests a neighborhood place you stroll to, order coffee, grab a newspaper from the rack up front and kill a few hours thinking about the tragedy of Rimbaud.
Of course, if you should try to eat at Pastis you'll see that all of this is ridiculous. The matre d' looks like a model; those mirrors aren't old, they've been "distressed"; and actually the owner made his explanations in Vanity Fair. So after an hour wait (off-peak, that is), you'll be seated next to an earnest-looking 20-something in a tattered dress who maybe could pass for a struggling artist, except that's really a $400 house frock from Mayle she's wearing, and she's not reaching for her sketchpad but for her Nokia 8800. Look around the room: yet another place that's packed with fauxhemians. 
 Being bohemian -- or counterculture, or alternative or whatever you want to call it -- used to be all about dichotomy: you chose one life at the expense of another. Opt out of corporate life to run a literary magazine, and you had to live in a fifth-floor walkup, shop in thrift stores, drive an old VW bug and eat at hole-in-the-wall cafes. On the other hand, you got to cling to your unsullied ideals and aesthetic sense. For many, the bohemian life was just a youthful phase. You could have your freedom for so long, then you had to go work for the Man. Now, of course, it's difficult to find an actual bohemian, yet boho trappings that vaguely suggest counterculture taste are everywhere, because the fauxhemian idea is that you don't have to choose anymore. You can be mainstream and alternative, a grown-up and a hipster, all at the same time.
Conspicuous consumption no longer cancels out the idealistic self-image. The revamped Volkswagen Beetle -- which is all about flashy design, not economic practicality like the ancestor it's calculated to remind you of -- is a good example, and so is a Classic Parisian Flea-Market Club Chair from Mitchell Gold as advertised in fine shelter magazines. Miramax, an "indie" film company whose marketing department sprays an intellectual mist onto its usually middlebrow product, is a fauxhemian juggernaut. Janeane Garofalo, who stars opposite Uma Thurman or Sylvester Stallone part of the time and rolls her eyes about mainstream Hollywood the rest of the time, is our fauxhemian It Girl. And Apple Computer's C.E.O., Steve Jobs, a centimillionaire in bluejeans and a black mock turtleneck, embodies the look and feel of fauxhemian chic.
La vie fauxh<heart>me is a peculiar artifact of the bust-to-boom 1990's. The decade started on a slackerish note, as a generation of Americans was informed it would probably be the first not to match its parents' income. Since the Man was laying everybody off, why not grow a goatee, chase those dreams and forget about growing up and making money? Of course, the intervening years played out differently. Real money has found its way to younger and younger people, crashing directly into the postundergrad secondhand-shop lifestyle.
What's more, a lot of that money has gone to people who never bothered to pay their dues by groveling before 80's-style Master of the Universe bosses. The cultural equivalent of dropping out to write poetry became dropping out to write Linux code -- the open-source, anticapitalist computer-operating system -- though plenty of people are making real money even off that.
A result is that corporate America has not only stopped trying to homogenize its new recruits, it is also practically begging college dropouts with nose rings to explain what the hell is going on out there. And gradually that old dichotomy has fallen away. What if you could just, you know, telecommute for the Man? Or maybe do a little consulting gig, only this one time? Or let's say the Man wants to put a million dollars of seed capital behind some side project you've been working on in your dorm -- or help your nascent literary Webzine go public.
Still, as this generation unlearned its expectations of failure, it never unlearned its love of bohemianism; it just reconfigured bohemianism to accommodate a grown-up income. It's one of the few traits it shares with its parents' generation: a widespread reluctance to grow up all the way. Whatever his or her age, the fauxhemian is not one of those stick-in-the-mud, conventional, middle-class grown-ups.
So it's critical at least to pretend to keep any middle-class definition of success at arm's length: it's O.K. to like the theory of a Parisian bistro or the practice of a boutique eatery like Pastis; eating at a strip-mall chain called Pastis Too!, however, would be unacceptable.
And obviously when you have enough people thinking this way -- when most people think they are more unconventional than most other people -- then being unconventional doesn't have much meaning anymore. So it is that Urban Outfitters, to take one example, was penalized by the market recently because it stocked a spate of "overly mainstream merchandise," as The Wall Street Journal put it. And while financially successful people flatter themselves by dressing up as bohemians, a working-class store like Sears seeks to boost itself not by offering up images of a well-appointed family home, but by changing its slogan to "The Good Life," as though it were some exclusive realm of luxury.
Which brings us back to Pastis and its "simple" democracy. In practice, as it turns out, reservations are accepted -- just not at peak hours. The restaurant has already played host to a number of parties for members of the media elite, and nobody expected them to hang around the bar waiting for a table for 40 to open up.
But that's the point, isn't it? Exclusivity and elegance aren't cool, but exclusivity dressed up in the artfully tattered guise of the downscale and democratic / that's the coolest thing of all.

From "American Moderns: Bohemian New York and the Creation of a New Century," by Christine Stansell, to be published in April by Metropolitan Books.

HEADLINE: East Hampton Plan: Leave the Beach Alone

BYLINE: By JOHN RATHER

 BODY:
PLOTTING a measured retreat from further development of its shorelines, the Town of East Hampton is considering severe restrictions on seawalls and other shoreline erosion control structures that it says imperil public beaches, dunes and bluffs.
The proposal, which would become the major erosion control component of the town's Local Waterfront Revitalization Program, cites global warming, rising sea level and storm damage as reasons why development in coastal areas should be barred from pressing too near the water. 
 But in an underpinning that has broad support among environmentalists and many coastal experts, it also finds that individual erosion control efforts by property owners as well as larger, publicly financed projects can disrupt the natural drift of sand along the shores, obliterate public beaches and strip the shoreline of its natural ability to rebuild itself.
The proposal is the culmination of 10 years of study of coastal erosion in the town, where beaches, shoreline development and wealthy second-home owners are essential to the local economy.
If it is enacted, the new town law would be among the most far-reaching responses to coastal erosion undertaken by any of the Island's 13 towns, and a possible model for other municipalities on Long Island and beyond. The Village of Quogue, which is in the Town of Southampton, has also restricted shoreline hardening. Some states, including North Carolina, have banned seawalls.
While the East Hampton erosion plan would allow property owners to maintain beach armoring in most areas where it already exists -- predominantly on the northern or bay side of the town -- it would prohibit its spread along the town's ocean shores and on bay shores that currently have little or no armoring.
The new coastal erosion regime would also shift authority for issuing permits for repairing or building armoring from the state to the town, which would be guided by its own erosion plan. The plan would create four zones ranging from an oceanfront zone where hardening would be strictly forbidden to a bayside zone where owners would be allowed to maintain existing shore armoring.
In a concession some regard as critical, property owners whose houses or land were in imminent peril of being swept away unless they erected or repaired sea walls or other protections would be able to apply for variances.
Some supporters of the plan said the loophole made the plan viable by assuring that it would not result in a taking of private land without compensation, a red flag for judges who might hear challenges to the plan. Robert S. DeLuca, president of the Group for the South Fork in Bridgehampton, said the taking issue could not arise as long as owners had recourse to variances.
"Simply not getting exactly what you want is unlikely to be construed as a taking of your land," he said. "What's important is that this proposal fundamentally changes the approach to coastal management from coastal fortification to coastal retreat. It tells property owners it's best and easiest to move development back from the shoreline rather than to fortify."
But critics said variances would only be available after owners had suffered possibly irreversible erosion damage. They said the proposal would lead to a rout for owners who built where the town had allowed them to.
"This purports to be a shoreline preservation law when in fact it is a shoreline destruction law," said Aram V. Terchunian, a coastal geologist often employed by property owners and the president of First Coastal Corporation, an environmental consulting firm in Westhampton Beach.
"The bluffs would be consumed, the dunes would be consumed, and the variance part undoes the whole law," Mr. Terchunian said. "They say in an extreme situation where you have placed your house as far inland as possible and erosion continues, only at that point would they let you put up a seawall. That's pretty extreme. Your house has to be about to fall in."
Mr. Terchunian said the proposal erred in concentrating on coastal structures parallel to the shore. "Every responsible coastal geologist will tell you the primary causes of erosion in East Hampton are the inlets, and they are shore-perpendicular," he said.
He said that sand trapped by the inlets, when dredged, was frequently not returned to the beaches but instead placed in upland areas, depriving the shoreline of the sand. "Proper sand management is what is needed," he said. "Instead, the town is gong to place a tremendous burden on hundreds of property owners."
Gerard Stoddard, a spokesman for coastal property owners and the president of the Fire Island Association, said he saw limits in local initiatives like East Hampton's. "What is needed," he said, "is a long-term coastal policy on a system-wide basis that provides the sand and the beaches needed to provide this protection."
But even the future of the East Hampton measure is unclear. Richard E. Whalen, a deputy town attorney, said it was difficult to predict when the town board would vote on the measure, which would amend local zoning. "I don't know where this law is going to go," he said. "I'm not sure we'll see it any time in the near future."
Part of the uncertainty followed the defeat in November of the incumbent town supervisor, Catherine Lester, a Democrat who supported the proposal. The town's newly elected Republican supervisor, Jay Schneiderman, has agreed with the premise of the proposal and has said that shoreline protection will be a goal of his administration. But he said the needs of shorefront homeowners and businesses must also be considered.
Another uncertainty involves the town's decision not to do an environmental impact statement on the possible effects of the proposal, which courts could construe as an omission.
Other problems could occur if the Town of Southampton, which is currently compiling an environmental study of its ocean shores, concludes that the East Hampton plan could have impacts on Southampton. The littoral drift, or prevailing movement of sand, is from east to west on ocean beaches on Long Island.
Since the colonial era, East Hampton has opened coastal areas and resources to all town residents. Most beaches are owned by the town trustees under colonial patents.
A narrative accompanying the proposal said that coastal development in the past "often failed to take into account potential damage from flooding, erosion, and coastal storms."
"Following major storms, homeowners recognizing their precarious predicament built so-called erosion protection structures to protect their property," it said. "However, groins, bulkheads and other hard structures have had detrimental effects on adjoining beaches or neighboring property and have often aggravated the erosion problems that they were designed to prevent."
Their legacy, the narrative said, was "a disappearance of sandy beaches in many locations, a significant loss for a town whose way of life and resort economy depend on public access to unspoiled beaches."
Larry Penny, the East Hampton Town Director of Natural Resources, said that erosion problems were growing worse in many areas of town. "Erosion is speeding up," he said. "We are not Holland, but it it's hard to know what to do. Obviously when you put in hardened structures in one spot, the spot next door takes a beating. So the next person puts up a structure and then you have a domino effect."
"On the other hand," he said, "sometimes it's impractical for people to move their houses back or bring in sand and pile it in front. So it is a conundrum."
Mr. Penny said that town surveys using aerial photographs and maps showed ocean shore recession from Montauk Point to the Village of Montauk averaged two feet a year. He said Gardiners Island, the largest privately owned island on the East Coast, appeared to be shrinking by up to 2.5 feet a year.
Mr. Penny said a generally accepted figure for sea level rise over the past 100 years was six to eight inches. An international debate among scientists and governments continues over whether global warming is occurring and will accelerate sea-level rise.
Jay Tanski, a coastal geologist for the New York Sea Grant Program, said it was difficult to take the long-term effects of rising sea level into account when making coastal erosion policies.
"Sea level has been rising and it appears it will maintain that trend or even increase because of global warming," Mr. Tanski said. But to say that therefore no steps should be taken to combat coastal erosion would be "like saying we should not go to doctors because we are all going to die sometime," he said.
Mr. Tanski said he opposed an outright ban on any approach to coastal erosion control. "It's not the best way because you eliminate approaches you might want to use in certain circumstances," he said. "What you want to do is look on a site-by-site, case-by-case basis and then make your best decision on the best approach."

HEADLINE: A Charter School Sets Its Course

BYLINE: By LINDA SASLOW

DATELINE: CENTRAL ISLIP

 BODY:
JUST like the biblical Nehemiah, who left a secure position to do the job of rebuilding the walls of Jerusalem, our job is to rebuild the minds of our young people," said Theresa Sanders, president of the Urban League of Long Island. "We wanted to make sure the name of our school reflected the job."
If its proposal wins state approval next week, the Urban League-sponsored Nehemiah School will be on its way to becoming one of two Long Island examples of the charter school, an educational innovation sweeping the country. 
 Charter schools are intended to compete with regular public schools for students and the tax dollars spent to educate them. Supporters of the concept say the competition is healthy and results in better schools.
But if it is up to community leaders, educators and many residents of Central Islip and Brentwood -- the two districts from which the Nehemiah charter school would be expected to draw most of its students -- there will be no charter school in their community.
At a public hearing convened this month by opponents of the charter school, more than 1,500 people -- a huge turnout for a civic forum -- crowded into the auditorium at Central Islip High School to express concerns that the charter school would drain money from local school districts, cause tax increases and reduce racial diversity, all for a program that might not improve student performance.
"My issue is not with charter schools as a concept," said the Central Islip superintendent of schools, Howard Koenig. "But the New York State charter law is fatally flawed in the way it funds charter schools. It hurts, not helps, the community in which it opens."
It's not as if the performance of the Central Islip and Brentwood schools were impeccable. Statewide school report cards released this month showed that in Central Islip only 66 percent of the students passed the English Regents exam, which is required to graduate from high school. In Brentwood, the percentage of passing students was 87. The statewide average was 93 percent.
But opponents of the charter school argue that the public schools' poor performance should dictate an increase of investment in them, not a cutback.
"If the Urban League wants to start a school, let them do it with their own funds," said John Rosado, father of two high school students in Central Islip and the first vice president of Adelante, a Hispanic civic group. "We should be working together, not competing, to improve the education in this community and to help our kids."
Since charter schools are officially public schools, they receive public education aid. For every student it enrolls, a charter school receives the equivalent of one per-student expenditure from the public school district in which the student resides.
Proponents of charter schools say that when money follows the students, there should be no additional financial burden for school districts and no impact on property taxes.
But opponents of the Nehemiah Charter School argue that this argument ignores economies of scale. Dr. Koenig calculated that, assuming that about half of the 230-student initial enrollment at Nehemiah comes from the Central Islip school district, the district will have to give $1,427,500 to the charter school in the next year.
"By its fifth year, with a projected enrollment of 1,267 students, we will lose more than 600 students and about $8,394,700," he said. "Home districts are also responsible for paying for expenses that include transportation, textbooks, computer hardware and software and library materials. We estimate that our taxpayers will have to come up with an additional $140 per household next year, and by year five, they will have to pay an extra $830, in addition to what they already pay to support the public school district.
"Either we'll have to come up with resources to replace the money that goes to the charter school, or we'll have to cut programs for our kids," he said. "We may have to eliminate extra labs for remediation, or cut our high school alternative school, or our elementary programs for students who did not perform well on standardized tests. Who knows how deep we'll have to go?"
Les Black, the school superintendent in Brentwood, estimated that the charter school will cost his district $1 million next year..
"By losing students, we won't save any money," he said, "because those leaving will be distributed among our 10 elementary schools, and in the final analysis, we won't be able to save even one teaching position."
Such concerns seem to have done little to slow the rapid rise of charter schools nationwide. According to the National Education Association, the number of charter schools has gone from zero to about 1,800 in eight years. The Washington-based Center for Education Reform says 350,000 students will be enrolled in charter schools this year. The Department of Education says 70 percent of charter schools have waiting lists.Since the first charter school opened in 1992, only about 3 percent of all charter schools have closed.
In 1998, New York became the 34th state (of a current 37) to provide for the establishment of publicly financed, tuition-free schools that operate independently of existing school districts. In New York, charter schools are free from most educational mandates that control teaching methodologies in regular public schools, but are held accountable on the basis of student achievement tests, including the state Regents exams. Charter schools enroll any students who wish to attend, using a lottery to select students if the school is oversubscribed.
The schools have boards of trustees and are driven by a mission statement. Charter schools that fail to meet their stated goals can be closed.
Under the New York Charter Schools Act, the State University of New York can grant up to 50 charters. Eight applications were approved last year, and three schools that received charters opened in the fall. Five others, including one in Roosevelt, have received preliminary approval to open this September.
The Nehemiah Charter School is one of 17 applications remaining from a statewide total of 90 originally submitted to SUNY's Charter Schools Institute. Discounting an application from the Child Development Center of the Hamptons, which is considered a special case because it handles only developmentally disabled students, the Nehemiah effort is the only suburban application still under consideration.
By the end of January, the SUNY panel is required to announce which, if any, of the applications it recommends for approval. If it is among the winners, and barring a reversal by the state Board of Regents, the Nehemiah Charter School could open as soon as September with 230 students in kindergarten through second grade, and plans to expand over the next five years to more than 1,200 students in kindergarten through 12th grade.
For the Urban League of Long Island, applying to start a charter school was a natural progression of its goals to provide education, training and employment opportunities for the disadvantaged, Ms. Sanders said. The Urban League had proposed to buy land from New York Institute of Technology in Central Islip, but N.Y.I.T. recently declined the offer, she said, leaving the Urban League to look for other possible spaces in the Town of Islip.
If approved, the Nehemiah Charter School will be managed by Edison Schools, a private company based in New York City that now manages 79 schools across the country.
Betty Davis, vice president for Eastern development for Edison Schools, said that the company, which opened its first school in 1992, had developed a base curriculum that is modified to reflect the specific community.
The plans for the Nehemiah Charter School include a school year of 200 instructional days (compared with 180 for a regular public school) and an eight-hour school day (an hour or so longer than in a regular public school).
"Our goal is to have our students finish by the end of 10th grade what typically takes 12 years," Ms. Sanders said, "allowing two years, in 11th and 12th grades, for our kids to focus on college preparation."
Two of the charter school's main objectives, she said, are holding teachers accountable for student performance and enforcing parent involvement. Instead of traditional report cards, teachers, students and parents would sign "learning contracts" stipulating academic goals that must be met. "If a student does not meet those goals," Dr. Davis said, "the child, parent and teacher meet to re-evaluate the contract, decide whether those goals were realistic, and develop a new one that will guarantee the success of the student."
The Nehemiah school is also planning to provide a laptop computer for every student.
The program seems to have some appeal in the community. Although the Urban League has not yet been able formally to recruit for enrollment, Ms. Sanders said that 400 people have already expressed interest in the charter school.
Marian Jones, a Central Islip resident, said she wanted the best possible education for her 7-year-old son and would enroll him at Nehemiah if she got the chance.
"If I could afford to send him to private school, I would," Ms. Jones said. "But a charter school seems like a good alternative because it offers smaller classes and more individual instruction."
Marianne Temple, a Brentwood mother of two, is also interested in sending her two children, ages 4 and 6, to Nehemiah.
"I'm not happy with what I see in the public school district and I don't want my kids going to those schools," Ms. Temple said. "A charter school seems to offer more innovative teaching methods and allows every child to learn at his own pace."
But opponents of the school fear that the charter school is making promises it may be unable to keep.
"The Nehemiah Charter School doesn't yet exist," said Mr. Black, the Brentwood superintendent. "Therefore, parents are going to sign their children up based on what it promises them. But in many charter schools throughout the country, the track record of promises like smaller class size and creative teaching methods is questionable."
Robert Lupinskie, vice president of the Nassau-Suffolk School Boards Association, said that in studies, "To date, nothing has established any improvement of outcomes or student achievement from charter schools."
Amy Stuart Wells, a professor at University of California, has been conducting a national study on charter schools, with results expected to be released this fall, she said.
"Up to now there has been no consistent evidence of any gains in test scores at charter schools," Dr. Wells said. "In some individual schools, scores have gone up, while in other they have gone down. There is no definitive trend in either direction, and right now, it's too early to tell."
One of the concerns in Islip is the negative impact on diversity.
In Central Islip, the ethnic breakdown is now one-third African-American, one-third Hispanic and one-third white, said Richard Ianuzzi, president of the Central Islip Teachers Association.
"One of the strengths of this school district is diversity," he said. "Since the Urban League is the lead applicant for the charter school, it will draw most of the students from its parent network, and we will end up having a segregated black school in an integrated area."
While a charter school is supposed to reflect -- racially and economically -- the school district in which it is located, research is beginning to show that many charter schools are enrolling homogeneous student bodies, according to a report from the National Education Association. Several studies have pointed to more segregation of students in charter schools, based on race, socioeconomic status and academic achievement.
Both the Islip chapter of the N.A.A.C.P. and Adelante of Suffolk County, which serves the Hispanic community, oppose the charter school.
Yvonne Patterson Quirk, president of the Islip N.A.A.C.P., said: "Removing students from public schools tends to divide the community. Then if the school should fail, what happens to those kids? The public schools will have to scramble to reassign them to classrooms, and that will cause more confusion and dissension than anything else."
Mr. Rosado of Adelante agreed. "This is a high-tax, low-wealth community, in which many parents are working two jobs to pay their taxes and improve their community," he said. "By siphoning money away from public education, it will only hurt our programs, and ultimately, our kids."

HEADLINE: Clock Factory Site Is Under Debate

BYLINE: By ALBERTA EISEMAN

 BODY:
FOR more than a century, the New Haven Clock Company was one of the city's leading manufacturers, producing clocks and watches that were sold around the country and the world.
At the peak of its success, in the late 1930's, the business, founded by Chauncey Jerome and later run by his nephew Hiram Camp, occupied two city blocks on Hamilton Street, in the part of New Haven known as the New Township -- a historic industrial community near Wooster Square. More than 1,500 men and women worked in the massive red brick buildings, making 3 million timepieces a year and putting the name of New Haven on the mantles and into the pockets of countless people. 
 But after World War II -- years during which the company produced timing devices for military use -- the transition to civilian pursuits proved unsuccessful. Debt mounted, and by 1959 the New Haven Clock Company had gone out of business. Then, the construction of Interstate 91 led to the loss of more than a dozen of the plant's buildings. The surviving block of 14 buildings changed hands from one owner to another.
Today, the complex is nearly empty, a small motor repair shop and a strip club the only tenants, and its future is clouded by controversy over whether all of the remaining structures should be spared or some be razed to allow a neighboring business to expand.
Adjacent to the factory on the north side is Palmieri Food Products, a fourth generation New Haven business that wants to build a parking lot and a 30,000-square-foot addition to their spaghetti sauce factory -- a project that would require demolition of 10 of the 14 clock company buildings and part of the courtyard. The city has already been awarded federal grants and loans for the Palmieri development. Palmieri has said its project would save 25 jobs and create 20 more if allowed to go through with the project.
But opposition remains.
"The remaining block, neglected but basically sound, is one of the few surviving examples of a 19th century industrial square," said Edward M. Franquemont, executive director of the 350-member New Haven Preservation Trust. "It's complete with arched opening into an interior courtyard surrounded on all sides by imposing multi-story industrial buildings -- it's as close to a castle as we have in the United States."
Despite the obvious lack of maintenance, the broken windows and cracked paving, the spacious courtyard still evokes a faded grandeur. "Pat Palmieri is a very innovative businessman," said Mr. Franquemont. "They are a historic business in New Haven and a wonderful family, and any solution we reach is going to have to satisfy their needs, as well as the needs of the city to get the building back in service and pay its back taxes and of the owners, to protect their investment.
"But we think that there are many other options to demolition and the interest shown by outside developers supports our theory," he said, referring to a New York City developer who has been in frequent touch with him in recent weeks.
"The citizens of New Haven need to win here, too," Mr. Franquemont continued. "They need to maintain a connection with the industrial past that made New Haven what it is."
In the city's Office of Business Development, Helen Rosenberg, the business services officer who has coordinated the 3 1/2-year effort to make use of the property, expressed doubt about any alternative to razing at least some of the structures.
"These buildings have been an albatross around the owners' neck," she said, referring to the Yagovine family who have owned the property since 1980.
At first there were a number of tenants such as clothing dress manufacturers, a stained glass studio and a storage company, but gradually they moved out, leaving only two tenants in the vast empty space. When the opportunity to sell to Palmieri Food Products came along, the owners agreed to sacrificing 10 of the buildings, retaining for retail use the original 1843 structure, which was remodeled in the 1850's, and three adjoining ones erected during the second half of the 19th century.
"The city has taken steps to try to find redevelopers, the owners tried to market the complex, but there has been no interest shown," Ms. Rosenberg said. "If the New Haven Preservation Trust really could find a dynamic developer who would fix up the buildings, we would love to work with them. But there have to be time constraints, we can't just wait forever."
Mr. Palmieri said he simply needs more space for his business. "My business is growing," he said. "We ship our sauce from North Florida to Maine, up and down the East coast. What do I tell my customers? If I can't perform for them, they will find someone else. Right now, I have five tractor trailers in the parking lot that we use for storage because we don't have enough room."
"The city told me they want to help me," he continued, "and I'm sure they are trying to help. I'm being patient, but my new addition was supposed to be up last November. And as for the clock company building, even if it were fixed up it's still bad space: the ceilings are too low, there are too many columns and it's unsafe, a fire hazard. And I'm not against historic preservation."
A year and a half ago, Mr. Palmieri said he bought the old New Haven yacht club "and I've been renovating it ever since, preserving a piece of New Haven."
Late last fall, the city was awarded about $1.5 million in federal grants and loan guarantees to redevelop the clock company site: a $490,000 Brownfields Economic Development Initiative Grant from the Department of Housing and Urban Development, contingent on approval by H.U.D. of an application for a $1 million Section 108 loan guarantee for the project. That money would cover the cost of environmental remediation, demolition, site preparation and construction of the Palmieri addition.
The announcement of those grants was greeted with cheers by local officials while the city's preservation groups voiced their concerns at a hearing held by the Board of Aldermen as part of the process of approving receipt of the grant. The city has agreed to postpone consideration of acceptance of the grant funds.
"We didn't want to look as if we were pushing the preservation community," Ms. Rosenberg said referring to the time it needed to find a developer that would preserve the historical significance of the site.
The clock factory complex is listed in the state's Historic Architecture and Engineering Record and is eligible for the National Register of Historic Places, but does not have that designation yet. Because federal money would be used to raze the buildings, any demolition would have to be reviewed by the State Historic Preservation Office and by the president's Advisory Council in Washington. As matters now stand, the application for the loan is being reviewed by the regional HUD office in Hartford, and will be sent to the HUD office in Washington for its review within the next few weeks.
"Perhaps a compromise will be reached," Ms. Rosenberg said, "otherwise HUD will either decide to accept the project as proposed and grant the funds or not grant the funds."
Mr. Franquemont said he understands that a city continually reinvents itself. "We don't ask that there never be any demolition in a city," Mr. Franquemont said. "What we ask is that nothing be lost by accident, without a real sense of what we are losing for what we are gaining, and that we have a vigorous debate about this part of our heritage."

HEADLINE: 'CRADLE WILL ROCK';
A Different World

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Walter Goodman's characterization of the time in which "Cradle Will Rock" took place is mellower than the world I saw when I joined Orson Welles's Mercury Theater, which he and John Houseman formed immediately after the events covered in the film. 
 Mr. Goodman rather sniffily dismisses the film on the grounds that its point of view "suffers from its own class-struggle theme, as working stiffs and artists without money are set against millionaire bosses and their fascist consorts." It is always difficult to convey the context in which historical events took place; to give today's audience a sense of the mental baggage that the people of another time brought to those events. But to impeach the characters of Larry Foreman and Mr. Mister as cliches is to confess ignorance of the matrix in which the original play was produced.
Mr. Goodman forgets -- and apparently doesn't want us reminded -- that at that time there were places in America where more than a class struggle was going on: certainly the miners of "Bloody Harlan County" would have called it by a harsher name, as would those who survived the machine-gun fire on the Ford picket line, where 17 men were shot down for daring to ask that their union be recognized.
In that same New York City which Mr. Goodman seems to see with revisionary eyes, female pickets were sometimes herded together by mounted police in order to be clubbed more easily. Many of the people who made up our audiences at the Mercury Theater often came to us straight from such picket lines, and stayed after the curtain to buy ambulances for those fighting Franco in Spain. (Mr. Goodman rather loftily dismisses this kind of activity with "protesters of all sorts in a period when protest was a leisure-time industry.")
In order to set up his tribute to Hallie Flanagan (a tribute with which I wholeheartedly agree), Mr. Goodman has found it necessary to denigrate some of the very people hired by Mrs. Flanagan's Federal Theater, when he tells us that "its mandate was to give jobs to unemployed actors, stagehands and other theater folk. That meant that . . . some of those who got jobs were not of the first caliber." As the Mercury Theater's assistant casting director, I had to monitor the Broadway shows of the time, and I can assure Mr. Goodman that even on Broadway, not all of those who obtained jobs were "of the first caliber."
As a fellow writer, I should like to remind Mr. Goodman that many of today's characters, including possibly both of us, will appear to be "cartoons" to future generations. After all, just as the era of "Cradle Will Rock" was the one that spawned an official government category, titled Premature Anti-Fascist (translation: you were on the record as opposing Hitler before it was officially decreed politically correct), who can say which of today's Great Ones will be found to be "too cartoonish" to be believed by those who follow us?
 
KEVIN O'MORRISON
Edmonds, Wash.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: PERSPECTIVES;
Stepping Up Middle-Income Housing Construction

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER

 BODY:
THE middle-income housing production program that the city's Housing Development Corporation launched in 1998 has moved into a second phase of financing, with consequences visible in farflung corners of the city.
In the Baychester section of the Bronx, Rella Fogliano has started construction on the second phase of four contiguous four-story structures built as a rectangle around a 12,000-square-foot courtyard on two acres off Palmer Avenue, within sight of Co-op City. 
 In the Fresh Meadows section of Queens, the financing program has made it possible for David E. Marx to break ground for a 137-unit apartment house as the first stage of development on a vacant five-acre parcel off Parsons Boulevard at 72nd Avenue. It will be a neighbor to a rental building he completed in the 90's at 158-13 72nd Avenue.
And in the Clinton Hill section of Brooklyn, John Frezza has begun the reconstruction of the old Clermont armory on Clermont Avenue between Willoughby and Myrtle Avenues into 111 apartments. Residents will enter the building through an atrium whose roof is supported by three of the original arched trusses over what was once a drill floor 125 feet wide and 180 feet long.
These and other projects are part of the second round of the "New Housing Opportunities" program of the Housing Development Corporation, a state-chartered public benefit corporation that provides bond financing for multifamily housing. In September 1998 enough financing was provided to generate 12 projects with a total of 930 apartments.
The program combines bond financing with the added nudge of a "shallow" subsidy per apartment. The amount varies with the project and the location, but it has so far averaged $21,700 per apartment. The developments also gets the benefit of the city's 421a program, which provides property tax abatements for as long as 25 years.
With the new round the program is now at 1,830 apartments in 25 projects, for a total of $185.6 million in first-mortgage financing at interest rates about a percentage point below conventional rates. The subsidy that the Housing Development Corporation provides has totaled $39.7 million so far. The subsidy takes the form of a second mortgage, typically at 1 percent interest.
These are modest numbers in relation to the public investment in the production of middle-income housing in the past under the Mitchell-Lama program, which produced thousands of rental and co-op apartments across the state from the 1960's through the mid-1980's. But they are significant in showing a revival in the use of public funds to induce new multifamily rental housing for moderate-income people. The beneficiaries are typically households with annual incomes ranging from $30,000 to $70,000.
W E could not have started construction without this program because the rents we can get in Fresh Meadows aren't high enough to support a conventional loan," said Mr. Marx, the Queens developer. With conventional financing, he said, "I would need to get about $25 a square foot" -- about $1,800 a month for a 650-square-foot one-bedroom.
Under the New Housing Opportunities Program, builders may normally charge up to $850 a month for a studio apartment, $1,200 for a one-bedroom, $1,550 for a two-bedroom and $1,750 for a three-bedroom. Income limits for renters are established in a manner similar to the Mitchell-Lama program: Household earnings may be as high as seven times the annual rent in families of one or two, or eight times the annual rent for three or more family members. Most potential tenants earn well below the maximum limits.
As the program has progressed, H.D.C. officials say, building costs have increased, obliging the agency to raise the maximum subsidy per apartment allowable under the program. The maximum allowable subsidy per unit (normally taking the form of a very-low-interest loan) was $20,000 a unit when the program started; it now has been raised to $40,000 a unit. Officials said they doubted it would go any higher.
Russell A. Harding, president of the Housing Development Corporation, said that by increasing the allowable subsidy, the program had "adapted nicely" to a rise in interest rates and construction costs, which is what has allowed it to carry on.
Perhaps the most unusual of the housing designs that the program has generated so far is Ms. Fogliano's 135-unit full-block development in the north Bronx, on land bounded by Tillotson, Palmer and Given Avenues near Interstate 95. Apartments are entered from internal walkways on all four levels; there are two major entrances from the street, one of which takes vehicles headed for the 71-car underground garage.
"It's an unusual site," said Ms. Fogliano, who founded MacQuesten General Contracting, a construction company based in Mount Vernon, N.Y., two years ago. Her father, Sabino Fogliano, headed Sabin Construction Company for 35 years, phasing out the business in the 80's.
Mr. Fogliano assembled the Baychester site, and his daughter spent two years seeking a zoning variance to make development feasible. She succeeded in 1997. The form of the building was governed by the need to adhere to height restrictions required by the Board of Standards and Appeals.
Because of the design, apartments are unusually large, and they are floor-throughs since there are no public central halls in the development. The apartment flooring is also unusual, a concrete plank with a vinyl surface that has the appearance of grainy wood. DePasquale and Geremia Architects and Planners, of Mount Vernon, was the architect. About 50 of the apartments have been taken at rents of $775 a month for one-bedrooms, $1,000 to $1,050 for two-bedrooms and $1,245 to $1,325 for three-bedrooms, Ms. Fogliano said. Occupancy begins next month.
The Fresh Meadows project by Mr. Marx is the first phase of a three-building plan he has for five acres of vacant land between 72nd and 71st Avenues off Parsons Boulevard. He is acting as the developer of a seven-story 200-unit assisted-living building, as well as a 200-bed nursing home. His mother, Frances Marx, will be the licensed operator of the assisted-living facility. The operating partners of the nursing home are Simon Pelman, Benjamin Landa and Benjamin Philipson.
At the apartment house, half the apartments will be one-bedrooms, renting at about $1,000 a month, and the rest will be two-bedrooms renting for about $1,300 a month. There will also be 20,000 square feet of medical space. Occupancy is expected in the early spring of next year.
Many of the new projects are reconstructions of older nonresidential structures as housing. The rehabilitations are eligible for the city's J-51 tax abatement. Among the conversions that have been financed in the second round are Bronx buildings at 597 Grand Avenue, which will have 52 apartments; 167 Clermont Avenue, with 110 apartments, and 139 Emerson Place, 50 apartments.
The rental programs are handled by the owner, or the management company appointed by the owner. The Housing Development Corporation provides information on how to go about applying for an apartment. The phone number is (212) 227-5500.

HEADLINE: A Festival of Arts and Ideas Expands

BYLINE: By RICHARD WEIZEL

 BODY:
FIVE years ago when a group of cultural arts and economic leaders in New Haven decided they wanted to create an annual festival located around the city's 350-year-old green, skeptics advised them that it couldn't be done.
Some supporters said even if organizers managed to get it off the ground, people used to summers of roller coasters and cotton candy likely wouldn't come to a European-style event that combined education and social issues with fun and entertainment. But the International Festival of Arts and Ideas, inspired by the success of the Special Olympics World Games here in 1995, attracted 50,000 people over a four-day period when it opened in 1996. 
 By last summer the multifaceted celebration of the arts, education, science and global cultures had expanded to 16 days and drew more than 110,000 visitors who pumped $11.6 million into the local economy, according to an independent analysis by the Business School at Quinnipiac College.
Last week, festival organizers unveiled perhaps their most ambitious plan yet: to expand to three cities and become the first state-wide festival in the United States by adding Stamford and New London.
But, in their belief that the arts can help spur economic growth and revitalization, the three very different coastal communities along a 100-mile stretch of the Connecticut Turnpike, are now linked together by what state officials, city leaders and festival organizers believe will become one of the major cultural events in the Northeast.
In New Haven, this year's festival is scheduled to open June 16 and run through July 1. That site will include events such as a Singapore production of "Othello" by the Saigon Water Puppet Theater of Vietnam, classical and pop concerts and dance, and family-theme entertainment.
The festival will be held for five-day intervals in Stamford (June 20-24) and in New London (June 27-July 1). Some events will be in all three cities; others will be exclusive to a particular city.
"Expanding to three cities will allow us to build one of the great international festivals in the world, and Connecticut is among very few states in this country where we could do this," said the festival director, Paul Collard.
Mr. Collard said that being a small state allows easy access to the three cities. Stamford and New London are both about a 45-minute drive from New Haven, he said, which in his native Britain is about the time it takes to get from one side of London to the other. Mr. Collard is a former organizer of the London Film Festival.
Mr. Collard said that "by collaborating with Stamford and New London we will be able to deliver a richer program, attain a higher profile, and attract a much broader audience."
That audience, expected to be more than 200,000 this year, is likely to be drawn more heavily from New York, which is near Stamford, and from Rhode Island, not far from New London.
Mr. Collard, who moved from London three years ago with his wife and four children to head the Connecticut event, said that expanding the festival's audience-base beyond the state is crucial to its continuing growth. He said he envisions other cities like Bridgeport and Hartford taking part in the future.
Gov. John G. Rowland is pledging hundreds of thousands of dollars in state funding, with festival organizers hoping for about $1 million from the state. Last year the state allocated about $700,000 for the event on top of about $800,000 in corporate donations and $300,000 from ticket sales.
Mr. Collard said the overall festival budget, which was about $2.4 million last year, is expected to double this year and ticket sales are expected to bring in more than a half-million dollars. Gov. Rowland said he has been impressed by the economic contribution the festival has made to New Haven.
"It gives me great pleasure to see three of Connecticut's major cities collaborating on this initiative," Gov. Rowland said, "which in addition to bringing world-class entertainment to people within the state, will help establish Connecticut as one of the top arts destinations in the United States."
Arts, business and political leaders in Stamford said their city's expanding emphasis on the arts as a vehicle for economic growth and revitalization makes it a perfect community for partnership in the festival, which was initiated by the nonprofit Stamford Cultural Development Corporation.
Events will be held in about an eight-block area in the center of the city's arts community near the Rich Forum and the Stamford Center for the Arts and will include free outdoor jazz concerts and street theater, and will highlight the United States premiere of the one-man show, "Shakespeare's Villains," performed by the British actor Steven Berkoff. Hugo and Ines, a mime and puppet company that festival leaders say enthralled last year's audiences in New Haven, will also perform this year in Stamford and New London.
"The festival certainly fits in extremely well with our goal to make Stamford an overall arts destination and the entertainment and arts capital not only of Fairfield County, but of neighboring Westchester County in New York," said Stamford Mayor Dannel P. Malloy.
Christopher Bruhl, president and chief executive of the Southwestern Area Commerce and Industry Association of Connecticut, a business council that includes 600 members in Fairfield County, has the perspective that comes with having also headed the Westchester Arts Council from 1980-90. Mr. Bruhl said he has learned from heading both groups how important a role the arts can play in a region's economic renaissance.
He said that because Fairfield County is home to 28 Fortune 1,000 companies, making it the third-largest concentration of such firms in any county in the nation behind just New York and Chicago, more people are commuting into the region every day to jobs than departing.
That makes it imperative, Mr. Bruhl said, for the arts to continue growing and for there to be two distinct facets to that growth -- "the bread and butter of year-round attractions like the Maritime Aquarium in Norwalk, and intense high-profile events like this festival that generate tremendous interest and building up to a week or two of excitement."
"A dynamic and growing cultural community is no longer a luxury for cities like Stamford in a time when many people can choose to live just about anywhere they want," continued Mr. Bruhl.
In New London, which like Stamford is in the middle of a cultural arts renaissance, the festival events will be held on the green overlooking Long Island Sound on the campus of Connecticut College. While there will be a wide range of outdoor concerts and shows, the main focus at the college will be on dance, which has played a prominent role in the history of the 89-year-old private, liberal arts school.
Three years ago the college launched a $10 million, multifaceted arts initiative that included the 1998 International Dance Festival that featured more than 100 dancers and national and international dance companies. Bringing major dance performances back to the campus as part of the international festival provides "an exciting opportunity to draw on our own history of dance and the arts," said Claire Gaudiani, the college president who is also president of the New London Development Corporation that is making the arts a major part of its economic revitalization plan for the city and region.
"We have long viewed the arts as an opportunity for social integration and to encourage people to share cultural diversity, and now this festival will bring together three diverse cities as well," Ms. Gaudiani said.
