HEADLINE: THEATER;
Check Out the Classics. They're Hot Again

BYLINE: By ALVIN KLEIN

 BODY:
BEFORE the season's end, Connecticut's high-profile regional theaters will be dreaming up new ways to check out the classics, mostly to lure and to enlighten new audiences.
Why the classics? Easy. The classics are hot, that's why. 
 Staging a voodoo "Macbeth" or a rock "Hamlet" is old news. So is free-for-all, free-form and free-of-charge Shakespeare. But even so-called Shakespeare festivals are neither all about Shakespeare nor particularly festive. And when a starry spectacle like "Titus," now at multiplexes everywhere, serves as a gory antidote to last year's even starrier "Midsummer Night's Dream," it is clear that the centuries-divide between classical and modern is blurry. How prophetic that the Julie Taymor masks and puppets (then unknown) were stealing the show -- the show was "The Tempest," produced by Theater for New Audiences -- at the state's Stratford festival, during its last gasps well over a decade ago.
It may be too soon to get a conceptual statement from Yale Repertory's artistic director, Stan Wojewodski Jr., about the time line or the demented state of "Richard III" in the Yale School of Drama's staging to run March l8 through April 8. For now, Mr. Wojewodski, trying to define his "strategy for this production," is talking about a "charming villain" who loses control when he gains the crown. It is then that melodrama becomes tragedy, or something like that.
The drama school's third-year students will be scaling what the director calls "a mountain of a play": Yale Repertory includes a production that is cast with drama students in its otherwise professional repertory every season. This is it. Previous School of Drama productions of classics have been staged by such directors as Everett Quinton (Farquhar's "Beaux Stratagem") and Mark Rucker ("Twelfth Night").
And Mark Brokaw, who has been acclaimed for his diverse Off Broadway triumphs ("As Bees in Honey Drown," "The Dying Gaul" and, in particular, "How I Learned to Drive" and "This Is Our Youth"), has replaced Roger Rees as director of "The Comedy of Errors" at Hartford Stage (April 6-May 7.)
How Mr. Brokaw will nail the unnailable farce is anybody's guess. What pleases Michael Wilson, Hartford Stage's artistic director, is that this is the theater's first Shakespeare since Mark Lamos's memorable "Cymbeline" in l997, that it is Hartford Stage's first "Comedy of Errors," though it is the theater's 19th Shakespeare production but, most of all, that "Shakespeare is hip again." "Young people are reveling in his language," Mr. Wilson said.
Since Mr. Brokaw's productions, even of the classics ("Tartuffe" at the New York Shakespeare Festival in Central Park last summer) tend to be "clear, minimalist and straightforward," in Mr. Wilson's words, it is hardly likely that he will go as ungrammatical and off-the-wall as the current Off Broadway "add-rap-tation" that shamelessly calls itself "Bomb-itty of Errors." (A press release describes it as a "fusion of hip-hop" that is meant to give "the bard a brand new beat.") An old timer depends on Mr. Brokaw's vision, version or variation upon a wild, crazy, slapstick, very silly and anything but straightforward play, to illuminate the difference between hip and hip-hop.
On a more sober side, Doug Hughes, Long Wharf's artistic director, has opted to close in Ibsen's already closed-in "Hedda Gabler," dispatching her to the confines of the theater's Stage II. That should be a clear and immediate form of assisted suicide for a classically unsatisfiable heroine of the doomed.
But Long Wharf's main stage is to make the dour Bertolt Brecht, once referred to as the master of "inchoate despair," come alive with a relevantly new difference that couldn't hit closer to home. The show is titled "The Good Person of New Haven," Not Szechwan, though the person is a woman, a prostitute, actually. The advertisements call it "a celebration of our home town."
Brecht, a celebration? Didn't one scholar once declare that the radical political playwright was "barely intelligible, particularly to safe and sane Americans?" Anyway, Long Wharf's Brechtian party dates are April 26 to June 4.
"I'm a modernizing-the-classics kind of guy," said Bill Rauch, artistic director of the Los Angeles-based Cornerstone Theater Company, the brainchildren of modern-day Brecht transported wherever. Consider the company's "Caucasian Chalk Circle" in Watts.
"Doug allowed us to take it slow and build it carefully," said Mr. Rauch of the evolution of Brecht in New Haven. Building "bridges between and within diverse communities" defines the mission of Cornerstone, which is expected to develop the New Brunswick Community Bridge Project in New Jersey with the George Street Playhouse (with which Long Wharf collaborated on two productions this season).
"We work to help build an inclusive theater of the United States," Mr. Rauch said, in a telephone conversation from the Great Lakes Theater Festival in Cleveland, where he was directing a new adaptation of Ibsen's "Wild Duck."
The term "community specific" is used to describe all Cornerstone productions, which have ranged from a Wild West "Hamlet" in North Dakota in 1986, the troupe's first year, to a timbertown take on Brecht: "The Good Person of Long Creek," in Oregon, two years later.
Mr. Hughes saw Shakespeare's "Winter's Tale," Cornerstone style; when he arrived at Long Wharf, he called Mr. Rauch "to build something together," the Cornerstone director recalled.
At the New Haven Arts and Ideas Festival last summer, it all began. Alison Carey, who comes from Storrs, founded Cornerstone with Mr. Rauch and wrote the adaptation of Brecht, several drafts' worth, each evolving from workshops "in neighborhood sites," Mr. Rauch said. In July, three staged readings were held at Long Wharf's Stage II.
But how does the play connect to the city? That was the abiding question and Ms. Carey and collaborators are providing the answer. "In New Haven, we have the most economic extremes," Mr. Rauch had observed. "Extreme wealth. Extreme poverty. And Alison is aware that New Haven, more than anywhere we've worked, has passion about the civic life of the city. In other communities, people just shrug. Here, everyone has an opinion and shares the faith that things can get better."
When auditions were held last spring, 292 people -- not actors, mind you, but one could say good people of New Haven -- showed up, "and that broke the record after 14 years of our lives."
The Long Wharf cast consists of 10 Equity actors -- and 27 from the community (20 of whom appear in a performance). The age range is 7 to 80-plus, Mr. Rauch said, and then there are 5 musicians.
"The spirit may be sentimental -- let's all get along and all that," Mr. Rauch went on. "But grittier realities of race and economics are keeping people apart. The play is a sometimes cynical fable. Brecht is a consummate storyteller. Who is so intensely theatrical today? Maybe Tony Kushner. Here, angels come down to the New Haven Green, looking for a good person. But Brecht was dealing with the intersection of money and morality."
As much to the point, Mr. Rauch added: "And a company like ours needs to work with big casts and huge canvases. What would we do with a three-character play? Most theaters can only afford small; we want big -- bigger."
And therein lives the future of epic theater.

HEADLINE: COPING;
Where Denial Meets Racial Reality

BYLINE: By FELICIA R. LEE

 BODY:
IT doesn't show itself so much in raw exercises of power or abuse, like job discrimination or name-calling, although that can be part of the package. Rather, say gay men who are black or Latino, homophobia in their neighborhoods trades most pervasively in myth, denial and fear.
People are talking these days with renewed urgency about this kind of gay bias, especially as it relates to AIDS. That's because of the recent devastating news from the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention: for the first time since AIDS was discovered about 20 years ago, it was diagnosed in more black and Hispanic gay men than in white gay men. 
 Stigma about homosexuality seems to play a major role in the spread of the disease, said Dr. Helene Gayle, who heads the H.I.V. program at the Centers for Disease Control. One of its surveys found that four times as many black men as white men who had sex with men did not identify themselves as gay or bisexual.
The latest news puts the racial reality of AIDS in stark terms, some gay black and Latino men are saying. It strengthens the position of advocates who say new strategies, more money and more attention is needed to battle AIDS in their communities, where many people still equate gay with white men. Too often there is silence around issues of sexuality, or the belief in myths like the ability of women to turn gay men straight.
"Part of the reason you're seeing this spread of H.I.V. is the denial in our community," said City Councilman Phil Reed, 49, who represents parts of East Harlem, the Upper West Side and the South Bronx. He's black and H.I.V.-positive. "There is so much you have to face in the day-to-day life of racism," he says, that for many people AIDS and homophobia don't seem like the most pressing concerns.
Keith Cylar, a co-executive director of Housing Works, an AIDS social service agency, has a story that speaks to the place where myth and painful social realities meet. He has had the experience often enough that he can laugh about it, although there is some pain beneath the mirth. A woman expresses interest and he tells her he is gay. She then tells Mr. Cylar that he just hasn't met the right woman.
"I've had black women tell me I'm too good-looking to be gay," Mr. Cylar, 41, said. He said he detected bitterness or even desperation in the attitude of some women, because so many are competing for a pool of black men whose eligibility has been diluted by prison, drugs or unemployment.
"We don't necessarily want to accept people who are athletic or highly intelligent in leadership roles who are gay," Mr. Cylar said. "The leadership in the black community is conservative because they have had to work that much harder to get where they are."
Andres Duque, 31, who lives with his partner in Jackson Heights, Queens, said that from his perspective as an openly gay Latino man, part of the problem is that the word "gay" has not been incorporated into the lexicon of many Latinos, even if they know a man has sex with men. Many associate AIDS, he said, with white gay men, who were in the forefront of the most visible battles for education and research to prevent the spread of H.I.V.
"Not too many Spanish-language shows feature gays," said Mr. Duque, who works for the Latino Commission on AIDS. "The soap operas tend to show gays in stereotypical ways."
How you label people and chose your affiliations remain paramount issues among Latinos, said Julio Dicent. He is 32, Puerto Rican and Dominican and lives in Washington Heights with his partner, Angel Ortiz. Both work as AIDS educators and advocates for people with the disease.
"The way Latino gay men deal with sexuality is very different from white men," Mr. Dicent said. "Where's my primary affiliation? Am I a gay man who happens to be Latin or African-American? I've been criticized a lot about a focus around AIDS by gay Latin men. They say we have a lot more pressing needs: the dropout rate in some Latin communities is 80 percent; incarceration, drug use, police brutality."
"Can you imagine being in the country illegally, not acculturated, not speaking the language, and being H.I.V.-positive?" Mr. Dicent said. "Even privileged gay white men are worried about issues of confidentiality and stigma. What happens when you don't feel entitled to certain services?"
Mr. Dicent said that terms like "out" and "in the closet" are rarely used by black or Latino gays. "We don't have the economic access to leave our communities," he said. "We start dating in our communities, though, and it's unsaid."
On the upside, Mr. Reed wonders if the new numbers, however alarming they are, suggest that more gay black and Latino men are learning their H.I.V. status. Perhaps, he says, this will usher in a new era of education and visibility. That is his hope, at least, and the hope of the many who bear witness to this tragedy.

HEADLINE: IN PERSON;
A Tale and the Man Who Had to Tell It

BYLINE: By CHARLES STRUM

 BODY:
KEITH SCRIBNER had just finished a master's degree in creative writing at the University of Montana in Missoula eight years ago and was living about 25 miles out of town in a log cabin at the end of a dirt road. It was there, as he listened to a radio broadcast, that faraway reality intruded: the saga of Arthur and Irene Seale and the man they had kidnapped, an Exxon official in New Jersey named Sidney J. Reso.
For Mr. Scribner, now 38 and a lecturer in the writing program at Stanford University in Palo Alto, Calif., the intrusion became a writer's obsession. The result is his first published novel, "The GoodLife" (Riverhead Books), which came out this month, to favorable reviews. 
 It is a thoughtful caper-thriller of a crime gone wrong. But the outcome has been known for years. The real mystery is one of human understanding: what was it like to live through hell, who would create such a hell and why?
The initial mystery, of the Seales' motivation and of Mr. Reso's fate, persisted through May and June of 1992. The captive's wife, Patricia, issued televised pleas for his return. The authorities said they had no leads. Then suddenly it was over.
After what the United States attorney called "a merry chase through the night," the F.B.I. seized the Seales in Hackettstown. They turned out to be ordinary people -- not the eco-terrorists they had claimed to be. Both were 45 years old and jobless, the parents of two teen-agers. They had crushing debt and few prospects except the corrupted optimism -- or desperation -- that had led them to demand $18.5 million for Mr. Reso's safe return. The ransom was never paid. Mr. Reso was found dead.
The Seales, for a brief time, had become two of the most wanted criminals in the country. Now, through Mr. Scribner's imagination, they have been reincarnated as Theo and Colleen Wolkoviak, two feckless strivers, not so different from many others, perhaps. Except that they committed an unspeakable crime in a very public way.
"How could these people, who seemed to me so basically normal, middle-class American people do this? To feel this was their only choice." Mr. Scribner said. "When I first heard about it I thought, 'How interesting. It's a corporate executive who's been kidnapped' -- a lot like what goes on in, I don't know, Brazil. It didn't happen so much in this country. Right away I thought of the social implications. Does this indicate something about class unrest?"
It was more complicated than that, of course, and in time it would become, in Mr. Scribner's hands, a story with the trappings of classic tragedy: how the Wolkoviaks's tortured dreams of the good life -- their tragic flaw -- had destroyed the lives of another couple.
Mr. Scribner stayed close to the basic plot of the real case, but compressed time, zeroing in on the implications of both couples' pursuit of the American dream, which the Wolkoviaks believed their captive had achieved.
At the time of his disappearance, Sidney Reso, 57, was president of Exxon International, directing the oil company's operations outside North America. He and his wife lived in an expensive housing development in Morris Township. In the book, the couple are named Stona and Nunny Brown.
Arthur Seale had been a police officer in Hillside, where his father had once served as deputy chief. He possessed a departmental record clouded by misconduct and left the force in 1977 with a disability pension after being hit by another officer's car. Later, he became a security officer at Exxon -- in Florham Park, where Mr. Reso worked -- earning about $60,000 a year. He and his wife had a son in college and a daughter in high school. But the Seales, both blond and fit, wanted more. They left New Jersey in 1986, living far beyond their means in the resort towns of Vail, Colo., and Hilton Head, S.C. Their ski-and-sail businesses failed. They returned to New Jersey to live with Mr. Seale's retired parents in Hunterdon County.
The Seales abducted Mr. Reso from his driveway in Morris Township on an ordinary Wednesday morning, April 29, as he was about to start the short drive to work. They shoved him into a crudely built coffin-like box in the back of a rented van and drove to a storage locker, where they held him for five days. Meanwhile, they tried to project the image of a normal home life while negotiating for ransom with Exxon.
Mr. Reso, who had suffered a gunshot wound in one arm during the abduction, remained bound and gagged with duct tape, lying in his own waste in 100-degree heat in the storage locker. During periodic visits, Mrs. Seale would dress the wound and give him water. When he died, five days after his abduction, the Seales buried his body in the Pine Barrens in South Jersey.
When the Seales were finally arrested, still angling for their windfall, Mr. Reso had been dead for seven weeks.
For Mr. Scribner, the tale proved hypnotic, but would not work as a standard narrative. "I wanted to be able to explore the dreams and justifications and passions and ambitions of these people from inside their own heads," Mr. Scribner said. "The only way to do that was five points of view. There was no way, with a single narrator."
Mr. Scribner's account takes place over just three days, during which time he lets the reader see and hear the Browns, the Wolkoviaks and Theo's father, Malcolm, who loves his son but is locked in a lifelong battle to understand the younger man's impetuousness, his penchant for failure.
Mr. Scribner writes cinematically, with scenes alternating among the hapless but curiously sympathetic Wolkoviaks, Nunny Brown's hopeless vigil and Stona Brown's cruel captivity.
"Another thing, as it evolved, was the pronounced suffering of Reso in that box," Mr. Scribner said. "Is it possible to imagine that? It was a chance for me to reveal that particular man's experience of being locked in this box and dying and also what his response would be, which mainly is this guilt about his past and his wish for redemption. You know we talk about character changing, or just revealing character. It gave me an opportunity to do both."
The Seales's transgressions are obvious, those of Stona Brown less so, initially. And here, Mr. Scribner, who, like Stona Brown, grew up Roman Catholic, decided to make Mr. Brown's final days a dual struggle -- the struggle to stay alive and the struggle to atone for both corporate sin and those of a more personal nature.
At first, Mr. Scribner had envisioned the Reso case as part of a longer novel; ultimately it became the novel itself. Although to anyone who followed the case closely, it appears that Mr. Scribner could be simply fleshing out details, his account came solely from his imagination.
"The original title for this was 'American Ethic'," Mr. Scribner said. "It was a line right out of Arthur Seale's mouth." The full quote, made in a jailhouse interview with Barbara Walters, was: "My whole life I've been a hard-working, moral, decent individual. And we really epitomized the American ethic."
But "The GoodLife" won out, being as it is a bit of wordplay on the Wolkoviaks's aspirations. In the universe Mr. Scribner has constructed, Colleen dreams of becoming the enormously well-compensated captain of a highly motivated sales squad for GoodLife products, a home-sales program.
The idea, he said, came from a man he met in Turkey, where he lived for a time.
"This Turkish guy that I knew was trying to get me to sell Amway," Mr. Scribner said. "And as soon as he made his presentation to me -- he was just so loaded with this stuff that I'd been making up about Colleen, all of the aphorisms, that business self-help speak -- this just fell into my lap."
Mr. Scribner, who graduated from Vassar College in 1984, grew up in Troy, N.Y. He majored in economics, intent on a business career -- "it was the '80's, I was ready to jump on." But a writing course in his senior year turned his head.
He went to Japan to teach English, came back and worked as a carpenter and as a teacher, but continued to write. He even taught, briefly, in New Jersey, at Saddle River Day School. At Stanford, he met his wife, a poet, Jennifer Richter. They have a 5-month-old son, Luke.
So far, he said, his plan to skip the business world has worked out.
"O.K.," Mr. Scribner said he told himself. "I'm going to give this 10 years. And basically, that's how long it took."
 
The New York Times Dec. 1, 1992
 MORRISTON, N.J., Nov. 30 -- In appearances before Federal and state judges today, Arthur D. Seale was sentenced to life in prison for the kidnapping, extortion and murder of Sidney J. Reso, a senior Exxon official.
 "What you have done is thoroughly evil," said Judge Garret E. Brown Jr. of United States District Court in Trenton. "Your actions were not for any cause. They were not rash or impulsive. They were cold-blooded and calculated. To the extent you seek mercy you will be given the same you gave your innocent victim -- none."
 Then, totaling the seven conspiracy and extortion counts in the indictment, Judge Brown imposed the maximum sentence, requested by the United States Attorney, Michael Chertoff: 95 years with no parole and a fine of $1.75 million.
 "You will spend the rest of your life in custody," Judge Brown told Mr. Seale, who pleaded guilty to both sets of charges in September, after his wife, Irene, confessed to their roles and led investigators to Mr. Reso's body. Referring in part to the Seales' treatment of Mr. Reso, Judge Brown added, "You will be fed, medical treatment will be provided, but you will not be bound, gagged, shot or placed in a coffin."
 Moments before Judge Brown passed sentence, Mr. Reso's son, Christopher, was permitted to address the court. Speaking of the family's anguish, he said: "When Arthur and Irene Seale were arrested and the answers finally came, they seemed more cruel and perverted than even our tormented dreams could conjure.
 "After all," he said, "these are people with their own family. Couldn't they realize the depth of the wound that this would inflict on our family? Shouldn't they have known in the core of their beings that what they contemplated was a violation of all that family and decency stood for?"
 
"The Goodlife"
 "Isn't it unique to think we could make loads of money for the reason being that we're better people?" In Vail, in their living room, Colleen had arrayed before Theo the products she'd bought at the GoodLife informational meeting that afternoon at the Sheraton in Denver. "But this is the Goodlife philosophy."
 Theo examined the hefty bottle of car wash, the glossy picture on the label and the bright red cap, weighing it in his hand. "What makes you think this stuff's any good?"
 "They're excellent products. Everyone knows that. But the point being most of your money comes from the plan, from the system you set up below you, and not from your own sales." On the coffee table -- made from a huge old blacksmith's bellows they'd found antiquing down toward Durango -- she's placed the various products: the car wash and wax, complexion soap made from honey (a quarter the price of department stores), dish detergent, metal polish, toothpaste, mouthwash, and the classic GoodLife product, LiquidGold, the all-purpose cleanser that had made millions.
 "Twenty wide and twenty deep is my initial plan. I comes out to four hundred people below me at a maximum take of twenty-one percent. Plus bonuses. Think about it. I've started the calculations, it's very complex. Let's just say, for a ballpark figure, easily six digits within twelve months."
 Theo smirked, looking to the side the way he did. Ready to suck the wind out of her sails. To shoot her down. But she wouldn't let him, not this time. She understood that her new income might emasculate him. The freedom it would afford her. The entree into certain social circles. She would be patient with her husband. "GoodLife is about understanding your goals," she said. "then setting out to fulfill them. It's about helping you get in touch with your own desires, what's inside you. Otherwise, you spend your life striving for some dream that might not even be your own. Do I want to achieve Distinction Status in six months, or do I want to take more time building a wider front line so I reach Laurel a little farther down the road, but I roll through Prestige and Majesty Status like a tank? I honestly don't know. So part of the system is that through my upline and my sponsor, I'll get to know myself better as part of the business-building process. In that sense, it's very gestalt."

HEADLINE: MIDSTREAM;
Baby BoomersDiscover Guilt-Edged Luxury

BYLINE: By JAMES SCHEMBARI; James Schembari is an editor at The Times. His column on the prime earning, spending and striving years appears the fourth Sunday of each month. E-mail: jimschem@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
WE baby boomers have been criticized for most of our lives. Our parents weren't thrilled with our hairstyles, our social protests or our music. When we told our parents we were going to backpack around Europe instead of getting a job right out of college, they thought they had raised a generation of bums.
But now that we have helped lead the nation to the greatest economic expansion in history, we are being criticized again, this time for enjoying it. Our houses are too gaudy, our cars too big, and we think too much of ourselves instead of the greater good. We often respond to the criticism with defensiveness and guilt. A recent article, "The Narcissistic 90's," in The Trend Journal, a newsletter, says concern over social issues has been replaced by the need to succeed. 
"Signs of a narcissistic society are seen on city streets and manicured suburban roads filled with gas guzzling, carbon-monoxide spewing four-wheel-drive vehicles," it says. "Trophy houses and starter mansions consume land and resources beyond realistic housing needs." The article does not swipe at baby boomers directly, but its target is clear.
Although the premise is hard to deny, it is not the whole story. Financial advisers say some baby boomers are extremely uncomfortable with their wealth and go out of their way not to let the money show. "One client said he pays in taxes three times what his father made in salary," said Kyra H. Morris, president of Morris Financial Concepts, a financial planning firm in Charleston, S.C. "Some are uncomfortable that they are making so much more than their parents or the people they run around with."
Ms. Morris told of a wealthy client who asked her advice about the wisdom of buying a fancy sports car. He thought it was too much money. "I told him, "If I can afford a $35,000 sports car, you can afford a $35,000 sports car," she said.
The man, who requested that his name not be used, said he was worried about his image. "Yeah, I really went back and forth on that," he said. "I still do not drive the car to work. It sends out the wrong message that I'm displaying too much wealth and flaunting my success."
To some boomers, the issue is not just about flaunting, but about the social responsibility that wealth brings. Considering that this generation once took to the streets over social issues, the pull some feel to put their money at the service of their idealism is not surprising.
Kenneth Bauer, 36, owner of Bauer International, a furniture importer and designer in Charleston, said his wealth had allowed him to donate to various groups. He and his wife, Dee Ann, also helped teach a village in Ghana how to make decorative brass hardware for his furniture. The village is now one of his suppliers.
"The trophy house and the 80-foot yacht are not what kicks me in the tail," he said. "My main focus is, I have an obligation to give back to the community because of my success."
James E. Carroll, 45, a partner at Carroll Realty in Isle of Palms, S.C., is active in several charities and said he tried not to flaunt his wealth.
"I'm almost embarrassed about the amount of money I make," he said. "I have an old Mercedes to drive clients around in and a Dodge Caravan. I wanted to buy a sailboat, but I can't see spending that kind of money. My whole goal is to save the money and not throw it around."
The newly wealthy are the most likely to feel conflicting urges. David B. Yeske of Yeske & Company, a financial planning firm in San Francisco, said people who come into wealth suddenly often lack a well-developed idea of what the money means in their lives. Is the money a goal in itself or a tool for social good?
"Some people are incapable of acting responsibly because they haven't developed the framework that relates them to their money in some meaningful way," he said.
But those who are least comfortable with their wealth are the most likely to ponder broader goals. "Those who are thinking more clearly and deeply what this money means," he said, "are usually very conflicted."
They are also the most likely to feel responsibility to the community. "That resonates with them," Mr. Yeske said. "Not those who just go out and act like it's Christmas and buy a new boat or a Mercedes."

SECTION: Section 14NJ; Page 8; Column 1; New Jersey Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1063 words

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY & CO.;
On Sale: Used Nuclear Plant (Safety Debate Included)

BYLINE: By STEVE STRUNSKY

 BODY:
WHETHER buying a used car or a used nuclear power plant, the idea is pretty much the same: pay a fraction of the original cost and accept that the merchandise has a shorter lifespan.
"I would guess so," said Dick Breitweiser, who reconditions used cars for Christopher Auto Sales in Lacey Township, and lives about a mile from the Oyster Creek Nuclear Generating Station. "I would say 90 percent of the cars need something, brakes or lights, or the radio doesn't work." 
 There are differences, though. For one thing, a jalopy's excess emissions do not pose a threat of catastrophe. And hundreds of jobs and millions of dollars a year in profits and tax revenues never hinged on extending the life of a pre-owned automobile, even a Lexus.
Such are the issues surrounding the proposed sale of the Oyster Creek plant by GPU Energy of Morristown to a company formed to buy up used nuclear plants and squeeze profits out of them in the emerging energy market created by deregulation. The deal is being opposed by local and national groups that want the plant shut down and say the proposed buyer, AmerGen Energy, does not have the mony to run the aging plant safely.
In fact, GPU announced in April 1997 that it would close Oyster Creek in September 2000 if it could not sell the plant, which was built 30 years ago for $96 million. Then the deal was announced last March to sell the plant to AmerGen Energy for $10 million. AmerGen, which has an office in Wayne, is a joint venture of Peco Energy of Philadelphia and British Energy of Edenbourgh.
Oyster Creek, the second oldest nuclear plant in the country, opened on Dec. 23, 1969, a week after its twin, the Nine Mile Point plant in upstate New York. Oyster Creek is licensed to operate through 2009, although the owner can apply for an extension.
GPU, the parent company of Jersey Central Power and Light, is getting out of the power-generating business. It has already sold a reactor to AmerGen at its Three Mile Island plant in Pennsylvania; that sale involved the TMI I reactor, which was not destroyed, as TMI II was, in the nuclear accident in 1979.
As New Jersey and other states dismantle the traditional system of regulated monopolies, GPU is transforming itself essentially into an energy broker, buying electricity in bulk and reselling it.
"GPU, the entire company, is getting out of the electrical-generation business," said Suzanne D'Ambrosio, a spokeswoman. "We're real happy that there was an interest in continuing to operate the plant."
With the purchase, AmerGen would also inherit a $455 million trust, financed by rate payers, to pay for the eventual closing.
The sale of Oyster Creek is subject to approval by the federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission, the New Jersey Board of Public Utilities and the board's counterpart in New York State, where GPU also has customers, and by the Ocean County Utilities Authority.
The proposed buyer's financial health is among the criteria reviewed, and a Washington-based nonprofit group, the Nuclear Information Resource Service, filed a petition this month seeking a hearing on AmerGen's finances before the Nuclear Regulatory Commission's atomic safety and licensing board.
"We don't believe that they've demonstrated the financial qualifications to take on this dilapidated reactor," said Paul Gunter, speaking for the group.
Mr. Gunter questioned the commitment of AmerGen's parent companies to finance operation of the reactors. Pressure to maximize profit could force the company to take safety shortcuts, he said, noting that AmerGen is a limited liability corporation, so the parent companies can avoid financial liability in the event of a disaster.
Mr. Gunter also criticized an announcement by AmerGen last week that it intends to lay off 10 percent of the plant's employees. An aging plant is likely to require increased attention, not less, he said.
He and other opponents also expressed concerns over the plant's buildup of spent fuel rods, which are housed in an increasingly crowded containment pool.
Bob DiSantis, a spokesman for AmerGen, dismissed the concerns, saying the employees to be laid off are in the business departments, not operations. Rather, he said, safety can only improve. "For any nuclear plant, becoming part of a larger nuclear organization is a good thing," he said.
The company has ample resources to operate Oyster Creek, Mr. DiSantis said, noting that regulators had to review the same criteria before approving the company's purchase at Three Mile Island.
Neil Sheehan, a spokesman for the nuclear commission, said no decision has been made on a hearing. He said the companies have asked for a decision on the sale by March.
Among the sale's strongest supporters is Mayor John C. Parker of Lacey, who is also chairman of the county utilities authority. Mr. Parker said the plant has been good for Lacey ever since he helped attract it in the early 1960's, after wary officials in Point Pleasant rejected it.
More than 40 percent of the 700 employees live in Lacey, Mr. Parker said. And the township receives $11.4 million a year in taxes from the plant, more than half this year's $17.4 million budget. GPU also sponsors youth athletic teams and contributes in countless ways to the fabric of the community, he added.
"They've been a wonderful neighbor," said Mr. Parker, a road and bridge builder whose family first settled in the area in 1687. "Because of them we have good schools, low taxes and no crime, or hardly any."
Others are less enthusiastic.
Maria Szczech, a former mayor of neighboring Ocean Township and a proponent of shutting down the plant, said her community receives few of its benefits and all of its risks. "The financial benefit, in terms of taxes, is nil," she said.
Willie DeCamp Jr., a trustee of an Ocean County group known as Oyster Creek Nuclear Watch, which favors closing, said local opposition is muted by economic dependence on the plant. "In Lacey, no one wants to stick their head up because so many of their neighbors make their living off the plant," he said.
Mr. Breitweiser, the used car man, raised a universal concern about nuclear waste that transcends Lacey's borders.
"Day to day you don't think about it," he said. "It's only when the sirens go off, and when they're selling it. And all that radioactive stuff in there, where does that go?"

HEADLINE: COMMUNITIES;
Long-Sought Arena Seems Likely for Newark

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS

DATELINE: NEWARK

 BODY:
Despite the "Perils of Pauline"-like turns during the last year over a sports arena in Newark, most people involved in the negotiations now agree that the $375 million project has a palpable momentum that makes it more and more likely.
But what these people cannot agree on is what is needed to sustain that momentum and alchemically transform what will no doubt be a shiny new architectural bauble into an engine of urban revitalization. 
 For one thing, there is a debate about the placement of the arena in relation to the city's transportation hub at Pennsylvania Station, and what placement would be the best stimulus to development. In addition, there is close examination of the vagaries of office space trends in the New York region to determine if Newark can count on a growing need for space.
Moreover, these questions are distinct from the tantalizing speculation surrounding the deal-making that might merge the New Jersey Nets with the New Jersey Devils and give the proposed 18,500-seat arena two tenants and nearly 200 nights a year of activity that some say is necessary to be economically viable.
Then there is the political drama surrounding the issues of whether the state will help the private and locally financed sports center and what will become of the state-owned Continental Airlines Arena in the Meadowlands, where the teams now play.
The real concern, say real estate specialists and public officials, is whether the arena -- together with the Performing Arts Center, which has already buoyed hopes of revitalization -- can counter a four-decades-long flight of resources and touch off development and job opportunities that could restore Newark to a vibrant city.
"It is not a slam dunk that an arena in a city as small as Newark will make it a great urban center," said Larry Goldman, the president of the New Jersey Performing Arts Center, the two-year old concert hall and theater complex four blocks from the proposed arena site. "It has to be something that enhances the urban environment, and these are intelligent people who want to do the right thing."
There are those -- especially among the residents in the proposed 40-acre redevelopment area -- who remain skeptical about the joint proposal of Mayor Sharpe James and the YankeeNets, which owns the New Jersey Nets and New York Yankees and which would own and operate the arena.
As the plan was submitted this month to Newark's Central Planning Board for consideration, Luz M. Torres, who lives in a house within blocks of the site, said that in her nearly 30 years in the city she has heard too many renaissance dreams and "will believe it when she sees it."
But others -- who know the specifics of the plan and who have an even larger stake in terms of property -- disagree with her, and are working to make some changes in an idea whose time they think has come.
"I earnestly hope and believe it will happen," said Jerome Gottesman, the president of Edison Properties, the huge parking lot company that owns several parcels in the area that would be condemned, barring his company from developing them himself. "But the question is how it should happen."
The city planning board is scheduled to begin hearings on Feb. 17, and the approval process by the City Council and the state is likely to take up to a year.
As it stands, the proposal put forth by the city and the YankeeNets calls for a $270 million, privately financed arena adjacent to Penn Station and accessible by covered walkways to Path trains, New Jersey Transit commuter rail and bus lines, Amtrak and the nearly complete light rail line to Newark Airport. About $25 million in local funds would be spent to widen roads, provide parking for 3,000 cars and create retail and commercial spaces as well as a grand entrance to the raised arena at Mulberry and Market Streets, west of the station.
If the city and the YankeeNets could get an additional $75 million in state financing, said Alfred Faiella, the deputy mayor for housing and economic development, that would allow the city to widen more roads and prepare the infrastructure for office and retail development, build a 25,000-seat soccer stadium on land west of the arena and closer to the retail strip and erect additional garages. "But the key to any of this is putting the arena right next to the train station," Mr. Faiella.
Mr. Gottesman, for one, is opposed to such a plan, and has gone to court to stop it because much of the land that the city would want for the footprint of the arena is owned by his company. He contends that the site should be used for office, retail and restaurant development while the arena should be closer to downtown.
Proximity to transportation is more crucial for office development than for an arena, he says, and juxtaposition of the arena and train station would help create a corridor of development and thriving economic activity stretching to and spilling into the retail hub along Broad Street.
Mr. Gottesman insisted in interviews that it was not just anger over the possible loss of his land to condemnation and the loss of development rights for lucrative office space that had motivated him to mount a court challenge. He said that the city's original proposal, unveiled in December 1998, envisioned placing the arena where he now wanted it, and for similar reasons.
He questioned why the city abandoned its earlier plan, and speculated that it might have to do with the overlap in ownership of the Gateway Center office complex and the YankeeNets organization. Gale & Wentworth, a partner in the Gateway Center, the office space next to the train station, is also a partner in the YankeeNets organization. Without competition from new office construction so close to mass transit, Mr. Gottesman asserted, the Gateway Center's position would certainly be enhanced.
Officials of Gale & Wentworth would not comment on his speculation. But Mr. Goldman of the arts center -- who is an urban planner and is knowledgeable about the city's redevelopment plans -- dismissed suggestions that real estate profits for the partners was a crucial consideration.
He said that the people behind the plan included Raymond Chambers, a business executive, philanthropist and partner in the YankeeNets who has shown a singular devotion to rebuilding the city. Mr. Goldman also said that proximity to the station, along with sensitive planning, was important for the success of the arena as well as its effect on additional development.
Much of the debate pivots on how real and deep the need is for spillover office space from Manhattan.
Mary Ann Tighe, a partner in Insignia/ ESG, a commercial real estate company in Manhattan and New Jersey, said that as recently as eight months ago Newark remained a tough sell despite tightening of the office real estate market in New York City. But with the continued rise in rents, Ms. Tighe said, Newark is becoming more attractive though still "a pioneering choice."
Nonetheless, she said, any development that ran people "through umbilical cords" from the train station to the arena rather than out on the streets would be a mistake. She said that office sites closer to the train station -- which set the stage for restaurants, stores, ATM's and other points of interaction along the path to an arena -- would be preferable.
"Transportation is crucial to the arena, it is true, but placement of it right there by the station is devastating to other downtown development and circumscribes it," Ms. Tighe said. "The arena will become a big wall around which you can't see to the rest of downtown and around which no one will venture."
Donald Eisen, executive managing director of Cushman and Wakefield of New Jersey, disagreed in part, saying that the market for office space was being driven by broader forces than just the overflow from New York.
Given that, Mr. Eisen said, questions about where the arena was placed might not be as crucial as some might think. He said the ultimate test would be whether the arena, the nearby Performing Arts Center and any other commercial and retail development would touch off residential development.
As he talked about Newark one recent evening, Mr. Eisen looked out his office window in East Rutherford overlooking the empty parking lots surrounding a darkened Meadowlands with its Giants stadium, Continental Arena and racetrack. It was "a suburban tableau," he said, the antithesis of a vibrant city where energy is always flowing.
"I think they will find other uses for the Meadowlands," he said. "But it is definitely a healthy development to get the teams into Newark to help rebuild the central city again. And as long as it promotes street activity and street life it may not be crucial where exactly an arena is."

HEADLINE: GRASS-ROOTS BUSINESS;
Rising Upstarts Breathe New Life Into Battered Aerospace Industry

BYLINE: By JOEL KOTKIN; Joel Kotkin is a senior fellow at the Pepperdine Institute for Public Policy. His column on the Main Street economy appears the fourth Sunday of each month. E-mail: grassrts@nytimes.com

DATELINE: LONG BEACH, Calif.

 BODY:
WHEN Carl Chen arrived in Southern California from Taiwan with $300 in his pocket, he looked skyward for opportunity. The year was 1968, and the region around Los Angeles was the uncontested world center of the burgeoning aerospace industry.
Three decades later, the industry is a shadow of its former self, with many of the most important companies from those days merged, moved or shrunk beyond recognition. Yet Dr. Chen, and a small band of entrepreneurs like him, believe there remains a bright future here in developing new and innovative aircraft. 
 "You have to be sort of childish to think this, but I think there's still a big opportunity in this business," said Dr. Chen, whose company, Advanced Aerodynamics and Structures, is working on a new line of small propjets in a 200,000-square-foot plant in this city. "Everybody else goes to a dot-com, but we are stupid enough to think that you can still make money making something."
Advanced, which says it has a $220 million backlog of orders for 182 of its new Jetcruzer corporate aircraft, exemplifies a new breed of aerospace manufacturers, hardened by bitter experience, that has emerged from the devastating downturn in Southern California aerospace.
Since 1993, the industry, once dominated by military and space contractors, has shed nearly 20,000 jobs in the region, and many of the flagship companies have migrated away or been acquired by companies based elsewhere, including Lockheed, Douglas Aircraft, Convair, and Hughes Aircraft, where Dr. Chen, who has a Ph.D. in engineering from the California Institute of Technology, once worked as a leading researcher.
Aerospace companies have also reduced employment in other regions, but the hemorrhaging was particularly severe in Southern California, which once dominated the business, not only nationally but in the world. Since the early 1990's, the region lost roughly one-fifth of its aerospace jobs, while the average elsewhere was just 3 percent. Now, for the first time in decades, Southern California is no longer the largest region for aerospace; it has been eclipsed by Seattle, home of Boeing, which acquired McDonnell Douglas in 1997.
Barry Sedlik, manager of economic and business development at Southern California Edison, the region's biggest privately owned electric utility, traces this collapse to a host of factors, including a widespread perception that living and doing business in the region is very expensive, which helps explain why many corporate headquarters have shifted to other regions after mergers and acquisitions. "When these firms moved, there weren't the allegiances that used to be there," Mr. Sedlik said.
Mr. Sedlik also credits effective "pork barrel" maneuvering by legislators from Georgia, Texas and other states, steering contracts to their districts and away from California. He said government procurement rules that stressed factors like local wages and cost of living tended to drive work elsewhere while more nuanced economic advantages, like the presence of a large skilled work force and easy access to suppliers, tended to be overlooked.
This trend has had a particularly harsh impact on the region's 20,000-odd smaller subcontractors, who account for the bulk of aerospace employment in the area. Many of these dozen-employee, million-dollar-a-year shops, long the heart and soul of the local industry, are being left behind by the few remaining prime contractors, whose escalating technological requirements and ever tougher price and delivery demands put even more subcontracting work beyond the small shops' reach.
"The landscape has changed," said David Goodreau, president of Quantum Manufacturing, a Burbank-based aerospace machine shop whose roots in the field date to before World War II. "The bigger companies can buy the equipment to meet the cost requirements of the primes. They can do the work of 10 of my shops." Quantum's payroll has dwindled to five workers in the last few years from 17.
Under these circumstances, the best entrepreneurial opportunities now may lie not in doing specialty work for the giants, but instead in developing new technology, as Advanced is doing. Some companies, like tiny Dyna-Cam Industries, are attempting this on little more than sweat and optimism. For more than 10 years, Dyna-Cam has been working on a high-efficiency new engine that may find uses in boats, aircraft and other vehicles.
Limping along on slightly more than $1 million invested by the founder, a former real estate agent named Pat Wilks, or borrowed from investors and the Small Business Administration, Dyna-Cam says it has orders for 50 of its new engines but not enough capital to begin full-scale production. "I'm not sure what's going to happen," said Ms. Wilks, whose father and brother are engine designers. "If we don't get more investment, we'll be in trouble soon."
Capital does not seem to be much of a problem for Advanced Aerospace. Begun with a $20 million investment from a Taiwanese businessman, the company went public in December 1996, raising enough money to finish developing the Jetcruzer. The company has tapped deeply into the region's reservoir of skilled workers, employing engineers with experience on projects like Lockheed Martin's F-117 Nighthawk stealth fighter, the B-2 Spirit stealth bomber from Northrop Grumman and the McDonnell Douglas MD-ll jetliner. The Jetcruzer makes use of innovations like a graphite composite skin and a very fuel-efficient engine. Unlike many aircraft its size, the Jetcruzer can carry passengers from New York to Los Angeles with only one stop. Its six-seat cabin was developed by designers from BMW's Southern California design studio, and is intended to appeal to younger executives and entrepreneurs whose success in the Internet economy put them into the target market for a business jet with a $1.5 million price tag.
Advanced expects to finish testing the aircraft by spring, and then submit it to the Federal Aviation Administration for safety approval. If all goes well, the company will have the Jetcruzer in full production by the end of the year, expanding its payroll to 300 from 100 today.
Given the still prodigious number of unemployed or underemployed skilled aerospace workers in the region, Dr. Chen expects little trouble staffing his plant. He already has 2,000 job applications on file.
"We have seen a lot of ups and downs in this business, and a lot of good people let go," Dr. Chen said, "but that has worked out for us. Everyone thinks this industry is wrong, but we believe we have turned out to be in the right place at precisely the right time."

HEADLINE: IN BRIEF;
Unemployment Drops To 4.1% in December

BYLINE: AP

 BODY:
The state's unemployment rate dipped to 4.1 percent in December, capping a year in which the rate never topped 5 percent, the state Labor Department reported last week.
The December rate matched the 4.1 percent national unemployment rate, a goal Governor Whitman has set for the state. It also matched February for the lowest rate of 1999. Before that, New Jersey unemployment had not dipped to that level since July 1989. 
 "What's nice about it is we're not seeing radical shifts one way or another," said state Labor Commissioner Mel Gelade. "Unemployment has been rather steadily going down, and the job growth has been accelerating."
State employers also added 9,400 jobs to their payrolls in December, seasonally adjusted, making it the year's best month for job growth. That brought 1999's job creation total to 65,300, a strong figure but still below 1998, when 76,200 jobs were created.
The good economic news from the unemployment front came two days after a report released by the Association for Children of New Jersey and New Jersey Policy Perspective concluded that the past decade's boom times have largely been enjoyed by the richest 20 percent of New Jersey households.
That report, which used data by two Washington-based research organizations, said 80 percent of New Jersey residents made less money or saw no gains from the late 1980's to the late 1990's after salaries were adjusted for inflation.

HEADLINE: IN BRIEF;
Shopping Mall Planned for Newark

BYLINE: By KAREN DeMASTERS

 BODY:
Plans are underway to construct a K-Mart in downtown Newark, which would be the first department store to open in the city since the 1967 riots.
A shopping mall with K-Mart as the anchor would be built on an 11.7-acre tract on Springfield Avenue in the Central Ward. Construction could begin within six months for the discount department store, and for a restaurant. 
 The $14 million mall is expected to provide 350 full-time jobs, Mr. Codey said.
The project is being put together by New Community Corporation, formed in 1968 to help rebuild Newark, and Resurrection Urban Development Corporation, an arm of the Metropolitan Baptist Church. Prudential Insurance, which has invested heavily in the city, is expected to provide a loan for the project.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: THROGS NECK;
Longtime Dumping Ground Will Soon Hear 'Fore!'

BYLINE: By DAVID CRITCHELL

 BODY:
A long-brewing plan to put a championship golf course in dormant Ferry Point Park has crossed its final hurdle, with the City Planning Commission voting unanimously in favor of the $22 million project.
Better known as a dumping ground for cars and debris, the former city landfill, in the shadows of the Bronx-Whitestone Bridge, will be the site of an 18-hole public golf course, complete with a driving range, pro shop, restaurant and walkways on the waterfront. 
 "This will be a high-quality private club experience for the public," said J. Pierre Gagne, the developer. Mr. Gagne teamed up with Jack Nicklaus to plan the course, which offers stunning views of the East River, Long Island Sound and the Manhattan skyline.
Mr. Gagne and his partners, known collectively as Ferry Point Partners, were granted a 35-year license by the city to develop, maintain and operate the site. They have pledged to spend at least $22.4 million to convert 222 of the park's 418 acres into the golf course and other recreational areas.
Under the details of the agreement, which was approved by the commission in the last week of December, Ferry Point Partners will install a playground, walking and bicycle paths and manicured green spaces, all for public use. The golf course will be the city's 14th, all publicly owned.
"After you say Bronx Zoo, Yankee Stadium and the Botanical Garden, this will follow as a place to visit in the Bronx," said Edward C. Wallace, a Manhattan lawyer representing Ferry Point Partners.
According to Mr. Gagne and Mr. Wallace, construction is expected to begin this spring. City golfers can expect to tee off on the par 72 championship-level course in summer 2001, they say.
City officials, many of whom have been pushing for the project for years, praised the deal last week.
"This will be a tremendous improvement on what was there and is a sensational gift for the community," said Madeline Provenzano, who is the local City Councilwoman. She cited strong community support for the plan as instrumental in its success.
The idea for building a golf course at the site is not new. It was first proposed by Robert Moses in the 1950's, when he was the parks commissioner. But the project languished and the park has been largely empty and unused since.
The plan regained momentum several years ago, however, as crime fell and the city's economy prospered.
"This is one of the greatest things that's happened in the city in years, and it wouldn't have happened without the rehabilitation of the city," Parks Commissioner Henry J. Stern said. "It's a win-win situation." DAVID CRITCHELL

HEADLINE: PRIVATE SECTOR;
After the Fed, a Large Presence

BYLINE: By ALEX BERENSON

 BODY:
BEFUDDLED by the stock market? Don't understand why shares of unprofitable Internet companies are soaring ever higher while shares of old-economy titans like General Motors go begging?
You are in good company. The man who managed the United States economy for most of the 1980's is as nervous about a bubble as you are. 
 Paul A. Volcker, the former Federal Reserve chairman, acknowledged as much earlier this month at his office at Rockefeller Center. "My God, everybody in the world owns stock in the dot-coms except me," Mr. Volcker said, a wry smile creasing his face. "I am just behind the curve."
For Wall Street, which looks always ahead, never behind, Mr. Volcker, 72, might seem a part of history. His fourth-floor corner office, overlooking the Rockefeller Center skating rink and featuring a museum's worth of knickknacks and testimonials, hardly dispels that impression.
But at 6-foot-7, with a heavy handshake, Mr. Volcker remains as much a physical presence as ever. And during a 90-minute discussion of the economy, the declining attractiveness of public service, and his recent work heading a commission on Swiss banks and the Holocaust, it became clear that for Mr. Volcker, retirement does not mean full-time fly-fishing.
Most economists agree that Mr. Volcker helped pave the way for the expansion of the 1980's -- and today -- by breaking the double-digit inflation that in 1979 and 1980 threatened to stifle the United States economy. On the day in 1987 that Mr. Volcker announced he would step down as Fed chairman, bonds suffered one of their biggest losses ever on fears that his successor (none other than Alan Greenspan) would not fight inflation as well as Mr. Volcker had.
Since then, Mr. Volcker has successfully adopted the attitude that former Federal Reserve chairmen, like former presidents, should be seen but not heard, especially on matters of policy. He worked as chairman of Wolfensohn & Company, a boutique New York investment bank, until 1996, when it was acquired by Bankers Trust.
Last month, Mr. Volcker made news once again, when the international commission he headed announced the results of its audit of Swiss banks that accepted deposits from Holocaust victims. The commission's report found that the banks threw up unnecessary obstacles to victims and families trying to claim their assets. But it exonerated the banks of charges that they systematically destroyed records to keep the victims' assets for themselves.
Mr. Volcker agreed to lead the commission only because of an appeal from an old friend who happened to head the Swiss central bank. Completing the report, which was praised by both the banks and Jewish organizations that brought the issue to light three years ago, was often frustrating, he said.
"A few weeks before the report was due to come out, I thought we'd never get a consensus, and I was prepared to put it out whether we had a consensus or not," he said. But once the banks and Jewish groups recognized that he was determined to issue the report with or without their agreement, they decided to participate to ensure their views would be heard.
The commission discovered 54,000 accounts of possible Holocaust victims that could be worth as much as $1.3 billion. His auditors, Mr. Volcker said, "found as close an approximation to the truth as it's possible to find after all this time."
With the report released, Mr. Volcker has moved on to smaller projects, including advising on the bailout of Japan's Long-Term Credit Bank. He has also departed from his tradition of public nonpartisanship to support Bill Bradley for president. Mr. Volcker explained that because he had pushed Mr. Bradley to run, he felt he should openly commit to the Bradley campaign.
Still, Mr. Volcker, one of a generation of public servants who came to Washington after World War II and viewed working for the federal government as the highest calling, admitted that even he has grown cynical.
"I was so proud of being in government all my life," he said. But now, "public service at almost all levels has come into various disrepute. You don't get the people in government that you should."
They don't know the rewards of public service that they are missing, he said. Even successful corporate leaders "don't have the same feeling of challenge and satisfaction."
Meanwhile, Mr. Volcker is trying -- and failing -- to make sense of the market. "You obviously have a kind of speculative fever," he said. "I think it is a kind of casino. It's all the rage, trading certificates that have no intrinsic value."
Does he see a bust on the horizon? "There's enormous confidence today, but it can evaporate very quickly for reasons that are not very clear," he said.
And what about inflation? Mr. Volcker remains as hawkish as if he had never left the Federal Reserve, dismissing suggestions that inflation is dead: "I'm never ready to say inflation is not a problem. If it's not a problem, it's a potential problem."

HEADLINE: Old Companies, New Stocks: But Will Outside Investors Bite?

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER

 BODY:
TWO big mutual life insurance companies -- John Hancock and Metropolitan Life -- are preparing to distribute millions of shares of stock to their policyholders and sell millions more to the public.
Neither stock is expected to roar out of the starting gates.
But analysts say that shares in both companies should provide investors with gradual gains as well as dividends. 
 "We're not recommending John Hancock and we probably won't recommend Met Life because we want our investors to see a very good growth rate of 40 to 50 percent a year, and the insurance stocks don't offer that," said Gerald R. Eddy, a senior editor at the Institute for Econometric Research, a company in Deerfield Beach, Fla., that tracks initial public offerings. "But over the long haul people will probably do fine with these stocks."
The John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company, which is to become John Hancock Financial Services Inc., has scheduled its offering for Thursday as it reorganizes as a shareholder-owned company. The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company's initial public offering is expected in late March. Another big mutual, the Prudential Insurance Company of America, and several Canadian mutuals are also planning to go public.
The companies will be unleashing a flood of shares on the market.
John Hancock, for example, plans to issue 331.7 million shares, including 229.7 million to its policyholders, the formal owners of the company, in compensation for their contributions through premium payments.
Met Life expects to issue more than 812 million shares, including about 576 million to its policyholders.
Most companies that have gone public in the last few years have issued 5 million to 10 million shares, though most were start-ups. Both big insurers have been doing business for more than a century.
Most policyholders will be allowed to take their compensation in cash or stock. Depending on other investment considerations, policyholders may find the stock more attractive because unlike the cash, the stock is not taxable until it is sold.
Outside investors are not expected to stampede for these stocks. Both companies have relatively low returns on equity and are likely to be priced at close to book value, while many competitors are already trading at 1.5 times their book value and better.
Moreover, shares in the entire field of financial services, including banks and brokerage firms, are depressed because of lackluster performance and rising interest rates.
All this means that companies with great brand names will be available relatively cheaply, but that noticeable early gains are not likely.
Some institutional investors are required to allocate some of their money to dividend-producing shares, so they are sure to be among the buyers of the converted life insurers.
"But people who look at Internet stocks are not going to be real interested in these companies," said Randall Roth, a senior analyst at Renaissance Capital in Greenwich, Conn., which provides research for institutional investors and runs the IPO Plus Aftermarket fund.
Even so, John Hancock expects to raise about $1.8 billion. And Met Life is anticipating about $5.6 billion, which would make its initial offering the country's richest ever, surpassing the previous record-holder, United Parcel Service, which raised $5.47 billion in November.
Met Life also expects to instantly become the company with the largest number of shareholders, perhaps 10 million, compared with the current leader, Lucent Technologies, which has about 4.6 million.

HEADLINE: INVESTING WITH: Robert A. Loest;
IPS Millennium

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD

 BODY:
NOBODY can accuse Robert A. Loest, a self-proclaimed futurist, of missing the big picture with his radically esoteric investment strategy. "Instead of looking at where we are in the economic cycle to decide which sectors to invest in," said Mr. Loest, who runs the $198.7 million IPS Millennium fund, "we look at where civilization is going."
If that description seems a mite abstract, well, the fund's returns show that its results are concrete. It returned 53.4 percent a year, on average, for the three years ended Jan. 14, compared with 29.8 percent a year for its peer group of large growth funds, according to Morningstar Inc., the Chicago financial publisher. 
 IPS Millennium holds 67 stocks, most of them high-flying technology issues. But he balances that by investing a portion of the fund in staid utilities, banks and other, often high-dividend-paying stocks.
Mr. Loest's take on business and markets is quite different from that of most money managers. "We view the economy as an ecosystem, like an oak forest or a tropical coral reef," he said from his office in Knoxville, Tenn. These days, he said, the most successful businesses are those that cooperate extensively with other companies. "Cooperation, not competition, is the ruling paradigm," said Mr. Loest, 56. "Any time one company makes a change, the effects are felt by every other company, like an ecosystem."
That perspective is not surprising for Mr. Loest, who holds a doctoral degree in biology and worked in basic research until the mid-1970's, when he left the field rather than perform experiments on animals. He then worked as a blacksmith until 1985, when a financial planner for whom he shod horses urged him to consider a money management career.
As befits his iconoclastic stance, Mr. Loest disregards company earnings, growth rates, intrinsic worth and other commonly used valuation measures. "The value of companies in the new information economy depends more on their degree of connectivity than on the company's internal assets," he said. Connectivity, he explained, is the degree to which they influence other companies and the depth of their relationships. So, Mr. Loest said, he looks at the number of continuing relationships a company has, as well as the level of dominance it has in its market.
He cited Yahoo, one of the fund's top five holdings. Its worth is minimal according to many valuation methodologies, he said, but extensive in light of all the relationships it has formed with other businesses.
The fund looks at all but the very smallest companies, seeking out those dominant ones with "the most highly developed ecosystem built around what they do," Mr. Loest said. This often means those that have created the technological standards around which other companies operate, like Microsoft and Cisco Systems.
Next, he measures connectivity by assessing a company's marketing relationships, joint development projects, products and services. Mr. Loest is especially keen on companies with what he calls disruptive technology or business models that can overturn established dominant companies. He cited Amazon.com, which threw the retail book market for a loop.
Prices do matter. Typically, he said, he waits to buy shares in companies only after they fall 30 percent to 50 percent from their 12-month high. Mr. Loest often sells a stock when it has fallen more than its peers for three to four consecutive quarters and no one seems to know why.
He originally bought shares of Yahoo in July 1997, at a split-adjusted price of $6.50 apiece. He added shares last summer, when the price dropped to $135, less than half its 12-month high.
"Yahoo lets people and businesses connect in totally new ways," Mr. Loest said. "I view it as the dominant stock in its space." Its only close competitor, America Online, which the fund also holds, is pursuing a very different business model, he said. AOL is restricting its content to proprietary products and trying to get as much of it as possible, as evidenced by its plans to acquire Time Warner, which has had a hard time adapting to the Internet, Mr. Loest noted.
Yahoo management is innovative, he said, adding calendars, address lists and other personal services to its search-engine functions. "They looked at how people were using the product," he said, "and were imaginative in adding features." Yahoo shares closed Friday at $351.9375.
The fund's biggest position, at 6.7 percent of assets, is JDS Uniphase, of San Jose, Calif., which makes fiber optic transmission components. The technology is critical, Mr. Loest said, as the world becomes highly connected through fiber optics and wireless data transmission. The company makes most of the equipment that lets fiber optic strands transmit data, dominating its market, he said.
JDS Uniphase is the dominant company within its "ecosystem," Mr. Loest said, as it has acquired most of its competitors. Last week, it agreed to buy E-Tek Dynamics, a San Jose, Calif.-based rival, for stock valued at $15 billion. He originally bought shares in Uniphase in September 1998 for $22 apiece. Shares closed Friday at $233.125.
One of his favorite electric utilities is Calpine, also of San Jose, which builds miniature power plants using combined cycle natural gas turbines. It is a relatively straightforward deregulation play. The plants are so small and efficient, Mr. Loest said, that office building complexes, and eventually individuals, will be able to disconnect from the main power grid. They produce electricity for about 1 cent per kilowatt hour, compared with 4 to 6 cents for traditional electric companies, he said.
Mr. Loest originally bought shares in June 1998 for $9 each. They closed Friday at $87.1875.

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW;
Federal Budgeteers Ponder A Multiple-Choice Surplus

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
LET the budget games bigger and more rancorous than ever -- begin
Congress will return to town this week, and the first order of business for the Republican majority will be to start sparring with President Clinton and the Democrats over what to do with the tax revenue that is flooding into the Treasury in quantities substantially greater than either party imagined even a few months ago. 
 Here is a reader's guide to Round One: How Big Is My Surplus?
Everyone agrees that the federal budget surplus is growing, but over the next few weeks there will be a complicated and jargon-ridden argument over just how large it will be. The Congressional Budget Office will go first, releasing its projections on Wednesday. The White House's Office of Management and Budget will follow early next month.
The fiscal situation is so complex this year that the budget office is likely to provide not one set of numbers but three.
The first set will be what budgeteers refer to as a "capped baseline." It will assume that government spending next year will decline, by tens of billions of dollars, to meet a statutory limit set in 1997 but shattered for the last two years. Under this script, spending would then decline again in 2002, and then grow at the rate of inflation for the rest of the decade.
Under the capped baseline, the government's operating surplus -- the portion of the surplus generated by general tax revenue rather than excess Social Security payroll taxes -- could be twice as much over the next 10 years as projected last year. That would mean a non-Social Security surplus of nearly $2 trillion for the decade.
That is a staggering amount of money even by Washington's standards, enough to set off a frenzied rush to enact tax cuts and big new spending programs, or to make an accelerated push toward paying off the national debt.
But Democrats and some Republicans say it is a fantasy, because the spending assumptions behind it are unrealistic. Especially in an election year, they say, there will be no will to slash spending, and given the surplus outlook, no need.
So the budget office will probably set out some alternative projections.
One, favored by many influential Republicans, is known as "without discretionary inflation," or WODI. It assumes no spending cuts this year. But it also assumes a freeze in discretionary spending -- basically everything except Social Security, Medicare and interest payments on the national debt -- for the rest of the decade, without even adjusting for inflation.
WODI could yield a surplus nearly as large as the capped baseline. Most Democrats, however, think WODI is no more realistic, given the overwhelming pressure on both parties to spend more each year. They are hoping the budget office will provide what they call a "discretionary growth baseline," which would assume that spending will grow from its current level at the rate of inflation each year for the rest of the decade.
In essence, Democrats want to bake some spending increases into the budget pie for the next decade, rather than having to fight each year just to keep inflation from eating away at the real value of expenditures. Under those assumptions, the 10-year surplus projection would be hundreds of billions of dollars less than under the other two options.
But the Congressional Budget Office projections, however numerous, will be only the start. Clinton administration officials say their estimates will almost certainly be lower than any of the Congressional numbers.
One reason is that the White House seems likely to start with slightly lower assumptions about economic growth and about the current fiscal year's surplus. Those small differences, multiplied over 10 years, could leave the White House surplus estimates for the decade as much as $400 billion lower than the Congressional surplus estimate, even if both were to work with a capped baseline.
Moreover, the White House is all but certain to build its main surplus estimate around an assumption that spending will at least keep pace with inflation.
CONFUSED? So are some of the people who make a living working with these numbers. But there are a few simple things to keep in mind as fiscal policy plays out this year.
First, by any measure, the projected non-Social Security surplus will be huge, providing an opportunity for a real national debate, in an election year no less, about how the fruits of the current prosperity should be invested.
Second, the numbers could change radically for the worse if the economy turns down or the stock market plunges.
Third, the two sides have largely agreed to take off the table the entire surplus generated by Social Security -- $2 trillion over 10 years by last year's projection -- and to use that money only for debt reduction or to overhaul the retirement system.
And fourth, the likelihood of political gridlock in Washington this year is so high that you will almost certainly have an opportunity to try to make sense of all this again next year.
