HEADLINE: PERSONAL BUSINESS;
States Cut Death Tax To Keep Rich at Home

BYLINE: By JAN M. ROSEN

 BODY:
ACROSS the nation, state legislatures have revised laws on gift and estate taxes, bringing them in line with federal law, and cheering lawyers who have seen an exodus of affluent older clients from traditionally high-tax states like New York to traditionally low-tax states like Florida.
"Now there is no reason to move to Florida to avoid transfer taxes," said Sanford J. Schlesinger, partner and head of the wills and estate department of the New York law firm Kaye, Scholer, Fierman, Hays & Handler. 
 The issue, which is a complicated one, works like this: At the federal level there is a unified tax credit for gifts and estates totaling $675,000 this year. That means that gifts and estates up to that level are not taxed. Above that level, gifts and estates are taxed at rates of 37 percent to 55 percent, depending on their size.
In addition, many states levy their own gift and estate taxes. But state estate taxes of up to 16 percent can also be claimed as a credit on federal returns -- and reduce the federal taxes dollar for dollar. What this means to the estate is that the combined federal and state taxes are no greater than the federal tax would have been alone. Because states are able to levy a 16 percent estate tax at no additional cost to their taxpayers, the tax has become known as a "sop up" or "sponge" tax, since it just sops up the federal credit.
Even Nevada, which has no income tax and previously had no estate tax, thereby attracting many retirees from neighboring California, has enacted a sop-up tax, Mr. Schlesinger said.
New York had a graduated gift and estate tax that went as high as 21 percent, costing the estates of affluent residents an extra 5 percent beyond the federal taxes. But New York has repealed its gift tax, effective Jan. 1, and changed its estate tax law, effective Feb. 1, making both the rates and the ceilings conform to federal law -- creating a sop-up tax.
"This is a very salutary change for New York," said Jonathan Herlands, partner in charge of the trusts and estate department of the New York law firm Janvey, Gordon, Herlands, Randolph, Rosenberg & Cox. "It has put New York and Florida on a level playing field."
Through Jan. 31 in New York, the ceiling at which estates become taxable is $300,000. The estates of a husband and wife totaling $1.3 million would be free of federal taxes, but could owe $57,000 in state taxes, Mr. Schlesinger said. "People did move to Florida on the concept this was a tax they could avoid easily," he said.
Mr. Schlesinger called New York "the last guest at the wedding" in changing its estate-tax law to conform to the federal law, joining 35 other states with sop-up taxes.
FOURTEEN states, including Connecticut, still have estate taxes that exceed the federal tax credit, imposing extra costs on their residents. And four states -- Connecticut, Tennessee, North Carolina and Louisiana -- and Puerto Rico still levy gift taxes, for which there is no federal tax credit.
Mr. Herlands predicted these states, too, would soon make their laws conform. New York saw a "hemorrhaging of wealth," as affluent people left the state to minimize the tax burden on their heirs, he said. "Now they are not running in droves to Florida," he continued, and their contributions to the New York economy and the income taxes they pay should more than offset the estate and gift taxes the state is forgoing.
Will people who have already moved to Florida return?
"I think once they get down there, they are seduced by the weather," Mr. Herlands replied.

HEADLINE: The Nation;
Unfurling a Battle Cry And Its Last Hurrah

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE

DATELINE: COLUMBIA, S.C.

 BODY:
THE leading Republican presidential candidates might sound timid to non-Southerners when they insist that the people of South Carolina should decide whether the Confederate flag should fly above the State Capitol.
After all, opinion polls have repeatedly shown that around 60 percent of South Carolinians have already decided they want the battle flag taken down or moved elsewhere, leaving the national and state flags on the dome. The decision really rests with a handful of Republicans in the State Legislature who control not only the flag's future, but also some of the votes the candidates need in the state's presidential primary next month. 
 But Gov. George W. Bush and Senator John McCain, who instantly defer to South Carolinians on the issue of the flag, may know exactly what they are doing in refusing to express an opinion. To many of the state's voters and public officials, particularly the Republican majority, the flag represents neither slavery nor a hazily remembered mixture of Southern courage and gentility. Instead, it flies primarily as a warning beacon, reminding the rest of the country that South Carolina brooks no interference in its affairs.
Running deep in the state, particularly in white rural areas, is a prickly, almost primordial sense of independence and insularity that resents any meddling. South Carolina is full of public officials who believe that the Civil War was fought not over slavery or a way of life, but over federal trespass on a very lofty ideal of state sovereignty. For some of them, this may be a last chance to re-enact the ancient struggle over sovereignty that haunts the state 140 years later.
"My ancestors fought for the question of who was supreme, the federal or the state government," said State Senator Glenn McConnell, a Charleston Republican who is a leader of the pro-flag forces. "They felt like South Carolina freely went into the union, and had the right to opt out, like an independent country. So no one from outside the state is going to have any effect on this issue."
AS pressure to move the flag increases, chiefly from black groups, local business leaders and Northern Democrats, tempers have flared, with legislators saying they will never budge as long as the N.A.A.C.P. continues its "outside" economic boycott of the state. The issue has now become a staple of the presidential campaign, and whenever there is a denunciation of the flag by one of the Democratic candidates -- or by President Clinton, who weighed in last week -- resistance to a compromise seems to grow, although compromise appears inevitable.
Seeing the Confederate flag as a contemporary banner of defiant states' rights may sound like a high-minded evasion of a history that is steeped in slavery. But whether they realize it or not, Mr. Bush and Mr. McCain -- both advised by flag supporters -- are paying homage to a tradition of stubbornness that is well known to students of the state's history. Carolina colonists staged the continent's first revolution in 1719, overthrowing the English power structure known as the Lords Proprietors when the nobles were unable to protect the residents against raids by Indians and pirates. A Charleston merchant, Christopher Gadsden, designed the Revolutionary War's famous naval flag with its "Don't Tread on Me" slogan and coiled rattlesnake; some South Carolina militias carried a similar flag into battle during the Civil War.
"This goes back to the first settlers, who were from the English-speaking Caribbean," said Walter Edgar, director of the Institute for Southern Studies at the University of South Carolina, who wrote "South Carolina: A History" (University of South Carolina Press, 1998). "They were a bunch of pretty tough, driven individuals, used to having their own way, and if anyone interfered, they were eliminated."
Dr. Edgar said it was no coincidence that South Carolina was the first state to secede in 1861, partly to preserve slavery but also to assert its independence from Washington. Since then, the state has also resisted women's suffrage, integration and even the enrollment of female cadets in the Citadel, the military college in Charleston. It is the only state without an official holiday marking the birthday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.
"It's all about controlling your own destiny," Dr. Edgar said. "This is a state that has always believed it should determine its own affairs."
Those who have explored public opinion on the flag have no trouble finding the ideological descendants of those first willful colonists. David Woodard, a Clemson University political scientist who has supervised polls on the flag, says resentment motivates most of the 36 percent of those surveyed who want to keep the flag flying.
"What they told us is they dislike being held hostage by the boycott, so they're just going to dig their heels in more deeply," Professor Woodard said. "I got the feeling that most of them don't even have a particular allegiance to the Confederate battle flag, but if some Northerner is telling them to take it down, that's why they want to keep it up."
Of course, the first voices demanding the flag's removal have not been from outsiders, but from black South Carolinians, who see the flag as a symbol of racism rather than independence. At last Monday's enormous anti-flag rally, which drew nearly 50,000 people, speaker after speaker made the point that the boycott and the protests were organized within the state.
MANY blacks say they suspect the word "outsider" is actually aimed at them, though their ancestors have been in the state since 1670 and often outnumbered whites. In the 1960's segregationists often blamed "outside agitators" for sit-ins and protests, refusing to acknowledge that the civil rights movement had roots in their state; references to the outsiders in the anti-flag boycott have a similar ring for many people.
"What they really mean by all this talk about states' rights is that whites don't like for blacks to tell them what they ought to do," said the Rev. Dr. William P. Diggs, pastor of the Trinity Baptist Church in Florence, who gave the closing benediction at the rally. "Whatever they do, they want to make it appear that it's their idea to do it."

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: HARLEM;
Residential Beachhead for Landing Gentry

BYLINE: By JAYSON BLAIR

 BODY:
As the saying goes, real estate is all about location, location, location. And Harlem has not been on that radar screen for decades.
But in what may be yet another a sign of the booming economy extending its reach into one of the city's poorer communities, the Corcoran Group, which proclaims itself New York's "premier luxury residential real estate" company, is planning to open an office in Harlem. 
 The move, which is scheduled to take place in a few months, would make Corcoran the first of Manhattan's top residential real estate companies to stake out a beachhead north of 110th Street, according to industry analysts.
"We have been doing a lot of business in Harlem," said Barbara Corcoran, the president and founder, in explaining the decision. "I keep watching the numbers, and I see the numbers increase in both quantity and the price."
"I just want to get in there before someone else does," added Ms. Corcoran, who said she was considering sites on upper Fifth Avenue and along mid-125th Street.
The Corcoran Group, which has 500 brokers worldwide and generates nearly $2 billion in sales annually, has 10 offices in New York, in neighborhoods like Greenwich Village. It focuses on renting luxury apartments and selling coops that often fetch above $1 million. Ms. Corcoran said five brokers have already agreed to transfer to the new office.
Although the company could not provide exact figures for its own sales in Harlem, its agents deal with dozens of properties in the neighborhood every year, she said.
Real estate experts say that spacious houses near Marcus Garvey Park in central Harlem, along Fifth Avenue in Hamilton Heights and West 141st and 145th Streets were being bought by people moving from more expensive and crowded areas.
It is not unusual that Corcoran Group agents have clients in TriBeCa or SoHo "who trades their loft for a whole house in Harlem," Ms. Corcoran said. "TriBeCa has already been discovered. They feel like Harlem is going to be the next place."
Ms. Corcoran suggests that any skeptics take a stroll along Hamilton Terrace. The street, she said, is lined with "beautifully maintained rows of town houses, all occupied by Wall Street brokers who hop the train downtown." JAYSON BLAIR

HEADLINE: The Nation;
In a Time of Plenty, The Poor Are Still Poor

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THE drumbeat of good economic news is becoming so familiar that the nation might be excused for taking its prosperity for granted. The United States enjoys the lowest unemployment rate in a generation, stratospheric stock markets, stable prices and even reduced welfare rolls.
But with the current economic expansion about to become the longest on record, there are other, less salutary numbers worth reflecting on. They suggest that those at the bottom of the economic ladder are not benefiting much from the boom and, by some measures, are falling even farther behind. 
 The degree of the problem remains subject to debate, but it is substantial and persistent enough that some analysts, particularly on the left, now see it not just as a social problem but as a potential threat to the economy's long-term prospects. And it is striking enough that politicians across the spectrum feel compelled to address it as they set out their election-year agendas.
The poverty rate in 1998, the most recent year for which data are available, stood at 12.7 percent, according to the Census Bureau. That was down from 15.1 percent in 1993, but virtually the same as at the peak of the last expansion, in 1989. And it is worse than 1969, the year the previous record-setting expansion ended, when 12.1 percent of Americans lived in poverty.
Nor is all the news on income good. Average income for families in the bottom fifth of the income scale fell 5 percent between the late 1970's and the late 1990's, after adjusting for inflation.
By contrast, income among the top fifth of families rose 33 percent, according to the Economic Policy Institute and the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, liberal research organizations.
Last, the median value of assets owned by families with incomes less than $25,000 -- including everything from bank accounts and stocks to homes and cars -- fell between 1995 and 1998, according to the Federal Reserve, while families with higher incomes saw the value of those assets surge.
On the plus side, the gap between rich and poor may no longer be widening. The government's most widely used measures of income inequality were basically unchanged through the latter part of the 1990's. And wage growth is picking up after a long period of decline and then stagnation.
Nonetheless, in an era of abundance, the continuing disparities are focusing new attention on how to deal with inequality. And while there remain sharp ideological differences, conservatives for the most part have joined liberals in acknowledging that the issue matters.
In the presidential primary campaign, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas talks of a "compassionate conservatism" that leaves no one behind. In Washington, President Clinton plans to use his State of the Union address this week to focus on how the nation can better use the bounty of these good times to help those at the bottom.
"As a society, we must answer an increasingly urgent question," Senator Edward M. Kennedy, the Massachusetts Democrat, said last week. "What can we do to close the widening gap in income and skills that leaves too many Americans unable to participate fully in the American Dream?"
Conservatives still argue that inequality and poverty statistics should be viewed in light of the extraordinary ability that Americans have to move up the income ladder, and that fewer people get left permanently behind than the numbers would suggest. Still, they are increasingly acknowledging the persistence of poverty and inequality to buttress their case that government solutions to problems like inferior schools and teenage pregnancy should give way to market-based approaches and an emphasis on personal responsibility.
"If you can read and write only at a third-grade level, the economy has to get extremely strong for there to be a market for you at the minimum wage or any wage," said John C. Weicher, director of urban policy studies at the Hudson Institute, a conservative research organization. "And while the economy can make a difference for many people, there are a lot of people for whom the economy is not the problem."
THERE is also an emerging view among conservatives that the most important gap is not in income, but in wealth. In their view, the nation is becoming divided between people who are able to save, invest and build wealth over the long run and those who are not. The solution, they say, rests in steps like overhauling Social Security to create private investment accounts for all workers, giving everyone a chance to own capital and have a direct stake in the system.
"The movement toward becoming one nation that can invest and one nation that cannot invest has potential consequences for social and political stability down the road," said Michael Tanner, director of health and welfare studies at the Cato Institute, a conservative research group. Policy debates over wealth and inequality still tend to be framed by liberals, who stress fairness and social responsibility. But liberals, too, are increasingly focusing on the economic implications.
Jared Bernstein, a labor economist at the Economic Policy Institute, cited the protests last month at the World Trade Organization meeting in Seattle and a recent Harris poll for Business Week that found that 75 percent of Americans believe the gains of the "new" economy are being distributed unequally.
"We've certainly banked a lot of our economic, political and social capital on this notion that the global, technology-driven economy is one that all Americans should buy into," Mr. Bernstein said. "That kind of poll result, the events in Seattle and this gap between overall growth and the economic fortunes of the middle class really threatens that contract."
Evidence linking an economy's long-run potential to its success in ameliorating inequality is still sketchy. But economists are now starting to generate research suggesting that if "inequality leads you to underinvest in the lives of the have-nots," Mr. Bernstein said, "then ultimately that can be a drag on economic growth, and that's a situation we may ultimately have to face if we don't wrestle this problem to the ground."

HEADLINE: Reckonings;
The Magic Mountain

BYLINE: By PAUL KRUGMAN

 BODY:
This week the Swiss ski resort of Davos, once the home of a sanitarium, will play host once again to the annual meeting of the World Economic Forum -- a unique gathering of the world's business and political elite. I last attended five years ago, even though the forum has officially declared me a G.L.T. (that's Global Leader of Tomorrow -- hold the mayo), which I think means that I have a standing invitation. But I'm sure that my first impression will be similar. After all, the sight of all those wealthy and important people in the same place, with scores of famous intellectuals in attendance, surely inspires the same thought in even the most cynical of observers:
Come the revolution, we shoot these people first. 
 O.K., not really. But the scene at Davos -- the superrich and their trophy wives schmoozing with officials elected and appointed, the lavish parties thrown by third-world nations, and so on -- represents a sort of distilled essence of everything that people love to hate about the New World Order. Those on both left and right who view globalization as a sort of conspiracy by rootless cosmopolitans against the rest of us could hardly have asked for a better spectacle.
As it happens, I am one of those who believe that globalization is overwhelmingly, though not entirely, a good thing. So the instinctive negative reaction that even someone like me feels toward "Davos Man" (a phrase coined by the political scientist Samuel Huntington) suggests just how serious a public relations problem now faces the global economy in which Davos Man flourishes.
The reality is that globalization makes the world a richer place, but the wealth it creates goes disproportionately to two sorts of people. On one side are those who benefit from vastly improved access to technology and capital -- which is to say, workers in developing countries. On the other are those in advanced countries who, directly or indirectly, have technology and capital to sell -- which means the rich and the highly educated. Largely left out of the party, possibly even made worse off, are those who fall into neither category. Most conspicuously, competition from those newly productive third-world workers is one, though probably not the most important, of the reasons that real wages of many American workers have stagnated or even declined over the last 25 years.
It is, to be honest, a picture that contains some shadows. Still, if you ask about the overall effect on the human condition, globalization has been a huge force for good. Just ask the South Koreans, who have telescoped three centuries of European progress into the last 40 years; or even ask the Bangladeshis, who remain desperately poor but whose export industries have kept them from sliding into Malthusian catastrophe. You could say -- and I would -- that globalization, driven not by human goodness but by the profit motive, has done far more good for far more people than all the foreign aid and soft loans ever provided by well-intentioned governments and international agencies.
But in saying this, I know from experience that I have guaranteed myself a barrage of hate mail. For there is another kind of person -- Seattle Man? -- who is passionately committed to a simpler view, without any ambiguities. Seattle Man believes that globalization is purely and simply a way for capitalists to exploit the world's workers. He contrasts the wealth and privilege of global movers and shakers with the poverty of sweatshop workers, and gets angry if you try to suggest that those sweatshops are better than the alternative (let alone that they might, as in South Korea, be the first step on the way to first-world living standards). Seattle Man, in short, does not believe that most of the world is still poor because development is hard to do; he is looking for villains. And in places like Davos he has found putative villains who might have been chosen by Central Casting.
Now with some exceptions the people who will be at Davos aren't really villains: they are no worse, though a lot richer, than the rest of us. But they have an image problem, one that threatens the process of the globalization for which they stand. Will the great and (in some cases) good who meet this week find answers to that problem? Stay tuned. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: The Nation: Party Time -- Holy Grail of Campaign 2000: Money and the Middle;
Most Candidates Squirm to Stay In the Center

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE

DATELINE: DES MOINES

 BODY:
FORCING Gov. George W. Bush to talk about abortion can be more challenging than getting a child to eat broccoli. He almost never raises the issue -- or even utters the word -- on his own. For months, he ignored his Republican rivals who assailed him relentlessly for his silence. Not until late last week, in the final countdown to tomorrow's Iowa Presidential caucuses, did Mr. Bush, cornered by reporters, offer more emphatic remarks about his opposition to abortion.
He was squirming all the way. 
 It was a far cry from four years ago when Bob Dole, then the Republican frontrunner, happily embraced the issue as he stomped through Iowa. He promised to declare his first day in office "American Family Day" and to immediately reverse executive orders by President Clinton that were "forcing abortion even farther into American life."
Mr. Bush's resistance to being yanked rightward on abortion and other nettlesome social issues reflects a reality of Campaign 2000 that is magnified in Iowa but has set the tone for the entire political season: The major candidates, Republicans and Democrats alike, insist that they will stick to the middle of the road.
The shift is most striking here because this state has a history of driving candidates to extremes in order to prod voters into venturing out on a bitter weekday evening to cast their ballots.
In scrambling to the center, the candidates are parroting Bill Clinton's template from 1992: They don't want to say or do anything that might come back to haunt them in November. The campaigns also perceive a post-partisan, even post-political, dimension in the American electorate. Voters these days don't want harsh partisanship or leaders who vow to upset the status quo.
As a result, Mr. Bush and the challenger he seems most worried about, Senator John McCain, are not that far apart on many issues. Nor are the two Republicans appreciably different from Democrats on some of the big questions. They all favor maintaining, if not increasing, military spending. They oppose new taxes. They want a balanced budget. They advocate free trade. They support the death penalty. Except for Mr. Bradley, they favor welfare reform as it has been pursued in recent years. And just as the two Republicans have had little to say about their anti-abortion positions, the Democrats do not advertise their abortion rights stands.
Still, the contrast from past campaigns in Iowa has been most pronounced with Mr. Bush. His advisers' calculation is that after the debacle with Newt Gingrich and impeachment, Republicans should do nothing that in a general election could marginalize them.
This is not to say that Mr. Bush is truly a moderate. He has a decidedly conservative record on abortion in Texas. Rather, he has walked a tightrope, trying to mask the extent of his conservatism so he can appeal to moderates, while not forsaking the right wing.
All this was on display Friday when Mr. Bush refused to cave in to the demands of his rivals that he apply an anti-abortion litmus test to his running mate or to judicial appointments. His advisers argued that he had said nothing he would have to defend -- and in fact, nothing new at all.
"The whole world has changed," said Ralph Reed, an adviser to Mr. Bush who was the executive director of the Christian Coalition. "As was the case with liberal Democrats in '92, religious conservative Republicans in 2000 are willing to give their candidates a little more rope to maintain their viability in the general election."
Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa, a liberal who backs Mr. Gore, put it this way: "There's no real grassroots movements out there like the freeze movements or the arms race back in the 80's. When the economy's good, those kind of issues get pushed to the back burner."
Instead, the campaigns have revived Mr. Clinton's early themes, talking about opportunity and responsibility, improving education and preparing American workers for the global economy. "Everybody is on everybody else's 45-yard line," said Rahm Emanuel, a former senior adviser to Mr. Clinton, "and Clintonism is the paradigm in which everybody is operating on."
The most reliable test of whether a candidate has veered too far to please (or appease) his base is whether he has said or done anything that could resurface in a crippling 30-second commercial in the general election. By that measure, all the candidates this year have at times strayed.
Democratic officials in Washington said they are salivating at the chance to remind voters that Mr. Bush cited Christ as the philosopher-thinker who most influenced him and of his hands-off policy on South Carolina flying the Confederate flag. The Republican Party has already produced a commercial highlighting Mr. Gore's remark that he would favor a litmus test on gays in the military for his appointments to the Joint Chiefs of Staff. (He quickly backtracked after a firestorm.)
But it is Mr. Bush who has been most chary of committing a sound bite he would live to regret. As he said here, he intends to out forth "a consistent message throughout in order to win the will of the people." It's true that, in contrast to his inoffensive public persona, Mr. Bush's campaign vigorously promotes its candidate as a true conservative -- if only to conservative voters.
But, characteristically, at a public event in Pella, Iowa, on Thursday, Mr. Bush, when asked by reporters why he did not mention abortion in a speech, said he did so in his private conversations with supporters. That same day, Mr. Gore, following a similar approach, met with gay supporters. But the meeting was not public. And in Burlington, Iowa, on Friday, Mr. Bradley -- who is also vying for support among gays -- was not eager to discuss homosexual rights. To a reporter's question, he offered a curt reply about civil rights and quickly moved on.
It's a far cry from 1988, when then Senator Paul Simon repeatedly invoked Hubert H. Humphrey and Bruce Babbitt pressed Michael S. Dukakis to have the "courage" to talk about tax increases.
John Haskell, a political science professor at Drake University here, argued that the view of Iowa as "a crazy, loony state" was always overblown. The only reason past candidates were more attuned to the fringes of their parties, he said, was that those races were more competitive -- leaving candidates battling over smaller slices of the electorate.
"When you come right down to it," he said, "Iowa is just a boringly moderate state."

HEADLINE: As Rates Surge, Survival Strategies

BYLINE: By GRETCHEN MORGENSON

 BODY:
INTEREST rates are rising. And though the effects on both investors and consumers have been muted so far, almost everyone will soon feel the impact, deep and wide.
Put simply, rising rates make life more difficult for just about everybody. For investors, higher rates will make gains in the stock and bond markets trickier than ever to find. And the higher borrowing costs that result from rising rates not only hurt consumers who are shopping for a home, they also pinch companies looking to expand their operations. 
 Even though the Federal Reserve Board has raised the benchmark federal funds rate by three-quarters of one percentage point since June, most bond market strategists believe there are more increases to come. They expect the Fed to raise rates by at least one-half point by April. The next meeting of the Fed's Open Market Committee on Feb. 1 and 2 should produce the first of two quarter-point increases, strategists say. From there it is anybody's guess.
While the Fed is moving slowly, bond traders have been quick to take rates on United States Treasury bonds higher. Yields on the benchmark 30-year United States Treasury bond finished at 6.70 percent last week, up significantly from the 5.86 percent seen in late August 1999. The yield on the 10-year Treasury -- at 6.77 -- is now above the average yield of 6.65 percent seen over the entire 1990's.
So far, these rate moves have done nothing to slow the roaring economy or stock market down. This should change. "By the first half of the year, the impact of the tightening will be felt," said Gemma Wright, senior interest rate strategist at Aubrey G. Lanston, an investment firm in New York.
Making this environment even more problematic is the fact that interest rates have been in decline for so long that many investors have forgotten what rising rates can do to their portfolios. Before the most recent bout of increases, the last time the Fed raised rates was in February 1994 when federal funds stood at 3 percent. By the following May, the rate was at 6 percent and bonds were in the midst of their worst year since 1927. Stocks basically treaded water.
Obviously, investors must rethink their strategies -- or at least their tactics. In the broadest terms, many of the investments that made money in a declining rate environment will no longer do so when rates are rising. And because increasing interest rates will be more harmful to companies whose financial footing is shakier than those on solid ground, hard-nosed risk assessment of a company whose stock or bond looks attractive is crucial today.
Among consumers, who have been happy to amass large amounts of debt, a scaling back may be in order. This is particularly true for those who borrowed at rates that fluctuate with the benchmarks.
And those planning charitable donations may want to check with their accountants, too.
For more on how to survive and prosper in a rising interest rate world, the following six articles guide investors and consumers through what is likely to be a whole new ballgame. GRETCHEN MORGENSON

HEADLINE: Stocks: Avoid Banks And Fasten Seat Belts

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
The prospect of rising interest rates has caused lots of fulminating and gyrating in the stock market over the last few months. Despite a palpable increase in volatility, major market indexes have kept moving higher.
The market's continued advance therefore sidesteps the question of what -- if anything -- investors should do to hedge against, or take advantage of, an increase in short-term interest rates of anywhere from half a percentage point to a full percentage point by the end of the second quarter. 
 Despite the consensus that rates are on the rise, few analysts advocate radical changes in investment strategy. "We think interest rates will rise by at least half a percentage point," from current levels, said Frederick B. Taylor, vice chairman and chief investment officer at the United States Trust Company.
Mr. Taylor challenges the idea that "you should do anything if it you think the increase is temporary and you are a long-term investor. In our judgment, this is likely to be a temporary move."
Still, there may be sectors that should be avoided. Historically, for instance, rising rates have not been friendly to financial stocks.
But many regional and money center bank stocks have been hammered over the last year. And that slide may limit the dimension of any further decline.
"There are some very, very low price-earnings ratios among financial stocks, which means you have a valuation cushion," said Douglas R. Cliggott, domestic equity strategist at J. P. Morgan Securities.
"But it is very unusual for a bank stock to go up when the discount rate is going up and its earnings growth rate is slowing down," he added.
Mr. Cliggott, who says he is very underweight in financial stocks, has both pared and rejiggered his model stock portfolio to best exploit opportunities in a rising rate environment. "We want maximum exposure to the global recovery, and are looking at companies with a lot of sales outside of the United States," he said.
Mr. Cliggott says "you will see a lot stronger earnings growth this year than last" among "industrial companies that had their exports hammered and pricing pummeled, energy companies that are benefitting from higher commodity prices and some of the big global consumer goods companies."
If the rise in rates is sharper and of longer duration than most expect, investors would be wise to cast a more skeptical eye over corporate balance sheets, as interest costs of highly leveraged companies would rise, too.
Greg Smith, chief investment strategist at Prudential Securities, agrees that rates are likely to rise, but remains bullish on the stock market: 75 percent of his model portfolio is committed to equities.
Still, there are sectors he does not like because of the likelihood of rising rates, a list that includes financial services and housing stocks, which would suffer as potential home-buyers find it costlier to borrow money. And he says rising rates may have an impact on some housing-related retailers, like Home Depot.
But unlike Mr. Cligott, who also underweights technology stocks, Mr. Smith does not see bad things happening if interest rates continue to rise.
"I am very positive on software companies," he said. "I don't think people understand that as companies get past Y2K they will be implementing new capabilities. Software companies, everyone from Computer Associates to Compuware to BEA Software, will have more demand than they can satisfy."
Mr. Taylor at United States Trust also likes technology, even though he admits the stocks are overpriced and "likely to remain overpriced" even if interest rates go up.
"We want to buy some of those industrial consumer-oriented businesses that are users of technology that may not be as expensive as the technology stocks," he said. KENNETH N. GILPIN

HEADLINE: For Bond Investors: Pick the Ugly Ducklings

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr.

 BODY:
It seems almost preposterous to contend that the bond market could be a rewarding place to be this year. Not after turning in its second-worst performance in a quarter century during 1999 -- negative returns at that -- as stocks, to rub it in, produced yet another year of double-digit gains.
And not when an unusually strong professional consensus agrees that the three-quarters of a percentage point that the Federal Reserve has raised short-term interest rates since last summer gets it just halfway to its likely goal. 
 As rates rise, of course, prices fall. The math is ironclad. And piling into a money market fund is not an unreasonable course of action today.
Yet one does not have to be a knee-jerk contrarian to see grounds for hope. For one thing, the bond market has almost never gone south two years in a row. More importantly, some believe the impending rise in rates seems likely to peak by mid-year, leading to what might be a substantial rally.
And if stocks falter in the meantime, bonds could get better sooner by attracting scared equities money.
"We're back in action as an alternative to the wonderful world of equities," Jack Malvey, chief global bond strategist for Lehman Brothers, predicted.
The way to play this prospect, according to Marilyn Cohen, a Los Angeles adviser who specializes in bonds for individuals, is to start accumulating these ugly ducklings now, but keeping maturities short. With two-year and five-year United States Treasuries yielding 6.45 percent and 6.63 percent, resepctively, nearly as much as the 6.70 percent offered for those coming due in 30 years, there is little incentive to risk buying the longer, more volatile maturities.
"I'd start nibbling right away," said Ms. Cohen, who heads her own firm, Envision Capital. The idea is to gradually feed in additional money as rates rise, not worrying about catching the yield peak, which few are lucky enough to do anyway.
"You're never rewarded in the good markets unless you are venturesome and take a position in the bad markets," Ms. Cohen said to justify a strategy, sound as it is, that risks being a bit early.
The assumption is that the Fed's tightening will, in fact, be successful in cooling the economy, which will curb demand for capital and allow rates to subside.
That's when investors shovel in the rest of their stake, moving out to more distant maturities. Keep in mind, though, that there is no clear signal. The cooling may come earlier or later than expected and the market may judge this well or poorly.
For all investors know, the current dip of 30-year rates below 10-year rates, for example, may mean investors are already expressing confidence that the Federal Reserve will succeed in keeping inflation at bay. When everybody expects the long bond to get to 7 percent, that's a reason for it not to happen.
So which bonds to buy?
Treasuries, which are extremely marketable, carry no risk of default and are not taxable by state and local governments, are preferred by many.
But municipals, tax-free except for capital gains (and the alternative minimum tax) currently yield nearly as much.
And for the more venturesome, especially in 401(k) or other tax-deferred accounts, investors might look at high-grade or high-yield corporates, though these are not very liquid. ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr.

HEADLINE: Foreign Waters: Not a Safe Harbor

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Diversification is likely to be the first thought that comes to mind when investors think about the threat of rising interest rates in the United States. Diversification is all about doing well in one market while another is fairing poorly.
But going abroad, in stocks or bonds, is no sure bet right now, although some analysts think that Americans will be looking overseas as their returns from American stocks come down to earth against a backdrop of rising interest rates. 
 One reason is that in recent years, diversification has not been a protection against big swoons here. Sharp falls in the major American stock indexes in 1997 and 1998 led the rest of the world lower.
And then there are the environments of foreign markets themselves, which will not be much of a refuge if they sour in the face of their own rising interest rates, too. In other words, uncertainity here does not suggest certainty abroad.
In Europe, the threat of an interest rate increase by the European central bank as the Continental economies rebound has some strategists worried about the outlook for both bonds and stocks.
Yields in France, Germany, Italy and Britain have been rising since late last year. And key stock market indexes in Europe are down so far this year, except in Germany.
In Asia, the outlook is better. Japan is still attracting investment from abroad as it struggles to keep its economic rebound moving. With the economy just beginning to recover, rising interest rates are not a major threat; currently rates are so low as to be barely noticeable.
The rest of Asia is also coming back from the steep economic declines that began with the sudden currency devaluations in the summer of 1997.
The Morgan Stanley Capital International index of emerging stock markets in Asia is up 3.8 percent this year, after rising 63 percent last year.
But in Asia, American investors face another problem: the dollar, the other key factor in investments abroad. It was weak against the Japanese yen and other Asian currencies in 1999, adding strongly to returns for American investors as the stronger yen value was translated back into dollars.
The Nikkei index in Japan was up 55.1 percent when the decline in the dollar was factored in. If the dollar now rallies, it will cut into American returns. This year's small dollar rally, for example, has magnified the 0.30 percent loss in the Nikkei stock index in yen terms to a loss of 2.46 percent in dollar terms.
The dollar does offer some hope for American investors who place their bets on Europe. If it swoons this year after a 16.2 percent rally against the euro in 1999, investments by Americans would get a boost. JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

HEADLINE: Consumer Rates Are Likely to Go Higher

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON

 BODY:
Borrowers should expect to pay more in interest after the Fed raises rates.
Credit card, consumer and auto loans are all tied to interest rates that tend to track Federal Reserve board actions. And even though mortgage rates have been rising for nine months in anticipation of higher inflation ahead, they, too, are likely to go up even more if the Fed raises rates, as expected. 
 About two-thirds of the 200 million individual credit card accounts are at variable rates, said David Robertson, president of The Nilson Report, a credit card newsletter published in Oxnard, Calif.
If the Fed raises rates, card holder rates can go up as soon as the next billing cycle, which might start the next day in some cases, or in as long as three months time, Mr. Robertson said. Most banks, he said, will raise rates at the very next billing cycle.
What is less obvious is that even people with fixed-rate credit cards may see rates rise. The fine print often allows a periodic adjustment and many contracts allow raising the rate if a payment is late.
One bright spot is auto loans. Some manufacturers offer very low rates to customers with solid credit histories who buy models the manufacturers are eager to move. DaimlerChrysler, for example, has granted some customers five-year loans at 0.9 percent interest for five years, below the inflation rate.
Mortgage interest rates have been rising for nine months in anticipation of higher long-term inflation, said Greg McBride of Bankrate.com, a company in North Palm Beach, Fla.,that monitors bank interest rates.
Mortgage rates tend to rise in advance of Fed actions, he said. But even so, Mr. McBride said that mortgage rates, which are now above 8 percent for 30-year loans, may notch even higher if the market anticipates continued increases in the inflation rate.
On the other side of the equation, savers are getting much better returns, he said. The national average yield on a one-year certificate of deposit was 5.05 percent last week, up from 4.27 percent a year ago. DAVID CAY JOHNSTON

HEADLINE: One Kind of Giving Gets More Attractive

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON

 BODY:
For those thinking about creating a charitable remainder trust, the expected rise in rates may have a major impact.
In a charitable remainder trust, an irrevocable gift is made to charity, but the charity does not receive the funds until the giver dies or, as charity officials like to say, when the gift "matures." 
 The giver gets an immediate deduction for the gift, but not for the full amount because the charity will not collect immediately. The amount that can be deducted is based on the age of the donor or donors and on interest rates set by the Internal Revenue Service.
The donor gets back a stream of payments for life and can decide how to invest the trust assets.
The expected rise in interest rates will have virtually no direct impact on charitable remainder unitrusts, which are generally invested in stocks and whose value thus rises and falls with the value of those stocks, said Leland Hoffman, president of the Planned Giving Design Center in Matthews, N.C., an Internet advisory service for charities.
But rates have a big impact on charitable remainder annuity trusts, which pay a fixed sum to the donor.
If people donate bonds to the trust and interest rates go up, then the bonds will be worth less, said Mr. Hoffman, who was a co-author of "Harnessing the Power of the Charitable Remainder Trust" (PhilanthroTec Inc., 5th Edition, 1999).
This means that people planning to finance a charitable remainder annuity trust with bonds want to act before rates rise.
Mr. Hoffman noted, however, that the Internal Revenue Service resets the official interest rate on the 19th of each month and that donors are allowed to use the rate in effect two months earlier. He recommends that appointments with estate lawyers or charity officials to execute trust documents be set in the last 10 days of the month to take advantage of the latest information on the official interest rate.
Paul Gordon Hoffman, a lawyer with Hoffman Sabban & Watenmaker in Los Angeles who is not related to the president of Planned Giving Design Center, said that charitable remainder annuity trusts financed with cash would generate an increasingly large deduction as interest rates rise.
When rates rise, the rules say that the value that eventually goes to charity rises and that means a larger tax deduction, in fact a far larger one.
Paul Gordon Hoffman said that a couple, both aged 65, who donate cash to a charitable remainder annuity trust, or CRAT in industry parlance, at the current official interest rate of 7.4 percent will get to deduct 37.8 percent, or $378,316 for a $1 million trust, assuming they take an annual payout of $60,000.
But if interest rates rise by 1 percentage point, he said, their deduction will grow to 42.6 percent, or $426,616 for a $1 million trust, assuming the same $60,000 annual payout. That is 12.7 percent more, or $48,300 in the case of $1 million trust.
Don't expect to get both a higher payout and a bigger deduction if interest rates rise, however. Paul Gordon Hoffman calculated that if the interest rate set by the I.R.S. rises 1 percentage point and the donor takes a payout of 7 percent, or 1 percentage point higher, the value of the charitable deduction falls to 33.1 percent. DAVID CAY JOHNSTON

HEADLINE: A Slower Economy, But Still aStrong One

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

 BODY:
First the good news: The economy is so strong that even a sharp rise in interest rates this year is unlikely to stop growth in its tracks or hit individuals too hard.
Employers are likely to continue creating new jobs, albeit at a slower pace. The unemployment rate would probably creep up, but remain at a relatively low level. Incomes would continue rising, but perhaps more modestly. 
 There is a case to be made that rate increases by the central bank do not filter through the economy with the force they once did. But Americans would feel the effects nonetheless, though the full impact would not become apparent until 2001. Still, even if the Fed raises rates by more than many expect -- say, a full percentage point this year -- the results would not be cataclysmic by any measure.
"A one percentage point increase will make housing a little less affordable, raise debt service payments for businesses and households, and if history is any guide it will reduce stock and other asset values," said Mark Zandi, an economist at RFA Dismal Sciences, a consulting firm in West Chester, Pa.
"It should also help to support the value of the dollar, which should result in greater constraint on our trade with overseas economies," Mr. Zandi said. "When you add all those things together, it will result in an economy that will grow more slowly, but not an economy that will fall off a cliff."
Mr. Zandi plugged a 100 basis point increase in the short-term federal funds target rate into his economic model, and found that growth would decline to 2.5 percent in 2001 from 3.5 percent this year. The unemployment rate would rise to 4.5 percent next year from 4.1 percent this year. Growth in median household income would fall to 2.6 percent from 3.9 percent.
But Mr. Zandi's forecast assumes that rising rates will take a bite out of the stock market, dampening the so-called wealth effect that leaves consumers feeling flush and eager to spend. If investors were to shrug off rising rates and continue pushing equity prices higher, the economy could retain considerably more momentum than if the stock market declines or stays flat.
"Much hinges on a weaker stock market and the market continuing to behave like it has historically in a rising rate environment," Mr. Zandi said. "If the stock market were to move higher and disregard the monetary tightening and higher long-term rates, then the impact on the economy would be very small. You might have fewer homes built, and we might export less overseas because of a stronger dollar, but consumers would spend aggressively and business would invest aggressively."
As Mr. Greenspan and every Fed chairman before him has learned, slowing the economy through interest rate increases is an imprecise business. The main reason that expansions end is not that they grow old and tired, but that the Fed tightens monetary policy a notch or two too much, stamping out inflation but squeezing out growth as well.
Part of the problem is that higher interest rates filter through the economy with a lag of many months. No one knows for sure what economic and financial conditions will be like when a rate increase finally begins to bite.
For the Fed, as it ponders whether another increase is justified, it is like having to know how hard to hit the brakes on the car miles before coming to the stop sign -- and without knowing what the traffic or weather conditions will be. RICHARD W. STEVENSON

HEADLINE: The World: The Yankee Dollar;
Latin America Decides, if You Can't Beat 'Em, Join 'Em

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA

 BODY:
EVEN in the loopy landscape of South American economies, Ecuador is an extreme case. Last year it defaulted on some of its debt, roughly 70 percent of its banks have been taken over by the state, inflation exceeded 60 percent, and the local currency -- the sucre -- is running at 25,000 to the dollar.
No wonder then that Ecuador's president tried the economic equivalent of a Hail Mary pass. On Jan. 9, President Jamil Mahuad announced that the United States dollar would be the new coin of the realm. The sucre would be used only as small change. 
 Ecuador thus joins a growing list of more than two dozen countries, the largest of them Panama, that use the dollar as their official currency, as well as the people in more than 50 other countries who unofficially put their trust in American money, according to the International Monetary Fund. In Russia alone, residents hold about $40 billion in American dollars.
Mr. Mahuad's abandonment of the sucre is raising questions about how many economically battered countries can take refuge behind the dollar without having an impact on the United States economy itself.
The question is difficult to answer, in part because there has never been anything quite like the current dominance of the dollar. More than $300 billion is circulating outside the United States, and from the tiniest Mexican pueblo to the street corners in Albania, the dollar is accepted, even favored over local currencies.
Until now, American treasury officials have been unwilling to either openly condemn or endorse the dollarization. But since the euro, Europe's new single currency, mad its debut last year, dollarization gained credence as a way for the United States to maintain the pre-eminence of the dollar and to export economic stability.
Some members of Congress take this view. "For a country like Ecuador, dollarization creates at the very least a period of stability," said Representative Jim Saxton, a New Jersey Republican who is the vice chairman of the Joint Economic Committee. A very short period. By the end of the week Mr. Mahaud had been ousted in a coup led by the military and Indian groups.
Steve H. Hanke, a professor of applied economics at Johns Hopkins University, has compared the performance of developing economies linked to the dollar with those that are not and found that the dollar's stability does seem to rub off. Dollarized countries and those that back their currency on a one-to-one ratio with dollars (as Argentina does now) enjoyed higher growth rates, lower inflation and smaller deficits from 1950 to 1993 than those that relied on their central banks to set monetary policy.
"The only way to extinguish the frequency and reduce the magnitude of recurring currency crises is to put these little half-baked central banks out of business," Professor Hanke said.
That's what happened in Ecuador, where the three top members of the central bank quit when the government decided to replace most of the 11 trillion sucres in circulation with about $450 million, at a rate of 25,000 sucres to $1.
Under dollarization, the banks lose their most important power, the ability to print money. That's one reason the three top bankers quit.
But the presidents of developing countries that adopt the dollar also lose some power. They can no longer resolve political crises by bullying their central bankers into lowering interest rates or printing money to cover government debts. The benefit is that it is more difficult for these governments to pursue inflationary economic policies.
Despite Professor Hanke's enthusiasm, though, economists are divided over the long-term effects of dollarization. The gyrations of a small national economy that used dollars would have little effect here, noted C. Fred Bergsten, director of the Institute for International Economics in Washington. "However, if one big country like Mexico or a group of countries in the hemisphere decide that they want to do it," he said, referring to dollarization, "it could have an effect on our monetary policy."
Mr. Bergsten wonders what would happen if the United States economy slowed, but high oil prices kept a dollarized Mexico booming. The demand for dollars south of the border could put upward pressure on interest rates just when the American states needed lower rates to kick-start economic growth.
"There are highly plausible circumstances which could require the Federal Reserve to alter course or have its own purely U.S. monetary objectives undercut," Mr. Bergsten said.
ECUADOR is also running the risk of being out of sync with the United States economy. For example, an interest rate hike, intended to slow expansion of the American economy, might send Ecuador into recession.
Congress is considering bills to give the secretary of the treasury the power to share with the dollarizing countries some of the revenue that they lose by not issuing their own currency. In the case of Argentina, that comes to about $750 million a year. In Ecuador, it would be about $30 million a year.
But formal arrangements would invariably be accompanied by pressure from the dollarizing country to have some say in setting monetary policy, perhaps with a seat on a new or expanded Federal Reserve Board. Something similar happened in Europe, where the central banks of 11 nations were replaced by a new European Central Bank that represents them all but gives special consideration to none.
For Washington, the desire to legislate the dollarizing process is a natural one. But a better idea may be to let foreign nations decide on their own whether to adopt American currency. This is what Ecuador did, without implicating the United States in the process at all. As Professor Hanke said, with Ecuador "the bottom line is that there aren't any realistic downsides for us."

HEADLINE: Navigating the Renaissance of an Ohio River That Once Caught Fire

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES

DATELINE: CLEVELAND, Jan. 21

 BODY:
The new federal overseer's job title, river navigator, has a Mark Twain ring, while the river, the Cuyahoga, bears an infamous image worthy of Dante: it was the Cuyahoga that burst into flames in 1969 and burned in plain sight of the nation under an oily burden of noxious pollutants.
"The river catching fire brought national attention and ridicule to Cleveland, but it also proved to be the instrumental rallying point in the passage of the Clean Water Act of 1972," said Steven R. Davis, the Cuyahoga's newly appointed navigator. 
 Mr. Davis, a watershed expert with the United States Forest Service, is a pioneer along the first 14 troubled waterways to be covered under the new American Heritage Rivers program. As navigator, he has the unusual job of reversing the federal stereotype of big, intrusive bureaucracy by diplomatically roaming and working for 80 communities and more than 100 city and township jurisdictions as a riverfront trouble-shooter.
"That's what's exciting about this. I'm a lone federal employee working at the grass-roots level to help the Cuyahoga," Mr. Davis said. He serves as part liaison, part catalyst for local civic, government and business leaders in northeast Ohio in their dealings with a score of federal agencies that have the wherewithal to help rebuild the economic and cultural life of the river.
He sees himself as a large-scale aquatic version of the traditional extension agent in agricultural regions: a specialist helping localities move from blight to bounty. On a good day, he hopes to prove a bit of a spark in river projects involving the private sector and the government -- a poetic enough notion considering that local lore says it was a spark from a welder's torch, or maybe from a passing train, that set the Cuyahoga to burning.
After only a few months on the job, Mr. Davis, a mustached 47-year-old whose style is far more amiably rustic than bureaucratic, already has a raft of tasks from his assorted governmental and environmental constituents. They range from the minuscule (how to clear the debris under the abandoned railroad trestle in Kent that blocks river passage) to the daunting (how to help Cleveland and Akron find the right plans and financing to solve serious sewage overflows during rainstorms that feed the river's violation of federal pollution standards).
"We're all here because of the river, the lifeblood for the first settlers of Cleveland and Akron," Mr. Davis said. He has been studying each twist and turn of the 100-mile river and measuring the considerable recovery efforts of the five regional "river partners" sponsoring the program -- government and civic associations that have been dedicated for years to the Cuyahoga's renaissance.
"People turned their back on the river as soon as the railroads came in in the 1850's," he noted, while taking inventory of waterfront trash heaps and finding reclamation handsomely under way in some areas. Notably, there is Cleveland's Flats neighborhood, now stylishly resurgent but once the slum area where flames first burst incongruously upon the Cuyahoga.
The Cuyahoga -- it got its name from a Native American term for crooked river because of the unusual U shape that causes it to flow both north and south -- was a teeming conduit after the Revolutionary War, as Western settlers journeyed from Lake Erie down the Ohio River. In modern times the river has reeled from industrial pollution, sporting deformed fish and prompting warnings against swimming the oil-slicked waters.
In three decades, the river's local and regional defenders have fought back. Fish are returning, but the warnings against eating them remain. And there are still bans on swimming and boating in the area's 33,000-acre Cuyahoga Valley National Recreation Area. The river's 813-square-mile watershed now supports 15 percent of Ohio's population.
Mr. Davis, who has an office in a 19th-century general store in the Cuyahoga national park, has worked for the Forest Service for 25 years. He served as the agency's specialist in dealing with the river problems of dozens of communities in California, Colorado and Wyoming.
Mr. Davis has no special financing beyond his own $60,000 annual paycheck. His task is to see what localities want and to broker plans and financing with private and government participation.
"There's a million things we need to do," said Mr. Davis, who is planning a canoe trip on the Cuyahoga to further erase the image of the burning river. "The program is new, so there's no real direction. But the blessing is, we can invent it as we go and work with local people to do it."

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE MONEY;
Democrats Look for Ways to Counter G.O.P. Advantage

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER

DATELINE: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 22

 BODY:
Democrats, facing the overwhelming financial superiority of the Republicans, have begun an aggressive and accelerated fund-raising and organizational effort in the hope that the eventual Democratic presidential nominee can match Republican spending this spring.
"We will win or lose in November depending on what we do in the first quarter of this year," said Joe Andrew, the national chairman of the Democratic National Committee, which is meeting here. "We will have to win on the ground, because they will always have superior dollars to spend on the air war." 
 Democratic officials are operating on the assumption that the Republicans will raise $250 million to $350 million to support their party's nominee -- who virtually all Democrats presume will be Gov. George W. Bush. Democrats cannot hope to match that figure but are expecting to raise and spend between $50 million and $150 million for this year's campaigns, officials said.
Democratic leaders hope to raise a substantial portion of the total in the first three months of the year, to be prepared for the long lull between the selection of the party's nominee, which will almost certainly be completed by the end of March, and the national convention in mid-August.
Fund-raisers are courting big donors and hammering traditional contributors to write their checks early. President Clinton has promised to attend at least 10 money-raising functions before the end of March. In just the past week, he has raised more than $2 million at events in Boston, Washington and Los Angeles.
Edward G. Rendell, the D.N.C.'s general chairman, said in an interview this week that the party was focusing on three major groups of donors: established Democratic contributors, those who have given in the past but dropped out and new donors.
Among the biggest challenges will be to try to corral contributors to former Senator Bill Bradley should he fail in his bid to win the presidential nomination, Mr. Rendell said. Mr. Rendell, the former mayor of Philadelphia, said many of Mr. Bradley's donors are Republicans and friends who have not contributed to Democratic causes before. But he said he hoped to be able to persuade them to support Vice President Al Gore if he wins the nomination.
Douglas Berman, Mr. Bradley's campaign chairman, said that was unlikely, in part because of the bitterness of the current primary campaign and in part because those donors are disillusioned with the Clinton-Gore brand of politics.
"A fair amount of that financial support will not be transferable," Mr. Berman said. "What brought them to Bradley was a desire for fundamental change in the direction of the last several years."
Mr. Andrew and other officials are in Louisville this weekend to lay out for the 50 state Democratic chairmen the party's strategy for prevailing despite the Republicans' money advantage and what most expect to be a relatively brief and easy nomination battle for Mr. Bush.
The answer, Mr. Andrew and other Democratic leaders said, boils down to two areas where they believe the Democrats can leverage their strengths into electoral advantage: message and targeting.
Democratic polls and focus groups, as well as impartial surveys, show a public preference for Democratic approaches to the issues that concern most voters: education, health care, preservation of Medicare and Social Security, management of the economy, even crime and public safety. Those issues come up repeatedly in discussions with Democratic officials here.
"We're going to win in Kentucky across the board because we're right on the issues," said Nicki Patton, the Kentucky state party chairwoman. "Our biggest challenge is going to be to get out the vote because I know our candidates are fundamentally closer to where the average working American family is."
The message will be carried by members of Congress and local candidates, and by an unusually early advertising campaign directed at the 17 states that Democrats have identified as in play in November.
But the biggest innovation, and the area where spending is growing the fastest, is what Mr. Andrew calls "the customized campaign." Since 1996, the national and state parties have been compiling a computerized database that allows officials to identify targeted voters by a host of variables, including demographic and economic data, party affiliation, consumer preferences, religion, education and likelihood to vote.
The database will contain physical and e-mail addresses and phone numbers, allowing campaigns alternate ways of reaching voters. The party has purchased delivery data from the United States Postal Service that maps out the most effective routes for door-to-door canvassing. It also tracks cable television subscriptions, allowing targeting of political advertising almost by neighborhood.
Mr. Andrew admits it sounds a bit Big Brotherish, but he insists that these are merely new tools for doing old-fashioned shoe-leather campaigning in the digital age.

HEADLINE: Group of 7 Nations Seek Their Own Paths to a Common Goal

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

DATELINE: TOKYO, Jan. 22

 BODY:
With the exception, perhaps, of the Russians, everyone came away from the meeting of the financial leaders of the Group of 7 industrialized countries today with something they wanted.
For the Japanese hosts, there was a statement, albeit a muddled one, of collective concern over the potential negative impact of an excessively strong yen on the global economy. 
 The Europeans conversely managed to keep their currency, the euro, out of the final communique despite concerns among policy makers outside Europe that its low value is being used to avoid taking steps for painful economic restructuring.
And for the Americans, there were pledges from their European and Japanese counterparts that they would work hard to increase their role in ensuring global prosperity.
But, peeking out around the edges of collective good will, there were reminders that the global economy is nothing more than an uneasy federation of national interests.
First, it became clear that in spite of an aggressive campaign by the Germans to promote their deputy finance minister, Caio Koch-Weser, as the next leader of the International Monetary Fund, no signs of consensus had emerged. If anything, it seemed the parties had moved further apart, with the French now considering offering their own candidate, perhaps Jean-Claude Trichet or a dark-horse candidate whose name has already surfaced, Laurent Fabius, a former prime minister.
The Europeans took umbrage at American concerns over the euro, with ministers from the region and the leader of the European Central Bank emphatically dismissing suggestions that a weak euro had created an export-led recovery in Europe.
"The economic potential behind the euro is obviously greater than that of any other currency, including the mark," said Hans Eichel, the German finance minister. "When people see how Europe picks up, the euro-dollar relationship will change."
And in a news conference, Finance Minister Christian Sautter of France drew attention to a reference in the communique to concerns about the rising level of debt among American households.
Mr. Sautter said, "Every country has its problems," and he added that he thought it was the first time the United States has ever countenanced any mention of its economic warts in such a document.
Gordon Brown, Britain's chancellor of the exchequer, seized an opportunity to tweak the French when he commended them for taking Britain's lead in forgiving all of the government-guaranteed debts owed by several of the world's poorest countries that have agreed to adopt reforms recommended by the I.M.F. aimed at increasing efficiency.
The French said today that they would forgive some 7 billion francs worth of debts under the Heavily Indebted Poor Countries initiative mounted by the Group of 7 last year.
In addition to exchange rates, monetary and fiscal policy, the global financial system and other matters, the ministers also grilled the Russian finance minister on his country's progress in reforming its economy. Russia is seeking debt forgiveness and a resumption of a $4.5 billion loan package from the I.M.F. that was put on hold after the country failed to meet some of the terms. The ministers offered a lukewarm assessment of Russia's economic progress, attributing it to "improved external factors."
"I'd like to make it clear that from Germany's standpoint at least, debt forgiveness is out of the question," Mr. Eichel said, adding that further talks will depend on whether Russia introduces credible, far-reaching reforms.

HEADLINE: HIGH SCHOOL FOOTBALL;
A Burst From South Bronx to Ohio State

BYLINE: By LENA WILLIAMS

 BODY:
Had Sammy Maldonado yielded to cultural tradition, he would have followed the cleat prints of thousands of other Latino kids onto the baseball field. But fate stepped in when Maldonado was 8 years old and placed the youngster on a football field.
Today, this son of a diminutive Puerto Rican immigrant is considered one of the greatest high school running backs in New York State history and one of the top-20 high school football players in the nation. Maldonado, who attends Harrison High School, is only the second high school player in the state to run for more than 7,000 yards in a career. Along with rushing for 7,581 yards, Maldonado set a state record for most touchdowns in a career with 99 -- 15 more were called back because of penalties -- and is the first player in state history to win two high school Heisman awards. He also led the Harrison Huskies to a 12-0 season and the Class B state championship. 
 After weighing full-scholarship offers to Ohio State, Penn State, Syracuse and Miami, Maldonado plans to sign a letter of intent in early February to attend Ohio State.
At 17, Maldonado has been embraced as a role model by New York's Latino community, from the South Bronx, where his parents made their first home, to Harrison, where he grew up. In this soft-spoken, seemingly all-American boy who is more fluent in English than Spanish, Latins have found a great hope.
"I dare say that this kid may become the first Latino American to win the Heisman Trophy," said Julio Pabon, founder of Latino Sports Ventures, a sports marketing firm that promotes Latino athletes. "Sammy has managed to excel in a sport that is not abundant with Latinos -- except maybe as place-kickers. We're going to see an Hispanic last name on a jersey in collegiate Division I-A football and maybe one day in the National Football League, and that is going to be great for the Latin community."
On Jan. 12, members of New York City's Latin community and beyond attended a luncheon thrown by Maldonado's father, Rafael, at Mickey Mantle's restaurant in Midtown Manhattan. The senior Maldonado said the celebration was his way of saying thanks to coaches, teachers, relatives and friends who have supported his son during his high school career.
But his invited guests, including Jose Torres, the former light-heavyweight champion, and Freeman McNeil, the former Jets running back, seized the moment to pay tribute to Maldonado's son, who received Estrellas del Suturo award (Stars of the Future) from Latino Sports Ventures and was honored by Bronx Borough President Fernando Ferrer for his contributions to the community.
"This boy has South Bronx milk," Ferrer said.
For his part, the boy readily accepts the responsibilities that come with carrying a people's hope on his shoulders.
"I'm willing to rise to the challenge," Maldonado said in an interview. "Pressure really doesn't affect me."
The 6-foot-1-inch, 220-pound Maldonado appears to be the prototype running back. According to his coach, Art Troilo Jr., the teenager has soft pass-catching hands and a formidable combination of speed, strength, agility and smarts. A highlight video that was played for luncheon guests showed one play in which Maldonado took a handoff on the 15-yard line, darted up the middle, sped around the left cornerback and dragged the right defensive back into the end zone with him for the score.
Asked which of his physical attributes was his best asset, Maldonado said "all of them."
"I can run over you or away from you," he said matter-of-factly. "Whatever comes naturally at the time, I do it."
He chose Ohio State over Syracuse because he prefers playing on natural grass. The Carrier Dome, Syracuse's home field, is artificial turf.
"He got hurt at Syracuse in his last game" -- a 28-26 victory over Lackawanna for the state title -- "he sprained his ankle," said his mother, Nereyda, who hasn't missed any of her son's games and doesn't plan to start now, even though he will be playing several hundred miles away. "He said he liked Ohio State because they like to run the ball a lot and it's more like the high school game."
Also, two of his idols, running backs Eddie George and Archie Griffin, attended Ohio State. Each won the Heisman Trophy -- Griffin managed to do it twice in 1974 and 1975 -- and both went on to play in the pros, George currently with the Tennessee Titans and Griffin with the Cincinnati Bengals.
"He's capable of following in their footsteps," Troilo said. "Sammy has that kind of God-given ability that you can't teach. He can play anywhere on the football field: defensive back, linebacker, halfback, fullback. He's a special player. But the best thing he does is run with the football because of his size, strength and vision."
Rafael Maldonado always knew his youngest of three sons -- Rafael Jr. is 28 and Thomas is 25 -- had talent.
"Ever since he was 8, he just loved football," said Maldonado. "He played basketball and baseball, but he liked physical sports."
The senior Maldonado came to New York in 1967 at the age of 17, discovered he liked the cold weather and decided to stay. He moved with a cousin to the South Bronx, got a job washing dishes and moved up the economic ladder to a good-paying job managing 40 parking garages in Manhattan. Shortly before Sammy was born in 1982, the family moved from the South Bronx to a house in Harrison.
"We wanted to give the boys a better education," their father said.
This past week, Maldonado who was named New York State Gatorade Player of the Year, was flown to Hawaii to attend the Hula Bowl yesterday. It was his first trip without his parents.
"It's only four days," his mother said with a sigh. "The only thing is that he will be alone on his birthday on Jan. 22. But it's good for him to go."
