HEADLINE: Reinstated Officer Is Renewed as a Candidate

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
James E. Davis can scarcely conceal his feeling of triumph. Fourteen months after Mr. Davis, a police officer and part-time minister, was fired from the force after his name appeared on a general election ballot, he won a court ruling saying that his dismissal was unjust.
That legal victory last week, which upheld Mr. Davis's challenge of his dismissal under a Police Department policy forbidding active officers to run as official candidates of any political party, has reinvigorated his political aspirations. 
 Two years ago, he stunned Brooklyn politicians by nearly toppling the Democratic Party leader, Assemblyman Clarence Norman Jr., in the primary. Mr. Davis's participation in the primary did not violate department policy because before the primary vote, the party has no official candidate. The trouble began after Mr. Davis's name appeared on the Liberal Party line in the general election.
But now, with the court ruling behind him, Mr. Davis says he will take on Mr. Norman again this year.
The prospect of a rematch is creating a stir in the Crown Heights district that Mr. Norman has represented in Albany for 18 years. In 1998, Mr. Davis lost the primary by just 580 votes, suggesting that Mr. Norman, long a political heavyweight, is vulnerable.
"I have always planned to run this year, and I never stopped campaigning," Mr. Davis said. "But there is a new energy from the people after this court decision. The people are calling me the lion slayer. I am energized and excited."
Mr. Norman says he is taking nothing for granted this year. In a recent interview, he said the primary results were close because he had been busy working on the campaigns of other Democrats in the borough, as well as the statewide campaign of Eliot L. Spitzer for attorney general.
"I spent a tremendous amount of time outside of my district," Mr. Norman said. "And we saw the results not being what we hoped they would be. This time, we will be absolutely focused."
Mr. Norman said he had already raised about $160,000 for his re-election campaign. "And that's not nearly as much as I'm going to have," he added. His campaign spent about $30,000 in the 1998 race.
Mr. Davis acknowledges that he is likely to be significantly outspent by Mr. Norman, but he maintains that he can win without matching his opponent dollar for dollar.
"It's not going to require that much money to beat him," Mr. Davis said. "What's important for me is to meet with all the community and civic leaders in the community. That's what made my showing so strong in the Democratic primary in 1998."
After the primary, the Police Department fired Mr. Davis, contending he had been the Liberal Party's official candidate in the the general election. But Mr. Davis contended that he had not been an official candidate and had never received notice that he was the party's designated candidate. The Liberal Party, as well as the Board of Elections, supported Mr. Davis's contention, and after 14 months of unemployment, Mr. Davis was ordered reinstated last week by the State Supreme Court, which also ordered the Police Department pay his back wages.
As in his previous race against Mr. Norman, Mr. Davis insists that the assemblyman has been so involved with running the party that he has been inattentive to the needs of the 43rd Assembly District.
"Clarence Norman has been there for almost 20 years and nothing has improved," Mr. Davis said.
In response, Mr. Norman, 49, mentions a litany of projects he has either led or supported, from the restoration of major thoroughfares to funds for senior citizens' centers and health care initiatives in the district. "I have been in the forefront of every major issue that affects the district."

HEADLINE: Battle for a Grocery Store On the Ballot in Vermont

BYLINE: By The New York Times

DATELINE: BURLINGTON, Vt., Jan. 22

 BODY:
The bread display is a thing of beauty: fat, crusty loaves of rye and oatmeal sitting next to baskets of multigrain hard rolls and chewy baguettes.
In that august culinary setting, the brand-new display of Koffee Kup white bread and hot dog rolls looks oddly out of place. It's there because the Onion River Food Co-op has been trying to prove to Burlington shoppers that the store does not sell organic bread alone. 
 "We'll obviously have to rearrange these shelves," said Ned Flinn, manager of the Onion River Food Co-op, a 3,500-square-foot food cooperative in Burlington's Old North End. "With all these new products coming in, we haven't figured out where to put them."
Mr. Flinn has many other things on his plate right now. On Tuesday, voters here in Vermont's largest city will be asked whether they want a new downtown grocery to be run by the co-op or by Shaw's, a supermarket chain with stores in all six New England states. The issue is on the ballot because of a petition drive by a group called Friends of Shaw's.
And if, on the surface, the contest appears to be a simple matter of competitive capitalist enterprise, just below the surface lies a host of issues that are charged with class differences, ethnic and cultural diversity, the benefits of local ownership versus the economies of scale.
"We have economic, racial and ethnic diversity in Burlington, and a 15,000-square-foot store won't meet their needs," said Sam Osborne, a Burlington resident and consultant for Shaw's, referring to the proposed co-op store. "Groups from every walk of life will be left out under the Onion River proposal." He said poor residents and the elderly were worried that they would dislike the selection and find the prices too high.
The Price Chopper supermarket closed in April 1999, leaving Burlington, with a population of about 38,000, without a downtown food store. The city sought applicants for a new market to be built on the city-owned site of the old police station.
Shaw's Supermarkets wants to build a 45,000-square-foot store on the site, said Bernard Rogan, spokesman for Shaw's, which has headquarters in East Bridgewater, Mass. Shaw's says it will need to build an underground garage, and it has asked the city to pick up $800,000 of the bill with a bond vote.
"Our contention was, and is, that you need a diverse product line because of the diversity of the population in Burlington," said Mr. Rogan, calling for more ethnic foods and other products. But the size of the Shaw's project has been a sticking point for many city officials.
Onion River has offered a site plan calling for 15,000 square feet of grocery store, 4,000 square feet of office and warehouse space, and above-ground parking. The timetable for opening the new store is about 18 months, Mr. Flinn said.
Jane Knodell, president of the City Council, was one of the Council members who voted with the majority in the 12-to-2 vote in favor of the Onion River proposal at a meeting on Dec. 13. "The size of Shaw's would have a negative impact on the neighborhood," Ms. Knodell said.
"There would be lots of truck traffic, huge Dumpsters. Their site design is very suburban.
"It's true that you may not get umpteen different versions of cornflakes offered at Onion River," she added, "but I'm not sure that makes anybody's life any better anyway."
A thorny issue has been the implications of making a natural foods co-op the only option in town. Typically, co-ops do not carry the standard commercial food products, particularly if they are irradiated, processed or adulterated in some way.
To address that, the city has told Onion River that it must expand its product offerings at its proposed store -- and it has already done so at its present site -- to include conventional foodstuffs. So far, the co-op has added Crisco, Cheerios, Grape-Nuts, American cheese -- and Koffee Kup bread, and more is coming.
Michael Monte, director of the Community and Economic Development Office for the city of Burlington, acknowledged that "people's gut reaction is that they want a regular, big supermarket like other people have. But when people take a closer look at some of the issues that crop up -- loss of local control, zoning changes -- they start to rethink that."
Not true, said Mr. Osborne, who founded the Friends of Shaw's Committee. He said his polling indicated that "seven out of eight people we talked to wanted Shaw's. They think Onion River is too expensive and that it won't meet their needs. The co-op won't even sell cigarettes. People don't want to be told what they can and can't do."

HEADLINE: Ecuador Coup Shifts Control To No. 2 Man

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER

DATELINE: LIMA, Peru, Jan. 22

 BODY:
After 18 hours of chaos that began when dissident military officers and Indian groups overthrew the elected president of Ecuador, Jamil Mahuad, the country's vice president assumed power early today when a rival military faction intervened on his behalf.
Gustavo Noboa Bejarano took office after Gen. Carlos Mendoza, the Ecuadorean armed forces chief of staff and acting minister of defense, abruptly announced that he was dissolving the three-man junta he briefly led in Latin America's first military overthrow of a sitting civilian president in more than a decade. 
 General Mendoza said he was acting to "prevent the international isolation of Ecuador," a reference to demands by the United States and Latin American countries that constitutional rule be preserved in a country undergoing severe economic crisis.
"Under the laws laid out in the Constitution, I find myself under the obligation to assume the presidency of Ecuador," Mr. Noboa, who becomes the sixth chief of state in four years, said this morning at a news conference in Quito, the capital. "I have the support of the armed forces and the national police."
Mr. Naboa's assumption of power was formally ratified by the Ecuadorean Congress in Guayaquil today.
Mr. Mahuad, a 50-year-old former mayor of Quito, left the Presidential Palace under military escort on Friday afternoon and resurfaced this morning on television to condemn the coup. He described it as a "Cantinflas comedy" that exposed Ecuador to international ridicule.
But he did acknowledge Mr. Noboa's authority and wished him luck. "A deposed president neither resigns nor abandons his post; he is deposed," Mr. Mahuad said. "I will never be an obstacle for the vice president to assume the presidency."
In a defiant television speech on Friday, Mr. Mahuad refused to resign, challenging the military by saying it would have to "remove me by force." He said that a military unit took him to an air force base where he was first threatened with arrest and then urged to flee the country, before he escaped, took temporary refuge in the Chilean embassy and then made his way to what he described as a "private home."
The military coup was immediately condemned by the Clinton administration and the Organization of American States, both of which threatened sanctions against any military-led government. Peter Romero, the State Department's top official for Latin America, warned the coup leaders on Quito radio on Friday that they faced "political and economic isolation" akin to Cuba's if they persisted.
Today, Mr. Romero, a former ambassador to Ecuador, described the situation as "chaos."
He said Mr. Noboa, a 62-year-old former dean of the Catholic University of Guayaquil and former governor of the country's most important province, would be under enormous pressure "not to do anything" to fix the economy.
The insurrection against Mr. Mahuad originated in Ecuador's worst economic crisis in more than 70 years. The economy contracted by 7.5 percent last year, the worst performance in Latin America. Inflation was more than 60 percent for the second consecutive year, and the country defaulted on half of its $13 billion in foreign debt in September.
Indians, who make up more than one-third of Ecuador's 12.5 million people and are largely peasant farmers, have been hit particularly hard.
Antonio Vargas, leader of the country's most powerful Indian group, had lobbied the government for $42 million in debt forgiveness and new loans, but was turned down and quickly turned into one of Mr. Mahuad's most ferocious critics, accusing him of inflicting "massive impoverishment" on Ecuadoreans.
Hoping to secure financing abroad, Mr. Mahuad responded to the recession with an austerity program that further eroded his popularity and included two especially criticized measures. He froze the life savings of thousands of Ecuadoreans during a banking crisis in March and, in a radical and desperate move, on Jan. 9 declared his intent to replace the nation's currency with the American dollar.
In a speech broadcast on Ecuadorean radio this morning, Mr. Noboa said he intended to continue with the dollarization program, "in accordance with Ecuadorean reality and technique." But he indirectly criticized some other aspects of Mr. Mahuad's rule and vowed to take quick action against what he described as rampant corruption, a central opposition demand.
The collapse of the Mahuad government began on Friday morning when Indian protesters marched on the national Congress in Quito. A military unit assigned to guard the legislative building instead stepped aside, allowing Mr. Vargas and his supporters to enter, seize control of offices there and proclaim the overthrow of Mr. Mahuad and the dissolution of Congress and the Supreme Court and their replacement by a "People's Parliament."
A group of more than 50 junior military officers led by Col. Lucio Gutierrez immediately joined the Indian group, and other officials began arriving and adhering to the uprising, among them Col. Fausto Cobo, commander of Ecuador's military academy. With television cameras broadcasting the takeover, Mr. Vargas announced the formation of a new governing junta composed of himself, Colonel Gutierrez and Carlos Solorzano, a former Supreme Court chief justice.
The military high command initially expressed lukewarm support for Mr. Mahuad. But as more and more colonels, majors and captains in charge of provincial units rose in rebellion, the generals were forced to reverse course, and by mid-afternoon they had issued a new statement urging the president to resign.
In an interview with an Ecuadorean television reporter, an unidentified military officer who had joined the insurrection complained that since Mr. Mahuad took office in August 1998, the value of his salary had declined from $1,100 a month to less than $300. Colonel Gutierrez, for his part, vowed to replace "this ignominious model of government" with one that would attack "corruption and impunity" by the bankers Mr. Mahuad was seen as protecting.
After Mr. Mahuad left his offices, the junta announced plans to march on and seize the Presidential Palace a few blocks away. But the military high command acted before it could get there, with General Mendoza and the army commander, Gen. Telmo Sandoval, sending troops to take control of the building and deploying tanks in the square in front of it to block the protesters' advance.
General Mendoza said he had acted to "avoid a social explosion." Just before midnight, after several hours of negotiations with Mr. Vargas and Colonel Gutierrez and their supporters, he emerged to announce that the country would be governed by a "triumvirate" in which he would replace Colonel Gutierrez but Mr. Vargas and Mr. Solorzano would remain.
Before dawn, however, he had moved to undercut his two partners in the junta, who said they remain opposed to Mr. Noboa taking power and called for the arrest of Mr. Mahuad. Salvador Quishpe, an aide to Mr. Vargas, argued that Ecuador needs to "undergo a process of purification," condemned Mr. Noboa as "one of the politicians responsible for this debacle" and said his group planned to continue its protests.
